    The City shall possess and hereby reserves to itself all the powers granted to cities by statute and constitution to acquire, construct, own, operate, improve, enlarge, extend, repair and maintain, either within or without its corporate limits, including, but not by the [sic] way of limitation, public utilities for supplying water, light, heat, power, gas, sewage system and garbage facilities, or any of them, to the municipality and the inhabitants thereof; and also to sell and deliver water, light, heat, power, gas and other public utility services without its corporate limits to an amount not to exceed the limitations set by statute and constitution. 
Section 17.2. - Management of Public Utilities. 
    All municipally owned or operated utilities shall be administered as a division of the Department of Public Works under the management and supervision of the head or director of the City Department of Public Works. 
Section 17.3. - Rates. 
    The Council shall have the power to fix from time to time such just and reasonable rates and other charges as may be deemed advisable for supplying the inhabitants of the City and others with such public services as the City may provide. No free service shall be permitted. Higher rates may be charged for service outside the corporate limits of the City. 
Section 17.4. - Utility Rates and Charges-Collection. 
(a)  The Council shall provide by ordinance for the collection of all public utility rates and charges of the City. Such ordinance shall provide at least: 
(1)  The terms and conditions under which utility services may be discontinued in case of delinquency in paying such rates or charges. 
(2)  That suit may be instituted by the City before a competent tribunal for the collection of such rates and charges. 
(b)  With respect to the collection of rates charged for water, the City shall have all the powers granted to cities by Act [No.] 178 of the Public Acts of 1939 [MCL 123.161 et seq.]. 
Section 17.5. - Disposal of Utility Plants and Property. 
    Unless approved by the affirmative vote of three-fifths of the electors voting thereon at a regular or special election, the City shall not sell, exchange, lease or in any way dispose of any property, easements, equipments, privileges, or assets belonging to and appertaining to any municipally owned public utility which is needed to continue operating such utility. All contracts, negotiations, licenses, grants, leases or other forms of transfer in violation of this section shall be void and no effect as against the City. The restrictions of this section shall not apply to the sale or exchange of any articles of machinery or equipment of any City[-]owned public utility which are worn out or useless or which have been or could with advantage to the service, be replaced by new and improved machinery or equipment, to the leasing of property not necessary for the operation of the utility, or to the exchange of property or easements for other needed property not necessary for the operation of the utility, or to the exchange of property or easements for other needed property or easements. It is provided, however, that the provisions of this section shall not extend to vacation or abandonment of streets or alleys as provided by statute. 
Section 17.6. - Utility Finances. 
(a)  The rates and charges for any municipal public utility for the furnishing of water, light, heat, power or gas shall be fixed as to at least meet all the costs of such utility. 
(b)  Transactions pertaining to the ownership and operation by the City of each public utility shall be recorded in a separate group of accounts under an appropriate fund caption, which accounts shall be classified in accordance with generally accepted utility accounting practice. Charges for all service furnished to, or rendered by, other City departments or agencies shall be recorded. An annual report shall be prepared to show the financial position of each utility and the result of its operation, which report shall be available for inspection at the office of the Clerk. 
CHAPTER XVIII. - PRIVATELY OWNED UTILITIES 

Section 18.1. - Franchise Required. 
    No person, partnership, association or corporation operating a public utility shall have the right to the use of the highways, streets, alleys or other public places of the City of wires, poles, pipes, tracks or conduits without the consent of the Council; nor may it conduct a local business in the City without first obtaining a franchise therefor from the City. 
Section 18.2. - Regulatory Powers. 
(a)  The City shall have the right (a) to regulate public utilities; (b) to regulate the location of poles and other facilities used by public utilities, and (c) to require that wire in streets and alleys be placed underground. 
(b)  The City shall have the right to permit and regulate the use by others than the owners, of property located in the streets, alleys and public places, in the operation of a public utility, upon the payment of a reasonable compensation to the owners thereof. 
Section 18.3. - Permit Revocable. 
    The Council may grant a permit at any time in or upon any street, alley or public place; provided, that such permit shall be revocable by the Council at its pleasure at any time, whether such right to revoke be expressly reserved in said permit or not. 
Section 18.4. - Franchise Elections. 
    No public utility franchise which is not revocable at the will of the City shall be granted unless the same shall have received the affirmative vote of three-fifths of the electors of the City voting thereon at a regular or special municipal election. No franchise shall be submitted under the provisions of the Charter, to the electors at a special election, unless the cost of holding the election, as determined by the Council, shall be paid to the Treasurer in advance of calling said election by the grantee in such franchise. 
State Law reference- Submitted to electors required if irrevocable, Mich. Const. 1963, art. VII, § 25; expenses of special election to be paid by grantee, MCL 117.5(i). 
Section 18.5. - Franchise Term. 
    No franchise shall be granted by the City for a longer period than thirty (30) years. No exclusive franchise shall ever be granted to any person, firm or corporation. 
State Law reference- Franchises limited to thirty (30) years, Mich. Const. 1963, art. VII, § 30. 
Section 18.6. - Further Regulatory Powers. 
    The grant of every franchise shall be subject to the right of the City whether in terms reserved or not, to make all regulations which shall be necessary to secure in the most ample manner the safety, welfare and accommodation of the public, and the right to make and enforce all such regulations as shall be reasonably necessary to secure adequate, sufficient and proper service, extensions and accommodations for the people, and insure their comfort and convenience. Such right of the City shall include but shall not be limited to the following, viz: 
(a)  To repeal the same for misuse, or nonuse, or for failure to comply with the provisions thereof; 
(b)  To require continuous and uninterrupted service to the public in accordance with the terms of the franchise throughout the entire period thereof; 
(c)  To require the public utility to which any franchise is granted to permit joint use of its property and appurtenance located in the streets, alleys and public places of the City, by the City and other utilities, insofar as such joint use may be reasonably practicable and upon payment of reasonable rental therefor; provided, that in event of the inability of the parties to agree, upon application by either party, the Council shall provide for arbitration of the terms and conditions of such joint use and the compensation to be paid therefor; 
(d)  To pay such part of the cost of improvement or maintenance of the streets, alleys, bridges, and public places of the City, as shall arise from its use thereof and to protect and save the City harmless from all damages arising from said use. 
Section 18.7. - Franchise Conveyed by Ordinance. 
    All contracts, granting or giving any original franchise, or extending or renewing or amending any existing franchise, shall be made by ordinance and not otherwise. Every such ordinance granting a franchise shall be accepted in writing by the granting before said ordinance takes effect, and if it is to be submitted to the electors, it shall be so accepted before its submission. Such acceptance shall be filed with the Clerk. Any noncompliance with this section shall automatically annul such franchise. 
Section 18.8. - Ordinance Regulation. 
    The Council may by ordinance provide for efficient inspection and regulation of all public utilities operated in the City. It is the intention of this section to provide means for securing to the City efficient service from all public utilities operated in the City and the proper observance of the conditions imposed by franchise, the Charter and ordinances of the City and laws of the State. 
Section 18.9. - Repeal and Termination of Franchise Acquisition of Utility Property. 
    All ordinances granting franchises, or extensions or renewals thereof, shall reserve to the City the right to terminate the same and to purchase all the property of the utility in the streets and highways in the City and elsewhere, used in or useful for the operation of the utility, at a price either fixed by the ordinance or to be fixed in the manner provided by the ordinance granting the same. Nothing in such ordinance shall prevent the City from acquiring the property of any such utility by condemnation proceedings or in any other lawful mode; but all such methods of acquisition shall be alternative to the power to purchase reserved in the ordinance granting such franchise, extension or renewal as hereinbefore provided. Upon the acquisition by the City of the property of any utility by purchase, condemnation or otherwise, all franchises, extensions and renewals shall at once terminate. 
Section 18.10. - Franchise Ordinance Requirement. 
    No ordinance granting such franchise, or extension or renewal thereof, shall be valid unless it shall expressly provide therein that the price to be paid by the City for the property that may be acquired by it from such utility by purchase, condemnation or otherwise, shall exclude all value of such franchise, extension or renewal, except that unless provided in such ordinance, the utility shall be entitled to the return of the proportionate amount for the unused period of any compensation paid to the City for such franchise, extension or renewal. 
Section 18.11. - Township Franchises. 
    All franchises to which the Township of Taylor is a party when this Charter becomes effective shall remain in full force and effect in accordance with their respective terms and conditions. 
CHAPTER XIX. - SCHEDULE 

Section 19.1. - Status of Schedule Chapter. 
    The purpose of this chapter is to inaugurate the government of the City of Taylor under this Charter, and it shall constitute part of this Charter only to the extent of the time necessary to accomplish this purpose. 
Section 19.2. - Submission of Charter. 
    This Charter shall be submitted to the electors of the territory constituting the City of Taylor for their approval or rejection at an election to be held on the 29th day of April, 1968, and if approved shall become effective at 8 o'clock p.m., on the 13th day of May, 1968. 
Section 19.3. - Form of Ballot. 
(a)  The form of the ballot for the submission of this Charter shall be as follows: Instruction: A cross (x) in the square before the word "YES" is in favor of the proposed Charter and a cross (x) in the square before the word "NO" is against the proposed Charter. 
(b)  The question to be presented shall be as follows: 
    Shall the proposed Charter for the City of Taylor as drafted by the Charter Commission elected November 8, 1966 be adopted? 
? YES 
? NO  
Section 19.4. - First Election of Officers. 
(a)  At the election to adopt or reject this Charter, the elective officers of the City under this Charter, consisting of a Mayor, a Clerk, a Treasurer, seven (7) Councilmen, two (2) Municipal Judges, and two (2) Constables, shall be elected on a nonpartisan basis. 
(b)  The final date and hour for filing nominating petitions shall be March 18, 1968, at 4 o'clock p.m., Eastern Standard Time, and notice of same shall be published in the official newspaper of the Township of Taylor by the Secretary of the Commission on March 6, and March 13, 1968. 
Section 19.5. - Publication of Proposed Charter; Notices. 
    The Secretary of the Charter Commission shall cause to be published the proposed Charter and all notices of registration, filing of nominating petitions and notice of election in the manner provided by law or this Charter. 
Section 19.6. - Duties of the Charter Commission. 
    In addition to the preparation of the foregoing provisions of this Charter, the Charter Commission shall do and provide all other things necessary for making nominations of the first City officers and holding the election on such Charter and for such officers. 
RESOLUTION OF ADOPTION 
    At a regular meeting of the Taylor Charter Commission held on the 2-1-68, in the Taylor Municipal Building, the following resolution was offered by Commissioner Roy Davis. 
    RESOLVED, that the Taylor Charter Commission does hereby adopt the foregoing proposed Charter for the City of Taylor and the Secretary of this Commission is directed to transmit a copy of this Charter to the Governor of the State of Michigan for his approval in accordance with statute and to cause this proposed Charter to be published in accordance with law. 
    Resolution supported by Commissioner Roy L. Ford and adopted by the following vote: 
AYE: Messrs. Bloink, Davis, Ford, Indorf, Koths, Sabo, Sutherland, Nicita. 
NAY: None 
ABSENT: Mr. Cretul. 
    The Chairman declared the foregoing resolution carried and requested the members of the Charter Commission to authenticate said resolution and also the copy of the Charter to be presented to the Governor. All of the Commissioners thereupon authenticated the resolution and Charter to be presented to the Governor by subscribing their names as follows: 
Anthony Nicita, Chairman 
William J. Sutherland, Vice-Chairman 
Roy L. Ford, Secretary 
Fred Bloink 
George Cretul (Absent) 
Roy Davis 
Edward Indorf 
Glen B. Koths 
John N. Sabo, Jr. 
The meeting thereupon adjourned subject to the call of the Chairman. 
    I, Roy L. Ford, Secretary of the Charter Commission elected to frame a Charter for the City of Taylor, Michigan, do hereby certify that the foregoing Charter was duly adopted by said Charter Commission at a session thereof held on the 1st day of February, 1968. 
DATED: February 1, 1968 
Roy L. Ford 
Secretary of the Charter Commission 
I do hereby approve the above and foregoing Charter of the City of Taylor.

Chapter 1 - GENERAL PROVISIONS 

Sec. 1-1. - Code designated and cited. 
    This codification of ordinances shall be known and cited as the "Code of Ordinances, City of Taylor, Michigan." 
(Code 1987, § 1-1) 
State Law reference- Codification authority, MCL 117.5b. 
Sec. 1-2. - Definitions and rules of construction. 
    In the construction of this Code and of all ordinances of the city, the following definitions and rules of construction shall be observed, unless they are inconsistent with the intent of the city council or the context clearly requires otherwise: 
    Generally. When provisions conflict, the specific shall prevail over the general. All provisions shall be liberally construed so that the intent of the city council may be effectuated. Words and phrases shall be construed according to the common and approved usage of the language, but technical words, technical phrases and words and phrases that have acquired peculiar and appropriate meanings in law shall be construed according to such meanings. 
    Agencies, officers. Any reference to any local, state or federal agency or officer shall include any successor agency or officer. 
    Charter. The term "Charter" means the Charter of the City of Taylor, Michigan, adopted April 29, 1968, and shall include any amendment to such Charter. 
    City. The term "city" means the City of Taylor, Michigan. 
    City council. The term "city council" or "council" means the city council of the City of Taylor, Michigan. 
    Code. The term "Code" or "this Code" means the "Code of Ordinances, City of Taylor, Michigan," as designated in section 1-1, and as hereinafter modified by amendment, revision and by the adoption of new chapters, articles, divisions or sections. 
    Computation of time. The time within which an act is to be done, as provided in this Code or in any order issued pursuant to this Code, when expressed in days, shall be computed by excluding the first day and including the last, except that if the last day is Sunday or a legal holiday it shall be excluded; and when the time is expressed in hours, the whole of Sunday or a legal holiday, from midnight to midnight, shall be excluded. 
    County. The term "the county" means the County of Wayne in the State of Michigan. 
    Gender. A word importing gender shall extend and be applied to both genders and to firms, partnerships and corporations as well. 
    Health officer or health department. The term "health officer" or "health department" means the county health officer or the county health department. 
    MCL. The abbreviation "MCL" means the Michigan Compiled Laws, as amended or revised, and any successor statute. 
    Municipal civil infraction. The term "municipal civil infraction" means an act or omission that is prohibited by this Code or any ordinance of the city, but which is not a crime under this Code or any other ordinance, and for which civil sanctions, including without limitation, fines, damages, expenses, and costs may be ordered, as authorized by chapter 87 of Public Act No. 236 of 1961 (MCL 600.8701 et seq.). A municipal civil infraction is not a lesser included offense of any criminal offense in this Code. 
    Number. A word importing the singular number only may extend and be applied to several persons and things as well as to one person and thing. 
    Officer, employee, department, board, commission or other agency. Whenever any officer, employee, department, board, commission or other agency is referred to by title only, such reference shall be construed as if followed by the words "of the City of Taylor, Michigan." Whenever, by the provisions of this Code, any officer, employee, department, board, commission or other agency of the city is assigned any duty or empowered to perform any act or duty, reference to such officer, employee, department, board, commission or agency means and includes such officer, employee, department, board, commission or agency or deputy or authorized subordinate. 
    Person. The term "person" and its derivatives and the term "whoever" includes a natural person, partnership, association, legal entity or a corporate body or any body of persons corporate or incorporate. Whenever used in any clause prescribing and imposing a penalty, the term "person" or "whoever," as applied to any unincorporated entity, means the partners or members thereof, and as applied to corporations, the officers thereof. 
    Shall/may. The term "shall" is always mandatory and not discretionary. The term "may" is permissive. 
    State. The term "the state" or "this state" shall be construed to mean the State of Michigan. 
    Tense. Except as otherwise specifically provided or indicated by the context, all words used in this Code indicating the present tense shall not be limited to the time of adoption of this Code but shall extend to and include the time of the happening of any act, event, or requirement for which provision is made therein, either as a power, immunity, requirement or prohibition. 
(Code 1987, § 1-2; Ord. No. 06-416, § 1, 10-3-2006; Ord. No. 07-421, § 1, 7-17-2007) 
State Law reference- Rules of construction, MCL 8.3 et seq. 
Sec. 1-3. - Interpretation per state acts. 
    Unless otherwise provided in this Code, or by law or implication required, the same rules of construction, definition and application shall govern the interpretation of this Code as those governing the interpretation of the Public Acts of Michigan. 
(Code 1987, § 1-3) 
State Law reference- Rules of construction, MCL 8.3 et seq. 
Sec. 1-4. - Captions. 
    Headings and captions used in this Code following the chapter, article, division and section numbers are employed for reference purposes only and shall not be deemed a part of the text of any section. 
(Code 1987, § 1-4) 
State Law reference- Catchlines in state statutes, MCL 8.4b. 
Sec. 1-5. - References and notes. 
    Charter references, state law references and editor's notes in this Code are by way of explanation only and should not be deemed a part of the text of any section. 
(Code 1987, § 1-5) 
Sec. 1-6. - Application to future legislation. 
    All of the provisions of this chapter, not incompatible with future legislation, shall apply to ordinances hereafter adopted amending or supplementing this Code unless otherwise specifically provided. 
(Code 1987, § 1-6) 
Sec. 1-7. - Reference to other sections. 
    Whenever in one section reference is made to another section hereof, such reference shall extend and apply to the section referred to as subsequently amended, revised, recodified or renumbered unless the subject matter is changed or materially altered by the amendment or revision. 
(Code 1987, § 1-7) 
Sec. 1-8. - Reference to offices. 
    Reference to a public office or officer shall be deemed to apply to any office, officer, or employee of the city, exercising the powers, duties or functions contemplated in the provision, irrespective of any transfer of functions or change in the official title of the functionary. 
(Code 1987, § 1-8) 
Sec. 1-9. - Certain provisions saved from repeal. 
    Nothing in this Code or the ordinance adopting this Code shall affect the following when not inconsistent with this Code: 
(1)  Any offense committed or penalty incurred or any right established prior to the effective date of the Code; 
(2)  Any ordinance levying annual taxes; 
(3)  Any ordinance appropriating money; 
(4)  Any ordinance authorizing the issuance of bonds or borrowing of money; 
(5)  Any ordinance establishing utility rates; 
(6)  Any ordinance establishing franchises or granting special rights to certain persons; 
(7)  Any ordinance authorizing public improvements; 
(8)  Any ordinance authorizing the purchase or sale of real or personal property; 
(9)  Any ordinance annexing or detaching territory; 
(10)  Any ordinance granting or accepting easements, plats or dedication of land to public use; 
(11)  Any ordinance dedicating, naming, establishing, locating, relocating, opening, paving, widening, vacating, etc., any street or public way in the city; 
(12)  Any ordinance establishing or prescribing grades in the city; 
(13)  Any ordinance prescribing the number, classification or compensation of any city officers or employees; 
(14)  Any ordinance prescribing traffic and parking restrictions pertaining to specific streets; 
(15)  Any ordinance pertaining to zoning; 
(16)  Any other ordinance, or part thereof, which is not of a general and permanent nature; 
and all such ordinances are hereby recognized as continuing in full force and effect to the same extent as if set out at length in this Code. Such ordinances are on file in the city clerk's office. 
(Code 1987, § 1-9) 
Sec. 1-10. - Amendment procedure. 
    This Code shall be amended by ordinance. The title of each amendatory ordinance, adapted to the particular circumstances and purposes of the amendment, shall be substantially as follows: 
(1)  To amend any section: An ordinance to amend section _____ (or sections _____ and _____) of the Code of Ordinances, City of Taylor, Michigan. 
(2)  To insert a new section or chapter: An ordinance to amend the Code of Ordinances, City of Taylor, Michigan, by adding a new section (new sections or a new chapter, as the case may be) which new section (sections or chapter) shall be designated as section _____ (sections _____ and _____) (or proper designation if a chapter is added) of said code. 
(3)  To repeal a section or chapter: An ordinance to repeal section _____ (sections _____ and _____, chapter _____, as the case may be) of the Code of Ordinances, City of Taylor, Michigan. 
(Code 1987, § 1-10) 
Sec. 1-11. - Supplementation of Code. 
(a)  By contract or by city personnel, supplements to this Code shall be prepared and printed whenever authorized or directed by the city council. A supplement to the Code shall include all substantive permanent and general parts of ordinances adopted during the period covered by the supplement and all changes made thereby in the Code. The pages of a supplement shall be so numbered that they will fit properly into the Code and will, where necessary, replace pages which have become obsolete or partially obsolete, and the new pages shall be so prepared that, when they have been inserted, the Code will be current through the date of the adoption of the latest ordinance included in the supplement. 
(b)  In preparing a supplement to this Code, all portions of the Code which have been repealed shall be excluded from the Code by the omission thereof from reprinted pages. 
(c)  When preparing a supplement to this Code, the codifier (meaning the person, agency or organization authorized to prepare the supplement) may make formal, nonsubstantive changes in ordinances and parts of ordinances included in the supplement, insofar as it is necessary to do so to embody them into a unified code. For example, the codifier may: 
(1)  Organize the ordinance material into appropriate subdivisions; 
(2)  Provide appropriate catchlines, headings and titles for sections and other subdivisions of the Code printed in the supplement, and make changes in such catchlines, headings and titles; 
(3)  Assign appropriate numbers to sections and other subdivisions to be inserted in the Code and, where necessary to accommodate new material, change existing section or other subdivision numbers; 
(4)  Change the term "this ordinance" or words of the same meaning to "this chapter," "this article," "this division," etc., as the case may be, or to "sections _____ to _____" (inserting section numbers to indicate the sections of the Code which embody the substantive sections of the ordinance incorporated into the Code); and 
(5)  Make other nonsubstantive changes necessary to preserve the original meaning of ordinance sections inserted in the Code; but in no case shall the codifier make any change in the meaning or effect of ordinance material included in the supplement or already embodied in the Code. 
(Code 1987, § 1-11) 
Sec. 1-12. - Severability. 
(a)  It is the legislative intent of the city council in adopting this Code, that all provisions and sections of this Code be liberally construed to protect and preserve the peace, health, safety and welfare of the inhabitants of the city and should any provisions or section of this Code be held unconstitutional or invalid, such holding shall not be construed as affecting the validity of any of the remaining provisions or sections, it being the intent that this Code shall stand, notwithstanding the invalidity of any provision or section thereof. 
(b)  The provisions of this section shall apply to the amendment of any section of this Code whether or not the wording of this section is set forth in the amendatory ordinance. 
(Code 1987, § 1-12) 
Sec. 1-13. - General penalties and sanctions for violations of this Code and city ordinances; continuing violations; injunctive relief. 
(a)  Unless a violation of this Code or any ordinance of the city is specifically designated in the Code or ordinance as a municipal civil infraction or a civil infraction, the violation shall be deemed to be a misdemeanor. 
(b)  The penalty for a misdemeanor violation shall be a fine not exceeding $500.00 (plus costs of prosecution), or imprisonment not exceeding 90 days, or both, unless a specific penalty is otherwise provided for the violation by this Code or any ordinance. However, unless otherwise provided by law, a person convicted of a violation of this Code which substantially corresponds to a violation of state law that is a misdemeanor for which the maximum period of imprisonment is 93 days shall be punished by a fine not to exceed $500.00 and costs of prosecution or by imprisonment for a period of not more than 93 days or by both such fine and imprisonment. 
(c)  The sanction for a violation which is a municipal civil infraction shall be a civil fine in the amount as provided by this Code or any ordinance, plus any costs, damages, expenses and other sanctions, as authorized under chapter 87 of Public Act No. 236 of 1961 (MCL 600.8701 et seq.), and other applicable laws. 
(1)  Unless otherwise specifically provided for by this Code or any ordinance, the civil fine for a municipal civil infraction violation shall be not less than $50.00 nor more than $500.00, plus costs and other sanctions, for each infraction. Costs shall include all expenses, direct and indirect, to which the city has been put in connection with the municipal civil infraction, with the exception of those costs permitted pursuant to subsection (f) of this section, costs of no more than $500.00 shall be ordered. 
(2)  In addition to any fine or cost ordered to be paid under subsection (c)(1) of this section, the judge or district court magistrate shall order the defendant to pay a justice system assessment of $10.00. Upon payment of the assessment, the clerk of the court shall transmit the assessment collected to the state treasurer for deposit in the justice system fund created in MCL 600.181. 
(3)  Increased civil fines may be imposed for repeated violations by a person of any requirement or provision of this Code or any ordinance. As used in this section, the term "repeat offense" means a second (or any subsequent) municipal civil infraction violation of the same requirement or provision: 
a.  Committed by a person within any three-year period (unless some other period is specifically provided by this Code or any ordinance); and 
b.  For which the person admits responsibility or is determined to be responsible. 
(4)  Unless otherwise specifically provided by this Code or any ordinance for a particular municipal civil infraction violation, the increased fine for a repeat offense shall be as follows: 
a.  The fine for any offense which is a first repeat offense shall be no less than $150.00, no more than $500.00, plus costs. 
b.  Repeat offenses are determined on the basis of the date of the commission of the offenses. 
(d)  A second repeat offense, a violation which is designated a municipal civil infraction shall constitute a misdemeanor punishable by a fine not exceeding $500.00 (plus costs of prosecution), or imprisonment not exceeding 90 days, or both. However, nothing herein requires an authorized city official to charge a repeat offense of the same ordinance by the same individual as a misdemeanor. 
(e)  A violation includes any act which is prohibited or made or declared to be unlawful or an offense by this Code or any ordinance; and any omission or failure to act where the act is required by this Code or any ordinance. 
(f)  Each act of violation and each day on which any violation of this Code or any ordinance continues constitutes a separate offense/infraction and shall be subject to penalties or sanctions as a separate offense/infraction. 
(g)  In addition to any remedies available at law, the city may bring an action for an injunction or other process against a person to restrain, prevent or abate any violation of this Code or any city ordinance. Any penalty or sanction imposed shall be in addition to the abatement of the violating condition, any injunctive relief, revocation of any permit or license, or other process. Actual costs incurred by the city to enforce any injunctive order or abate any violation of this Code may be assessed against a defendant. 
(h)  If a person fails to pay any fines or costs assessed pursuant to this section or any provision of this Code or any ordinance, then the amount due shall accrue interest at the rate of six percent per annum from the date when it becomes due and such fine or cost together with the accrued interest and an administrative cost of 15 percent shall be filed with the city assessor's office and shall be collected in the manner fixed by law for the collection of taxes and assessments. 
(i)  The penalties and sanctions provided by this section, unless another penalty or sanction is expressly provided, shall apply to the amendment of any section of this Code whether or not such penalty or sanction is enacted in the amendatory ordinance. 
(Code 1987, § 1-13; Ord. No. 06-416, § 2, 10-3-2006; Ord. No. 07-421, § 2, 7-17-2007) 
Charter reference- Limitation on penalties, § 7.3(f). 
State Law reference- Limitation on penalties, MCL 117.4i, 117.4l; municipal civil infractions, MCL 600.8701 et seq. 
Sec. 1-14. - Appearance tickets. 
(a)  The fire chief, fire marshal, fire inspectors, chief building inspector, assistant building inspectors, zoning inspectors, animal control officers and the director of public works and/or their written designees are hereby authorized to issue and serve appearance tickets for violations of local ordinances of the city if they have reasonable cause to believe that the person upon whom or to whom the appearance ticket is issued has committed an offense of the ordinance. 
(b)  The term "appearance ticket" means a complaint of written notice issued and subscribed by a police officer or other public servant authorized by law or ordinance to issue it, directing a designated person to appear in a designated local criminal court at a designated future time in connection with the person's alleged commission of a designated violation of state law or local ordinance for which the maximum permissible penalty does not exceed 93 days in jail and a fine of $500.00. The appearance tickets shall be numbered consecutively, be in such form as determined by the attorney general, the state court administrator and the director of the department of state police and shall consist of the following parts: 
(1)  The original which shall be a complaint or notice to appear by the officer and filed with the court; 
(2)  The first copy which shall be the abstract of court record; 
(3)  The second copy which shall be delivered to the alleged violator. 
(c)  With the prior approval of such state officials, the appearance ticket may be appropriately modified as to content or number of copies to accommodate law enforcement and local court procedures and practices. 
(Code 1987, § 1-14; Ord. No. 85-147, §§ 1-3, 9-3-1985; Ord. No. 97-306, § 1, 12-16-1997) 
State Law reference- Authority for this section, MCL 764.9c et seq.

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 2-1. - Master plan adopted. 
    There is hereby adopted by reference, the City of Taylor Master Plan and any amendments, extensions, or additions to the master plan, as adopted by the planning commission of the city, are hereby deemed to have been approved and adopted by the city council as the master plan for the city. 
(Code 1987, § 22-31; Ord. No. 98-312, § 1, 4-7-1998; Ord. No. 08-430, § 1, 4-15-2008; Ord. No. 14-485, § 1, 9-2-2014; Ord. No. 19-498, § 1, 1-2-2019) 
Secs. 2-2-2-18. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - CITY COUNCIL[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Charter reference- Elective and appointive officers of the city, ch. IV; legislative department, ch. VI; city legislation, ch. VII; elections, ch. X. 

Sec. 2-19. - Smoking in meeting room. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person while at or in attendance of any public meeting or public assembly within the city council room to smoke any cigar, cigarette, pipe or any variation thereof, in any room where such public meeting or public assembly is being held. 
(Code 1987, § 2-16; Ord. No. 75-65, § 1, 7-8-1975) 
State Law reference- Smoking in public places, MCL 333.12601 et seq. 
Sec. 2-20. - Participation in pension and retirement benefit program. 
(a)  No member of the city council who is first elected or first appointed from and after November 25, 1997, shall be eligible or entitled to participate in the pension and retirement benefit program under the group retirement annuity contract. 
(b)  Any changes (reductions, improvements or enhancements) to the group retirement annuity contract, whether negotiated by the city's governmental management and administrative employees association or otherwise, from and after the effective date of the ordinance from which this section is derived (December 2, 1997), shall not be applicable to past, present, or future council persons, whose date of service with the city council first began prior to November 25, 1997. 
(Code 1987, § 2-17; Ord. No. 97-303, § I, 12-2-1997) 
Sec. 2-21. - Limitation on city council fringe benefits. 
(a)  Regardless of any previous or future determination by the city's local officers pension and fringe benefits compensation commission to the contrary, any member of the city council first elected or selected to serve as a member of the city council, on or after November 3, 2009, shall not receive from the city at the city's cost or expense the following fringe benefits: Blue Cross/Blue Shield benefits or similar medical insurance benefits, life insurance, accidental death/travel insurance, dental insurance, optical insurance or payment in lieu of insurance. However, a member of the city council shall be eligible to purchase the fringe benefits referenced in this section and section 2-20 through the city's fringe benefits programs at the member of the city council's own cost and expense. 
(b)  Nothing in this section shall be construed to affect the fringe benefits received by or made available to members of the city council elected or serving prior to November 3, 2009. 
(Code 1987, § 2-18; Ord. No. 09-435, § 1, 3-13-2009) 
Secs. 2-22-2-45. - Reserved.

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 2-46. - 23rd district court judges' participation in city benefit plans. 
(a)  No judge who is first elected or first appointed to serve on the 23rd district court for the city, from and after October 1, 2008, shall be eligible nor entitled to participate in the following city benefit plans: 
(1)  The city general employees' retirement system, as amended, division 2 of this article. Any changes (reductions, improvements or enhancements) to the city general employees' retirement system whether negotiated by the city governmental management and administrative employees association or otherwise, from and after the effective date of the ordinance from which this section is derived (October 1, 2008), shall not be applicable to past, present, or future judges elected or appointed to serve on the 23rd district court for the city, whose date of service first began prior to October 1, 2008. 
(2)  The city defined contribution pension plan, as amended and restated effective January 1, 2006. 
(3)  The city health insurance plan. 
(b)  Nothing in this section shall be construed to affect the rights of judges elected, appointed or serving on the 23rd district court prior to October 1, 2008, related to the city benefit plans. 
(Ord. No. 08-433, § 1, 9-16-2008) 
Secs. 2-47-2-65. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - GENERAL EMPLOYEE'S RETIREMENT 

Sec. 2-66. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this general employees' retirement division, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Accumulated member contributions means the sum of all amounts contributed by the member to the member's individual account in the reserve for employee contributions, including interest, if applicable pursuant to the relative collective bargaining agreement, credited to such account. 
    Actuarial equivalent means a payment or a series of payments which have the same actuarial present value, as of a given date, as another payment or series of payments. The actuarial present value shall be determined using the appropriate rates of experience and rates of interest adopted by the board of trustees. 
    Actuarial tables, as referred to in this division, means actuarial tables used in the administration and calculation of benefits as referred to in this division are the original tables used by Allmerica Financial Corporation (f/k/a State Mutual Life Assurance Company). Each member of the board of trustees has a copy of the actuarial tables, and the tables are also on file in the offices of the city treasurer, city clerk, and human resources department. 
    Beneficiary means an individual who is being paid or who has entitlement to a pension or other benefit payable from the funds of the retirement system on account of a reason other than the individual's membership in the retirement system. 
    Board of trustees or board means the board of trustees of the retirement system provided for in section 2-84. 
    City means the City of Taylor, Michigan, including its officers, boards, departments, commissions and instrumentalities. 
    Compensation means the salary or wages paid an employee for personal services rendered to the city during the time in which the employee is a member of the retirement system. Specifically, the term "compensation" means base wage, and any other pay in accordance with any applicable collective bargaining agreement. 
    Credited service means the amount of service credited a member by the board in accordance with section 2-69. 
    Employee means an individual who is employed by the city on a fulltime basis for personal services, including elected officials but excluding those employees who are: 
(1)  Members of the city police and fire retirement system; 
(2)  Employees of the 23rd district court (except any judge who was either elected prior to March 31, 1997, or who was elected after March 31, 1997, and who has made an irrevocable election to not participate in the state judges' retirement system, and except any individual who maintains an individual personal services agreement with the city which provides for membership in the general employees' retirement system); 
(3)  Seasonal employees of the city; 
(4)  Neither covered by a collective bargaining agreement nor a personal services contract; 
(5)  Employees only by virtue of membership on a city board or a city commission; 
(6)  Otherwise excluded from membership by applicable law; 
(7)  Any individual who is a participant in the city defined contribution pension plan; 
(8)  Members of the city governmental management and administrative employees association who were first hired on or after March 7, 2001; 
(9)  Members of AFSCME Local 1917 who were first hired on or after December 22, 2004; 
(10)  Members of AFSCME Local 1128 who where first hired on or after December 22, 2004; 
(11)  Elected officials who were first appointed or first elected to the office of city council on or after November 25, 1997; and 
(12)  Elected officials who were first appointed or first elected to the office of mayor, clerk or treasurer on or after November 8, 2005. 
First hired, appointed and/or elected shall refer to those individuals who have not previously participated in the city general employees retirement system. 
    Final average compensation means: 
(1)  For benefit group A, means the average of the member's compensation for the five years prior to their retirement date that produce the highest average. 
(2)  For benefit group B, means the average of the member's compensation for the five consecutive years prior to their retirement date that produce the highest average, excluding vacation, sick leave banks and other banks. 
(3)  For benefit group C, means the average of the member's compensation for the five years prior to their retirement date that produce the highest average. 
(4)  For benefit group D, means the average of the member's compensation for the five consecutive years prior to their retirement date that produce the highest average, excluding vacation, sick leave banks and other banks. 
(5)  For benefit group E, means the average of the member's compensation for the five years prior to their retirement date that produce the highest average. 
(6)  For benefit group F, means the average of the member's compensation for the five years prior to their retirement date that produce the highest average. 
(7)  For benefit group G, means the average of the member's compensation for the five years prior to their retirement date that produce the highest average. 
(8)  For benefit group H, means the average of the member's compensation for the five years prior to their retirement date that produce the highest average. 
For all benefit groups, earnings in the fractional year containing the retirement date may be used in the calculation by comparing the like number of paydays counting from the beginning of the calendar year in each of the five years being used to calculate the final average compensation, and replacing the like number of paydays that produce the lowest earnings, if this results in an increase in the final average compensation. 
    Interest means such rates of interest per annum, compounded annually, as the board from time to time shall determine. 
    Member means an individual who meets the requirements of section 2-68. 
    Pension means an annual amount payable by the retirement system in equal monthly installments throughout the future lifetime of a retiree, or for a temporary period, as provided in this division. 
    Retiree means an individual who retires with a pension payable from the funds of the retirement system. 
    Retirement system means the city general employees' retirement system. 
    Vested former member means an individual who ceases to be a member for a reason other than retirement or death and who satisfies the requirements of section 2-75. 
(Code 1987, § 2-151(2); Ord. No. 05-405, § 2, 11-1-2005) 
Sec. 2-67. - Retirement system continued. 
(a)  Continuation and purpose. The city general employees' retirement system as established, and from time to time amended, is continued for the purpose of providing retirement income to eligible employees of the city and survivor benefits to their eligible beneficiaries. The city guarantees the benefits enumerated in the pension plan/contract No. GA-9004 (Allmerica), as amended, by the full faith and credit of its taxing and borrowing authority. 
(b)  Effective date. This restatement of the city general employees' retirement system is effective November 6, 2005. This restatement will apply to individuals who are current and/or vested deferred members of the retirement system on the effective date of this restatement. The retirement rights of an individual whose city employment terminated before the effective date of this restatement will be governed by the provisions of the retirement system in effect on the date the individual last terminated employment. 
(c)  City guarantee of financial obligations. The city, as the employer and plan sponsor, hereby pledges its full faith and credit in that it guarantees its financial obligations hereunder. 
(Code 1987, § 2-151(1); Ord. No. 05-405, § 1, 11-1-2005) 
Sec. 2-68. - Membership. 
(a)  Requirement of membership. An employee shall become a member of the retirement system in accordance with the provisions of the employee's collective bargaining agreement at the time the employee becomes a member of the employee's appropriate collective bargaining unit, or otherwise in accordance with any applicable personal services contract. Membership in the retirement system shall not include any individuals who are participants in any other retirement plans provided for by the city. 
(b)  Termination of membership. The membership of a member shall terminate upon that person ceasing to be an employee. A former member who is not and will not become eligible for a retirement or death benefit under this division shall have their accumulated member contributions refunded. 
(c)  Cases of doubt. In all cases of doubt, the board shall decide who is a member of the retirement system. 
(Code 1987, § 2-151(3); Ord. No. 05-405, § 3, 11-1-2005) 
Sec. 2-69. - Credited service. 
(a)  Personal service credit. Personal service rendered by a member shall be credited to the member's individual service account in accordance with the provisions of this division and board rule. Service shall be credited in years and fractions of a year. Not more than one year of credited service shall be credited a member on account of all personal service rendered during any period of 12 consecutive months. Not more than 1/12 of a year of credited service shall be credited a member on account of all personal service rendered during a calendar month. The board may credit a member with service credit for periods the member was in receipt of worker's compensation arising as a result of city employment. Where a member is employed 15 or more days of the last month of service, the member will receive credited service for that last month of service; and, where the member is employed 14 or fewer days during the last month of service, the member will not receive credited service for that last month of service. 
(b)  Military service credit; intervening. A member who leaves or left the employ of the city to enter an armed service of the United States during time of war, period of compulsory military service, or period of national emergency recognized by resolution of the city council shall be granted credited service for periods of active duty subject to the following conditions: 
(1)  The member is reemployed by the city within six months from the date of termination of the minimum period of required active military duty; 
(2)  The member pays the retirement system the total amount of accumulated member contributions withdrawn at the time of, or subsequent to, leaving the employment of the city to enter an armed service, plus interest from the date of withdrawal to the date of repayment at interest rates established by the board, unless otherwise established by an applicable collective bargaining agreement; 
(3)  Not more than six years of credited service shall be granted a member under the provisions of this subsection (b); 
(4)  Credited service shall not be granted for periods of armed service which are used to obtain or increase a benefit from another retirement system. 
The purchase of prior military service credit is addressed in the respective collective bargaining agreements. Notwithstanding any provision of this division to the contrary, contributions, benefits and service credit with respect to qualified military service will be provided in accordance with section 414(u) of the Internal Revenue Code. 
(c)  Credited service forfeited. Credited service shall be forfeited and no longer in force if an individual's accumulated member contributions are paid to the individual or a beneficiary (including an estate), except as provided under sections 2-72 through 2-75 and 2-77(b). 
(d)  Reinstatement of credited service. If a former member is reemployed by the city and again becomes a member of the retirement system, the member may have all of the member's forfeited credited service restored after the member has worked for a period of time equal to the time the member was not employed with the city (the gap period). The rules regarding the repayment of accumulated member contributions which were withdrawn at the time of separation of employment, the restoration of credited service, and any actuarial reduction of the pension benefits are addressed by the respective collective bargaining agreements in effect at the time of the repayment. 
(Code 1987, § 2-151(4); Ord. No. 05-405, § 4, 11-1-2005) 
Sec. 2-70. - Benefit groups. 
    The benefit groups set forth in this section are designated for the purpose of determining benefit eligibility conditions, benefit amounts and contribution amounts applicable to a member. At the time of retirement, the participant may elect to be covered by any benefit group in which the participant was a member for at least six consecutive months. 
(1)  Benefit group A shall consist of those members of Local 1917, AFSCME, AFL-CIO, who were hired before August 4, 1988. 
(2)  Benefit group B shall consist of those members of Local 1917, AFSCME, AFL-CIO, who were hired on or after August 4, 1988 through December 21, 2004. 
(3)  Benefit group C shall consist of those members of Local 1128, AFSCME, AFL-CIO, who were hired before August 4, 1988. 
(4)  Benefit group D shall consist of those members of Local 1128, AFSCME, AFL-CIO, who were hired on or after August 4, 1988 through December 21, 2004. 
(5)  Benefit group E shall consist of those members of the city governmental management and administrative employees association (TGM&AEA) who were hired before May 18, 1988, and eligible 23rd district court judges. 
(6)  Benefit group F shall consist of those members of the TGM&AEA who were hired on or after May 18, 1988 through March 6, 2001, and eligible 23rd district court judges. 
(7)  Benefit group G shall consist of all elected officials of the city who were elected or appointed before November 27, 1989, except 23rd district court judges. 
(8)  Benefit group H shall consist of all elected officials of the city who were elected or appointed on or after November 27, 1989, except 23rd district court judges. 
(9)  In cases of doubt, the board shall determine the benefit groups that apply to a member. 
(10)  Note the following: 
a.  In city ordinance No. 97-303 § I(a), it is provided that: "No member of the city council who is first elected or first appointed from and after November 25, 1997, shall be eligible or entitled to participate in the pension and retirement benefit program under the group annuity contract No. GA-9004 of Allmerica Financial f/k/a State Mutual Life Assurance Company nor any other pension plan established by and contributed to by the city." 
b.  In city ordinance No. 97-303 § I(b), it is there provided that: "Any changes (reductions, improvements or enhancements) to the group retirement annuity contract No. GA-9004, whether negotiated by the city governmental management and administrative employees association or otherwise, from and after the effective date of the ordinance from which this division is derived shall not be applicable to past, present, or future council persons, whose date of service with the city council first began prior to November 25, 1997." 
(Code 1987, § 2-151(5); Ord. No. 05-405, § 5, 11-1-2005) 
Sec. 2-71. - Retirement conditions. 
    A member may retire upon satisfaction of each of the following requirements: 
(1)  All city employment terminates prior to the date retirement is to be effective; 
(2)  A written application for retirement is filed with the board setting forth the date, not less than 30 days nor more than 90 days prior to the execution and filing of the application, the retirement is to be effective; and 
(3)  The individual meets the applicable age and/or service requirements for retirement. 
(Code 1987, § 2-151(6); Ord. No. 05-405, § 6, 11-1-2005) 
Sec. 2-72. - Normal retirement. 
(a)  Age and service eligibility conditions for normal retirement are: 
(1)  Benefit group A. The member has attained the earlier of the age of 55 years with eight or more years of credited service, or 25 years of credited service regardless of age. 
(2)  Benefit group B. The member has attained the age of 55 years with ten or more years of credited service. The age and service requirements for benefits under the pension plan will be changed from 55 years of age and 25 years of service to 50 years of age and 25 years of service as of the first annual pension valuation date on which the pension plan's actuary (currently Gabriel Roeder, Smith) determines that the pension plan would be fully (100 percent) funded if the pension plan's current liability as of that valuation date was calculated using the 50 years of age and 25 years of service requirements. 
(3)  Benefit group C. The member has attained: 
a.  The earlier of the age of 55 years with eight or more years of credited service if hired before August 1, 1982; 
b.  Ten or more years of credited service if hired on or after August 1, 1982; or 
c.  25 years of credited service regardless of age. 
(4)  Benefit group D. The member has attained the age of 55 years with ten or more years of credited service. The age and service requirements for normal retirement benefits under the pension plan will be changed from 55 years of age and ten years of service to 55 years of age and ten years of service or 50 years of age and 25 years of service, as of January 1, 2009, or as of the first annual pension valuation date on which, the pension plan's actuary (currently Gabriel Roeder, Smith) determines that the pension plan would be fully (100 percent) funded if the pension plan's current liability as of that valuation date was calculated using the aforementioned service requirements, whichever comes first. (Note: This improvement will result in the late retirement benefit commencing after age 55 with ten years of service or after age 50 with 25 years of service.) 
(5)  Benefit group E. The member has attained the earlier of the age of 55 years with four or more years of credited service, or 25 years of credited service regardless of age. 
(6)  Benefit group F. The member has attained the age of 55 years and has at least five years of credited service. 
(7)  Benefit group G. The member has attained the earlier of the age of 55 years with four or more years of credited service, or 25 years of credited service regardless of age. 
(8)  Benefit group H. The member has attained the age of 55 years and has at least five years of credited service. 
(b)  Upon normal retirement a member shall be paid a pension computed according to the following: 
(1)  Benefit group A. A benefit equal to 55 percent of final average compensation. 
(2)  Benefit group B. A benefit equal to two percent of final average compensation per year of credited service up to a maximum of 25 years of credited service. The pension multiplier will increase from two percent to 2.2 percent as of the first annual pension valuation date on which the general employees' retirement system (pension plan) actuary (currently Gabriel, Roeder, Smith) determines that the pension plan would be fully (100 percent) funded if the pension plan's current liability as of that valuation date was calculated using the 2.2 percent multiplier. 
(3)  Benefit group C. A benefit equal to 55 percent of final average compensation. 
(4)  Benefit group D. A benefit equal to two percent of final average compensation per year of credited service up to a maximum of 25 years of credited service. The pension multiplier will increase from two percent to 2.2 percent as of January 1, 2009, or when the first annual pension valuation date on which the general employees' retirement system ("pension plan") actuary (currently Gabriel, Roeder, Smith) determines that the pension plan would be fully (100 percent) funded if the pension plan's current liability as of that valuation date was calculated using the 2.2 percent multiplier, whichever comes first. 
(5)  Benefit group E. A benefit equal to: 
a.  30 percent of final average compensation with four years of credited service; 
b.  36.25 percent of final average compensation with five years of credited service; 
c.  42.5 percent of final average compensation with six years of credited service; 
d.  48.75 percent of final average compensation with seven years of credited service; 
e.  55 percent of final average compensation with eight or more years of credited service; and 
f.  65 percent of final average compensation with 13 or more years of credited service. 
(6)  Benefit group F. A benefit equal to: 
a.  30 percent of final average compensation with five years of credited service; 
b.  32.5 percent of final average compensation with six years of credited service; 
c.  35 percent of final average compensation with seven years of credited service; 
d.  37.5 percent of final average compensation with eight years of credited service; 
e.  40 percent of final average compensation with nine years of credited service; 
f.  42.5 percent of final average compensation with ten years of credited service; 
g.  45 percent of final average compensation with 11 years of credited service; 
h.  47.5 percent of final average compensation with 12 years of credited service; 
i.  52.5 percent of final average compensation with 13 years of credited service; 
j.  60 percent of final average compensation with 14 years of credited service; and 
k.  65 percent of final average compensation with 15 or more years of credited service. 
(7)  Benefit group G. A benefit equal to: 
a.  30 percent of final average compensation with four years of credited service; 
b.  36.25 percent of final average compensation with five years of credited service; 
c.  42.5 percent of final average compensation with six years of credited service; 
d.  48.75 percent of final average compensation with seven years of credited service; and 
e.  55 percent of final average compensation with eight or more years of credited service. 
(8)  Benefit group H. A benefit equal to: 
a.  30 percent of final average compensation with five years of credited service; 
b.  32.5 percent of final average compensation with six years of credited service; 
c.  35 percent of final average compensation with seven years of credited service; 
d.  37.5 percent of final average compensation with eight years of credited service; 
e.  40 percent of final average compensation with nine years of credited service; 
f.  42.5 percent of final average compensation with ten years of credited service; 
g.  45 percent of final average compensation with 11 years of credited service; 
h.  47.5 percent of final average compensation with 12 years of credited service; 
i.  50 percent of final average compensation with 13 years of credited service; 
j.  52.5 percent of final average compensation with 14 years of credited service; and 
k.  55 percent of final average compensation with 15 or more years of credited service. 
(c)  Normal retirement benefits shall commence the first day of the month following the last day of employment. 
(Code 1987, § 2-151(7); Ord. No. 05-405, § 7, 11-1-2005) 
Sec. 2-73. - Early retirement. 
(a)  Age and service eligibility conditions for early retirement are: 
(1)  Benefit group A. The member has attained: 
a.  The earlier of the age of 48 years with eight or more years of credited service; or 
b.  18 years of credited service regardless of age. 
(2)  Benefit group B. The member has attained the age of 50 years with ten or more years of credited service. 
(3)  Benefit group C. The member has: 
a.  Attained the earlier of the age of 48 years with eight years of credited service if hired before August 1, 1982; or 
b.  Attained the age of 48 years with ten years of credited service if hired on or after August 1, 1982; or 
c.  Completed 18 years of credited service regardless of age. 
(4)  Benefit group D. The member has attained the age of 50 years with ten or more years of credited service. 
(5)  Benefit group E. The member has attained the completion of four or more years of credited service regardless of age. 
(6)  Benefit group F. The member has attained the completion of five or more years of credited service regardless of age. 
(7)  Benefit group G. The member has attained the completion of four or more years of credited service regardless of age. 
(8)  Benefit group H. The member has attained the completion of five or more years of credited service regardless of age. 
(b)  Upon early retirement a member shall be paid a pension computed according to the following: 
(1)  Benefit group A. A benefit equal to a benefit which is computed as a normal retirement benefit but actuarially reduced to reflect retirement prior to the normal retirement date and based on final average compensation at the early retirement date. The benefit equals 55 percent of final average compensation multiplied by the actuarial reduction factor specified in accordance with actuarial table A as referred to in this division, early retirement. For the purpose of calculating the early retirement benefit only, the normal retirement date shall be the first day of the month coincident with or next following the date at which the member would have attained normal retirement eligibility had the member remained in the employ of the employer. 
(2)  Benefit group B. A benefit equal to a benefit which is computed as a normal retirement benefit but actuarially reduced to reflect retirement prior to the normal retirement date and based on final average compensation at the early retirement date. The benefit equals 50 percent of final average compensation if the member has 25 years or more of credited service, or two percent per year of credited service if the member has fewer than 25 years but at least ten years of credited service, multiplied by the actuarial reduction factor specified in accordance with actuarial table A as referred to in this division, early retirement. For the purpose of calculating the early retirement benefit only, the normal retirement date shall be the first day of the month coincident with or next following the date at which the member would have attained normal retirement eligibility had the member remained in the employ of the employer. The pension multiplier in this subsection (b)(2) will increase from two percent to 2.2 percent as of the first annual pension valuation date on which the general employees' retirement system (pension plan) actuary (currently Gabriel, Roeder, Smith) determines that the pension plan would be fully (100 percent) funded if the pension plan's current liability as of that valuation date was calculated using the 2.2 percent multiplier. 
(3)  Benefit group C. A benefit equal to a benefit which is computed as a normal retirement benefit but actuarially reduced to reflect retirement prior to the normal retirement date and based on final average compensation at the early retirement date. The benefit equals the normal retirement benefit multiplied by the ratio that the number of years of credited service completed by the member on the member's early retirement date bears to the number of years of credited service the member could otherwise have completed by the member's normal retirement date had the member remained in the employ of the employer, multiplied by the corresponding actuarial reduction factor specified in accordance with actuarial table A, early retirement. For the purpose of calculating the early retirement benefit only, the normal retirement date shall be the first day of the month coincident with or next following the date at which the member would have attained normal retirement eligibility had the member remained in the employ of the employer. 
(4)  Benefit group D. A benefit equal to a benefit which is computed as a normal retirement benefit but actuarially reduced to reflect retirement prior to the normal retirement date and based on final average compensation at the early retirement date. The benefit equals 50 percent of final average compensation if the member has 25 years or more of credited service, or two percent per year of credited service if the member has fewer than 25 years but at least ten years of credited service, multiplied by the actuarial reduction factor specified in accordance with actuarial table A, early retirement. For the purpose of calculating the early retirement benefit only, the normal retirement date shall be the first day of the month coincident with or next following the date at which the member would have attained normal retirement eligibility had the member remained in the employ of the employer. The multiplier in this subsection (b)(4) will be increased from two percent to 2.2 percent as of January 1, 2009, or when the first annual pension valuation date on which the general employees' retirement system (pension plan) actuary (currently Gabriel, Roeder, Smith) determines that the pension plan would be fully (100 percent) funded if the pension plan's current liability as of that valuation date was calculated using the 2.2 percent multiplier, whichever comes first. 
(5)  Benefit group E. A benefit equal to a benefit which is computed as a normal retirement benefit but actuarially reduced to reflect retirement prior to the normal retirement date. The benefit equals the normal retirement benefit multiplied by the actuarial reduction factor as determined in actuarial table A, early retirement. For the purpose of calculating the early retirement benefit only, the normal retirement date shall be the first day of the month coincident with or next following the date at which the member would have attained normal retirement eligibility had the member remained in the employ of the employer. 
(6)  Benefit group F. A benefit equal to a benefit which is computed as a normal retirement benefit but actuarially reduced to reflect retirement prior to the normal retirement date. The benefit equals the normal retirement benefit multiplied by the actuarial reduction factor as determined in actuarial table A, early retirement. For the purpose of calculating the early retirement benefit only, the normal retirement date shall be the first day of the month coincident with or next following the date at which the member would have attained normal retirement eligibility had the member remained in the employ of the employer. 
(7)  Benefit group G. A benefit equal to a benefit which is computed as a normal retirement benefit but actuarially reduced to reflect retirement prior to the normal retirement date. The benefit equals the normal retirement benefit multiplied by the actuarial reduction factor as determined in actuarial table A, early retirement. For the purpose of calculating the early retirement benefit only, the normal retirement date shall be the first day of the month coincident with or next following the date at which the member would have attained normal retirement eligibility had the member remained in the employ of the employer. 
(8)  Benefit group H. A benefit equal to a benefit which is computed as a normal retirement benefit but actuarially reduced to reflect retirement prior to the normal retirement date. The benefit equals the normal retirement benefit multiplied by the actuarial reduction factor as determined in actuarial table A, early retirement. For the purpose of calculating the early retirement benefit only, the normal retirement date shall be the first day of the month coincident with or next following the date at which the member would have attained normal retirement eligibility had the member remained in the employ of the employer. 
(c)  Early retirement benefits shall commence the first day of the month following the month in which the member elects to exercise their early retirement rights as set forth in this division. 
(Code 1987, § 2-151(8); Ord. No. 05-405, § 8, 11-1-2005) 
Sec. 2-74. - Late retirement. 
(a)  Age and service eligibility conditions for late retirement are: 
(1)  Benefit group A. Any time following eligibility for normal retirement for which personal service credit is received. 
(2)  Benefit group B. Any time following eligibility for normal retirement for which personal service credit is received. 
(3)  Benefit group C. Any time following eligibility for normal retirement for which personal service credit is received. 
(4)  Benefit group D. Any time following eligibility for normal retirement for which personal service credit is received. 
(5)  Benefit group E. Any time following eligibility for normal retirement and having attained 65 percent of final average compensation for which personal service credit is received. 
(6)  Benefit group F. Any time following eligibility for normal retirement and having attained 65 percent of final average compensation for which personal service credit is received. 
(7)  Benefit group G. Any time following eligibility for normal retirement and having attained 55 percent of final average compensation for which personal service credit is received. 
(8)  Benefit group H. Any time following eligibility for normal retirement and having attained 55 percent of final average compensation for which personal service credit is received. 
(b)  Upon late retirement a member shall be paid a pension computed according to the following: 
(1)  Benefit group A. A benefit equal to a benefit which is computed as a normal retirement benefit based on their final average compensation as of their late retirement date but actuarially increased to reflect late retirement on the basis of the factors specified in actuarial table H, late retirement, to reflect the fact that the benefits will be paid for a shorter period of time than if the member had retired on the member's normal retirement date. For the purpose of calculating the late retirement benefit only, the normal retirement date shall be the earlier of the first day of the month coincident with or next following the date the member has: 
a.  Attained the age of 55 years with eight years of credited service; or 
b.  Completed 25 years of credited service regardless of age. 
(2)  Benefit group B. A benefit equal to a benefit which is computed as a normal retirement benefit based on their final average compensation as of their late retirement date but actuarially increased to reflect late retirement on the basis of the factors specified in actuarial table H, late retirement, to reflect the fact that the benefits will be paid for a shorter period of time than if the member had retired on the member's normal retirement date. For the purpose of calculating the late retirement benefit only, the normal retirement date shall be the earlier of the first day of the month coincident with or next following the date the member has attained the age of 55 years with ten years of credited service. 
(3)  Benefit group C. A benefit equal to the amount the member would have received had the member retired on their normal retirement date based on their final average compensation as of their late retirement date, plus an additional two percent of the member's final average compensation for each year worked between their normal retirement date and late retirement date. 
(4)  Benefit group D. A benefit equal to the amount the member would have received had the member retired on their normal retirement date based on their final average compensation as of their late retirement date, plus an additional two percent of the member's final average compensation for each year worked between their normal retirement date and late retirement date. The pension multiplier in this subsection (b)(4) will increase from two percent to 2.2 percent as of January 1, 2009, or when the first annual pension valuation date on which the general employees' retirement system (pension plan) actuary (currently Gabriel, Roeder, Smith) determines that the pension plan would be fully (100 percent) funded if the pension plan's current liability as of that valuation date was calculated using the 2.2 percent multiplier, whichever comes first. 
(5)  Benefit group E. A benefit equal to the amount the member would have received had the member retired on their normal retirement date and based on their final average compensation as of their late retirement date, but actuarially increased, on the basis of the factors specified in actuarial table H, late retirement, to reflect the fact that the benefits will be paid for a shorter period of time than if the member had retired on their normal retirement date. For the purpose of calculating the late retirement benefit only, the normal retirement date shall be the earlier of the first day of the month coincident with or next following the date the member has: 
a.  Attained the age of 55 years with 13 years of credited service; or 
b.  Completed 25 years of credited service. 
(6)  Benefit group F. A benefit equal to the amount the member would have received on their normal retirement date and based on their final average compensation as of their late retirement date, and actuarially increased in accordance with factors specified in actuarial table H, late retirement to reflect the fact that the benefits will be paid for a shorter period of time than if the member had retired on their normal retirement date. For the purpose of calculating the late retirement benefit only, the normal retirement date shall be the first day of the month coincident with or next following the date the member has attained the age of 55 years with 15 years of credited service. 
(7)  Benefit group G. A benefit equal to the amount the member would have received had the member retired on their normal retirement date and based on their final average compensation as of their late retirement date, but actuarially increased on the basis of the factors specified in actuarial table H, late retirement, to reflect the fact that the benefits will be paid for a shorter period of time than if the member had retired on their normal retirement date. For the purpose of calculating the late retirement benefit only, the normal retirement date shall be the earlier of the first day of the month coincident with or next following the date the member has: 
a.  Attained the age of 55 years with eight years of credited service; or 
b.  Completed 25 years of credited service. 
(8)  Benefit group H. A benefit equal to the amount the member would have received had the member retired on their normal retirement date, but based on final average compensation as of their late retirement date and actuarially increased in accordance with factors specified in actuarial table H, late retirement, to reflect the fact that the benefits will be paid for a shorter period of time than if the member had retired on their normal retirement date. For the purpose of calculating the late retirement benefit only, the normal retirement date shall be the first day of the month coincident with or next following the date the member has attained the age of 55 years with 15 years of credited service. 
(c)  Late retirement benefits shall commence the first day of the month following the last day of employment. 
(Code 1987, § 2-151(9); Ord. No. 05-405, § 9, 11-1-2005) 
Sec. 2-75. - Deferred vested retirement. 
(a)  A member who ceases to be a member for a reason other than retirement or death shall be a vested former member if the following requirements are met: 
(1)  The former member has satisfied the credited service requirement for the member's benefit group specified in subsection (b) of this section;
