(2)  The former member's accumulated member contributions remain deposited in the retirement system unless otherwise provided for in the member's collective bargaining agreement in effect at the time the member separates from service. 
(b)  The service requirements for vested former member status are: 
(1)  Benefit group A. Eight or more years of credited service. 
(2)  Benefit group B. Ten or more years of credited service. 
(3)  Benefit group C. Eight or more years of credited service if hired before August 1, 1982, or ten or more years of credited service if hired on or after August 1, 1982. 
(4)  Benefit group D. Ten or more years of credited service. 
(5)  Benefit group E. Four or more years of credited service. 
(6)  Benefit group F. Five or more years of credited service. 
(7)  Benefit group G. Eight or more years of credited service if elected or appointed before May 18, 1988, four or more years of credited service if elected or appointed on or after May 18, 1988 but before November 27, 1989. 
(8)  Benefit group H. Five or more years of credited service. 
(c)  A vested former member is entitled to commence receiving deferred vested retirement benefits upon meeting the following requirements: 
(1)  Benefit group A. The member has attained the age of 55 years, however, if the member had attained the age of 48 years with eight years of credited service or had completed 18 years of credited service regardless of age at the time of the member's separation of employment, the member may elect to retire any time after separation of employment but prior to age 55 years and receive an early retirement benefit as provided in section 2-73. 
(2)  Benefit group B. The member has attained the age of 55 years, however, if the member had attained the age of 50 years with ten or more years of credited service at the time of the member's separation of employment, the member may elect to retire any time after separation of employment but prior to age 55 years and receive an early retirement benefit as provided in section 2-73. 
(3)  Benefit group C. The member has attained the age of 55 years, however, if the member had attained the age of 48 years with eight years of credited service if hired before August 1, 1982; or the age of 48 years with ten years of credited service if hired on or after August 1, 1982; or had completed 18 years of credited service regardless of age at the time of the member's separation of employment, the member may elect to retire any time after separation of employment but prior to age 55 years and receive an early retirement benefit as provided in section 2-73. 
(4)  Benefit group D. The member has attained the age of 55 years, however, if the member had attained the age of 50 years with ten or more years of credited service at the time of the member's separation of employment, the member may elect to retire any time after separation of employment but prior to age 55 years and receive an early retirement benefit as provided in section 2-73. 
(5)  Benefit group E. The member has attained the age of 55 years; however, the member may elect to retire any time after separation of employment but prior to age 55 years and receive an early retirement benefit as provided in section 2-73. 
(6)  Benefit group F. The member has attained the age of 55 years; however, the member may elect to retire any time after separation of employment but prior to age 55 years and receive an early retirement benefit as provided in section 2-73. 
(7)  Benefit group G. The member has attained the age of 55 years; however, the member may elect to retire any time after separation of employment but prior to age 55 years and receive an early retirement benefit as provided in section 2-73. 
(8)  Benefit group H. The member has attained the age of 55 years; however, the member may elect to retire any time after separation of employment but prior to age 55 years and receive an early retirement benefit as provided in section 2-73. 
(d)  The amount of pension payable to a vested former member shall be the amount of accrued normal pension determined according to the following: 
(1)  Benefit group A. A benefit equal to an amount which is computed as a normal retirement benefit based on credited service and final average compensation at the time of separation of employment. 
(2)  Benefit group B. A benefit equal to an amount which is computed as a normal retirement benefit based on credited service and final average compensation at the time of separation of employment. 
(3)  Benefit group C. A benefit equal to an amount which is computed as a normal retirement benefit based on credited service and final average compensation at the time of separation of employment. 
(4)  Benefit group D. A benefit equal to an amount which is computed as a normal retirement benefit based on credited service and final average compensation at the time of separation of employment. 
(5)  Benefit group E. A benefit equal to an amount which is computed as a normal retirement benefit based on credited service and final average compensation at the time of separation of employment. 
(6)  Benefit group F. A benefit equal to an amount which is computed as a normal retirement benefit based on credited service and final average compensation at the time of separation of employment. 
(7)  Benefit group G. A benefit equal to an amount which is computed as a normal retirement benefit based on credited service and final average compensation at the time of separation of employment. 
(8)  Benefit group H. A benefit equal to an amount which is computed as a normal retirement benefit based on credited service and final average compensation at the time of separation of employment. 
(e)  The normal retirement benefit payable to a vested former member shall be based upon the terms and conditions and upon final average compensation in effect at the time of separation of employment. 
(f)  The death of a vested former member prior to retirement or an election to receive a refund of the accumulated member contributions on deposit in the retirement system shall cause forfeiture of credited service and all rights to retirement and a pension, unless otherwise provided by the retirement system, an applicable collective bargaining agreement, or applicable state or federal law. 
(Code 1987, § 2-151(10); Ord. No. 05-405, § 10, 11-1-2005) 
Sec. 2-76. - Retiree medical. 
    Retiree medical benefits are provided, in the appropriate case, in accordance with collective bargaining agreements and Public Act No. 28 of 1966 (MCL 38.571 et seq.). 
(Code 1987, § 2-151(11); Ord. No. 05-405, § 11, 11-1-2005) 
Sec. 2-77. - Election of form of payment and payment options. 
(a)  A member or vested former member may elect to have pension payments made under any one of the forms of payment provided below. A member or vested former member may elect a beneficiary, and the election shall be filed with the board, in writing, on forms provided by the retirement system. A member or vested former member may make, change or revoke their election of the form of payment and of their beneficiary at any time prior to the date the first pension payment is made. The change or revocation shall be in writing and filed with the board on forms provided by the retirement system. 
(1)  Straight life annuity (normal form of payment). Payable for the life of the member with a death benefit equal to the member's remaining contributions, if any, with interest to the member's retirement date. 
(2)  Life annuity with 60 months certain option (actuarial table C). A member may elect to receive a reduced monthly retirement benefit, in an amount actuarially equivalent to the straight life annuity option, paid for life commencing on the member's retirement date with the provision that if the retiree should die after the retirement date and before collecting 60 monthly payments, the balance of the 60 payments will be paid in one lump sum to the retiree's designated beneficiary. 
(3)  Life annuity with 120 months certain option (actuarial table D). A member may elect to receive a reduced monthly retirement benefit, in an amount actuarially equivalent to the straight life annuity option, paid for life commencing on the member's retirement date with the provision that if the retiree should die after the retirement date and before collecting 120 monthly payments, the balance of the 120 payments will be paid in one lump sum to the retiree's designated beneficiary. 
(4)  Life annuity with 180 months certain option (actuarial table E). A member may elect to receive a reduced monthly retirement benefit, in an amount actuarially equivalent to the straight life annuity option, paid for life commencing on the member's retirement date with the provision that if the retiree should die after the retirement date and before collecting 180 monthly payments, the balance of the 180 payments will be paid in one lump sum to the retiree's designated beneficiary. 
(5)  Life annuity with 240 months certain option (actuarial table F). A member may elect to receive a reduced monthly retirement benefit, in an amount actuarially equivalent to the straight life annuity option, paid for life commencing on the member's retirement date with the provision that if the retiree should die after the retirement date and before collecting 240 monthly payments, the balance of the 240 payments will be paid in one lump sum to the retiree's designated beneficiary. 
(6)  Contingent annuitant option (actuarial table G). A member may elect to receive a reduced monthly retirement benefit, in an amount actuarially equivalent to the normal retirement benefit, payable throughout the retiree's life and designate any person as their contingent annuitant. Upon the retiree's death, the surviving contingent annuitant will receive, for their lifetime, 100 percent, 75 percent, 66.67 percent or 50 percent of the actuarially reduced monthly benefit, in accordance with the continuation percentage which the member has elected. 
(b)  At time of retirement, a member may elect to withdraw their accumulated member contributions and thereby actuarially reduce their monthly retirement benefit in accordance with actuarial table B. The reduction related to the withdrawal of accumulated contributions shall be applied to the straight life annuity benefit prior to any reduction related to the election of a certain or contingent annuitant option provided in this subsection. This option is available to all benefit groups. 
(Code 1987, § 2-151(12); Ord. No. 05-405, § 12, 11-1-2005) 
Sec. 2-78. - Preretirement death benefits. 
(a)  Eligibility conditions for preretirement death benefits are: 
(1)  Benefit group A. Death while actively employed for eight or more years of credited service. 
(2)  Benefit group B. Death while actively employed for ten or more years of credited service. 
(3)  Benefit group C. Death while actively employed for eight or more years of credited service if hired before August 1, 1982, or ten or more years of credited service if hired on or after August 1, 1982. 
(4)  Benefit group D. Death while actively employed for ten or more years of credited service. 
(5)  Benefit group E. Death while actively employed for four or more years of credited service. 
(6)  Benefit group F. Death while actively employed for five or more years of credited service. 
(7)  Benefit group G. Death while actively employed for four or more years of credited service. 
(8)  Benefit group H. Death while actively employed for five or more years of credited service. 
(b)  The preretirement death benefits are as follows: 
(1)  Benefit group A. An amount equal to 50 percent of the retirement benefit the member could have received if eligible for retirement at the time of death, payable to the member's spouse for life. If the member is not eligible to retire at the date of death, the benefit begins at the earliest date the member could have retired had the member survived. If the member is not married at date of death, then the member's designated beneficiary will receive a refund of the accumulated member contributions. 
(2)  Benefit group B. An amount equal to 50 percent of the retirement benefit the member could have received if eligible for retirement at the time of death, payable to the member's spouse for life. If the member is not eligible to retire at the date of death, the benefit begins at the earliest date the member could have retired had the member survived. If the member is not married at date of death, then the member's designated beneficiary will receive a refund of the accumulated member contributions. 
(3)  Benefit group C. An amount equal to 50 percent of the retirement benefit the member could have received if eligible for retirement at the time of death, payable to the member's spouse for life; or in the absence of a spouse, to the member's dependent children. If the member is not eligible to retire at the date of death, the benefit begins at the earliest date the member could have retired had the member survived. If the member is not married and has no dependent children at date of death, then the member's designated beneficiary will receive a refund of the accumulated member contributions together with interest at the rate that the board has established as effective at the time of that member's death. 
(4)  Benefit group D. An amount equal to 50 percent of the retirement benefit the member could have received if eligible for retirement at the time of death, payable to the member's spouse for life, or in the absence of a spouse, to the member's dependent children. If the member is not eligible to retire at the date of death, the benefit begins at the earliest date the member could have retired had the member survived. If the member is not married and has no dependent children at date of death, then the member's designated beneficiary will receive a refund of the accumulated member contributions. 
(5)  Benefit group E. An amount equal to 100 percent of the member's accrued pension at the time of death, payable to the member's spouse actuarially adjusted based on the member's age at death and the age of the member's spouse; or in the absence of a spouse, to the member's children until the children attains the age of 21 years actuarially adjusted based on the member's age at death and the ages of the children. If the member is not married and has no children under the age of 21 years, then the member's designated beneficiary will receive a refund of the accumulated member contributions. 
(6)  Benefit group F. An amount equal to 100 percent of the member's accrued pension at the time of death, payable to the member's spouse actuarially adjusted based on the member's age at death and the age of the member's spouse; or in the absence of a spouse, to the member's children until the children attains the age of 21 years actuarially adjusted based on the member's age at death and the ages of the children. If the member is not married and has no children under the age of 21 years, then the member's designated beneficiary will receive a refund of the accumulated member contributions. 
(7)  Benefit group G. An amount equal to 50 percent of the retirement benefit the member could have received if eligible for retirement at the time of death, payable to the member's spouse for life. If the member is not eligible to retire at the date of death, the benefit begins at the earliest date the member could have retired had the member survived. If the member is not married at date of death, then the member's designated beneficiary will receive a refund of the accumulated member contributions. 
(8)  Benefit group H. An amount equal to 50 percent of the retirement benefit the member could have received if eligible for retirement at the time of death, payable to the member's spouse for life. If the member is not eligible to retire at the date of death, the benefit begins at the earliest date the member could have retired had the member survived. If the member is not married at date of death, then the member's designated beneficiary will receive a refund of the accumulated member contributions. 
(Code 1987, § 2-151(13); Ord. No. 05-405, § 13, 11-1-2005) 
Sec. 2-79. - Disability retirement. 
(a)  Eligibility conditions. Eligibility conditions for disability retirement are: 
(1)  Benefit group A. There is no age or service requirement, but the member must be in receipt of Social Security disability benefits in order to be eligible to receive a disability benefit hereunder. 
(2)  Benefit group B. The member must have at least ten years of credited service and be in receipt of Social Security disability benefits in order to be eligible to receive a disability benefit hereunder. 
(3)  Benefit group C. There is no age or service requirement, but the member must be in receipt of Social Security disability benefits in order to be eligible to receive a disability benefit hereunder. 
(4)  Benefit group D. The member must have at least ten years of credited service and be in receipt of Social Security disability benefits in order to be eligible to receive a disability benefit hereunder. 
(5)  Benefit group E. There is no age or service requirement, but the member must be in receipt of Social Security disability benefits in order to be eligible to receive a disability benefit hereunder. 
(6)  Benefit group F. There is no age or service requirement, but the member must be in receipt of Social Security disability benefits in order to be eligible to receive a disability benefit hereunder. 
(7)  Benefit group G. There is no age or service requirement, but the member must be in receipt of Social Security disability benefits in order to be eligible to receive a disability benefit hereunder. 
(8)  Benefit group H. There is no age or service requirement, but the member must be in receipt of Social Security disability benefits in order to be eligible to receive a disability benefit hereunder. 
(b)  The benefits. The disability retirement benefits are as follows: 
(1)  Benefit group A. An amount equal to 66.67 percent of final average compensation with a maximum benefit of $1,500.00 per month. The benefit shall be recalculated at the member's normal retirement date based on the normal retirement benefit formula. 
(2)  Benefit group B. An amount equal to two percent of final average compensation per year of credited service. The benefit shall be recalculated at the member's normal retirement date based on the normal retirement benefit formula. 
(3)  Benefit group C. An amount equal to 66.67 percent of final average compensation with a maximum benefit of $2,000.00 per month. The benefit shall be recalculated at the member's normal retirement date based on the normal retirement benefit formula. 
(4)  Benefit group D. An amount equal to two percent of final average compensation per year of credited service. The benefit shall be recalculated at the member's normal retirement date based on the normal retirement benefit formula. 
(5)  Benefit group E. An amount equal to 66.67 percent of final average compensation with a maximum benefit of $2,000.00 per month. The benefit shall be recalculated at the member's normal retirement date based on the normal retirement benefit formula. 
(6)  Benefit group F. An amount equal to 66.67 percent of final average compensation with a maximum benefit of $2,000.00 per month. The benefit shall be recalculated at the member's normal retirement date based on the normal retirement benefit formula. 
(7)  Benefit group G. An amount equal to 66.67 percent of final average compensation with a maximum benefit of $2,000.00 per month. The benefit shall be recalculated at the member's normal retirement date based on the normal retirement benefit formula. 
(8)  Benefit group H. An amount equal to 66.67 percent of final average compensation with a maximum benefit of $2,000.00 per month. The benefit shall be recalculated at the member's normal retirement date based on the normal retirement benefit formula. 
(c)  Termination. The payment of disability retirement benefits shall cease upon the termination of a disability retiree's Social Security benefits. 
(d)  Reemployment of a disability retiree. In the event an individual, who was previously in receipt of a disability retirement benefit from the retirement system, is reemployed by the city, they shall again become a member of the retirement system and all credited service standing to the member prior to disability retirement shall be restored. Those members whom the board finds to have been disabled as a result of causes arising out of and in the course of their employment with the city shall receive credited service for the period during which the member was in receipt of disability retirement benefits. 
(e)  Limitation on disability pension. 
(1)  Worker's compensation benefit amounts paid to a disability retiree shall be offset against and payable in place of benefits provided under subsection (a) of this section. If there is a redemption or settlement of the worker's compensation benefit, weekly benefits at the established amount shall be considered to continue until the weekly benefits paid after the effective date of the settlement equal the amount of the redemption or settlement. Thereafter, the disability retiree will be considered to have no income from worker's compensation benefits. Worker's compensation benefits for bona fide medical expenses, as determined by the board of trustees, shall not be considered income. 
(2)  The board of trustees shall periodically request substantiated income information from disability retirees. Failure to provide the requested information within 90 days of the request may cause suspension of payment of the benefit until the information is received. 
(Code 1987, § 2-151(14); Ord. No. 05-405, § 14, 11-1-2005) 
Sec. 2-80. - Retiree reemployment. 
(a)  No elected or appointed official shall increase their accrued pension benefits, including their final average compensation for pension purposes, if elected or appointed to a different elective office after July 19, 2011. Such personal service rendered in this different elective office shall not be credited to that individual's service credit account for any pension benefit purpose, including any increase in his/her final average compensation and/or any and all pension benefits. 
(b)  An individual who has retired and is receiving a pension benefit, and who subsequently becomes reemployed by the city, shall continue to receive such pension benefit, shall not be entitled to receive any additional credited service, and shall not become a member of the retirement system. 
(Code 1987, § 2-151(15); Ord. No. 05-405, § 15, 11-1-2005; Ord. No. 11-463, § 1, 8-2-2011) 
Sec. 2-81. - Denial of benefit claim; appeal. 
    A benefit claimant shall be notified in writing within 30 days after board action of a denial of a claim for benefits. The notification shall give the reason for the denial. A claimant may appeal the denial and request a hearing. The appeal shall be in writing, filed with the board within 90 days of the denial, and shall contain a statement of the claimant's reason for believing the denial to be improper. The board shall schedule a hearing of the appeal before the board or, at the discretion of the board, before a committee of the board within 60 days of receipt of the appeal. A final decision on the matter being appealed shall be made by the board. 
(Code 1987, § 2-151(16); Ord. No. 05-405, § 16, 11-1-2005) 
Sec. 2-82. - Member contributions. 
(a)  Benefit group A. The member shall contribute five percent of compensation to the extent such compensation is eligible to be included in such member's final average compensation. 
(b)  Benefit group B. The member shall contribute five percent of compensation to the extent such compensation is eligible to be included in such member's final average compensation. 
(c)  Benefit group C. The member shall contribute five percent of compensation to the extent such compensation is eligible to be included in such member's final average compensation. 
(d)  Benefit group D. The member shall contribute five percent of compensation to the extent such compensation is eligible to be included in such member's final average compensation. 
(e)  Benefit group E. The member shall contribute five percent of compensation to the extent such compensation is eligible to be included in such member's final average compensation. 
(f)  Benefit group F. The member shall contribute five percent of compensation to the extent such compensation is eligible to be included in such member's final average compensation. 
(g)  Benefit group G. The member shall contribute five percent of compensation to the extent such compensation is eligible to be included in such member's final average compensation. 
(h)  Benefit group H. The member shall contribute five percent of compensation to the extent such compensation is eligible to be included in such member's final average compensation. 
(i)  Payroll deductions. The individual responsible for preparing the city's payroll shall deduct the contributions required by this subsection from the compensation of each employee who is a member, on each and every payroll, for each and every payroll period, so long as the employee remains a member. The amounts deducted shall be paid to the retirement system and credited to the reserve for accumulated member contributions. In the event there is a failure to make such deductions required hereunder, the board shall determine the appropriate corrective measures required and shall proceed accordingly. 
(j)  Consent to deductions. Each member shall be deemed to consent and agree to the deductions made and provided for by this subsection. Payment of compensation, less this deduction, shall be a full and complete discharge and acquittance of all claims and demands for the service rendered, except as to benefits provided by the retirement system. 
(k)  Contribution determination. Member contributions shall be determined by reference to the portion of a member's compensation that is eligible for inclusion in the member's final average compensation, regardless of whether such compensation is paid in one of the years that is actually included in the member's final average compensation. 
(l)  Cumulative payments. The cumulative payments under this retirement system shall be no less than the accumulated member contributions. 
(Code 1987, § 2-151(17); Ord. No. 05-405, § 17, 11-1-2005) 
Sec. 2-83. - Funds of retirement system. 
(a)  Reserve for accumulated member contributions. 
(1)  The reserve for accumulated member contributions is the account in which is accumulated the contributions deducted from the compensation of members and which shall be charged with refunds and transfers of accumulated member contributions. 
(2)  A member's accumulated contributions shall be transferred from the reserve for accumulated member contributions to the reserve for pension payments if a pension becomes payable on account of the member's retirement or death. 
(b)  Reserve for pension payments. 
(1)  The reserve for pension payments is the account which is charged with all pension payments and refunds of accumulated member contributions which have been transferred to this account. If a disability pension is terminated and the individual again becomes a member or becomes a vested former member, the pension reserve at the date of termination of disability shall be transferred from the reserve for pension payments to the reserve for accumulated member contributions and the reserve for employer contributions in the proportion transfers were made from such accounts because of the retirement. 
(2)  Each year following receipt of the report of the annual actuarial valuation, the balance in the reserve for pension payments shall be set equal to the actuarial present value of pensions being paid retired members and beneficiaries by a transfer to or from the reserve for employer contributions. The pending transfer shall be taken into account by the actuary when making the actuarial valuation. 
(c)  Reserve for employer contributions. The reserve for employer contributions is the account to which city contributions are credited and from which shall be made transfers to the reserve for pension payments. If a pension becomes payable due to a member's retirement or death, the difference shall be transferred from the reserve for employer contributions to the reserve for pension payments, between: 
(1)  The present value of the expected payments on behalf of the member; and 
(2)  The amount transferred from the reserve for accumulated member contributions on behalf of the member. 
(d)  Reserve for undistributed investment income. 
(1)  The reserve for undistributed investment income is the account to which is credited: 
a.  All interest, dividends and other income from retirement system assets; 
b.  All gifts and bequests; 
c.  All appropriations for retirement system administrative expenses; and 
d.  All other monies received by the retirement system, the disposition of which is not specifically provided. 
There shall be transferred from the reserve for undistributed investment income all amounts required to credit interest to the other reserve accounts and to pay the administrative expenses of the retirement system. 
(2)  Whenever the board of trustees determines that the balance in the account is more than sufficient to cover current charges, the excess or any part thereof may be used to fund contingency reserves, meet special requirements of the other reserve accounts or be transferred to the reserve for employer contributions. Whenever the balance in the account is insufficient to cover current charges, the amount of the insufficiency shall be transferred to the account from the reserve for employer contributions. 
(e)  Assets not segregated. The descriptions of the reserve accounts shall be interpreted to refer to the accounting records of the retirement system and not to the physical separation or investment of assets by reserve account. 
(f)  Interest credited to reserve accounts. 
(1)  The board of trustees shall, at the end of each calendar year, credit interest on the individual beginning-of-the-year balances in the reserve for accumulated member contributions, and on the mean balances in the reserve for pension payments and the reserve for employer contributions. The amount of interest so credited shall be charged to the reserve for undistributed investment income. Interest shall not be credited for any period after the separation of the individual from city employment. 
(2)  The rate or rates of interest to be used for crediting interest shall be the rate or rates set forth in an applicable collective bargaining agreement. In the event that a rate of interest is not set forth in an applicable collective bargaining agreement, or in the event that the terms of a member's participation in the retirement system are not governed by a collective bargaining agreement, the board of trustees shall determine the rate or rates of interest to be used for crediting of interest. 
(Code 1987, § 2-151(18); Ord. No. 05-405, § 18, 11-1-2005) 
Sec. 2-84. - Board of trustees; authority and membership. 
(a)  The board of trustees of the retirement system shall be vested with the authority and responsibility for: 
(1)  The administration, management and operation of the retirement system; 
(2)  Construing and making effective the provisions of the retirement system contained in this division; and 
(3)  The investment of the assets acquired by the retirement system. 
(b)  The board of trustees shall be a quasi-judicial body consisting of the following six individuals: 
(1)  The human resources director or designee, or a citizen to be appointed by the mayor in lieu of the human resources director; provided, however, that the individual so designated or appointed shall serve as trustee for the entire term; 
(2)  The budget and finance director or designee, or a citizen to be appointed by the mayor in lieu of the budget and finance director; provided, however, that the individual so designated or appointed shall serve as trustee for the entire term; 
(3)  The city treasurer; 
(4)  A member who is a representative of the city governmental management and administrative employees association; 
(5)  A member who is a representative of Local 1917, AFSCME, AFL-CIO; and 
(6)  A member who is a representative of Local 1128, AFSCME, AFL-CIO. 
(c)  The board of trustees is vested with the authority and fiduciary responsibility for the administration, management and operation of the retirement system pursuant to collective bargaining agreements and applicable federal and state law. The board of trustees has a duty to properly administer the provisions of the plan and invest the funds of the trust in accordance with Public Act No. 314 of 1965 (MCL 38.1132 et seq.) known as Act 314. Each and every trustee is, therefore, considered a fiduciary and has fiduciary responsibilities as a result. Act 314 provides that a trustee shall discharge the trustee's duties solely in the interest of the participants (members) and their beneficiaries and act with the same care, skill, prudence, and diligence under the circumstances then prevailing that a prudent man would exercise. Act 314 defines the term "fiduciary" as one who exercises any discretionary authority or control in the investment of a retirement system's assets. Fiduciaries who breach their responsibilities shall be personally liable for any losses to the plans which they administer and shall be subject to other equitable or remedial relief, including removal from their positions. Certain criminal penalties are also provided. 
(Code 1987, § 2-151(19); Ord. No. 05-405, § 19, 11-1-2005) 
Sec. 2-85. - Board of trustees; term of office; vacancies. 
(a)  The term of office of the member-elected trustee shall be three years, one such term of office expiring annually. 
(b)  Each trustee shall, prior to taking office, take an oath of office administered by the city clerk. 
(c)  A vacancy shall occur on the board of trustees if a member-elected trustee: 
(1)  Ceases to be a member; or 
(2)  Becomes employed in the same union represented by one of the other member-elected trustees. 
A vacancy shall occur on the board of trustees if any trustee resigns or is removed from office. with respect to the mayoral appointees, a vacancy shall occur if that person no longer resides in the city, in addition to the foregoing reasons for vacancy occurrence as delineated in this subsection (c). 
(d)  In the event a trustee fails to attend three consecutive meetings, unless excused for cause by the trustees attending the meetings, the board shall provide notice to the trustee's union of the trustees failure to attend scheduled meetings. 
(e)  In the event that there exists a basis for the removal from office of a trustee hereunder, the board shall give such trustee notice of the impending removal action, and an opportunity to respond thereto, at least 48 hours in advance of any such removal action. The board shall also provide such notice to the mayor or to the trustee's union in the appropriate case. 
(f)  In the event: 
(1)  A vacancy occurs in the position of a mayor-appointed trustee (including the human resources director or designee, and the budget and finance director or designee), then the mayor will appoint an individual who meets the necessary qualifications to fill the remainder of the unexpired term, such appointment to occur within 30 days after the vacancy. 
(2)  A vacancy occurs in the position of a member-elected trustee, the member-elected trustee's union shall elect a successor who meets the necessary qualifications to fill the remainder of the unexpired term, and shall notify the board of trustees of the name of the successor in writing, both events to occur within 30 days after the vacancy in the position of the member-elected trustee occurs. 
The board shall fill the vacancy at the regular meeting of the board of trustees which is scheduled to occur immediately following the expiration of the foregoing time periods. 
(Code 1987, § 2-151(20); Ord. No. 05-405, § 20, 11-1-2005) 
Sec. 2-86. - Meetings; quorum; voting; record of proceedings. 
    The board of trustees shall hold meetings regularly, at least one in each calendar quarter, and shall designate the time and place of each meeting. All meetings of the board of trustees shall be public and shall be held subject to the provisions of the Michigan Open Meetings Act, as amended. Notice of the meetings will be posted in the city hall prior to the meeting date. Four trustees shall constitute a quorum at any meeting of the board of trustees. Each trustee shall be entitled to one vote on each question before the board of trustees. At least four concurring votes shall be required for a valid action by the board of trustees. The board of trustees shall adopt its own rules of procedures and shall keep a written record of its proceedings. 
(Code 1987, § 2-151(21); Ord. No. 05-405, § 21, 11-1-2005) 
Sec. 2-87. - Board of trustees; officers; services; compensation. 
(a)  The board of trustees shall elect from its membership a chairperson and a vice-chairperson. The chairperson shall preside over the meetings of the board of trustees. If the chairperson is unable to preside over a meeting, the vice-chairperson shall preside over that meeting. 
(b)  The city treasurer shall be treasurer of the retirement system and custodian of its assets except as to such assets as the board may from time to time otherwise hold, or direct to be held by a third party custodian, as authorized by state law. This shall not prevent the board from appointing a bank or other agent as custodian of any securities. 
(c)  The board of trustees shall appoint as the legal advisor an attorney who is not eligible to participate in the plan as a member, retiree or beneficiary. 
(d)  The board of trustees shall appoint an actuary who shall advise the board of trustees on the actuarial operation of the retirement system. The term "actuary" means a member of the American Academy of Actuaries, or an individual who has demonstrated the educational background necessary to effectively render actuarial advice to the retirement system, and who has at least five years of relevant pension actuarial experience. A partnership or corporation may be designated as actuary if the duties of the actuary are performed by or under the direct supervision of an individual who meets the preceding requirements. 
(e)  The board of trustees is authorized and empowered to employ such professional and other services as it requires for the proper discharge of its responsibilities. 
(f)  Members of the board of trustees shall serve without additional compensation or benefits for their services as trustee, except that member-elected trustees shall suffer no loss in compensation on account of their services as trustees. 
(Code 1987, § 2-151(22); Ord. No. 05-405, § 22, 11-1-2005) 
Sec. 2-88. - Investment of retirement system assets. 
(a)  The board is the trustee of the monies and assets of the retirement system. The board shall have full power and authority to invest and reinvest the monies and assets subject to all terms, conditions, limitations and restrictions imposed by the Michigan Public Employee Retirement System Investment Act (currently Public Act No. 314 of 1965 (MCL 38.1132 et seq.)). Notwithstanding anything therein contained to the contrary, however, the plan assets may not be invested in any type of investment that will provide capital or financing to the city or any of its related entities. 
(b)  The board may employ outside investment counsel to advise the board in the making and disposition of investments. All monies and assets of the retirement system shall be held for the sole purpose of meeting disbursements authorized in accordance with the provisions of this division and shall be used for no other purpose. 
(c)  In exercising its discretionary authority with respect to the management of the monies and assets of the retirement system, the board shall exercise the care, skill, prudence and diligence under the circumstances then prevailing, that a person of prudence, acting in a like capacity and familiar with such matters, would use in the conduct of an enterprise of like character and with like aims. 
(d)  All monies and investments of the retirement system shall be held for the exclusive benefit of the members, retirees and beneficiaries, and for the exclusive purpose of meeting the disbursements for pensions and other payments authorized by this division. 
(e)  Except as otherwise provided in this division, no member of the board of trustees and no employee of the city shall have any interest, direct or indirect, in the gains or profits arising from any investments made by the board. No person, directly or indirectly, whether personally or as an agent or partner of others, shall borrow any monies or investments of the retirement system, or in any manner use the same except to make current and necessary payments as are authorized by the board. 
(Code 1987, § 2-151(23); Ord. No. 05-405, § 23, 11-1-2005) 
Sec. 2-89. - Experience tables and regular interest. 
    The board of trustees shall from time to time adopt such mortality and other tables of experience, and a rate or rates of regular interest as are necessary in the operation of the retirement system on an actuarial basis. 
(Code 1987, § 2-151(24); Ord. No. 05-405, § 24, 11-1-2005) 
Sec. 2-90. - Board of trustees; records; reports. 
(a)  The board of trustees shall keep such records as are required to properly manage and report the operations of the retirement system. The board of trustees shall keep such additional records as are recommended by the actuary as necessary for the operation of the retirement system on an actuarial basis. 
(b)  The board of trustees shall prepare a summary annual report for each fiscal year, as that term is defined in Act 314. The summary annual report shall contain information about the financial and other activities of the retirement system during the fiscal year as Act 314 requires. A copy of the summary annual report and a copy of the most recent actuarial valuation report shall be furnished to the city. Any such report shall be deemed accepted and approved by the city unless protested by written notice to the board of trustees within 90 days of receipt thereof. 
(c)  The board of trustees may inspect the records of the city whenever such inspection may be reasonably necessary in order to determine any fact pertinent to the performance of its duties. The board of trustees, however, shall not be required to make such inspection, but may in good faith rely on any statement of the city or any of its officers. 
(Code 1987, § 2-151(25); Ord. No. 05-405, § 25, 11-1-2005) 
Sec. 2-91. - Payments from the retirement system. 
    All payments from the retirement system shall be made only on checks or vouchers signed by two persons authorized by resolution of the board. A copy of the resolution designating the persons and containing specimen signatures of the persons shall be filed with the city treasurer and the board's designated custodial service provider, as applicable, and shall serve as authorization to make payments upon the vouchers. No checks or vouchers for the retirement system shall be drawn unless previously authorized by a general or specific resolution of the board. 
(Code 1987, § 2-151(26); Ord. No. 05-405, § 26, 11-1-2005) 
Sec. 2-92. - Assignments prohibited; right of set-off. 
(a)  The right of an individual to a pension, to the return of accumulated member contributions, any other right accrued or accruing to any individual under the provisions of this retirement system, and any money belonging to the retirement system shall not be subject to execution, garnishment, attachment, and operation of bankruptcy or insolvency law, or any other process of law whatsoever, and shall be unassignable, except as is otherwise specifically required by state or federal law, or as provided in this division. 
(b)  The right of an individual to a pension, to the return of accumulated member contributions, and any other benefit under the provisions of the retirement ordinance shall be subject to award by a court pursuant to section 18 of chapter 84 of the Revised Statutes of 1846 (MCL 552.18), and to any other order of a court pertaining to child support. 
(c)  If an award or order described in subsection (b) of this section requires the retirement system to withhold payment of a pension, deferred pension, accumulated member contributions, or other benefit from the person to whom it is due, or requires the retirement system to make payment, or requires the person to request that the retirement system make payments of a pension, deferred pension, accumulated member contributions, or other benefit, for the purpose of meeting the person's obligations to a spouse, former spouse or child, as provided in subsection (b) of this section, the withholding or payment provisions of the award or order shall be effective only against such amounts as they become payable to the individual receiving a pension. The limitation contained in this subsection shall not apply to the accumulated member contributions of an individual who has terminated employment prior to acquiring a vested former member status. 
(d)  If an individual is covered under a group insurance or prepayment plan participated in by the city, and makes a permitted election to continue such coverage as a retired member or as a beneficiary, the individual may authorize the board of trustees to deduct from the member's pension payments required to continue coverage under such group insurance or prepayment plan. 
(e)  The retirement system shall have the right of setoff to recover overpayments made by the retirement system and to satisfy any claim arising from embezzlement or fraud committed by a member, retired member, vested former member, beneficiary or other individual having a claim to benefits. 
(Code 1987, § 2-151(27); Ord. No. 05-405, § 27, 11-1-2005) 
Sec. 2-93. - Correction of errors. 
    The board of trustees shall correct errors in the records of the retirement system. The board shall seek to recover any overpayments, and shall make up any underpayments, which have been made. The recovery of overpayments may be accomplished by reducing the amount of future payments so that the actuarial present value of actual payments to the recipient is equal to the actuarial present value of the payments to which the recipient was correctly entitled. 
(Code 1987, § 2-151(28); Ord. No. 05-405, § 28, 11-1-2005) 
Sec. 2-94. - Subrogation. 
    If an individual becomes entitled to a pension payable by the retirement system as the result of an accident or injury caused by the act of a third party, the retirement system shall be subrogated to the rights of the individual against the third party to the extent of benefits which the retirement system pays or becomes liable to pay. 
(Code 1987, § 2-151(29); Ord. No. 05-405, § 29, 11-1-2005) 
Sec. 2-95. - Internal Revenue Service qualification. 
(a)  The retirement system is intended and has been administered to be a qualified pension plan under section 401 of the Internal Revenue Code, as amended (IRC or Code), or successor provisions of law, including: 
(1)  The Tax Reform Act of 1986 (TRA '86); 
(2)  The Technical and Miscellaneous Revenue Act of 1988 (TAMRA); 
(3)  The Unemployment Compensation Amendments of 1992 (UCA); 
(4)  The Omnibus Budget Reconciliation Act of 1993 (OBRA); 
(5)  The Uniformed Service Employment and Reemployment Rights Act of 1994 (USERRA); 
(6)  The Uruguay Round Agreements Act of 1994 (GATT); 
(7)  The Small Business Job Protection Act of 1996 (SBJPA '96); 
(8)  The Taxpayer Relief Act of 1997 (TRA '97); 
(9)  The Internal Revenue Service Restructuring and Reform Act of 1998 (RRA '98); 
(10)  The Economic Growth and Tax Relief Reconciliation Act of 2001 (EGTRRA); and 
(11)  Other applicable laws, regulations and administrative authority. 
The retirement system is a governmental plan under IRC § 414(d) and is administered for the exclusive benefit of the plan's participants (members) and their beneficiaries. The retirement system trust is an exempt organization under IRC § 501. The board of trustees may adopt such additional provisions to the retirement system as are necessary to fulfill this intent. 
(b)  Limitations on benefits and contributions. The amount of annual benefits and contributions credited a member in any given year shall be subject to the following limitations: 
(1)  Defined benefit plans. The maximum permissible annual pension benefit with respect to any member shall be in accordance with IRC § 415(b). 
a.  Special dollar limitations. If the benefit is payable prior to age 62, the dollar limitation shall be reduced to the actuarial equivalent of a benefit commencing at age 62. In the case of any fulltime police or fire employee, who is a qualified participant as defined in IRC § 415(b)(2)(G), there is no reduction in the dollar limitation. If the benefit is not payable until after age 65, the dollar limitation shall be increased to the actuarial equivalent of a benefit commencing at age 65. 
b.  In the case of a member who has less than ten years of participation in the plan, the dollar limitation shall be reduced one-tenth for each year of participation in accordance with IRC § 415(b)(5). 
(2)  Defined contribution plans. 
a.  For limitation years beginning after December 31, 1986, The term "annual addition" means, for purposes of this subsection, the sum, credited to a participant's (member's) account for any limitation year, of: 
1.  Employer contributions; 
2.  Employee contributions; and 
3.  Forfeitures. 
b.  Annual additions that may be contributed or allocated to a participant's (member's) account for a limitation year will not exceed the lesser of: 
1.  100 percent of participant's (member's) compensation, within the meaning of IRC § 415(c)(3); or 
2.  $40,000.00, as adjusted for increases in the cost of living pursuant to IRC § 415(d). 
c.  Valuation of investments. Investments of the plan shall be valued as of the last day of each plan year in accordance with the methods consistently followed and uniformly applied to determine fair market value and in accordance with the requirements of Revenue Ruling 80-155. Contributions to the plan, along with earnings thereon, shall be distributed in accordance with the terms of the plan. 
(3)  Excess benefit payment. The retirement system shall not pay any benefit that would exceed the benefit limitations for governmental plans as set forth in IRC § 415 and regulations, as amended. 
(4)  Compensation. As defined by IRC § 415(c)(3)(D) and Department of Treasury Regulations § 1.415-2(d)(2)(i), compensation means amounts actually paid to the member during the limitation year, including: wages, salary, professional fees, percentage of profits, commissions, tips and bonuses paid or made available to the member during the limitation year for personal services actually rendered in the course of employment, any elective deferral, and any amount which is contributed or deferred by the employer at the election of the member and which is not includible in the gross income of the member by reason of IRC §§ 125, 132(f) or 457. 
(c)  Distributions. 
(1)  Distributions from the retirement system will comply with the requirements of Internal Revenue Code § 401(a)(9) and the regulations thereunder, including requirements regarding the beginning date for distributions and the period over which a member's interest in the retirement system will be distributed. A member's interest in the trust must begin to be distributed by the later of: 
a.  April 1 of the calendar year following the calendar year that the member attains the age of 701/2; or 
b.  April 1 of the calendar year the member retires. 
With respect to distributions under the plan made for calendar years beginning on or after January 1, 2001, the plan will apply the minimum distribution requirements of IRC § 401(a)(9) in accordance with the regulations under IRC § 401(a)(9) that were proposed in January 2001, notwithstanding any provision in the plan to the contrary. This amendment shall continue in effect until the end of the last calendar year beginning before the effective date of final regulations under IRC § 401(a)(9) or such other date as may be specified in guidance published by the Internal Revenue Service. 
(2)  Effective date. The provisions of this subsection (c) will apply for purposes of determining required minimum distributions for calendar years beginning with the 2003 calendar year. 
(3)  Precedence. The requirements of this subsection (c) will take precedence over any inconsistent provisions of the plan. 
(4)  Requirements of Department of Treasury Regulations Incorporated. All distributions required under this subsection (c) shall be determined and made in accordance with the Department of Treasury regulations under section 401(a)(9) of the Internal Revenue Code. 
(5)  TEFRA § 242(b)(2) elections. Notwithstanding the other provisions of this section, other than this subsection (c), distributions may be made under a designation made on or before January 1, 1984, in accordance with section 242(b)(2) of the Tax Equity and Fiscal Responsibility Act (TEFRA) and the provisions of the plan that relate to section 242(b)(2) of TEFRA. 
(6)  Time and manner of distribution. 
a.  Required beginning date. The member's entire interest will be distributed, or begin to be distributed, to the member no later than the member's required beginning date. 
b.  Death of member before distributions begin. If the member dies before distributions begin, the member's entire interest will be distributed, or begin to be distributed, no later than as follows: 
1.  If the member's surviving spouse is the member's sole designated beneficiary, then, except as provided in the plan, distributions to the surviving spouse will begin by December 31 of the calendar year immediately following the calendar year in which the member died, or by December 31 of the calendar year in which the member would have attained age 701/2, if later. 
2.  If the member's surviving spouse is not the member's sole designated beneficiary, then, except as provided in the plan, distributions to the designated beneficiary will begin by December 31 of the calendar year immediately following the calendar year in which the member died. 
3.  If there is no designated beneficiary as of September 30 of the year following the year of the member's death, the member's entire interest will be distributed by December 31 of the calendar year containing the fifth anniversary of the member's death. 
4.  If the member's surviving spouse is the member's sole designated beneficiary and the surviving spouse dies after the member but before distributions to the surviving spouse begin, this subsection (c)(6)b will apply, other than subsection (c)(6)b.1 of this section, as if the surviving spouse were the member. 
For purposes of this subsection (c)(6)b, subsection (c)(8)c of this section and defined in subsection (9) of this section, distributions are considered to begin on the member's required beginning date (or, if subsection (c)(6)b.4 of this section applies, the date distributions are required to begin to the surviving spouse under subsection (c)(6)b.1 of this section). If annuity payments irrevocably commence to the member before the member's required beginning date (or to the member's surviving spouse before the date distributions are required to begin to the surviving spouse under subsection (c)(6)b.1 of this section), the date distributions are considered to begin is the date distributions actually commence. 
c.  Form of distribution. Unless the member's interest is distributed in the form of an annuity purchased from an insurance company or in a single sum on or before the required beginning date, as of the first distribution calendar year distributions will be made in accordance with subsections (c)(8) and (9) of this section. If the member's interest is distributed in the form of an annuity purchased from an insurance company, distributions thereunder will be made in accordance with the requirements of section 401(a)(9) of the IRC and the Department of Treasury regulations. Any part of the member's interest which is in the form of an individual account described in section 414(k) of the IRC will be distributed in a manner satisfying the requirements of section 401(a)(9) of the IRC and the Department of Treasury regulations that apply to individual accounts. 
(7)  Determination of amount to be distributed each year. 
a.  General annuity requirements. If the member's interest is paid in the form of annuity distributions under the plan, payments under the annuity will satisfy the following requirements: 
1.  The annuity distributions will be paid in periodic payments made at intervals not longer than one year; 
2.  The distribution period will be over a life or over a period certain not longer than the period described in subsection (c)(8)c of this section and defined in subsection (c)(9) of this section; 
3.  Once payments have begun over a period certain, the period certain will not be changed even if the period certain is shorter than the maximum permitted. 
b.  Amount required to be distributed by required beginning date. The amount that must be distributed on or before the member's required beginning date or, if the member dies before distributions begin, the date distributions are required to begin under subsection (c)(6)b.1 or 2 of this section is the payment that is required for one payment interval. The second payment need not be made until the end of the next payment interval even if that payment interval ends in the next calendar year. Payment intervals are the periods for which payments are received, e.g., bimonthly, monthly, semi-annually, or annually. All of the member's benefit accruals as of the last day of the first distribution calendar year will be included in the calculation of the amount of the annuity payments for payment intervals ending on or after the member's required beginning date. 
c.  Additional accruals after first distribution calendar year. Any additional benefits accruing to the member in a calendar year after the first distribution calendar year will be distributed beginning with the first payment interval ending in the calendar year immediately following the calendar year in which such amount accrues. 
(8)  Requirements for minimum distributions where member dies before date distributions begin. 
a.  Member survived by designated beneficiary. Except as provided in the adoption agreement, if the member dies before the date distribution of the member's interest begins and there is a designated beneficiary, the member's entire interest will be distributed, beginning no later than the time described in subsection (c)(6)b.1 or 2 of this section, over the life of the designated beneficiary or over a period certain not exceeding: 
1.  Unless the annuity starting date is before the first distribution calendar year, the life expectancy of the designated beneficiary determined using the beneficiary's age as of the beneficiary's birthday in the calendar year immediately following the calendar year of the member's death; or 
2.  If the annuity starting date is before the first distribution calendar year, the life expectancy of the designated beneficiary determined using the beneficiary's age as of the beneficiary's birthday in the calendar year that contains the annuity starting date. 
b.  No designated beneficiary. If the member dies before the date distributions begin and there is no designated beneficiary as of September 30 of the year following the year of the member's death, distribution of the member's entire interest will be completed by December 31 of the calendar year containing the fifth anniversary of the member's death. 
c.  Death of surviving spouse before distributions to surviving spouse begin. If the member dies before the date distribution of the member's interest begins, and the member's surviving spouse is the member's sole designated beneficiary, and the surviving spouse dies before distributions to the surviving spouse begin, this subsection will apply as if the surviving spouse were the member, except that the time by which distributions must begin will be determined without regard to subsection (c)(6)b.1 of this section. 
(9)  Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this subsection (c), shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this subsection (c)(9), except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
a.  Designated beneficiary means the individual who is designated as the beneficiary under the plan and is the designated beneficiary under § 401(a)(9) of the code and section 1.401(a)(9)-1, Q&A-4, of the Department of Treasury regulations. 
b.  Distribution calendar year means a calendar year for which a minimum distribution is required. For distributions beginning before the member's death, the first distribution calendar year is the calendar year immediately preceding the calendar year, which contains the member's required beginning date. For distributions beginning after the member's death, the first distribution calendar year is the calendar year in which distributions are required to begin pursuant to paragraph 6. 
c.  Life expectancy means life expectancy as computed by use of the single life table in section 1.401(a)(9)-9 of the Department of Treasury regulations. 
d.  Required beginning date means the date specified in this subsection. 
(d)  Eligible rollover distributions. This subsection applies to distributions made on or after January 1, 1993. Notwithstanding any provision of the plan to the contrary that would otherwise limit a distributee's election under this subsection, a distributee may elect, at the time and in the manner prescribed by the board, to have any portion of an eligible rollover distribution paid directly to an eligible retirement plan specified by the distributee as a direct rollover. The following definitions shall apply with regard to this subsection: 
(1)  Eligible rollover distribution. An eligible rollover distribution is any distribution of all or any portion of the balance to the credit of the distributee, except that an eligible rollover distribution does not include: any distribution that is one of a series of substantially equal periodic payments (not less frequently than annually) made for the life (or life expectancy) of the distributee or the joint lives (or joint life expectancies) of the distributee and the distributee's designated beneficiary, or for a specified period of ten years or more, and any distribution to the extent such distribution is required under IRC § 401(a)(9). For purposes of the direct rollover provision, a portion of a distribution shall not fail to be an eligible rollover distribution merely because the portion consists of after-tax employee contributions which are not includible in gross income. However, such portion may be paid only to an individual retirement account or annuity described in IRC § 408(a) or (b), or to a qualified plan described in IRC § 401(a) or 403(b) that agrees to separately account for amounts so transferred, including separately accounting for the portion of such distribution which is includible in gross income and the portion of such distribution which is not so includible. 
(2)  Eligible retirement plan. An eligible retirement plan is an individual retirement account described in IRC § 408(a), an individual retirement annuity described in IRC § 408(a), an annuity plan described in IRC § 403(a), an annuity contract described in IRC § 403(b), an eligible plan under IRC § 457 which is maintained by a state, political subdivision of a state and which agrees to separately account for amounts transferred into such plan or a qualified trust described in IRC § 401(a), that accepts the distributee's eligible rollover distribution. The definition of eligible retirement plan shall also apply in the case of a distribution to a surviving spouse or to a spouse or former spouse who is the alternate payee under a domestic relations order. 
(3)  Distributee. A distributee includes a member or former member. In addition, the member's or former member's surviving spouse is a distributee with regard to the interest of the surviving spouse. 
(4)  Direct rollover. A direct rollover is a payment by the retirement system to the eligible retirement plan specified by the distributee. 
(e)  Maximum annual earnings. For plan years beginning on or after January 1, 1989, and before July 1, 1996, the annual compensation of each participant (member) taken into account for determining all benefits provided under the plan for any determination period shall not include any amounts in excess of the annual compensation limit provided for in IRC § 401(a)(17) prior to the Omnibus Budget Reconciliation Act of 1993 ("OBRA '93") and adjusted for inflation in the manner provided by IRC § 401(a)(17). For plan years beginning on or after July 1, 1996, the annual compensation of each member taken into account shall not exceed the annual compensation limit provided for in IRC § 401(a)(17), as amended by the Omnibus Budget Reconciliation Act of 1993 ("OBRA '93"). This limit may be adjusted as required by federal law for qualified government plans and shall be further adjusted for inflation in the manner provided by IRC § 401(a)(17). Annual compensation means compensation during the plan year or such other consecutive 12-month period over which compensation is otherwise determined under the plan. The cost-of-living adjustment in effect for a calendar year applies to annual compensation for the determination period that begins with or within such calendar year. 
(f)  Actuarial assumptions. Actuarial equivalence will be determined on the basis of the interest rate and mortality tables adopted by the board. Actuarial assumptions that will be used to determine the amount or level of any optional benefit forms will be the actuarial equivalent of the normal retirement benefit. Optional benefits provided under the plan shall be actuarially adjusted in relation to the straight life annuity option. For purposes determining the IRC § 415 limitations, the interest rate assumption will not be less than the greater of five percent or the rate specified in the plan for determining actuarial equivalence for the particular form of retirement benefit. The actuarial early retirement reduction and reduction of the dollar limit if the member has less than ten years of participation under IRC § 415 do not apply to income received as a pension or annuity as a result of a member's personal injury, sickness or death and shall be administered in accordance with IRC § 415(b)(2), as amended. 
(g)  Forfeitures. Upon a member's separation of employment, the value of any forfeitable accrued benefit shall be forfeited by the member as of the member's last date of employment. The value of such forfeitures shall be used to reduce the employer's future contributions under the plan in accordance with IRC § 401(a)(8). No forfeitures under the plan shall be applied to increase the benefits that any member or beneficiary would otherwise receive at any time prior to the time when the plan may be terminated. If a member whose employment has terminated does not retain a vested benefit under the plan, they shall no longer be a member or retain or earn credited service under the plan unless and until they again become an employee. 
(h)  Military service. Notwithstanding any provision of the plan to the contrary, contributions, benefits and credited service with respect to qualified military service will be provided in accordance with IRC § 414(u) and regulations. 
(i)  Forfeitability of accrued benefits. A member's right to their normal retirement benefit is nonforfeitable on the attainment of their normal retirement age as defined in IRC § 411(d)(3) and as defined and protected by article IX, section 24 of the state Constitution. In the event of termination or partial termination of the plan, a member's interest is nonforfeitable to the extent funded in conformity with applicable sections of this Code and any regulations. 
(j)  Prohibition against reversion. The retirement system and trust have been created for the exclusive benefit of the members and beneficiaries as set forth herein. The funds thereof have been established for the benefit of the members and for the operation of the retirement system. No part of the principal and income of any of the funds of the system and trust shall revert to or be returned to the city prior to the satisfaction of all liabilities hereunder to all members, beneficiaries and anyone claiming by or through them. 
(k)  Vesting. A member shall be 100 percent vested in their accrued benefit when they attain normal retirement age in accordance with IRC § 411(e) as in effect in 1974. 
(l)  Actuarial reports. Annually, or more frequently, the board shall obtain actuarial computations from an enrolled actuary as to the contributions necessary to fund the benefits provided by the plan on a reasonable basis in accordance with any applicable regulations, and such actuary shall certify such amounts to the employer. Contributions accumulated under the plan, along with the earnings thereon, will be distributed in accordance with the terms of the plan. 
(m)  Assignment of benefits. None of the benefits, payments, proceeds, claims, or rights of any participant (member) or their beneficiary hereunder shall be subject to execution, garnishment, attachment, the operation of bankruptcy or insolvency law, or other process of law, nor shall any participant (member) or beneficiary have any right to transfer, assign, encumber, or otherwise alienate, any of the benefits or proceeds which the participant (member) may expect to receive, contingently or otherwise under the plan, except as provided under a domestic relations order. 
(Code 1987, § 2-151(30); Ord. No. 05-405, § 30, 11-1-2005) 
Sec. 2-96. - Accrued rights not impaired. 
    In no case shall the accrued rights of any member, retiree, or beneficiary be impaired or diminished by the provisions of this division. 
(Code 1987, § 2-151(31); Ord. No. 05-405, § 31, 11-1-2005) 
Sec. 2-97. - Mandatory bargaining subjects. 
    Notwithstanding any other provisions of this division, any matter relating to the retirement system provided by this division applicable to current members represented by a collective bargaining agent is a mandatory subject of bargaining under the Public Employment Relations Act, Public Act No. 336 of 1947 (MCL 423.201 et seq.). 
(Code 1987, § 2-151(32); Ord. No. 05-405, § 32, 11-1-2005) 
Sec. 2-98. - Fraud penalty. 
    Whoever with intent to deceive shall make any statement or report under this division which is untrue, or shall falsify or permit to be falsified any record or records of the retirement system, or who shall otherwise violate the provisions of this division as it may from time to time be amended, with intent to deceive, shall be guilty of a misdemeanor. 
(Code 1987, § 2-151(33); Ord. No. 05-405, § 33, 11-1-2005) 
Sec. 2-99. - Severability. 
    If any section or part of a section of this division is for any reason held to be invalid or unconstitutional, such holding shall not be construed as affecting the validity of the remaining sections of this division or this division in its entirety. All ordinances, resolutions or other provisions of law inconsistent with the provisions of this division (excepting any current collective bargaining agreement) are hereby repealed to the extent of such inconsistency. To the extent that any provision of this division is inconsistent with any provision of any current collective bargaining agreement, such collective bargaining agreement provision shall prevail and control. 
(Code 1987, § 2-151(34); Ord. No. 05-405, § 34, 11-1-2005) 
Secs. 2-100-2-126. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - STANDARDS OF CONDUCT[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
State Law reference- Standards of conduct and ethics, MCL 15.341 et seq.; conflicts of interests as to contracts, MCL 15.321 et seq.; political activities by public employees, MCL 15.401 et seq. 

Sec. 2-127. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this division, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    City official or employee means a person elected, appointed or employed, or otherwise serving in any capacity involving the exercise of a public power or trust. 
    Conflict of interest means either a personal interest or a duty or loyalty to a third party that competes with or is adverse to a city official's or employee's duty to the public interest in the exercise of official duties or official actions. 
    Frivolous complaint means a complaint where it is determined that at least one of the following conditions are met: 
(1)  The primary purpose of initiating the complaint was to harass, embarrass, or injure; or 
(2)  There was no reasonable basis to believe that the facts alleged by the complainant were in fact true. 
    Gift means anything of true value which is given to a public official or city employee without payment of fair market value. 
    Immediate family means a spouse, child, parent, sister or brother wherever residing, any relative sharing the same household, or a spouse of any of the above mentioned. 
    Official duties or official actions means decisions, recommendations, approvals, disapprovals or other actions which involve the use of discretionary authority. 
(Code 1987, § 2-171; Ord. No. 07-423, § 1, 8-7-2007) 
Sec. 2-128. - Conflict of interest. 
(a)  No city official or employee shall engage in employment, render services or engage in any business, transaction or activity which is in direct conflict of interest with the city official's or employee's official duties, No city official or employee may use any confidential information obtained in the exercise of the city official's or employee's official duties for personal gain or for the gain of others. 
(b)  No city official or employee shall intentionally take or refrain from taking any official action, or induce or attempt to induce any other city official or employee to take or refrain from taking any official action, on any matter before the city which would result in a financial benefit for the city official or employee, a close business or political associate, an immediate family member, an outside employer, any business in which the city official or employee (or any immediate family member of the city official or employee) has a financial interest except as allowed in sections 4.11 and 5.11 of the city Charter. 
(c)  Any city official or employee who is a member of a decision making or advising body shall disclose any conflict of interest to the city clerk and the chair and other members of that decision making body. In the case of an employee, the disclosure must be made to the employee's immediate supervisor. See also MCL 15.342b. 
(Code 1987, § 2-172; Ord. No. 07-423, § 2, 8-7-2007) 
Sec. 2-129. - Prohibited conduct. 
(a)  Gifts. A city official or employee shall not, directly or indirectly, solicit or accept any gifts, favors, gratuities or special consideration in any calendar year, with a total value of more than $150.00 from any one company, business or entity, currently doing business with the city, (or seeking to do business with the city), or who is currently negotiating to do business with the city, or who otherwise is seeking any action or approval by the city, unless specifically allowed by city policy. A city official or employee may not solicit or accept, without reimbursement to the provider, any of the following: meals, sporting event tickets, social amenities, or attendance at any event from any person, organization or entity that does business or is seeking to do business with the city with a total value of more than $150.00. By way of example, and not by limitation, a city official or employee could accept sporting event tickets with a value of $140.00 from vendor A in a calendar year and $120.00 from vendor B in a calendar year and not be in violation of this provision. This provision shall not apply to solicitations for charities or political fundraising done in compliance with the Michigan Campaign Finance Act, MCL 169.252. Exceptions are as follows: 
(1)  Free attendance at charity, political, or officially-related widely attended events. 
(2)  Anything paid for by federal, state, or local government. 
(b)  Noncity business on city time. City officials and employees are to conduct only city business and may not conduct work for another employer during their usual and normal work hours with the city. 
(c)  Loans. A city official or employee shall not use the city official's or employee's official position to accept loans of either a personal or business nature from anyone other than a commercial lender at prevailing market rates. 
(d)  Preferential treatment. A city official or employee shall not use the city official's or employee's official position to unreasonably secure, request or grant, any privileges, exemptions, advantages, contracts, or preferential treatment for the city official or employee or others from the city or any business, individual or other third party. 
(e)  Use of information. A city official or employee who acquires information in the course of the city official's or employee's official duties, which by law or policy is confidential, shall not divulge that information to an unauthorized person nor use the information to further the private interest of the city official or employee or any third-party information which is deemed exempt from disclosure under the Freedom of Information Act, Public Act No. 442 of 1976 (MCL 15.231 et seq.), or which is the subject of a duly called closed meeting held in accordance with the Open Meetings Act, Public Act No. 267 of 1976 (MCL 15.261 et seq.). 
(Code 1987, § 2-173; Ord. No. 07-423, § 3, 8-7-2007) 
Sec. 2-130. - Primacy of collective bargaining agreements. 
    Nothing in this chapter shall be read or implied to supersede any provisions of any collective bargaining agreement in effect on the effective date of the ordinance codified in this division. 
(Code 1987, § 2-174; Ord. No. 07-423, § 4, 8-7-2007) 
Sec. 2-131. - Board of ethics. 
(a)  Created. There is hereby created an independent body called the board of ethics. 
(b)  Objectives. The objectives of the board of ethics is to enforce and administer the standards of conduct set out in this division and maintain the public confidence in the integrity of its elected and appointed officials. 
(c)  Board membership; terms; quorum; meetings; rules. 
(1)  The board of ethics shall consist of five members, appointed by the mayor with the advice and unanimous consent of the city council. Current city officials or employees shall not be eligible for appointment to the board.
