The processing fee shall be waived for charitable and nonprofit organizations which qualify under section 501(c) (3) of the United States Internal Revenue Code. The processing fee is nonrefundable. 
b.  A daily property use fee in an amount established by resolution of the city council to compensate the city for the use of public property and its unavailability for ordinary and usual purposes resulting from the filming activity. 
c.  A monitoring fee to reimburse the city for staff time required to monitor the filming activity, and for reasonable costs for other city services or equipment approved for use during such activities, in an amount as determined at the time of the city's review of permit application. 
d.  The processing fee and the property use fee shall be waived for the following: 
1.  Productions conducted by a cable television company operating under a franchise granted by the city which are not conducted on public property, do not interfere with public rights-of-way, and which involve fewer than two motor vehicles; 
2.  Productions for wholly charitable or educational purposes and from which no profit is derived, either directly or indirectly; and 
3.  Student filming: productions directed or produced by a person currently enrolled in courses related to the production. 
(Ord. No. 10-449, § 1(4-137), 4-6-2010) 
Sec. 4-184. - Accompanying plans. 
    Each application for a permit required by this article shall be accompanied by a detailed explanation, including drawings and diagrams where applicable, of the prospective permittee's plans to provide for the following: 
(1)  The size or area of the property to be used, including a sketch of the filming site showing placement of work trucks, location of production vehicles; 
(2)  A sketch of the "base camp," if any, showing any off-street location for crew parking, honey wagon, catering, and nonessential production vehicles; 
(3)  Traffic control plan of the exact filming location, listing roads or lanes to be closed, if any; 
(4)  A description of the duration of the proposed activity and daily hours of operation; 
(5)  Facilities for cleanup and waste disposal; 
(6)  A letter of notification and signatures from businesses/neighborhoods impacted by filming if required by the city; and 
(7)  Insurance and bonding arrangements. 
(Ord. No. 10-449, § 1(4-138), 4-6-2010) 
Sec. 4-185. - Investigation of application. 
    Upon receipt by the city, copies of the application for a permit required by this article shall be forwarded to the appropriate city departments, and to such other appropriate city officials as deemed necessary. 
(Ord. No. 10-449, § 1(4-139), 4-6-2010) 
Sec. 4-186. - Permit issuance requirements. 
    In processing an application for a production filming permit required by the article the city shall, at a minimum, require the following: 
(1)  Security personnel. The permittee shall employ at the permittee's own expense such security personnel as are necessary and sufficient to provide for the adequate security and protection of the maximum number of attendants at the location of the filming activity and for the preservation of order and protection of property in and around the site of the filming activity. No permit shall be issued unless the police chief or designee is satisfied that such necessary and sufficient security personnel will be provided by the permittee for the duration of the production filming. 
(2)  Notification. The permittee or designee shall notify affected residents, occupants and businesses, in advance of filming, and as instructed by the city, of the duration and location of filming activities, including information about planned special effects, road and lane closures, "no parking" requests, sidewalk usage and the time that any barricades will be placed on the street and/or sidewalk. 
(3)  Access. Production vehicles may not block parking lot access drives, fire hydrants, or be parked in fire lanes, and must allow a minimum of 20 feet of clearance between vehicles parked on either side of the road for emergency response vehicles to pass. 
(4)  Base camps. Base camps may not be located on a public street unless approved in writing by the city or the police chief or designee. Only the necessary production vehicles (i.e., grip and light trucks) may be parked on a public street, if necessary, at the filming location. Crew parking, honey wagon, catering and other nonessential production vehicles shall be at a predetermined location. 
(5)  Insurance. As a condition of issuing a permit under the article, the permittee shall furnish insurance in an amount to be determined by the city but in no event in an amount less than $1,000,000.00 to protect the city against claims of third persons for personal injury, wrongful death and property damage and to indemnify the city for damage to the city property arising out of the permittee's activities. An additional minimum of $5,000,000.00 of such general liability insurance coverage shall be required in the event motor vehicles, aircraft, helicopters, explosives or pyrotechnics are used in the activity. Such insurance shall be evidenced by the standard general special endorsement for or the certificate of insurance (public liability) form provided by the city. The applicant shall also submit verification that adequate worker's compensation insurance coverage is maintained. 
(6)  Fire protection. The permittee shall at the permittee's own expense take adequate steps as determined by the fire chief to ensure fire protection. 
(7)  Hold harmless agreement. The permittee shall execute a hold harmless agreement as provided by the city prior to the issuance of any permit. 
(8)  Other conditions. Prior to the issuance of a permit, the city may impose any other conditions reasonably calculated to ensure compliance with the requirements of this section and to protect the health, safety, welfare and property of attendants or of citizens of the city, including a limitation on the duration of the permit and the location of activities thereunder. 
(Ord. No. 10-449, § 1(4-140), 4-6-2010) 
Sec. 4-187. - Findings. 
    In processing an application for a permit required by this article, the city shall issue a permit as provided for in this chapter when, from a consideration of the application and from such other information as may be otherwise obtained, the city finds that: 
(1)  The conduct of such activity will not unduly interfere with the use and enjoyment of neighboring property or unduly interfere with traffic or pedestrian movement or endanger public safety and that no streets will be completely closed to traffic for an unreasonable period of time. Adequate advance notice of any street closure shall be given. 
(2)  The conduct of such activity will not unduly interfere with normal governmental or city operations, threaten to result in damage or detriment to public property, or result in the city incurring costs or expenditures in either money or personnel not reimbursed in advance by the applicant. 
(3)  The activity does not propose to include obscene matter or an obscene performance and will not involve conduct in violation of state, local, or federal laws, rules, or regulations, including Public Act No. 343 of 1984 (MCL 752.361 et seq.). 
(4)  At the determination of the city that the condition of such activity will not constitute a fire hazard or any other type of hazard and all property safety precautions will be taken as determined by the heads of the applicable departments or their designees. 
(5)  The permit shall not authorize the production of a film that in any manner requires the use of property owned by or under the control of the city in violation of Public Act No. 84 of 2008 (MCL 123.1191 et seq.), prohibiting the production of a film that includes obscene matter or an obscene performance or that requires that individually identifiable records be created and maintained for every performer provided in 18 USC 2557. The city reserves the right to review all proposed scripts for any production filming activities. The decision of the city to issue, conditionally issue, or deny a permit shall be final unless appealed in writing within five working days of the decision by requesting a hearing before the city council at the next available meeting. Where conditions are imposed as prerequisite to the issuance of a permit and where a permit is denied, notice thereof shall be mailed to the applicant by certified mail within five days of such action. In the case of a permit denial, the reasons therefor shall be stated in the notice. 
(Ord. No. 10-449, § 1(4-141), 4-6-2010) 
Sec. 4-188. - Grounds for denial. 
    A filming permit, required by this article, may be denied if: 
(1)  The applicant fails to comply with any or all requirements of this article, or with any or all conditions imposed pursuant to this article, or with any other applicable provision of state, local or federal laws, rules or regulations; 
(2)  The applicant has knowingly made a false, misleading or fraudulent statement in the application or in any supporting document. 
(Ord. No. 10-449, § 1(4-142), 4-6-2010) 
Sec. 4-189. - Contents; posting; transferability. 
(a)  A permit required by this article shall specify: 
(1)  The name and address of the permittee; 
(2)  The kind and location of the filming activity; 
(3)  The maximum number of attendants permissible; 
(4)  The duration of the permit and any other conditions imposed pursuant to this article. 
(b)  The permit shall be posted in a conspicuous place upon the premises of the filming activity, and shall not be transferred to any other person or location. 
(Ord. No. 10-449, § 1(4-143), 4-6-2010) 
Sec. 4-190. - Revocation of permit. 
(a)  The city may revoke a permit issued pursuant to this article whenever the permittee, employee or agent fails, neglects or refuses to fully comply with any and all provisions and requirements set forth in this article, including the conditions imposed upon issuance of the permit, or with any and all provisions, regulations, ordinances, statutes or other law incorporated by reference in this article. 
(b)  A permit shall automatically be revoked if riotous, disorderly, obscene or otherwise unlawful conduct occurs at a filming location or if an assemblage exceeds 125 percent of the estimated attendance, as indicated on the application for a permit. In such instances the premises may be closed by the police department or fire department and the assembly disbursed. 
(Ord. No. 10-449, § 1(4-144), 4-6-2010) 
Sec. 4-191. - Cost of additional services. 
    If deemed necessary by the city, additional police, code enforcement, fire, and other city services shall be provided for the purpose of protecting, assisting and regulating the proposed activity. The estimated cost of providing such additional services shall be paid in advance to the city by the applicant. Any additional city services will be provided/coordinated through the city. 
(Ord. No. 10-449, § 1(4-145), 4-6-2010) 
Sec. 4-192. - Cleanup and restoration. 
    The applicant shall conduct operations in an orderly fashion with continuous attention to the storage of equipment not in use, maintenance of the area, and the cleanup of trash and debris. The area used shall be cleaned of trash and debris within two hours of the completion of the activity or within such other time established in the permit to the city's satisfaction. The applicant shall be responsible for restoring any area damaged or disrupted before leaving the site. If the site is not repaired or restored to the city's satisfaction, the city shall have the necessary restoration and/or repairs performed and the applicant shall reimburse the city for such work within ten days of completing filming. In the event the applicant fails to so reimburse the city, the city may secure its reimbursement from either a cash or surety bond which shall be posted with the city to ensure faithful performance of such restoration. Such faithful performance bond shall be filed at the time of the application in the amount of $500.00 or in any higher amount determined by the city to be reasonably required under the circumstances. The amount of the bond shall in no way limit the applicant's liability or responsibility for the cost of repairs or restoration in the event these costs exceed the bond amount. 
(Ord. No. 10-449, § 1(4-146), 4-6-2010) 
Chapter 6 - ANIMALS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference- Authority to adopt animal control ordinance, MCL 287.290; dog law, MCL 287.261 et seq.; crimes related to animals and birds, MCL 750.49 et seq.; wildlife conservation, MCL 324.40101 et seq.; endangered species protection, MCL 324.36501 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 6-1. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Animal means any live beings of the Kingdom Animalia, other than humans. 
    Board kennel means any lot, premises or establishment of an owner who keeps, grooms, cares for, trains, breeds, handles, maintains, boards or sells four or more domestic animals, four months or older, for profit or as a business. 
    Department of public works representative (DPW), for purposes of this chapter, means any person authorized by the director of the department of public works including the DPW director and the animal control officer to enforce this chapter. 
    Domestic animal means an animal that has traditionally, through a long association with humans, lived in a state of dependence upon humans and have been traditionally kept as household pets; such as dogs, cats, hamsters, gerbils, mice, nonbreeding (under human control) rabbits, parakeets, parrots, canaries, love birds, finches, noncarnivorous fish, nonpoisonous and nonconstricting reptiles under three feet in length, nonpoisonous amphibians and nonpoisonous spiders. 
    Farm means the land, plants, animals, buildings, structures, including ponds used for agricultural or aquacultural activities, machinery, equipment, and other appurtenances used in the commercial production of farm products. 
    Farm animal or livestock. 
(1)  The term "farm animal" or "livestock" means horses, ponies, jackasses, equine, cattle, sheep, goats, and other domestic animals normally kept or raised on a farm. 
(2)  The term "farm animal" or "livestock" does not include wild, vicious or exotic animals. 
    Fowl means any domesticated farm animal such as a chicken, pigeon, rooster, goose, duck, guinea hen or turkey. 
    Individual dog or cat license. 
(1)  The term "individual dog or cat license" means the license of one or several dogs or cats as required by this chapter. 
(2)  The term "individual dog or cat license" does not include the licensing of dogs or cats under a kennel license. 
    Kennel, private, means any lot, premises or establishment by an owner where four or more domestic animals age four months or older are harbored, housed, bred, raised or trained for hobby, sporting activity, breeding, and not for profit. Aquarium fish and caged domestic birds are exempt. Private kennels are subject to the health and sanitation provisions of the city and shall not become a nuisance. 
    Owner, when applied to the proprietorship of a domestic animal, includes and pertains to every person having a right or property in such animal, and every person who keeps or harbors such animal or has it in the owner's care, and every person who permits such an animal to remain on or about any premises occupied by the owner. 
    Police officer, for purposes of this chapter, means any person employed or elected by the state, the city or the county, whose duty it is to preserve peace or make arrests or to enforce the law, and includes the animal control officer working in and through the police department. 
    Running at large constitutes the status of any animal not on a leash or confined in some other manner. 
    Vicious animal means any animal that attacks, bites, scratches or injures human beings or animals without adequate provocation, or which because of temperament, conditioning, or training, has a known propensity to attack, bite or injure human beings or animals. 
    Wild or exotic animal means any animal not domesticated and being incapable by its nature of being domesticated and is normally found in the wild, including, but not limited to: alligators, badgers, bears, beavers, bobcats, chinchilla, chipmunks, cougars, coyotes, crows, deer, doves, dog-wolves, eagles, elk, ferrets, foxes, gophers, grouse, hares, hawks, jaguars, kangaroos, lions, lynx, mink, muskrats, opossums, owls, partridges, peacocks, pheasants, porcupines, prairie dogs, quails, raccoons, skunks, squirrels, tigers, weasels, wild turkeys, wolverines, wolves and woodchucks, wild hybrids or the offspring of any animals that have been bred to a wild animal. Poisonous, predatory animals, and endangered species are included as well. 
(Code 1987, § 5-1; Ord. No. 75-52, § 1, 2-11-1975; Ord. No. 87-165, § 1, 2-3-1987; Ord. No. 88-196, 9-6-1988; Ord. No. 94-270, 10-4-1994) 
Sec. 6-2. - Compliance with chapter required. 
(a)  No wild or exotic animals, fowl, farm animals or livestock are permitted in a kennel, household or otherwise. 
(b)  Domestic animals, dogs, cats, and nonbreeding rabbits, respectively, are limited to a total of three animals age four months or older per household. 
(c)  No animal shall be kept or harbored within the city, nor shall any kennel be maintained or operated within the city, except in compliance with the provisions of this chapter and all other ordinances of the city applicable thereto. No person shall keep or harbor any animal within the city except in compliance with this chapter and all other applicable ordinances thereto. 
(Code 1987, § 5-2; Ord. No. 75-52, § 7, 2-11-1975; Ord. No. 87-165, § 7, 2-3-1987; Ord. No. 88-196, 9-6-1988; Ord. No. 94-270, 10-4-1994) 
Sec. 6-3. - Noncompliance with chapter declared nuisance. 
(a)  Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this section, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this subsection, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Animal nuisance means a nuisance created when an animal: 
(1)  Runs uncontrolled; 
(2)  Molests or disturbs persons or vehicles by chasing, barking or biting; 
(3)  Attacks other animals; 
(4)  Damages property other than that of the owner or harborer; 
(5)  Barks, whines, howls, honks, brays, cries, meows or makes other noises excessively; 
(6)  Creates noxious or offensive odors; 
(7)  With the exception of leader, guide and service dogs, defecates upon any public place or upon premises not owned or controlled by the owner or harborer unless promptly removed by the animal owner or harborer; or 
(8)  Creates an insect breeding and/or attraction site due to an accumulation of excreta. 
(b)  Noncompliance declared nuisance. Any keeping or harboring of any animal contrary to the provisions of this chapter or any maintenance or operation of a kennel contrary to such provisions is hereby declared to be a nuisance per se. 
(Code 1987, § 5-3; Ord. No. 75-52, § 7, 2-11-1975; Ord. No. 87-165, § 7, 2-3-1987; Ord. No. 88-196, 9-6-1988; Ord. No. 94-270, 10-4-1994) 
Sec. 6-4. - Enforcement and administration. 
    The provisions of this chapter, and the rules and regulations adopted pursuant to this chapter, shall be administered and enforced by the director of the department of public works, the animal control officer(s) and/or the Taylor Police Department. 
(Code 1987, § 5-4; Ord. No. 75-52, § 7, 2-11-1975; Ord. No. 87-165, § 7, 2-3-1987; Ord. No. 88-196, 9-6-1988; Ord. No. 94-270, 10-4-1994; Ord. No. 2014-486, § 1, 12-2-2014) 
Sec. 6-5. - Finances. 
    All expenses incurred in the construction, repair, maintenance and operation of the animal shelter and in the administration and enforcement of this chapter, shall be paid from the general fund of the city. All fees, charges, receipts and revenues, created or provided for by this chapter, shall be paid into the general fund. 
(Code 1987, § 5-5; Ord. No. 75-52, § 7, 2-11-1975; Ord. No. 87-165, § 7, 2-3-1987; Ord. No. 88-196, 9-6-1988; Ord. No. 94-270, 10-4-1994) 
Sec. 6-6. - Cruelty. 
    No person within the city shall treat any animal in a cruel or inhumane manner. No person within the city, owning, keeping or harboring any animal in a kennel or otherwise, shall willfully or negligently cause or permit such animal to suffer torture or unnecessary pain. 
(Code 1987, § 5-6; Ord. No. 75-52, § 7, 2-11-1975; Ord. No. 87-165, § 7, 2-3-1987; Ord. No. 88-196, 9-6-1988; Ord. No. 94-270, 10-4-1994) 
State Law reference- Cruelty to animals, MCL 750.50. 
Sec. 6-7. - Sanitary keeping of animals. 
    No animal shall be kept or harbored, nor shall any kennel be maintained or operated in any unclean, unsanitary or unsightly manner, or in such manner as to cause unpleasant or obnoxious odors, or in such manner as to constitute a menace to the public health, safety and welfare. A person who violates this section shall be responsible for a municipal civil infraction. 
(Code 1987, § 5-7; Ord. No. 75-52, § 7, 2-11-1975; Ord. No. 87-165, § 7, 2-3-1987; Ord. No. 88-196, 9-6-1988; Ord. No. 94-270, 10-4-1994; Ord. No. 06-415, § 6, 10-3-2006) 
Sec. 6-8. - Noise. 
    No person within the city shall keep or harbor any animal in a kennel or otherwise which by loud, frequent or habitual barking, howling, growling, yelping, baying, whining, or other noise, shall cause a serious annoyance to the neighborhood or to people passing to and fro upon the streets, or shall disturb the public peace, or shall constitute a menace to the public health, safety and welfare. A person who violates this section shall be responsible for a municipal civil infraction and subject to all of the provisions, remedies and sanctions set forth in section 1-13 of the Taylor Code of Ordinances. 
(Code 1987, § 5-8; Ord. No. 75-52, § 7, 2-11-1975; Ord. No. 87-165, § 7, 2-3-1987; Ord. No. 88-196, 9-6-1988; Ord. No. 94-270, 10-4-1994; Ord. No. 2014-486, § 2, 12-2-2014) 
Sec. 6-9. - Damages by animals. 
    All persons owning animals shall be liable for damages for any and all injuries to persons or property that may be caused by their animals, which damages may be determined and collected in appropriate civil proceedings therefor, in which proceedings, the proof of the failure or refusal by such owner to comply with the provisions of this chapter shall constitute prima facie evidence of negligence on the part of such owners. 
(Code 1987, § 5-9; Ord. No. 75-52, § 7, 2-11-1975; Ord. No. 87-165, § 7, 2-3-1987; Ord. No. 88-196, 9-6-1988; Ord. No. 94-270, 10-4-1994) 
State Law reference- Common law liability for dogs, MCL 287.288. 
Sec. 6-10. - Running at large. 
    It shall be unlawful for the owner of any animal to allow the animal to be found running at large, or outside of any fenced-in or secured area except on leash and under physical control. A person who violates this section shall be responsible for a municipal civil infraction and subject to all of the provisions, remedies and sanctions set forth in section 1-13 of the Taylor Code of Ordinances. 
(Code 1987, § 5-10; Ord. No. 87-165, § 7, 2-3-1987; Ord. No. 88-196, 9-6-1988; Ord. No. 94-270, 10-4-1994; Ord. No. 2014-486, § 3, 12-2-2014) 
Sec. 6-11. - Sick, diseased or dead animals. 
(a)  If the animal control officer has impounded or received an injured animal whose prospects for recovery are poor, and the animal's suffering can not be relieved, the animal may euthanize animal immediately. (Euthanasia is a service provided to pet owners for a service fee amount as prescribed by resolution of the city council.) If an animal is impounded or received with a suspected contagious or life-threatening disease, a veterinarian will be consulted to determine disposition of the animal. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person within the city to deposit, throw or place any dead or fatally sick or injured animal or part thereof on any public or private place, or into or on the bank of any stream, lake, pond, sewer or other body of water; provided, however, that this section shall not apply to any animal burial ground or other facility which is designated and/or licensed for the burial or disposal of animals or animal parts and is being operated in accordance with the rules and regulations pertaining thereto. 
(Code 1987, § 5-11; Ord. No. 75-52, § 7, 2-11-1975; Ord. No. 87-165, § 7, 2-3-1987; Ord. No. 87-167, § 7, 3-17-1987; Ord. No. 88-196, 9-6-1988; Ord. No. 94-270, 10-4-1994) 
Sec. 6-12. - Bites by animals. 
(a)  Report to police department or animal control officer. If any person is bitten by an animal, it shall be the duty of that person, or the owner or custodian of the animal having knowledge of the incident, to report the incident to the police department or animal control officer within 12 hours thereafter. If the owner or custodian of any animal has any reason to believe or suspect that such animal has been exposed to rabies, it shall be the duty of that person to report the same to the police department or to the animal control officer within 12 hours thereafter. 
(b)  Quarantine. In the event of any report as required by subsection (a) of this section, the police department or animal control officer or animal shelter wardens shall take such animal into its possession and deliver it to the animal shelter. The animal shelter shall promulgate and adopt rules as it deems necessary for the procedure in all such cases and for the disposition of any animal delivered into its custody. Veterinary clinic or in-home quarantine is acceptable only if the animal is licensed and has current vaccinations (this policy is limited to the discretion of the animal control officer) and is to be under the observation of a veterinarian, for a period of ten days. 
(Code 1987, § 5-12; Ord. No. 75-52, § 7, 2-11-1975; Ord. No. 87-165, § 7, 2-3-1987; Ord. No. 88-196, 9-6-1988; Ord. No. 94-270, 10-4-1994) 
State Law reference- Rules for control of rabies and the disposition of nonhuman agents carrying disease, including rabid animals, MCL 333.5111; dogs attacking or biting persons, MCL 287.286a, 287.288, 287.351. 
Sec. 6-13. - Rabies. 
(a)  If an animal has been exposed to rabies or has been bitten by an animal suspected of having rabies, such animal shall be confined by a leash or chain on the owner's premises and shall be placed under the observation of a veterinarian at the expense of the owner for a period of ten days. The owner shall notify the animal control officer of the fact that the animal has been exposed to rabies and at animal control officer's discretion, the animal control officer is empowered to have the animal removed from the owner's premises to a veterinary hospital and there placed under observation for a period of ten days at the expense of the owner; or, the animal control officer may impound the animal in the animal shelter for a period of ten days at the expense of the owner, at a charge prescribed by resolution of city council. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person within the city knowing or suspecting an animal has rabies to allow the animal to be taken off the person's premises or beyond the limits of the city without the written permission of the animal control officer. 
(c)  Any person suspecting an animal to be rabid shall immediately notify the animal control officer or a police officer to observe the animal and take reasonable action to protect the public health and safety up to and including summarily destroying the animal if it poses an immediate danger to any person or animal. 
(Code 1987, § 5-13; Ord. No. 75-52, § 7, 2-11-1975; Ord. No. 87-165, § 7, 2-3-1987; Ord. No. 88-196, 9-6-1988; Ord. No. 94-270, 10-4-1994) 
State Law reference- Rules for control of rabies and the disposition of nonhuman agents carrying disease, including rabid animals, MCL 333.5111. 
Sec. 6-14. - Tethering. 
(a)  Definition of tethering. 
Tethering means the practice of securing a dog to a stationary object by means of a metal chain or coated steel cable, rope or any other material used for keeping a dog restrained. Tethering does not mean walking a dog on a leash, or for temporary grooming, or other professional service. 
(b)  Tethering. 
(1)  It shall be unlawful for a person to: 
a.  Continuously tether a dog for more than three hours per day; or 
b.  Tether a dog on a tether made of anything but a coated steel cable more than ten feet in length; or 
c.  Use a tether or any assembly or attachments thereto to tether a dog that shall weigh more than ten percent of the animal's body weight, or due to weight, inhibit the free movement of the animal within the area tethered; or 
d.  Tether a dog on anything except a buckle-type collar or harness, or tethering on a choke chain or around the dog's neck, or tethered to training collars such as choke or pinch-style collars, or in such a manner as to cause injury, strangulation, or entanglement of the dog on fences, trees, or other manmade or natural obstacles; or 
e.  Tether a dog without access to shade when sunlight is likely to cause overheating, or appropriate shelter to provide insulation and protection against cold and dampness when the atmospheric temperature falls below 40 degrees Fahrenheit, or to tether a dog without securing its food and water supply so that it cannot be tipped over by the tether; or 
f.  Tether a dog in an open area where it can be teased by persons or an open area that does not provide the dog protection from attack by other animals; or 
g.  Tether a dog in an area where bare earth is present and no steps have been taken to prevent the surface from becoming wet and muddy in the event of precipitation; or 
h.  Tether a dog less than four months of age; or 
i.  Tether more than one dog to a single tether; or 
j.  Tether a dog to a stationary object which would allow a dog to come within five feet of any property line; or 
k.  Tether a dog without a swivel attached and/or equipped on both ends. 
(2)  The director of the department of public works and/or the animal control officer, or his/her designee, may in his/her discretion order a more restrictive tethering requirement if circumstances require and it is not detrimental to the health, safety or welfare of the dog. 
(Ord. No. 14-484, § 1, 6-17-2014) 
Secs. 6-15-6-44. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - KEEPING REGULATIONS[2] 
Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference- Dog law, MCL 287.261 et seq. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 6-45. - Prima facie evidence of ownership. 
    In all prosecutions for violation of this chapter, the records of the clerk's office shall be prima facie evidence of the ownership of any dog or cat, showing: 
(1)  The name of the owner; 
(2)  The license number to whom any license was issued; and 
(3)  The license tag affixed to the collar or harness of the dog or cat showing a corresponding number. 
(Code 1987, § 5-31; Ord. No. 75-52, § 7, 2-11-1975; Ord. No. 87-165, § 7, 2-3-1987; Ord. No. 88-196, 9-6-1988; Ord. No. 94-270, 10-4-1994) 
Sec. 6-46. - Common law liability. 
    Nothing in this chapter shall be construed as limiting the common law liability of the owner of a dog or cat for damages committed by it. 
(Code 1987, § 5-32; Ord. No. 75-52, § 7, 2-11-1975; Ord. No. 87-165, § 7, 2-3-1987; Ord. No. 88-196, 9-6-1988; Ord. No. 94-270, 10-4-1994) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, MCL 287.288. 
Sec. 6-47. - Complaints; hearings. 
    On sworn complaint to the local district court that any one of the following facts exist: 
(1)  After January 10 and before December 31 in each year, a dog or cat over six months old is running at large, unaccompanied by its owner, or a dog is engaged in lawful hunting and not under the reasonable control of its owner, or without a license attached to the collar on such dog or cat; 
(2)  A dog or cat or any animal, licensed or unlicensed, has at any time destroyed property or causes damage by trespassing on the property of a person who is not the owner; 
(3)  A dog or cat, licensed or unlicensed, has at any time attacked or bitten a person; 
(4)  A dog or cat or any animal, licensed or unlicensed, has shown vicious habits or has molested a person when lawfully on the public highway; 
(5)  A dog or cat duly licensed and wearing a license tag, has run at large, contrary to the provisions of this chapter; 
the judge shall issue a summons to show cause why such dog, cat or any animal should not be killed. Upon such hearing the judge may either order the dog or cat or animal killed or confined to the premises of the owner. If the owner disobeys this order the owner is guilty of a misdemeanor. Costs as in a civil case shall be taxed against the owner of the dog or cat and collected by the county. The local district court shall audit and pay claims for services of officers rendered pursuant to this section, unless the claims are paid by the owner of the dog or cat. 
(Code 1987, § 5-33; Ord. No. 75-52, § 7, 2-11-1975; Ord. No. 87-165, § 7, 2-3-1987; Ord. No. 87-167, § 12, 3-17-1987; Ord. No. 88-196, 9-6-1988; Ord. No. 94-270, 10-4-1994) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, MCL 287.286a. 
Sec. 6-48. - Owning, keeping animals which trespass or cause damage. 
    No person within the city shall own, keep or harbor any animal, whether such animal is licensed or unlicensed, which has destroyed or damaged property of any other person or which trespasses on such property. 
(Code 1987, § 5-34; Ord. No. 75-52, § 7, 2-11-1975; Ord. No. 87-165, § 7, 2-3-1987; Ord. No. 88-196, 9-6-1988; Ord. No. 94-270, 10-4-1994) 
Sec. 6-49. - Damage to livestock or poultry. 
    Whenever any person sustains any loss or damage to any livestock or poultry by dogs or cats or any animal, or whenever any livestock of any person is necessarily destroyed because of having been bitten by a dog or cat or any animal, such person or agent may complain to the animal control officer. The complaint shall be in writing on forms to be furnished by the city, signed by the person making it and shall state when, where, what and how much damage was done, and, if known, by whose dog or cat or animal. The animal control officer shall examine the place where the alleged damage was sustained and the livestock or poultry injured or killed and make diligent inquiry in relation to such claim and, if possible, a determination of who was the owner of the dog or cat or animal by which such damage was done. If during the course of the investigation the owner of the dog or cat or animal causing the loss or damage shall be determined, the animal control officer shall and is hereby authorized to file a complaint against the alleged owner in the local district court. 
(Code 1987, § 5-35; Ord. No. 75-52, § 7, 2-11-1975; Ord. No. 87-165, § 7, 2-3-1987; Ord. No. 87-167, § 12, 3-17-1987; Ord. No. 88-196, 9-6-1988; Ord. No. 94-270, 10-4-1994) 
State Law reference- Killing of dogs pursuing, worrying, or wounding livestock, MCL 287.279. 
Sec. 6-50. - Stealing, confining dogs or cats/animals. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person within the city to steal or confine, hide or conceal, any dog or cat or other animal, licensed or unlicensed, unless legally authorized to do so or unless such confining is justifiable in the protection of person, property or game. 
(Code 1987, § 5-36; Ord. No. 75-52, § 6, 2-11-1975; Ord. No. 87-165, § 6, 2-3-1987; Ord. No. 88-196, 9-6-1988; Ord. No. 94-270, 10-4-1994) 
Sec. 6-51. - Killing of animals. 
    Any person within the city, including a law enforcement officer, animal control officer or department of public works representative, may kill any animal which the animal control officer sees in the act of pursuing, worrying or wounding any livestock or poultry or attacking persons, and there shall be no liability on such person in damages or otherwise for such killing. The entering of any field or enclosure which is owned by or leased by a person producing livestock or poultry outside of the city by any dog or cat or other animal unaccompanied by the owner or the owner's agent shall constitute a trespass, and the owner shall be liable for damages. Except as provided in this section, it shall be unlawful for any person within the city, other than a law enforcement officer, animal control officer or representative of the department of public works to kill or capture or attempt to kill or capture any dog, cat or other animal. 
(Code 1987, § 5-37; Ord. No. 75-52, § 6, 2-11-1975; Ord. No. 87-165, § 6, 2-3-1987; Ord. No. 88-196, 9-6-1988; Ord. No. 94-270, 10-4-1994) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, MCL 287.279. 
Sec. 6-52. - Vicious animals. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person within the city to permit a vicious, fierce or dangerous animal to go unconfined and unrestrained on such a person's premises or to run at large. 
(b)  No person within the city shall own, keep or harbor any dog or cat or any animal, licensed or unlicensed, which has attacked, bitten or scratched any other person, except in the defense of the animal's owner, or the family or property of such owner, or which exhibits a vicious nature and molests passersby when lawfully on the public highway, regardless of whether or not the animal is on the public highway. 
(Code 1987, § 5-38; Ord. No. 75-52, § 7, 2-11-1975; Ord. No. 87-165, § 7, 2-3-1987; Ord. No. 88-196, 9-6-1988; Ord. No. 94-270, 10-4-1994) 
State Law reference- Dangerous animals, MCL 287.321 et seq. 
Sec. 6-53. - Additional remedies for enforcement of sections 6-48 and 6-52. 
    In addition to all other remedies, whenever there has been a violation of sections 6-48 and 6-52 involving any animal, the district court may order that such animal be destroyed by the animal control officer in a humane manner. In addition to all remedies mentioned in this section, the city may commence and prosecute appropriate actions or proceedings in the district court or any other court having jurisdiction, to restrain or prevent any noncompliance with or violation of any of the provisions of this chapter, or to correct, remedy or abate such noncompliance or violation. 
(Code 1987, § 5-39; Ord. No. 75-52, § 7, 2-11-1975; Ord. No. 87-165, § 7, 2-3-1987; Ord. No. 87-167, § 12, 3-17-1987; Ord. No. 88-196, 9-6-1988; Ord. No. 94-270, 10-4-1994; Ord. No. 2014-486, § 4, 12-2-2014) 
Secs. 6-54-6-79. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - LICENSE FOR DOGS AND CATS[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
State Law reference- Dog licensing, MCL 287.266 et seq.; authority to license dogs, MCL 287.290. 

Sec. 6-80. - Required. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person within the city to own, possess or harbor a dog or cat six months of age or over for a period of five days or more without first having obtained a license therefor. A person who violates this section shall be responsible for a municipal civil infraction and subject to all of the provisions, remedies and sanctions set forth in section 1-13 of the Taylor Code of Ordinances. 
(Code 1987, § 5-51; Ord. No. 75-52, § 2, 2-11-1975; Ord. No. 87-165, § 2, 2-3-1987; Ord. No. 88-196, 9-6-1988; Ord. No. 94-270, 10-4-1994; Ord. No. 2014-486, § 5, 12-2-2014) 
Sec. 6-81. - Application. 
(a)  All applications for animal licenses shall be filed with the city clerk's office or with the animal control officer on such forms as may be provided by them. 
(b)  It shall be the duty of any person owning or harboring a dog or cat on or before December 31 of each year, on or before any dog or cat becomes six months of age, or within 30 days after such person becomes a resident of the city, or within five days after the person becomes the owner of a dog or cat six months of age or more, to apply for a license or to apply for a kennel license. The applicant for an animal license shall give the applicant's full name and address, and the age and description of the dog or cat. If the applicant has become a resident of the city within 30 days, or the owner of a dog or cat within five days, the applicant shall give the date of becoming a resident or acquiring the dog or cat, as the case may be. The applicant shall submit a certificate that the dog/cat has been immunized against rabies within the year preceding the date of the application, or the dog owner has a valid three-year rabies vaccination certificate, and further, such certificate must have an expiration date of more than 90 days from the date it is submitted. In the event that an owner submits such a certificate with an expiration date of 90 days or less from the date it is submitted, no license shall be issued; and the owner must obtain and submit a renewed certificate and must obtain a renewed license within 90 days. 
(c)  A person who violates this section shall be responsible for a municipal civil infraction and subject to all of the provisions, remedies and sanctions set forth in section 1-13 of the Taylor Code of Ordinances. 
(Code 1987, § 5-52; Ord. No. 75-52, § 2, 2-11-1975; Ord. No. 87-165, § 2, 2-3-1987; Ord. No. 88-196, 9-6-1988; Ord. No. 90-210, 9-4-1990; Ord. No. 94-270, 10-4-1994; Ord. No. 2014-486, § 6, 12-2-2014) 
Sec. 6-82. - Fees. 
(a)  Fees for dog or cat licenses shall be as follows: 
(1)  Regular fee. A fee as prescribed by resolution of the city council shall be charged for each dog or cat. 
(2)  Reduced fees. In the case of any individual dog or cat license issued after June 1 of each year, provided the owner proves to the satisfaction of the city clerk or animal control officer that the dog or cat was not acquired by the owner prior to May 1 or did not become six months of age prior to May 1 or that the owner was not a resident of the city and owner of the dog or cat prior to May 1, the fee shall be reduced as prescribed by resolution of the city council. 
(3)  Late applications. When an application is made for an individual dog or cat license after April 1 or after the dog or cat is six months of age or more than 30 days after the dog or cat has been acquired or its owner has moved into the city, an additional charge shall be made by way of penalty as prescribed by resolution of the city council; provided, however, in the case of anyone moving into the city after April 1 or acquiring a dog or cat after April 1 and furnishing satisfactory proof to the city clerk or animal control officer of such fact, the license fee shall be the same as per license issued prior to April 1. 
(b)  All license fees shall be paid to the city treasurer; provided, however, that the city treasurer may designate and authorize certain officers or employees of the police department, including the animal control officer, to accept such fees in the name of the city treasurer and to issue proper receipts therefor. 
(Code 1987, § 5-53; Ord. No. 75-52, § 2, 2-11-1975; Ord. No. 87-165, § 2, 2-3-1987; Ord. No. 88-196, 9-6-1988; Ord. No. 94-270, 10-4-1994) 
Sec. 6-83. - Issuance. 
    Dog or cat licenses shall be issued by the city clerk's office or the animal control officer upon filing and approval of proper applications, payment of the required fee and full compliance with the provisions of this division. 
(Code 1987, § 5-54; Ord. No. 75-52, § 2, 2-11-1975; Ord. No. 87-165, § 2, 2-3-1987; Ord. No. 88-196, 9-6-1988; Ord. No. 94-270, 10-4-1994) 
Sec. 6-84. - Tags. 
(a)  Issuance. Upon issuance of a dog or cat license, there shall be delivered to the licensee by the city clerk or animal control officer a license tag of metal or other suitable material, containing the number of the license duly stamped or engraved thereon, the year of issuance, the term "Taylor" and also bearing the term "Immunized" in the case of individual dog or cat licenses. The shape and style of the tag shall be changed each year on January 1 thereof. 
(b)  Attachment to collar. Every person owning or harboring a dog or cat shall provide the same with a substantial collar of durable material and shall be responsible for attaching the license tag securely thereto, to be worn by the dog or cat. Absence of the license tag from any dog or cat shall be prima facie evidence that the dog or cat is not licensed. 
(c)  Removal. No person within the city shall remove any license tag from any dog or cat without the consent of the person owning or harboring the dog or cat, nor shall any person attach a tag on the collar or harness of said dog or cat other than the dog or cat for which the tag was issued. 
(d)  Loss of tag. In case of the loss of a tag the owner may secure a duplicate from the city clerk's office upon payment of a fee prescribed by resolution of the city council. 
(e)  Kennel tags. Upon the issuance of a kennel license, there shall be delivered to the licensee by the city clerk's office a number of metal tags equal to the number of dogs or cats authorized to be kept in the kennel. Such tags shall contain a serial number and the words "Kennel License, Taylor, Wayne County, Michigan" stamped or engraved thereon. Such tags shall be readily distinguishable from the individual license tags for the same year. The licensee of a kennel shall at all times keep one of such tags attached to the collar of each domestic animal four months old or over, kept by the licensee under a kennel license. No animal bearing a kennel tag shall be permitted to stray or to be taken anywhere outside the limits of the kennel. This section does not prohibit the taking of animals having a kennel license outside the kennel temporarily and on leash, nor does it prohibit the taking of such animals out of the kennel temporarily for the purpose of hunting, breeding, trial or show. 
(Code 1987, § 5-55; Ord. No. 75-52, § 4, 2-11-1975; Ord. No. 87-165, § 4, 2-3-1987; Ord. No. 88-196, 9-6-1988; Ord. No. 94-270, 10-4-1994) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, MCL 287.271. 
Sec. 6-85. - Transfer. 
    Whenever the ownership or possession of any dog or cat is permanently transferred from one person to another within the city, the license of such dog or cat may not be transferred but a new license must be obtained in accordance with the provisions of this division. Further, every license so issued shall not be transferable to some other dog or cat. 
(Code 1987, § 5-56; Ord. No. 75-52, § 2, 2-11-1975; Ord. No. 87-165, § 2, 2-3-1987; Ord. No. 88-196, 9-6-1988; Ord. No. 94-270, 10-4-1994) 
Sec. 6-86. - Expiration. 
    All dog or cat licenses shall expire on December 31 in the year following their issuance, or in the year of their issuance for licenses issued after December 31 of the preceding year. 
(Code 1987, § 5-57; Ord. No. 75-52, § 2, 2-11-1975; Ord. No. 87-165, § 2, 2-3-1987; Ord. No. 88-196, 9-6-1988; Ord. No. 94-270, 10-4-1994) 
Sec. 6-87. - Foreign licenses. 
    In the case of a dog or cat which has been duly licensed in another county, city or village in the state or by lawful authority of any state in the United States of America, if application is made by the owner or person harboring such a dog or cat within 30 days after taking up residence in the city, and at least 60 days prior to the expiration of the dog's or cat's foreign license, and proper evidence is furnished that the dog or cat has been immunized against rabies subsequent to the previous January 1, the fee shall be as prescribed by resolution of the city council. 
(Code 1987, § 5-58; Ord. No. 75-52, § 2, 2-11-1975; Ord. No. 87-165, § 2, 2-3-1987; Ord. No. 88-196, 9-6-1988; Ord. No. 94-270, 10-4-1994) 
Secs. 6-88-6-117. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - KENNELS[4] 
Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
State Law reference- Kennels, MCL 287.270 et seq. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 6-118. - Operation. 
(a)  All dogs or cats in a kennel shall be provided with adequate shelter to protect them from the weather and the elements. No dog or cat shall be so penned, caged, boxed, housed or kept that reasonable, adequate outside runs, pens or yards are not individually available to such animal for exercise, health and well-being. There shall be a dwelling situated on the premises on which any kennel is located, in which dwelling there shall reside such person as is responsible for the care, upkeep and control of the dogs or cats contained in the kennel. 
(b)  No wild or exotic animals, fowl, farm animals or livestock, are permitted in a kennel, household or otherwise. 
(Code 1987, § 5-71; Ord. No. 75-52, § 7, 2-11-1975; Ord. No. 87-165, § 7, 2-3-1987; Ord. No. 88-196, 9-6-1988; Ord. No. 94-270, 10-4-1994) 
Sec. 6-119. - Location. 
    No kennel shall be kept or allowed within 100 feet of any dwelling, well, spring, stream, drainage ditch or drain. 
(Code 1987, § 5-72; Ord. No. 94-270, 10-4-1994) 
Secs. 6-120-6-136. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - LICENSE[5] 

Footnotes: 
--- (5) --- 
State Law reference- Authority to license kennels, MCL 287.270b. 

Sec. 6-137. - Required. 
    No person within the city shall establish, maintain or operate a kennel without first obtaining a license in the manner provided in this division or as provided in Public Act No. 339 of 1919 (MCL 287.261 et seq.), and better known as the "1919 Dog Law." 
(Code 1987, § 5-86; Ord. No. 75-52, § 3, 2-11-1975; Ord. No. 87-165, § 3, 2-3-1987; Ord. No. 88-196, 9-6-1988; Ord. No. 94-270, 10-4-1994) 
Sec. 6-138. - Application. 
    All applications for kennel licenses shall be filed with the city clerk's office or animal control officer on such forms as may be prepared by them. The application for a kennel license shall be made on or before December 31 of each year and shall give a description of the premises where the kennel is to be operated, the capacity of the kennel quarters, and the largest number of animals, including those four months of age or younger, to be kept thereat, and a description of the type of kennel to be licensed and the functions to be engaged in by such kennel. It shall give permission for any duly authorized officer or representative of the city and county to inspect the premises at all reasonable times. All kennel licenses shall expire on December 31 in the year following their issuance, or in the year of their issuance for licenses issued after December 31 of the preceding year. 
(Code 1987, § 5-87; Ord. No. 75-52, § 3, 2-11-1975; Ord. No. 87-165, § 3, 2-3-1987; Ord. No. 88-196, 9-6-1988; Ord. No. 94-270, 10-4-1994) 
Sec. 6-139. - Compliance with zoning ordinance. 
    No kennel license shall be issued or transferred until the building department has certified that the maintenance and operation of such kennel is in full compliance with the provisions of the zoning ordinance in appendix A to this Code. 
(Code 1987, § 5-88; Ord. No. 75-52, § 3, 2-11-1975; Ord. No. 87-165, § 3, 2-3-1987; Ord. No. 88-196, 9-6-1988; Ord. No. 94-270, 10-4-1994) 
Sec. 6-140. - Fees. 
(a)  Regular fee. Fees for kennel licenses shall be as prescribed by resolution of the city council. 
(b)  Reduced fees. In the case of any kennel application for any kennel established after June 1 of each year, the fee for a kennel license shall be one-half of the amount provided for in this section for a full year. 
(c)  Late applications. When an application is made for a kennel license after January 1, or in the case of kennel established after June 1, more than 30 days after such kennel has been established, the fee shall be as prescribed by resolution of the city council. 
(d)  Payment. All license fees shall be paid to the city clerk; provided, however, the city clerk may designate and authorize certain officers or employees, including the animal control officer, to accept such fees in the name of the city clerk and to issue proper receipts therefor. 
(Code 1987, § 5-89; Ord. No. 75-52a, § 3, 5-27-1975; Ord. No. 87-165, § 3, 2-3-1987; Ord. No. 88-196, 9-6-1988; Ord. No. 94-270, 10-4-1994) 
Sec. 6-141. - Issuance. 
    Kennel licenses shall be issued by the city clerk or animal control officer upon filing and approval of proper applications, upon payment of the required fees and upon full compliance with the provisions of this division. 
(Code 1987, § 5-90; Ord. No. 75-52, § 3, 2-11-1975; Ord. No. 87-165, § 3, 2-3-1987; Ord. No. 88-196, 9-6-1988; Ord. No. 94-270, 10-4-1994) 
Sec. 6-142. - Posting. 
    Each kennel license shall be posted in a conspicuous place on the premises where the kennel is maintained. 
(Code 1987, § 5-91; Ord. No. 75-52, § 3, 2-11-1975; Ord. No. 87-165, § 3, 2-3-1987; Ord. No. 88-196, 9-6-1988; Ord. No. 94-270, 10-4-1994) 
Sec. 6-143. - Limitations. 
    A license for a private kennel shall in no way authorize the holder thereof to operate a boarding kennel, nor shall a license for a boarding kennel authorize the holder thereof to operate a private kennel, providing, however, that nothing in this section shall prevent anyone from obtaining both a private and a boarding kennel license if the person is otherwise qualified to receive such licenses. 
(Code 1987, § 5-92; Ord. No. 75-52, § 3, 2-11-1975; Ord. No. 87-165, § 3, 2-3-1987; Ord. No. 88-196, 9-6-1988; Ord. No. 94-270, 10-4-1994) 
Sec. 6-144. - Transferability. 
    A kennel license shall expire upon the sale, transfer or other disposition by the owner of the kennel for which such license was issued; provided, however, that the license may be transferred to a new owner with the approval of the issuing authority. The issuing authority shall approve the transfer upon a showing by that the transferee is in compliance with all applicable laws, ordinances and regulations of the city. 
(Code 1987, § 5-93; Ord. No. 75-52, § 3, 2-11-1975; Ord. No. 87-165, § 3, 2-3-1987; Ord. No. 87-167, § 3, 3-17-1987; Ord. No. 88-196, 9-6-1988; Ord. No. 94-270, 10-4-1994) 
Sec. 6-145. - Grounds for denial or revocation; written notice. 
(a)  Any license issued pursuant to this division may be revoked by the chief of police, animal control officer or department of public works representative, and any application for a license required by this division may be denied by the chief of police, animal control officer, department of public works representative for any one or more of the following reasons: 
(1)  Fraud or misrepresentation in the application for such license: 
(2)  Fraud or misrepresentation in the use for exercise of such license or in the operation of a kennel; 
(3)  Any violation of this chapter, or of the rules and regulations authorized by this chapter, or of any ordinance of the city; 
(4)  Any violation of any of the laws of the United States or the state; 
(5)  The use or exercise of such license, or the operation of a kennel, in an unlawful manner or in such manner as to constitute a breach of the peace or a menace to the health, safety or welfare of the public; or 
(6)  Any failure or inability on the part of the applicant or licensee to meet and satisfy the requirements and provisions of this chapter and the resulting rules and regulations. 
(b)  Written notice of such revocation or denial, stating the reason therefor, shall be delivered to the applicant or licensee personally at the time of such revocation or denial, or shall be mailed to the address stated in the application, within five days following such revocation or denial. 
(Code 1987, § 5-94; Ord. No. 75-52, § 7, 2-11-1975; Ord. No. 87-165, § 7, 2-3-1987; Ord. No. 88-196, 9-6-1988; Ord. No. 94-270, 10-4-1994) 
Sec. 6-146. - Appeal of denial or revocation. 
    Whenever any license issued pursuant to this division has been revoked, or whenever any application for a license required by this division has been denied, any person directly aggrieved by such revocation or denial may have a hearing before the city council, provided the person shall file with the city clerk, within 15 days following such revocation or denial, a written request for such hearing. Following a hearing, the city council shall either affirm such revocation or denial or shall order such license to be issued or reinstated on such terms and conditions as shall seem reasonable and just. 
(Code 1987, § 5-95; Ord. No. 75-52, § 7, 2-11-1975; Ord. No. 87-165, § 7, 2-3-1987; Ord. No. 88-196, 9-6-1988; Ord. No. 94-270, 10-4-1994) 
Secs. 6-147-6-175. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - IMPOUNDMENT 

Sec. 6-176. - Animal shelter. 
    There is hereby established, under the jurisdiction and control of the department of public works and under the supervision of an animal control officer, working in and through the department of public works, an animal shelter in which shall be impounded: 
(1)  All animals that may be found running at large which may be unlicensed in the city; 
(2)  All vicious, dangerous or diseased animals; or 
(3)  All animals owned, kept, possessed or harbored contrary to the terms and provisions of this chapter. 
(Code 1987, § 5-111; Ord. No. 75-52, § 5, 2-11-1975; Ord. No. 87-165, § 5, 2-3-1987; Ord. No. 88-196, 9-6-1988; Ord. No. 94-270, 10-4-1994) 
Sec. 6-177. - Animal control officer. 
    The animal control officer shall have such duties and powers as are provided in this chapter and shall perform such other duties as may be assigned to the animal control officer, from time to time. It shall be the duty of the animal control officer or other persons designated by the director of public works to make diligent inquiry as to the dogs or cats owned, animals harbored or kept, or kennels operated, in the city and whether such dogs or cats and kennels are licensed. Any dog or cat found unlicensed after January 1 of each year may be seized and impounded by the animal control officer or other authorized persons. If the owner or person harboring such dogs or cats is known, the animal control officer or other officers shall file a complaint against the owner or person in the court of competent jurisdiction. 
(Code 1987, § 5-112; Ord. No. 75-52, § 5, 2-11-1975; Ord. No. 87-165, § 5, 2-3-1987; Ord. No. 88-196, 9-6-1988; Ord. No. 94-270, 10-4-1994) 
Sec. 6-178. - Records. 
    The animal control officer, upon receiving any domestic animal, shall make a complete registry entering the breed, color, and sex of such animal and whether licensed, if required. If licensed, the animal control officer shall enter the name and address of the owner and the number of license tag and forthwith notify the owner, if any, at the owner's registered or other known address. The refusal of any person to deliver or turn over to the animal control officer or subordinates any animal kept or harbored in violation of the provisions of this chapter shall be deemed a violation thereof. 
(Code 1987, § 5-113; Ord. No. 75-52, § 5, 2-11-1975; Ord. No. 87-165, § 5, 2-3-1987; Ord. No. 88-196, 9-6-1988; Ord. No. 94-270, 10-4-1994) 
Sec. 6-179. - Holding of animal for five days; notice to owner. 
    The animal shelter shall not sell or otherwise dispose of a domestic animal within five days after its acquisition. If the animal has a collar, license, or other evidence of ownership the operator of the shelter shall notify the owner in writing and disposition of the animal shall not be made within seven days from the date of mailing the notice. Each operator of the animal shelter shall be required to maintain a record on each identifiable domestic animal acquired, indicating a basic description of the animal, the date it was acquired and under what circumstances. The record shall also indicate the date of notice sent to the owner of any animal and subsequent disposition. When the animal is claimed, a pound fee will be imposed upon the owner or responsible party in an amount as prescribed by resolution of city council. If the animal is not licensed at the time the animal is claimed by owner, a pound fee plus a deposit in an amount prescribed by resolution of the city council will be required. The deposit will be returned to owner upon proof of rabies immunizations, and a license must be purchased at that time. 
(Code 1987, § 5-114; Ord. No. 75-52, § 5, 2-11-1975; Ord. No. 87-165, § 5, 2-3-1987; Ord. No. 88-196, 9-6-1988; Ord. No. 94-270, 10-4-1994) 
Sec. 6-180. - Conditions for release. 
(a)  Any domestic animal seized or impounded by the animal control officer shall be released upon the following conditions: 
(1)  When the animal is claimed, a pound fee will be imposed upon the owner or responsible party in an amount as prescribed by resolution of the city council. 
(2)  The showing of a city license or, if the animal has no license, the making of an application for same, a deposit will be required as prescribed by resolution of the city council. 
(3)  The presentation of satisfactory evidence that the dog or cat has been immunized against rabies in a manner approved by the health officer. 
(b)  If the dog or cat has not been immunized against rabies in a manner approved by the health officer, then the claimant shall be required to have it vaccinated and immunized against rabies and present a certificate of vaccination by a registered veterinarian to the animal control officer within ten days. A deposit will be required at this time, to be prescribed by resolution of city council, and will be returned to the animal owner upon proof of rabies vaccines and purchase of an animal license. Failure to present such certificate of vaccination within the time specified shall constitute authorization to the animal control officer or employees to impound the dog forthwith wherever it may be found in the city and dispose of such dog in accordance with provisions of this article. 
(Code 1987, § 5-115; Ord. No. 75-52, § 5, 2-11-1975; Ord. No. 78-101, § 1, 4-11-1978; Ord. No. 87-165, § 5, 2-3-1987; Ord. No. 88-196, 9-6-1988; Ord. No. 94-270, 10-4-1994) 
Sec. 6-181. - Adoption of dogs, cats and ferrets. 
(a)  Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this section, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this subsection, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Adoption means a transfer of ownership, with or without remuneration, of a dog, cat, or ferret from an animal control shelter or animal protection shelter to an individual for the purpose of being a companion animal for that individual. As used in this subdivision, a companion animal includes, but is not limited to, a dog that is used for hunting or as a guard dog. 
    Alteration means a professional sterilization procedure performed by a veterinarian that renders a dog, cat, or ferret incapable of reproducing. 
    Altered, in reference to a dog, cat, or ferret, means having undergone alteration. 
    Animal means a mammal, except livestock as defined in Public Act No. 284 of 1987 (MCL 287.121 et seq.), and rodents. 
    Animal control shelter means a facility operated by a municipality for the impoundment and care of animals that are found in the streets or at large, animals that are otherwise held due to the violation of a municipal ordinance or state law, or animals that are surrendered to the animal control shelter. 
    Animal protection shelter means a facility operated, by a person, the Humane Society, the Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals or any other nonprofit organization, for the care of homeless animals. 
    Cat means domestic cat of any age of the species Felis catus. 
    Department means the state department of agriculture. 
    Director means the director of the department or authorized representative. 
    Dog means a domestic dog of any age of the species Canis familiaris. 
    Ferret means an animal of any age of the species Mustela furo. 
    Health certificate means a certificate in a form prescribed by the department in which a veterinarian attests to the age, sex, breed and description of an animal and to the fact that, at the time of preparation of the certificate, the veterinarian examined the animal and found the animal free from visual evidence of communicable disease. 
    Municipality means a county, city, village or township. 
    Pet shop means a place where animals are sold or offered for sale, exchange, or transfer. 
    Veterinarian means a person licensed to practice veterinary medicine under part 188 of the public health code, Public Act No. 368 of 1978 (MCL 333.18801 et seq.). 
(b)  Adoption contracts. 
(1)  Except as otherwise provided in this section, an animal control shelter or animal protection shelter shall not permit a person to adopt a dog, cat or ferret that has not been altered, unless that person has entered into a contract for the alteration of the dog, cat or ferret with the animal control shelter or animal protection shelter. The contract shall state that the adopting person agrees to have an alteration performed on the dog, cat or ferret and shall otherwise comply with this section. 
(2)  A contract with an animal control shelter or animal protection shelter entered into pursuant to subsection (b)(1) of this section shall require the adopting person to have an alteration performed on the dog, cat, or ferret within four weeks after the adoption date if at the time of adoption the dog, cat, or ferret is six months of age or older. If the dog, cat or ferret to be adopted is under six months of age at the time of adoption, the contract shall contain the date upon which the dog, cat or ferret will be six months of age and shall require the person adopting the dog, cat or ferret to have an alteration performed on the dog, cat, or ferret within four weeks after that date. This section does not prevent a veterinarian from performing an alteration on a dog, cat, or ferret that is under six months of age. 
(3)  Upon certification by a veterinarian in writing that a dog, cat or ferret has a serious, permanent medical or health problem that prevents an alteration, the dog, cat or ferret adopted is not required to be altered. Upon certification by a veterinarian in writing that an alteration poses a serious, temporary medical or health problem, the alteration may be postponed. The person adopting the dog, cat or ferret shall have it reevaluated by a veterinarian at intervals not to exceed 14 days and shall have the alteration performed no later than seven days after a veterinarian determines that the temporary problem is resolved. 
(4)  Except as otherwise provided in subsection (b)(6) of this section, a contract entered into pursuant to subsection (b)(1) of this section shall require the adopting person to leave with the animal control shelter or animal protection shelter, or a designee of the animal control shelter or animal protection shelter, a good faith deposit in an amount as currently established or as hereafter adopted by resolution of the city council from time to time, that indicates the person's intention to have the adopted dog, cat or ferret altered within the time provided pursuant to subsection (b)(2) of this section. If the person fails to comply with the terms of the contract, the deposit is forfeited. The good faith deposit shall be returned to the adopting person if the adopting person submits written certification from a veterinarian of either of the following: 
a.  The dog, cat or ferret died within the time period in which the alteration was required under subsection (b)(2) of this section. 
b.  The dog, cat or ferret has a serious, permanent medical or health problem that prevents an alteration. 
(5)  If the adopting person complies with the terms of a contract entered into under subsection (b)(1) of this section, the good faith deposit shall be refunded by the animal control shelter, animal protection shelter, or a designee of the animal control shelter or animal protection shelter, upon submission by the adopting person of written certification by a veterinarian that the adopted dog, cat, or ferret was altered. The certificate shall include: 
a.  The date of alteration; 
b.  The name of the owner of the dog, cat, or ferret; 
c.  The description of the dog, cat, or ferret; and 
d.  The signature of the veterinarian who performed the alteration. 
(6)  The good faith deposit under subsection (b)(4) of this section is not required if one or more of the following apply: 
a.  A dog is transferred to a local, state or federal law enforcement agency. 
b.  A dog is transferred to an organization or trainer that trains guide or leader dogs for blind persons, hearing dogs for deaf or audibly impaired persons or service dogs for physically limited persons. 
c.  A dog, cat or ferret is transferred to another animal control shelter or animal protection shelter or is transferred to a person who will transfer the animal to another animal control shelter or animal protection shelter. Before the first animal control shelter or animal protection shelter releases the animal, it shall obtain from the person to whom the animal is to be released a written statement by the second animal control shelter or animal protection shelter that it is willing to accept the animal for purposes of adoption or humane euthanasia. Promptly after receipt of the animal by the second animal control shelter or animal protection shelter, the person to whom the animal was released shall provide the first animal control shelter or animal protection shelter with a written statement by the second animal control shelter or animal protection shelter containing a description of the dog, cat or ferret and acknowledging its receipt on a date specified in the statement. 
(7)  A contract entered into pursuant to subsection (b)(1) of this section shall include a statement that if the terms of the contract are breached because a person adopting a dog, cat, or ferret fails to have the animal altered as requested in the contract, then the person agrees to pay liquidated damages of the greater of an amount as currently established or as hereafter adopted by resolution of the city council from time to time, or actual reasonable costs incurred by the animal control shelter or animal protection shelter to enforce the contract. Immediately before a person signs the contract, a representative of the animal control shelter or animal protection shelter shall verbally direct the person's attention to the liquidated damages agreement in the contract. 
(8)  If a person fails to comply with a contract for the alteration of a dog, cat or ferret as required under subsection (b)(6) of this section, a court with appropriate jurisdiction may order the transfer of ownership of the adopted animal only to one of the following: 
a.  The facility from which the animal was adopted. 
b.  A veterinarian, animal control shelter, or animal protection shelter willing to accept the animal and either humanely euthanize the animal or adopt the animal to an owner who agrees to have the animal altered. 
(c)  Violation. A person violating any provision of this section shall be guilty of a municipal civil infraction and a court of appropriate jurisdiction may enter a judgment in the amount of $100.00 plus costs. 
(Code 1987, § 5-115.5; Ord. No. 98-316, §§ 1-3, 7-21-1998) 
Sec. 6-182. - Disposition of valuable animals. 
    The animal control officer shall perform the following duties: If in the animal control officer's judgment any impounded domestic animal is valuable or otherwise desirable of keeping, the animal control officer may dispose of the animal to any person who will undertake to keep and harbor the animal within the city in accordance with provisions of this chapter, and who shall satisfy the animal control officer that the person is capable of fulfilling such undertaking. Where two or more persons desire a particular animal, such animal shall be sold to the highest bidder of such persons; provided, however, that no bid shall be less than the cost to the city for keeping the animal. 
(Code 1987, § 5-116; Ord. No. 75-52, § 5, 2-11-1975; Ord. No. 87-165, § 5, 2-3-1987; Ord. No. 88-196, 9-6-1988; Ord. No. 94-270, 10-4-1994) 
Sec. 6-183. - Contracts with other municipal corporations. 
    A department of public works representative is hereby authorized to negotiate contracts with other municipal corporations, including cities, villages and townships, for the care, maintenance, destruction and disposal of all dogs or cats seized and impounded by such municipal corporations; provided, however, that no such contract shall become valid and binding on the city until it has been approved by the city council. 
(Code 1987, § 5-117; Ord. No. 75-52, § 5, 2-11-1975; Ord. No. 87-165, § 5, 2-3-1987; Ord. No. 88-196, 9-6-1988; Ord. No. 94-270, 10-4-1994)

ARTICLE II. - STATE CONSTRUCTION CODE 

Sec. 8-19. - Enforcing agency designated. 
    Pursuant to the provisions of the state construction code, in accordance with section 8b(6) of Public Act No. 230 of 1972 (MCL 125.1508b(6)), the building official of the city is hereby designated as the enforcing agency to discharge the responsibility of the city under Public Act No. 230 of 1972 (MCL 125.1501 et seq.) as amended, Appendix G of the Michigan Building Code shall be enforced by the enforcing agency within the City of Taylor. The city assumes responsibility for the administration and enforcement of said Act throughout its corporate limits. 
(Code 1987, § 6-1; Ord. No. 01-358, § 1, 3-5-2002; Ord. No. 12-469, § 1, 2-7-2012) 
Sec. 8-20. - Construction board of appeals established. 
(a)  The construction board of appeals shall be established pursuant to the regulations as defined in the Stille-DeRossett-Hale Single State Construction Code Act, Public Act No. 230 of 1972 (MCL 125.1501 et seq.). 
(b)  The construction board of appeals shall establish procedures necessary to administer the official duties related to construction code administration and enforcement. 
(Code 1987, § 6-31; Ord. No. 02-369, § 1, 8-20-2002) 
State Law reference- Authority for this section, MCL 125.1514. 
Sec. 8-21. - Designations of regulated flood-prone hazard areas. 
    The Federal Emergency Management Agency ("FEMA") Flood Insurance Study ("FIS") entitled "Wayne County, Michigan (All Jurisdictions)" and dated December 2, 2013 and the Flood Insurance Rate Map(s) ("FIRMS") panel number(s) 26263C, 0244E, 0263E, 0382E, 0383E, 0384E, 0391E, 0392E, 0401E, 0403E, 0411E, dated February 12, 2012 and map panel numbers 26163C, 0243F and 0381F dated December 3, 2013 are adopted by reference for the purposes of the administration of the Michigan Construction Code, and declared to be a part of Section 1612.3 of the Michigan Building Code, and to provide the content of the "Flood Hazards" section of Table R301.2(1) of the Michigan Residential Code. 
(Ord. No. 12-468, § 1, 1-17-2012; Ord. No. 12-470, § 1, 2-7-2012; Ord. No. 13-481, § 1, 10-15-2013)

ARTICLE III. - PROPERTY MAINTENANCE CODE 

Sec. 8-44. - Adoption. 
    The International Property Maintenance Code, 2012 edition, as published by the International Code Council, is hereby adopted as the Property Maintenance Code and Ordinance of the City of Taylor, for regulating and governing the conditions and maintenance of all property, buildings and structures, by providing for the standards for supplied utilities and facilities and other physical things and conditions essential to ensure that structures are safe, sanitary and fit for occupation and use; the condemnation of buildings and structures unfit for human occupancy and use, and the demolition of such existing structures as herein provided; and, providing for the issuance of permits and collection of fees therefore. Each and all of the regulations, provisions, penalties, conditions and terms of said code on file with the city are hereby referenced to, adopted and made part hereof as if fully set forth in this article, with the additions, insertions, deletions and amendments, if any, prescribed in section 8-45 of this article. Printed copies of such code shall be kept in the office of the city clerk and made available for inspection by and distribution to the public at a reasonable charge. 
(Ord. No. 2015-487, § 1, 1-6-2015; Ord. No. 17-493, § 1, 3-21-2017)

Section 602.3. Insert: January 1 to December 31. 
(Ord. No. 2015-487, § 2, 1-6-2015; Ord. No. 17-493, § 1, 3-21-2017)

ARTICLE IV. - DRAINLAYERS 

Sec. 8-64. - License required. 
(a)  No person shall engage in the trade or business of drainlaying in the city unless the person shall first obtain a license therefor. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person to employ any other person to engage in the business or trade of drainlaying in the city without having a licensed drainlayer in charge of such work who shall be responsible therefor. 
(Code 1987, § 6-196; Ord. No. 75-68, §§ 2, 6, 9-9-1975) 
Sec. 8-65. - Application; fee. 
    Applications for licenses required by this article shall be made upon proper forms and submitted to the city clerk, and the applicant at the time of filing such application shall deposit a fee as provided by resolution of the city council with the city treasurer, and no such application shall be accepted for filing with the city clerk until such fee has been made. 
(Code 1987, § 6-197; Ord. No. 75-68, § 3, 9-9-1975) 
Sec. 8-66. - Examination of applicants. 
    Subsequent to the filing of an application for a license required by this article, the applicant shall submit to an examination by the plumbing inspector or such other person whom the city building trades board may designate to determine the ability and qualification of the applicant as a drainlayer. 
(Code 1987, § 6-198; Ord. No. 75-68, § 4, 9-9-1975) 
Sec. 8-67. - Requirements for granting license. 
    Any applicant for a drainlayer's license who successfully passes the examination, files with the city clerk a bond in the sum prescribed by resolution of the city council and pays the license fee shall be entitled to engage in the business of drainlaying in the city and such license therefor shall upon the recommendation of the plumbing inspector be granted to the applicant by the building trades board. 
(Code 1987, § 6-199; Ord. No. 75-68, § 5, 9-9-1975) 
Sec. 8-68. - Surety bond. 
(a)  The surety for the bond referred to in section 8-67 shall be some suitable surety company authorized to do business in the state. The bond shall be approved by the city clerk and conditioned that the licensee shall faithfully observe all the ordinances of the city pertaining to drainlaying, all rules and regulations established under the authority of this article, and shall indemnify the city or any person against all losses and damages that may result by reason of inadequate workmanship or negligence, on the part of the drainlayer or agent, servant or employee in the performance of such work. 
(b)  The bond shall be for the benefit of all persons injured or aggrieved by any violation or neglect to observe the provisions of this article or the rules and regulations established pursuant to this article and shall be renewed at intervals of one year or more often, if in the judgment of the building trades board the security shall be impaired. 
(c)  Upon failure or refusal to comply with this section, the license of the person shall be revoked by the building trades board. 
(Code 1987, § 6-200; Ord. No. 75-68, §§ 9, 10, 9-9-1975) 
Sec. 8-69. - License fees.
