(Code 1987, § 7-23; Ord. No. 75-66, § 16, 7-22-1975; Ord. No. 07-418, § 1, 4-3-2007) 
Sec. 10-24. - Notice of suspension, revocation of license. 
    Written notice of suspension or revocation of a license required by this chapter stating the cause therefor shall be delivered to the licensee personally or mailed to the address stated in the licensee's application for the license. 
(Code 1987, § 7-24; Ord. No. 75-66, § 17, 7-22-1975) 
Sec. 10-25. - Right to hearing following denial, suspension, revocation of license. 
(a)  Any person whose license is revoked or suspended or the renewal thereof has been refused, or any person whose request for a license is refused shall have the right to a hearing before the city council, provided a written request therefor is filed with the city clerk within ten days following the delivery of mailing of the notice of revocation or suspension or within ten days following such refusal. 
(b)  The city council may reverse any refusal to issue a license or any revocation of a license and the city council may grant or reinstate any license. Any revocation, suspension or refusal to renew a license shall not become final until the licensee has exhausted the remedies under the provisions of this chapter. 
(Code 1987, § 7-25; Ord. No. 75-66, § 18, 7-22-1975) 
Sec. 10-26. - Selling defective, faulty merchandise. 
    No holder of a license required by this chapter shall sell or offer for sale any defective, faulty, incomplete, deteriorated, used or secondhand articles of merchandise, unless the goods are so labeled and represented to prospective customers. 
(Code 1987, § 7-26; Ord. No. 75-66, § 14, 7-22-1975; Ord. No. 07-418, § 1, 4-3-2007) 
Chapter 11 - MEDICAL MARIHUANA 
ARTICLE I. - GENERAL 

Sec. 11-1. - Purpose. 
    The City of Taylor recognizes that the citizens of the State of Michigan, by initiative, approved the medical use of marihuana and the possession of marihuana for such purposes by persons suffering from debilitating conditions defined in the Michigan Medical Marihuana Act, MCL 333.26421 et seq., (the "MMMA"). In addition, the MMMA authorizes registered qualifying patients to be assisted in such use by registered primary caregivers. It is in the public welfare to establish local standards to ensure that the procedures utilized to help the seriously ill with medicinal marihuana are compatible with the character of the community. The neighborhoods must be protected from any residual odors or dangerous conditions that are associated with marihuana cultivation and processing, including, but not limited to, explosions and fires caused by the grow process. This chapter is intended to impose local requirements for those individuals registered as "qualifying patients" and "primary caregiver" as defined under the MMMA, to contain growth of medical marihuana to specifically zoned areas within the city, and to restrict presence in neighborhoods only to those qualifying patients and/or caregivers who take safety measures to prevent hazards and odors associated with the growth and processing of marihuana. This chapter is intended to preserve the character of the community, and protect the citizens from any disruption, traffic, offensive odors or nuisance due to the growth, processing and distribution of medical marihuana, and to protect against dangerous conditions for the safety of the community. 
(Ord. No. 2018-497, § 1, 4-17-2018) 
Sec. 11-2. - Definitions. 
    The terms used in this article, whether lower case or capitalized, "qualifying patient(s)" or "primary caregiver" will have the meaning assigned to "registered qualifying patient" and "registered primary caregiver" in the MMMA. All other terms will have the meanings assigned to them by the MMMA and/or as otherwise defined in section 11-21 of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 2018-497, § 1, 4-17-2018) 
Sec. 11-3. - Local requirements; residential dwellings. 
(a)  The growth, manufacturing, processing, or storage of medical marihuana by a qualifying patient or his or her primary caregiver shall only occur at the residence of qualifying patient or the primary caregiver, or other location permitted by this chapter, and shall only be allowed inside of an enclosed, locked facility, or other closed area equipped with locks or other security devices that permit access only by the qualifying patient or his or her primary caregiver. Such facility shall be under the exclusive control of the qualifying patient or his or her primary caregiver through written lease, contract or deed. 
(b)  A qualifying patient, or his or her primary caregiver, shall not distribute, transfer or sell the medical marihuana to another person other than to the qualifying patient on the qualifying patient's or the primary caregiver's residential dwelling or premises. No person shall be allowed or have access to medical marihuana other than the qualifying patient and his or her primary caregiver or other persons who may lawfully assist the patient under the MMMA. 
(c)  Only one qualifying patient, or his or her primary caregiver, may grow, store, cultivate, manufacture or store medical marihuana per residential dwelling and the number of plants at any one single family residential dwelling shall not at any time exceed 12. 
(d)  No marihuana shall be cultivated, grown, manufactured or processed in any manner that would transmit or emit odor from the dwelling or property to neighboring private or public properties or areas. 
(e)  The odor of marihuana from the growth, manufacturing, processing, or cultivation must be contained through use of operable filtration to ventilation and exhaust equipment. Odors must otherwise be effectively confined to the interior of the building or dwelling from which the odor is generated. No ventilation or exhaust system may be installed where marihuana is grown or cultivated without a filtration system approved by the building department. 
(f)  All growth, storage, manufacturing and cultivation of medical marihuana must otherwise comply with the following: 
(1)  The MMMA, all rules and regulations associated with the MMMA, all provisions of this article, the City of Taylor's zoning ordinance and all other applicable ordinances and codes. 
(2)  The property shall be registered with the City of Taylor's building department. Upon registration, a plan shall be submitted and approved by the City of Taylor's building official and fire marshal for the processing, storage and cultivation of medical marihuana. The plan shall describe, in detail, the process and methods used for the growth, processing and/or cultivation of medical marihuana, including a description of the heating equipment and processes, chemical storage, filtration equipment, electrical wiring and lighting, and plant material and water disposal methods to be utilized. 
(3)  The property shall be required to pass, on an annual basis, all required inspections by the City of Taylor including, but not limited to, the fire department and building department. Such inspections shall include, but not be limited to, inspections of the heating equipment, filtration system, electrical wiring, lighting, watering and disposal methods that are used for the cultivation, growth and/or harvesting of medical marihuana, and the storage of any chemicals associated with the cultivation, growth, manufacturing and/or processing of medical marihuana. A certificate of approval will be issued to the registrant following passage of the required inspections. 
(4)  First time registrants shall be required to pay the applicable plan review and inspection fees. For the subsequent annual inspections, the registrant will not be required to pay any additional fees as long as the registrant applies for the annual inspections at least 60 days prior to the expiration of the certificate of approval. If the registrant fails to timely apply for the annual inspections, then payment of plan review and inspection fees will be required. 
(5)  All medical marihuana shall be grown and contained within the structure in an enclosed locked facility that is not accessible by any person other than the qualified patient and his or her primary caregiver, or other person authorized to assist the patient, under the MMMA. 
(6)  On-site lighting in rooms with windows where medical marihuana is grown shall employ shielding methods between 11:00 p.m. and 7:00 a.m., without alteration to the exterior of the residence, to prevent ambient light spillage that may create a disturbance for neighboring property. 
(7)  Information and records obtained through the registration process with the city that are deemed confidential under the MMMA shall be withheld from public disclosure, unless disclosure is compelled by law. 
(8)  All discarded marihuana and all by-products associated with the growth, processing and cultivations of medical marihuana must be disposed of in a way that prevents persons or animals from accessing the discarded materials. 
(Ord. No. 2018-497, § 1, 4-17-2018) 
Sec. 11-4. - Cost recovery. 
    In the event of any explosion, release, or other hazardous condition or situation that results from the growth, cultivation or processing of medical marihuana, the responsible party shall be responsible for reimbursement of any and all emergency response costs as set forth in chapter 2, article VI, Cost Recovery for Emergency Response, of the City of Taylor's Code of Ordinances. 
(Ord. No. 2018-497, § 1, 4-17-2018) 
Sec. 11-5. - Consumption or use by qualifying a patient. 
    A person within the City of Taylor who has been issued and possesses a lawful registry identification card as a qualifying patient as set forth in MMMA, shall not consume or use marihuana in any of the following places: 
(a)  Any public place; 
(b)  A common area of a hotel, motel, apartment building, condominium complex, or other business establishment, including the driveways, entrance areas, parking lots, areas open to the public or other residents and/or guests; 
(c)  A hotel, motel, apartment building, rental dwelling or similar facility or any other establishment at which the owner or property manager has prohibited marihuana use, growth, cultivation, manufacture, or transfer on the premises. 
(Ord. No. 2018-497, § 1, 4-17-2018) 
Sec. 11-6. - Violations; penalties. 
    Any person in violation of any provision of this chapter shall be guilty of a misdemeanor, punishable by a fine of up to $500.00 plus cost of prosecution, 90 days imprisonment, or both, for each violation. 
(Ord. No. 2018-497, § 1, 4-17-2018) 
Secs. 11-7-11-20. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - MEDICAL MARIHUANA FACILITIES[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2018-497, § 1, adopted April 17, 2018, amended the code by the addition of §§ 11-7-11-17; however, said provisions have been redesignated as §§ 11-21-11-31 for purposes of allowing future expansion of the Code. 

Sec. 11-21. - Definitions, interpretation and conflicts. 
    For the purposes of this chapter: 
(a)  Any term defined by the Michigan Medical Marihuana Act ("MMMA"), MCL 333.26421 et seq., as amended, or the Medical Marihuana Facilities Licensing Act ("MMFA"), MCL 333.27101, et seq., as amended, shall have the definition provided for in the MMMA and/or MMFA. If the definition of a word or phrase set forth below is in conflict with the definition in the MMMA or the MMFA, or if a term is not defined below but is defined in the MMMA or the MMFA, then the definition in the MMMA or the MMFA shall apply. 
(b)  All activities related to medical marihuana, including those related to a medical marihuana provisioning center, a medical marihuana cultivation facility, secure transporter, processor or a safety compliance facility shall be in compliance with the rules and regulations of the Michigan Department of Licensing and Regulatory Affairs or any successor agency, the rules and regulations of the City of Taylor, and the MMMA and MMFA. 
(c)  Any use which purports to have engaged in the cultivation or processing of medical marihuana into a usable form, or the distribution of medical marihuana, or the testing of medical marihuana either prior to enactment of the MMMA or the MMFA, or after enactment of the MMMA or MMFA but without obtaining the required licensing set forth in this chapter or state law, shall be deemed to not be a legally established use and therefore, not entitled to legal nonconforming status under the provisions of this chapter and and/or state law. 
(d)  The following terms shall have the definitions given: 
    Cultivation or cultivate as used in this chapter shall mean (i) all phases of growth of marihuana from seed to harvest; or (ii) preparing, packaging or repackaging, labeling, or relabeling of any form of marihuana; or (iii) to the extent permitted by the MMMA or the MMFA, if at all, the extraction of resin from the marihuana or the creation of marihuana infused products for sale or packaged form to a medical marihuana provisioning center. 
    Department means the State of Michigan Department of Licensing and Regulatory Affairs. 
    Medical marihuana means any marihuana intended for medical use that meets all requirements for medical marihuana contained in the MMMA, MMFA and any other applicable law. 
    Medical marihuana provisioning center means a licensee that is a commercial entity located in the city that has a license from the state and the city that purchases marihuana from a grower or processor and sells, supplies or provides marihuana to registered qualifying patients directly or through the patients' registered primary caregivers. A medical marihuana provisioning center includes any commercial property where marihuana is sold at retail to registered qualifying patients or registered primary caregivers. A noncommercial location used by a primary caregiver to assist a qualifying patient connected to the caregiver through the department's marihuana registration process in accordance with the MMMA is not a medical marihuana provisioning center for purposes of this chapter. 
    Medical marihuana grower facility, also known as Medical marihuana cultivation facility, means a licensee that is a commercial entity located in the city and is licensed by the state and city that cultivates, dries, trims or cures and packages marihuana for sale to a processor or medical marihuana provisioning center. 
    Medical marihuana facility shall be used to collectively refer to a licensee under this chapter. 
    Person means an individual, partnership, firm, company, corporation, association, sole proprietorship, limited liability company, joint venture, estate, trust or other legal entity. 
    Processor means a commercial entity that has a license issued by the state that purchases marihuana from a grower and that extracts resin from the marihuana or creates a marihuana-infused product for sale and transfer in packaged form to a medical marihuana provisioning center. 
    Safety compliance facility means a commercial entity that is licensed by the state that receives marihuana from a medical marihuana facility or a registered qualifying patient or a registered primary caregiver, tests it for contaminants and for tetrahydrocannabinol and other cannabinoids, and returns it to the marihuana facility or a registered qualifying patient or registered primary caregiver with the test results. 
    Secure transporter means a commercial entity that is licensed by the state that stores marihuana and transports marihuana between medical marihuana facilities for a fee. 
    Stakeholder means, with respect to a trust, the beneficiaries, with respect to a limited liability company, the managers or members, with respect to a corporation, whether profit or non-profit, the officers, directors or shareholders, and with respect to a partnership or limited liability partnership, the partners, both general and limited. 
    Restricted/limited access area means a building, room or other area under the control of the licensee with access limited to qualifying patients, designated caregivers, staff members and other licensee agents or service professionals conducting business within the licensed facility. 
(Ord. No. 2018-497, § 1, 4-17-2018) 
Sec. 11-22. - License allocation and fees. 
(a)  No person shall operate a medical marihuana provisioning center, medical marihuana grower facility, processor, transporter or safety compliance facility in the City of Taylor without first obtaining a license to do so from the city and the State of Michigan. 
(b)  The city may issue no more than two licenses for medical marihuana provisioning centers, no more than one license per "Class" as defined by MCL 333.27501(1) of the MMFA for medical marihuana grower facilities, no more than two licenses for processor facilities, no more than one license for secure transporters and no more than one license for safety compliance facilities. The term of each license shall be one year, and shall be renewed annually unless revoked per section 11-30. Each license is exclusive to the person(s) to which it was granted and is non-transferable. 
(c)  The application review fee for a medical marihuana facility license shall be set by the city council. The application review fee is non-refundable if the application is reviewed. The annual fee for a medical marihuana facility license shall be set by the city council. A paid for application fee shall apply as a credit against the annual fee owed by a medical marihuana facility granted a license under this chapter for the year in which it is paid. 
(d)  Each medical marihuana facility shall be required to pass, on an annual basis, all required inspections by the City of Taylor including, but not limited to, the fire department and building department. The annual fee must be paid and the annual inspections must be applied for at least 60 days prior to the expiration of the annual license. 
(e)  No one person or stakeholder shall be allowed to have more than one license for each category of the medical marihuana facilities permitted in the city. 
(Ord. No. 2018-497, § 1, 4-17-2018) 
Sec. 11-23. - Medical marihuana facility license applications. 
(a)  No person shall submit an application to the city for a medical marihuana facility license required by this chapter without being first granted prequalification status by the State of Michigan. An application for a medical marihuana facility license required by this chapter shall be made in writing to the city clerk. Upon the expiration of an existing license, a license will be automatically renewed by the City of Taylor if: 
(1)  There are no uncured violations in the prior year; 
(2)  The applicant has paid the annual licensing fee for the renewal period; and 
(3)  Any stakeholder changes have been fully disclosed to the City of Taylor. 
(b)  An application for a medical marihuana facility license required by this chapter shall contain the following: 
(1)  The appropriate non-refundable application fee and the refundable licensee fee as set forth in section 11-22(c); 
(2)  If the applicant is an individual, the applicant's name, date of birth, physical address, copy of photo identification, email address and one or more phone numbers, including emergency contact information; 
(3)  If the applicant is not an individual, the names, dates of birth, physical addresses, copy of photo identification, email addresses and one or more phone numbers of each stakeholder of the applicant, including designation of the highest ranking stakeholder as an emergency contact person and contact information for the emergency contact person. Articles of Incorporation, assumed name registration documents, Internal Revenue Service SS-4 EIN confirmation letter and the operating agreement of the applicant, if a limited liability company; 
(4)  The name and address of the proposed medical marihuana facility and any additional contact information deemed necessary by the city clerk; 
(5)  For the applicant, for each stakeholder of the applicant, and for each agent or employee of the applicant, an affirmation under oath as to whether they are at least 21 years of age and have never been indicted for, charged with, arrested for, convicted of or pled guilty or nolo contender to a felony or controlled substance related misdemeanor, and if not the case, then the name and location of the court, arresting agency, prosecuting agency, the case caption, the offense, the disposition and the location and length of incarceration, if applicable; 
(6)  A signed release authorizing the City of Taylor Police Department to perform a criminal background check to ascertain whether the applicant, each stakeholder of the applicant, each operator and employee of the applicant meet the criteria set forth in this chapter; 
(7)  The name, date of birth, physical address, copy of photo identification, and email address for any operator or employee of the medical marihuana facility, if other than the applicant; 
(8)  An affirmation under oath as to whether the applicant or operator has had a business license revoked or suspended, and if revoked or suspended, the reason(s) for such suspension or revocation; 
(9)  Proof that the applicant, operator and their employees are primary caregivers, if required under the MMMA and/or MMFA; 
(10)  Proof of ownership of the entire premises where the medical marihuana facility is to be operated or written consent from the property owner for use of the premises in a manner requiring licensure under this chapter along with a copy of the lease for the premises; 
(11)  Proof of an insurance policy covering the medical marihuana facility and naming the city as an additional insured party, available for the payment of any damages arising out of an act or omission of the applicant or its stakeholders, agents, employees, or subcontractors, in the amount of (a) at least $1,000,000.00 for property damage; (b) at least $2,000,000.00 for injury to one person; and, (c) at least $4,000,000.00 for injury to two or more persons resulting from the same occurrence. The insurance policy underwriter must have a minimum A.M. Best company insurance ranking of B+; 
(12)  A description of the security plan for the medical marihuana facility, including, but not limited to, any lighting, alarms, barriers, recording/monitoring devices and/or security guard arrangements proposed for the facility and premises. The security plan must contain the specification details of each piece of security equipment. Each medical marihuana facility must have a security guard present during business hours; 
(13)  A floor plan or blueprint drawn to scale by a State of Michigan licensed engineer or architect of the medical marihuana facility building and the location of same within the building if a multi-tenant building, together with details of how it is separated from the other occupants of the same building; 
(14)  An affidavit that neither the applicant nor any stakeholder of the applicant is in default to the city. Specifically, that the applicant or stakeholder of the applicant has not failed to pay any property taxes, special assessments, fines, fees or other financial obligations to the city; 
(15)  An affidavit that the transfer of marihuana to and from medical marihuana facilities shall be in compliance with the MMMA and/or MMFA; 
(16)  A staffing plan; 
(17)  Any proposed text or graphical materials to be shown on the exterior of the proposed medical marihuana facility; 
(18)  A patient education plan; 
(19)  A description of the process for tracking quantities and inventory controls for medical marihuana in any form; 
(20)  A business plan; 
(21)  A location area map of the medical marihuana facility and surrounding area that identifies the relative locations and the distances (closest property line to the subject facility's property line) between the medical marihuana facility and the following: a religious institution, a public park, a residential zoning district, a residential land use, a child care facility, a public or private educational facility including, but not limited to, pre-schools, nursery, elementary, secondary and high schools; 
(22)  A facility sanitation plan indicating how the waste will be stored and disposed of and how any marihuana will be rendered unusable upon disposal. Disposal by on-site burning or introduction in the sewerage system is prohibited; 
(23)  Verification, with copies of actual bank statements, showing that the applicant has liquid funds in the applicant's name in the amount needed to complete the medical marihuana facility, but in no event less than $250,000.00 of immediately available funds; 
(24)  As it relates to a medical marihuana grower facility, the following additional items shall be required: 
a.  A cultivation plan that includes at a minimum a description of the cultivation methods to be used, including plans for the growing mediums, treatments and/or additives; 
b.  A product testing plan that includes at a minimum a description of how and when samples for laboratory testing will be selected, what type of testing will be requested and how the test results will be used; 
c.  An affidavit that at least one primary caregiver, if required and permitted under the MMMA and/or MMFA, is to be involved in cultivation of marihuana and that no more than the permitted number of medical marihuana plants as set forth in the MMFA will be cultivated on the premises at any one time; 
d.  A chemical and pesticide storage plan that states the names of pesticides and chemicals to be used in cultivation, where and how pesticides and chemicals will be stored in the facility, the location of the required safety data sheets, and a plan for the disposal of unused pesticides; 
e.  All cultivation must be performed indoors and shall not be visible from any point outside the facility. 
(c)  Upon receipt of a completed medical marihuana facility application that meets the requirements of this chapter and confirmation that the number of existing licenses does not exceed the maximum number set forth in section 11-22(b), the city clerk shall forward a copy of the application to each of the following for their review and approval: the city attorney, the police department, the fire department, the department of public services, the planning director and the mayor. Once an application is verified by each department to be sufficiently complete and comprehensive, the application will receive a date stamp by the city clerk verifying the date the application is deemed complete. All medical marihuana facility applications stamped and dated by the city clerk as complete will be forwarded to the advisory committee as set forth in section 11-23(e). 
(d)  No application shall be approved unless: 
(1)  The fire department and the department of public services have inspected the proposed location for compliance with all applicable laws, codes and regulations; 
(2)  The applicant, each stakeholder of the applicant, and the employees and operators of the applicant, have passed an administrative background check and a criminal background check conducted by the police department; 
(3)  The planning and zoning director has confirmed that the proposed location complies with the requirements of this chapter and the City of Taylor zoning ordinance; 
(4)  The mayor's office has confirmed that the applicant and each stakeholder of the applicant are not in default to the city; 
(5)  The city attorney has completed a detailed review of the medical marihuana facility application for compliance with all applicable laws, regulations and ordinances; 
(6)  If the proposed location is not owned by the applicant, a notarized acknowledgement document executed by the owner of the property approving the purpose shall be required. 
(e)  All applications deemed complete pursuant section 11-23(c) shall be reviewed by an advisory committee consisting of a representative of the mayor's office, the city council chairperson or designee, a city councilmember designated by the city council chairperson, the police chief or designee, and the fire chief or designee. The advisory committee shall review the applications based upon the requirements of this chapter and recommend approval or denial of an application to the mayor and city clerk. The mayor and city clerk shall jointly make the determination as to whether a license will be issued to an applicant. Both the mayor and city clerk must agree in order for a license to be issued. If the mayor and city clerk determine that an applicant is to be granted a license, the city clerk shall issue the license to the applicant. All licenses issued are contingent upon the State of Michigan issuing a license for the operation of the facility in accordance with state law. 
(f)  Licensees shall report any other change in the information required by section 11-23 to the city clerk within ten days of the change. 
(Ord. No. 2018-497, § 1, 4-17-2018) 
Sec. 11-24. - Minimum operational standards for medical marihuana provisioning centers. 
    The minimum operational standards for medical marihuana provisioning centers shall be as follows: 
(a)  A medical marihuana provisioning center shall comply with the MMMA and MMFA, including, but not limited to, the requirements of MCL 333.27504, and the rules and regulations of the Michigan Department of Licensing and Regulatory affairs or any successor agency; 
(b)  No medical marihuana provisioning center shall be open between the hours of 9:00 p.m. and 9:00 a.m. 
(c)  Consumption of marihuana shall be prohibited on the premises of a medical marihuana provisioning center. A sign shall be posted on the premises of each medical marihuana provisioning center indicating that consumption is prohibited on the premises. 
(d)  Medical marihuana provisioning centers shall continuously monitor the entire premises with a surveillance system that includes security cameras. The video recordings shall be maintained in a secure off-site location for a period of 30 days. 
(e)  Unless otherwise permitted by the MMMA or the MMFA, public or common areas of the medical marihuana provisioning center must be separated from restricted or non-public areas of the facility by a permanent barrier. Unless permitted by the MMMA or the MMFA, no medical marihuana is permitted to be stored, displayed or transferred in an area accessible to the general public. 
(f)  All medical marihuana storage areas within medical marihuana provisioning center must be separated from any customer/patient areas by a permanent barrier. Unless permitted by the MMMA or MMFA, no medical marihuana is permitted to be stored in an area accessible by the general public or registered customers/patients. Medical marihuana may be displayed in a sales area only if permitted by the MMMA or MMFA. 
(g)  Any usable medical marihuana remaining on the premises of a medical marihuana provisioning center while the facility is not in operation shall be secured in a safe permanently affixed to the premises. 
(h)  Outdoor drive-through windows on the premises of a medical marihuana provisioning center shall not be permitted. Drive-through service may be permissible if all transactions take place indoors. 
(i)  No medical marihuana provisioning center shall be operated in a manner creating noise, dust, vibration, glare, fumes or odors detectable to normal senses beyond the boundaries of the property on which the facility is operated. 
(j)  The license required by this chapter shall be prominently displayed on the premises of a medical marihuana provisioning center. 
(k)  Disposal of medical marihuana shall be accomplished in a manner that prevents its acquisition by any person who may not lawfully possess it and shall otherwise be in compliance with state law. 
(l)  All medical marihuana delivered to a patient shall be packaged and labeled as provided by state law. 
(m)  All registered patients must present both their state issued medical marihuana patient/caregiver card and a driver's license or government issued identification card prior to entering restricted/limited areas or non-public areas of the medical marihuana provisioning center, and if no restricted/limited area is required, then promptly upon entering the medical marihuana provisioning center. 
(n)  The facility shall be open for inspection by the city at any time to confirm compliance with this chapter. An inspection may be conducted during the hours of operation and/or at any time anyone is present at the facility. 
(o)  It shall be prohibited to display any signs that are inconsistent with any local or state laws or applicable codes and regulations, including the City of Taylor zoning ordinance. All exterior signs, and all other interior signs or displays visible from the outside of the facility, shall be displayed in a manner that is consistent with the general character of the district in which the facility is located. The symbol or image of a marihuana leaf, or any other marihuana related symbols or paraphernalia, shall not be displayed on any exterior building signage or be otherwise visible from the outside of the facility. The size of any exterior sign shall not exceed 25 square feet. 
(p)  It shall be prohibited to use advertising material that is misleading, deceptive or false, or that is designed to appeal to minors. 
(q)  No licensed medical marihuana provisioning center shall place or maintain, or cause to be placed or maintained, an advertisement for medical marihuana in any form or through any medium. 
(1)  Within 1,000 feet of the real property comprising a public or private elementary, vocational or secondary school; and 
(2)  Within 100 feet of a public park, public or private youth center, public swimming pool or a church or other structure in which religious services are conducted. 
(r)  Certified laboratory testing results that display at a minimum the tetrahydrocannabinol (THC), Cannabidiol (CBD), total cannabinoid testing result and a pass/fail rating based on the certified laboratory's microbiological, mycotoxins and pesticide and solvent residue analyses must be available to all medical marihuana provisioning center patients/customers upon request. 
(Ord. No. 2018-497, § 1, 4-17-2018) 
Sec. 11-25. - Minimum operational standards for medical marihuana grower facilities. 
    The minimum operational standards for medical marihuana grower facilities shall be as follows: 
(a)  A medical marihuana grower facility shall comply with the MMMA and MMFA, including, but not limited to, the requirements of MCL 333.27501, and the rules and regulations of the Michigan Department of Licensing and Regulatory affairs or any successor agency; 
(b)  Consumption and/or use of medical marihuana shall be prohibited at a cultivation facility. 
(c)  All cultivation must be performed indoors and shall not be visible from any point outside the facility. 
(d)  The facility shall be open for inspection by the city at any time to confirm compliance with this chapter. An inspection may be conducted during the hours of operation and/or at any time anyone is present on the premises. 
(e)  Medical marihuana grower facilities shall continuously monitor the entire premises with a surveillance system that includes security cameras. The video recordings shall be maintained in a secure off-site location for a period of 30 days. 
(f)  A medical marihuana grower facility shall maintain a log book and/or database identifying by date the amount of medical marihuana and the number of medical marihuana plants on the premises which shall not exceed the amount permitted pursuant to the grower license issued by the State of Michigan. This log shall be available to law enforcement personnel to confirm that the facility does not have more medical marihuana than authorized at the location and shall not be used to disclose more information than is reasonably necessary to verify the lawful amount of medical marihuana at the facility. 
(g)  All medical marihuana plants will be tagged with unique identification that shall include the following: 
(1)  The date the plant was tagged; 
(2)  The expected harvest date; and, 
(3)  The strain name of the marihuana plant. 
(h)  All medical marihuana stored at the premises shall be contained within the building in a locked facility in accordance with the MMMA and MMFA. 
(i)  All necessary building, electrical plumbing and mechanical permits shall be obtained for any portion of the premises where electrical wiring, lighting and/or watering devices that support the cultivation, growing or harvesting of marihuana are located. 
(j)  That portion of the structure where the storage of any chemicals such as herbicides, pesticides and fertilizers shall be subject to inspection and approval by the Taylor Fire Department to ensure compliance with the applicable fire codes and regulations. 
(k)  The dispensing of medical marihuana at the medical marihuana grower facility shall be prohibited. 
(l)  There shall be no other accessory uses permitted within the same facility other than those associated with cultivating, processing or testing medical marihuana. Multi-tenant commercial buildings may permit accessory uses in suites segregated from a medical marihuana grower facility. 
(m)  All persons working in direct contact with medical marihuana shall conform to hygienic practices while on duty, including, but not limited to: 
(1)  Maintaining adequate personal cleanliness; 
(2)  Washing hands thoroughly in adequate hand-washing areas before starting work and at any other time when the hands may have become soiled or contaminated; and, 
(3)  Refraining from having direct contact with medical marihuana if the person has or may have an illness, open lesion, including boils, sores or infected wounds, or any other abnormal source of microbial contamination, until the condition is resolved. 
(n)  Litter and waste shall be properly removed and the operating systems for waste disposal shall be maintained in an adequate manner so that they do not constitute a source of contamination in areas where medical marihuana is exposed. 
(o)  Floors, walls and ceilings shall be constructed in such a manner that they may be adequately cleaned and kept clean and in good repair. 
(p)  There shall be adequate screening or other protection against the entry of pests. Rubbish shall be disposed of so as to minimize the development of odor and minimize the potential for the waste from becoming an attractant, harborage or breeding places for pests. 
(q)  All buildings, fixtures, structures and other facilities shall be maintained in a sanitary condition. 
(r)  Each facility shall provide its occupants with adequate and readily accessible toilet facilities that are maintained in a sanitary condition and good repair. 
(s)  Medical marihuana that can support the rapid growth of undesirable microorganisms shall be held in a manner that prevents the growth of these microorganisms. 
(t)  Medical marihuana grower facilities shall be free from infestation by insects, rodents, birds or vermin of any kind. 
(u)  Medical marihuana grower facilities shall produce no products other than useable medical marihuana intended for human consumption. 
(v)  No medical marihuana grower facility shall be operated in a manor creating noise, dust, vibrations, glare, fumes or odors detectible to the normal senses beyond the boundaries of the property on which the medical marihuana grower facility operates. 
(w)  Exterior signage or advertising identifying the facility as a Medical Marihuana Grower facility is prohibited. 
(Ord. No. 2018-497, § 1, 4-17-2018) 
Sec. 11-26. - Minimum operational standards for medical marihuana processor facilities. 
    The minimum operational standards for medical marihuana processor facilities shall be as follows: 
(a)  A medical marihuana processor facility shall comply with the MMMA and MMFA, including, but not limited to, the requirements of MCL 333.27502, and the rules and regulations of the Michigan Department of Licensing and Regulatory affairs or any successor agency. 
(b)  Consumption and/or use of medical marihuana shall be prohibited at a cultivation facility. 
(c)  All activity related to processing must be performed indoors and shall not be visible from any point outside the facility. 
(d)  The facility shall be open for inspection by the city at any time to confirm compliance with this chapter. An inspection may be conducted during the hours of operation and/or at any time anyone is present on the premises. 
(e)  Medical marihuana processor shall continuously monitor the entire premises with a surveillance system that includes security cameras. The video recordings shall be maintained in a secure off-site location for a period of 30 days. 
(f)  A medical marihuana processor facility shall maintain a log book and/or database identifying by date the amount of medical marihuana and all products created or processed at the facility. This information shall be available to law enforcement personnel to confirm compliance with this chapter and the MMFA. 
(g)  All medical marihuana stored at the premises shall be contained within the building in a locked facility in accordance with the MMMA and MMFA. 
(h)  All necessary building, electrical, plumbing and mechanical permits shall be obtained for any portion of the premises where the processing of medical marihuana is located. 
(i)  That portion of the structure where the storage of any chemicals used in the processing at the facility shall be subject to inspection and approval by the Taylor Fire Department to ensure compliance with the applicable fire codes and regulations. 
(j)  The dispensing of medical marihuana at the medical marihuana processor facility shall be prohibited. 
(k)  There shall be no other accessory uses permitted within the same facility other than those associated with processing medical marihuana. Multi-tenant commercial buildings may permit accessory uses in suites segregated from a medical marihuana processor facility. 
(l)  All persons working in direct contact with medical marihuana shall conform to hygienic practices while on duty, including, but not limited to: 
(1)  Maintaining adequate personal cleanliness; 
(2)  Washing hands thoroughly in adequate hand-washing areas before starting work and at any other time when the hands may have become soiled or contaminated; and, 
(3)  Refraining from having direct contact with medical marihuana if the person has or may have an illness, open lesion, including boils, sores or infected wounds, or any other abnormal source of microbial contamination, until the condition is resolved. 
(m)  Litter and waste shall be properly removed and the operating systems for waste disposal shall be maintained in an adequate manner so that they do not constitute a source of contamination in areas where medical marihuana is exposed. 
(n)  Floors, walls and ceilings shall be constructed in such a manner that they may be adequately cleaned and kept clean and in good repair. 
(o)  There shall be adequate screening or other protection against the entry of pests. Rubbish shall be disposed of so as to minimize the development of odor and minimize the potential for the waste from becoming an attractant, harborage or breeding places for pests. 
(p)  All buildings, fixtures, structures and other facilities shall be maintained in a sanitary condition. 
(q)  Each facility shall provide its occupants with adequate and readily accessible toilet facilities that are maintained in a sanitary condition and good repair. 
(r)  Medical marihuana that can support the rapid growth of undesirable microorganisms shall be held in a manner that prevents the growth of these microorganisms. 
(s)  Medical marihuana processor facilities shall be free from infestation by insects, rodents, birds or vermin of any kind. 
(t)  Medical marihuana processor facilities shall produce no products other than useable medical marihuana intended for human consumption. 
(u)  No medical marihuana processor facility shall be operated in a manor creating noise, dust, vibrations, glare, fumes or odors detectible to the normal senses beyond the boundaries of the property on which the medical marihuana processor facility operates. 
(v)  Exterior signage or advertising identifying the facility as a medical marihuana processor facility is prohibited. 
(Ord. No. 2018-497, § 1, 4-17-2018) 
Sec. 11-27. - Minimum operational standards of safety compliance facilities. 
    The minimum operational standards for safety compliance facilities shall be as follows: 
(a)  A safety compliance facility shall comply with the MMMA and MMFA, including, but not limited to, the requirements of MCL 333.27505, and the rules and regulations of the Michigan Department of Licensing and Regulatory affairs or any successor agency; 
(b)  No more than ten percent of the revenue generated by a safety compliance facility located in the city shall be derived from the testing of medical marihuana and/or medical marihuana related derivatives, products and/or services; 
(c)  Consumption and/or use of medical marihuana shall be prohibited at the facility; 
(d)  The facility shall be open for inspection by the city at any time to confirm compliance with this chapter. An inspection may be conducted during the hours of operation and/or at any time anyone is present at the facility; 
(e)  A safety compliance facility shall continuously monitor the entire premises with a surveillance system that includes security cameras. The video recordings shall be maintained in a secure off-site location for a period of 30 days. 
(f)  A safety compliance facility shall maintain a log book and/or database identifying by date the amount of medical marihuana on the premises and from which particular source. The facility shall maintain the confidentiality of qualifying patients in compliance with the MMMA and or MMFA; 
(g)  All medical marihuana stored at the premises shall be contained within the building in an enclosed, locked facility in accordance with the MMMA and/or MMFA; 
(h)  All persons working in direct contact with medical marihuana shall conform to hygienic practices while on duty; 
(i)  Litter and waste related to the testing of medical marihuana shall be properly removed and the operating system(s) for waste disposal shall be maintained in an adequate manner so that they do not constitute a source of contamination in areas where medical marihuana is exposed; 
(j)  Floors, walls and ceilings shall be constructed in such a manner that they may be adequately cleaned, and shall be kept clean and in good repair; 
(k)  Any buildings, fixtures and other facilities shall be maintained in a sanitary condition; 
(l)  Medical marihuana that can support the rapid growth of undesirable microorganisms shall be held in a manner that prevents the growth or spread of these microorganisms; and 
(m)  No safety compliance facility shall be operated in a manner that creates noise, dust, vibrations, glare, fumes or odors detectible to the normal senses beyond the boundaries of the property on which the safety compliance facility operates; and 
(n)  Exterior signage or advertising identifying the facility as a medical marihuana safety compliance facility is prohibited. 
(Ord. No. 2018-497, § 1, 4-17-2018) 
Sec. 11-28. - Minimum operational standards of secure transporter facilities. 
    The minimum operational standards for secure transporter facilities shall be as follows: 
(a)  A secure transporter facility shall comply with the MMMA and MMFA, including, but not limited to, the requirements of MCL 333.27505, and the rules and regulations of the Michigan Department of Licensing and Regulatory affairs or any successor agency; 
(b)  Consumption and/or use of medical marihuana shall be prohibited at the facility; 
(c)  The facility shall be open for inspection by the city at any time to confirm compliance with this chapter. An inspection may be conducted during the hours of operation and/or at any time anyone is present at the facility; 
(d)  A secure transporter facility shall continuously monitor the entire premises with a surveillance system that includes security cameras. The video recordings shall be maintained in a secure off-site location for a period of 30 days; 
(e)  A secure transporter facility shall maintain a log book and/or database identifying by date the amount of medical marihuana in its possession. The facility shall maintain the confidentiality of qualifying patients in compliance with the MMMA and/or MMFA; 
(f)  All medical marihuana stored at the premises shall be contained within the building in an enclosed, locked facility in accordance with the MMMA and/or MMFA; 
(g)  All persons working in direct contact with medical marihuana shall conform to hygienic practices while on duty; 
(h)  Floors, walls and ceilings shall be constructed in such a manner that they may be adequately cleaned, and shall be kept clean and in good repair; 
(i)  Any buildings, fixtures and other facilities shall be maintained in a sanitary condition; 
(j)  Medical marihuana that can support the rapid growth of undesirable microorganisms shall be held in a manner that prevents the growth or spread of these microorganisms; 
(k)  No secure transporter shall be operated in a manner that creates noise, dust, vibrations, glare, fumes or odors detectible to the normal senses beyond the boundaries of the property on which the facility operates; and 
(l)  Exterior signage or advertising identifying the facility as a medical marihuana secure transporter is prohibited. 
(Ord. No. 2018-497, § 1, 4-17-2018) 
Sec. 11-29. - Location of medical marihuana facilities. 
(a)  Medical marihuana facilities may only be located in the I-1 and I-2 zoning districts. All medical marihuana facilities are subject to the conditions and requirements set forth in the city's zoning ordinance. 
(b)  No medical marihuana facilities shall be located within 1,000 feet from the nearest lot lines of the following: a religious institution, a public park, a residential zoning district, a residential land use, a child care facility, a public or private educational facility including, but not limited to, pre-schools, nursery, elementary, secondary and high schools. The setback distance shall be measured as a straight line from the nearest points of the lot lines. 
(Ord. No. 2018-497, § 1, 4-17-2018) 
Sec. 11-30. - Denial and revocation. 
(a)  A license issued under this chapter may be revoked after an administrative hearing at which the mayor determines that any grounds for revocation under section 11-30(b) exist. Notice of the time and place of the hearing and the grounds for revocation must be given to the licensee at least five days prior to the date of the hearing, by first class mail to the address given on the license application or any address provided pursuant to section 11-23. 
(b)  A license applied for or issued under this chapter may be denied or revoked on any of the following basis: 
(1)  A violation of this chapter; 
(2)  Any conviction of or release from incarceration for a felony under the laws of this state or any other state, or the United States, within the past five years by the applicant or any stakeholder of the applicant as measured from the date of the application or the date of becoming a stakeholder, whichever occurs later, or while licensed under this chapter, or any conviction of a controlled substance related felony by the applicant or any stakeholder of the applicant; 
(3)  The commission of fraud or misrepresentation or the making of a false statement by the applicant or any stakeholder of the applicant while engaging in any activity for which this chapter requires a license; 
(4)  Sufficient evidence that the applicant(s) lack, or have failed to demonstrate, the requisite professionalism and/or business experience required to assure strict adherence to this chapter and the rules and regulations governing medical marihuana in the State of Michigan; 
(5)  A demonstrated history of excessive calls for public safety (police, fire and/or EMS) originating from the facility, being three or more calls within any 30-day period; 
(6)  The facility fails to open for business within six months of receiving a license from the city pursuant to this chapter; 
(7)  The facility ceases to operate for a period of six months; and 
(8)  The medical marihuana facility is determined by the city to have become a nuisance. 
(Ord. No. 2018-497, § 1, 4-17-2018) 
Sec. 11-31. - Penalties and discipline. 
(a)  The City of Taylor may require an applicant or licensee of a medical marihuana facility to produce documents, records or any other material pertinent to the investigation of an application or alleged violation of this chapter. Failure to provide the required material may be grounds for application denial, license revocation or other penalty provided in this chapter. 
(b)  Any person in violation of any provision of this chapter or any provision of a license issued under this chapter is responsible for a misdemeanor, punishable by a fine of up to $500.00 plus cost of prosecution, 90 days imprisonment, or both, for each violation. This section is not intended to prevent enforcement of any provision of the state law by the City of Taylor police department. 
(c)  The mayor may temporarily suspend a medical marihuana facility license without a hearing if the mayor finds that public safety or welfare requires emergency action. The mayor shall cause the temporary suspension by issuing a notice of suspension in connection with institution of proceedings for a hearing. 
(e)  If the mayor temporarily suspends a license without a hearing, the licensee is entitled to a hearing within 30 days after the notice of suspension has been issued. The hearing shall be limited to the issues cited in the notice of suspension. 
(f)  If the mayor does not hold a hearing within 30 days after the date of suspension was issued, then the suspended license shall be automatically reinstated and the suspension vacated. 
(Ord. No. 2018-497, § 1, 4-17-2018)

Sec. 12-19. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Age means chronological age, except as otherwise provided by law. 
    Housing accommodation includes improved or unimproved real property or a part thereof, which is used or occupied or is intended, arranged or designed to be used or occupied as the home or residence of one or more persons. 
    National origin includes the national origin of an ancestor. 
    Person means an individual, agent, association, corporation, joint apprenticeship committee, joint stock company, labor organization, legal representative, mutual company, partnership, receiver, trust, trustee in bankruptcy, unincorporated organization, the state or a political subdivision of the state or an agency thereof, or any other legal or commercial entity. 
    Political subdivision means a county, city, village, township, school district or special district or authority of the state. 
    Real estate broker or salesperson means a person, whether licensed or not, who, for or with the expectation of receiving a consideration, lists, sells, purchases, exchanges, rents, or leases real property: 
(1)  Negotiates or attempts to negotiate any of those activities; 
(2)  Holds himself out as engaged in those activities; 
(3)  Negotiates or attempts to negotiate a loan secured or to be secured by a mortgage or other encumbrance upon real property; 
(4)  Is engaged in the business of listing real property in a publication; or 
(5)  A person employed by or acting on behalf of a real estate broker or salesman. 
    Real estate transaction means the sale, exchange, rental or lease of real property or an interest therein. 
    Real property includes a building, structure, mobile home, real estate, land, mobile home park, trailer park, tenement, leasehold or an interest in a real estate cooperative or condominium located in the city. 
(Code 1987, § 8-16; Ord. No. 79-108, § 2, 2-13-1979) 
State Law reference- Similar definitions, MCL 37.2103, 37.2501. 
Sec. 12-20. - Recognition and reaffirmation of policy. 
    The opportunity to obtain housing and other real estate without discrimination because of religion, race, color, national origin, age, sex or marital status as prohibited by federal and state law is hereby recognized and reaffirmed in the city. 
(Code 1987, § 8-17; Ord. No. 79-108, § 1, 2-13-1979) 
Sec. 12-21. - Construction of article provisions. 
    Nothing in this article shall be construed to discourage real estate brokers or salespersons from engaging in the legitimate business practices of buying and selling real property in any neighborhood of the city to persons of any race, religion or nationality; or shall anything in this article be construed as discouraging any person or family of whatever race, religion or nationality from seeking real property in any neighborhood of the city. 
(Code 1987, § 8-18) 
Sec. 12-22. - Prohibited acts. 
(a)  A person engaging in a real estate transaction, or a real estate broker or salesman, shall not on the basis of religion, race, color, national origin, age, sex, familial status or marital status of a person or a person residing with that person: 
(1)  Refuse to engage in a real estate transaction with a person. 
(2)  Discriminate against a person in the terms, conditions, or privileges of a real estate transaction or in the furnishing of facilities or services in connection with a real estate transaction. 
(3)  Refuse to receive from a person or transmit to a person a bona fide offer to engage in a real estate transaction. 
(4)  Refuse to negotiate for a real estate transaction with a person. 
(5)  Represent to a person that real property is not available for inspection, sale, rental or lease when in fact it is so available, knowingly fail to bring a property listing to a person's attention, refuse to permit a person to inspect real property, or otherwise make unavailable or deny real property to a person. 
(6)  Make, print, circulate, post, mail, or otherwise cause to be made or published a statement, advertisement, notice or sign, or use a form of application for a real estate transaction, or make a record of inquiry in connection with a prospective real estate transaction, which indicates, directly or indirectly, an intent to make a preference, limitation, specification or discrimination with respect to the real estate transaction. 
(7)  Offer, solicit, accept, use, or retain a listing of real property with the understanding that a person may be discriminated against in a real estate transaction or in the furnishing of facilities or services in connection therewith. 
(8)  Discriminate against a person in the brokering or appraising of real property. 
(b)  A person shall not deny a person access to, membership or participation in, a multiple listing service, real estate brokers' organization or other service, organization, or facility relating to the business of selling or renting real property or to discriminate against any person in the terms or conditions of that access, membership, or participation because of religion, race, color, national origin, age, sex, familial status or marital status. 
(c)  This section is subject to section 12-23. 
(Code 1987, § 8-19; Ord. No. 79-108, § 3, 2-13-1979) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, MCL 37.2502. 
Sec. 12-23. - Exemptions from section 12-22. 
(a)  Section 12-22 does not apply to any of the following: 
(1)  The rental of a housing accommodation in a building that contains housing accommodations for not more than two families living independently of each other if the owner or a member of the owner's immediate family resides in one of the housing accommodations, or to the rental of room or rooms in a single-family dwelling by a person if the lessor or a member of the lessor's immediate family resides in the dwelling. 
(2)  The rental of a housing accommodation for not more than 12 months by the owner or lessor if it was occupied by the owner or lessor and maintained as the owner's or lessor's home for at least three months immediately preceding occupancy by the tenant and is maintained as the owner's or lessor's legal residence. 
(3)  With respect to the age provision and the familial status provision only, the sale, rental or lease of housing accommodations meeting the requirements of federal, state or local housing programs for senior citizens, or accommodations otherwise intended, advertised, designed or operated, bona fide, for the purpose of providing housing accommodations for persons 50 years of age or older. 
As used in this subsection, the term "immediate family" means a spouse, parent, child or sibling. 
(b)  Information relative to the marital status of an individual may be obtained when necessary for the preparation of a deed or other instrument of conveyance. 
(Code 1987, § 8-20; Ord. No. 79-108, § 4, 2-13-1979) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, MCL 37.2503. 
Sec. 12-24. - Application for financial assistance or financing; prohibited practices; nonapplicability. 
(a)  A person to whom application is made for financial assistance or financing in connection with a real estate transaction or in connection with the construction, rehabilitation, repair, maintenance, or improvement of real property, or a representative of that person, shall not: 
(1)  Discriminate against the applicant because of the religion, race, color, national origin, age, sex, familial status or marital status of the applicant or a person residing with the applicant. 
(2)  Use a form of application for financial assistance or financing or make or keep a record or inquiry in connection with an application for financial assistance or financing which indicates, directly or indirectly, a preference, limitation, specification or discrimination, as to the religion, race, color, national origin, age, sex, familial status, or marital status of the applicant or a person residing with the applicant. 
(b)  A person whose business includes engaging in real estate transactions shall not discriminate against a person because of religion, race, color, national origin, age, sex, familial status, or marital status, in the purchasing of loans for acquiring, constructing, improving, repairing, or maintaining a dwelling or the making or purchasing of loans or the provision of other financial assistance secured by residential real estate. 
(c)  Subsection (a)(2) of this section does not apply to a form of application for financial assistance prescribed for the use of a lender regulated as a mortgagee under the national housing act, chapter 847, 48 Stat. 1246, or by a regulatory board or officer acting under the statutory authority of this state or the United States. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, MCL 37.2504. 
Sec. 12-25. - Condition, restriction, or prohibition limiting use or occupancy of real property; exceptions; inserting or honoring void provision. 
(a)  A condition, restriction, or prohibition, including a right of entry or possibility of reverter, that directly or indirectly limits the use or occupancy of real property on the basis of religion, race, color, national origin, age, sex, familial status, or marital status is void, except a limitation of use as provided in section 12-23(a)(3) or on the basis of religion relating to real property held by a religious institution or organization, or by a religious or charitable organization operated, supervised or controlled by a religious institution or organization, and used for religious or charitable purposes. 
(b)  A person shall not insert in a written instrument relating to real property a provision that is void under this section or honor such a provision in the chain of title. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, MCL 37.2505. 
Sec. 12-26. - Representation of change in composition, value, behavior or quality of schools. 
    A person shall not represent, for the purpose of inducing a real estate transaction from which the person may benefit financially, that a change has occurred or will or may occur in the composition with respect to religion, race, color, national origin, age, sex, familial status or marital status of the owners or occupants in the block, neighborhood, or area in which the real property is located, or represent that this change will or may result in the lowering of property values, an increase in criminal or antisocial behavior, or a decline in the quality of schools in the block, neighborhood, or area in which the real property is located. 
(Code 1987, § 8-21; Ord. No. 79-108, § 5, 2-13-1979) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, MCL 37.2506. 
Sec. 12-27. - Use by landlord of reasonable accommodations. 
    This article does not preclude the use by a landlord of reasonable accommodations as required by section 102(2) of the Michigan handicappers' civil rights act, Public Act No. 220 of 1976 (MCL 37.1102). 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, MCL 37.2506. 
Chapter 14 - COMMUNITY DEVELOPMENT[1] 
Footnotes:

State Law reference- Housing and slums clearance projects, MCL 125.651 et seq.; housing corporation law, MCL 125.601 et seq.; urban redevelopment corporations, MCL 125.901 et seq.; rehabilitation of blighted areas, MCL 125.71 et seq.; industrial development revenue bond act of 1963, MCL 125.1251 et seq.; economic development corporations, MCL 125.1601 et seq.; downtown development authority, MCL 125.1651 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 14-1. - Revenue bonds. 
    The city council is authorized to issue revenue bonds pursuant to the industrial development revenue bond act of 1963, Public Act No. 62 of 1963 (MCL 125.1251 et seq.). The economic welfare of the city must be benefited by any such bond issue. The city council shall adopt separate resolutions on each individual manufacturer or business concern seeking the support of the city for a revenue bond issue spelling out such specifications as may be necessary in the resolution authorizing the issuance of bonds. 
(Code 1987, § 9-1; Ord. No. 74-39, § 8, 10-9-1974) 
Sec. 14-2. - Development plans and tax increment financing plans. 
    The following development plans and tax increment financing plans have been created and are on file in the office of the city clerk: 
(1)  Northern Corridor and Eureka Road Project; 
(2)  Northern Corridor, Eureka Corridor and Trolley-Beverly Area Project; 
(3)  Northern Corridor, Eureka Corridor, Trolley-Beverly Area and Northline Area Project; 
(4)  Telegraph and Golf District. 
(Code 1987, § 9-2; Ord. No. 83-133, 5-17-1983; Ord. No. 83-139, 12-13-1983; Ord. No. 84-144, 12-18-1984) 
State Law reference- Tax increment financing authority act, MCL 125.1801 et seq. 
Secs. 14-3-14-22. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - DEPARTMENT OF COMMUNITY DEVELOPMENT 

Sec. 14-23. - Created. 
    There is hereby created a department of community development. 
(Code 1987, § 9-16; Ord. No. 74-39, § 3, 10-9-1974) 
Sec. 14-24. - Appointment of director; compensation. 
    The administrative head of the department of community development shall be the director of community development who shall be appointed by the mayor according to the provisions of the city Charter, and the compensation shall be fixed as determined by the city council. 
(Code 1987, § 9-17; Ord. No. 74-39, §§ 3, 4(a), 10-9-1974) 
Sec. 14-25. - Qualifications of director. 
    The director of community development shall hold no license to sell, appraise or otherwise handle in any way real estate, nor be connected with any industrial organization or financing institution. 
(Code 1987, § 9-18; Ord. No. 74-39, § 5(a), 10-9-1974) 
Sec. 14-26. - Powers and duties of director. 
    The director of community development shall have such powers, duties and responsibilities as provided by the mayor, city Charter, this article and state law. The director shall: 
(1)  Confer with and advise the mayor, city council, citizens, local group organizations, the city planning department and planning commission and other appropriate governmental departments on all development in the city; 
(2)  Coordinate all industrial and commercial proposals with the appropriate city departments; 
(3)  Advertise industrial and commercial advantages and opportunities of the city within the means provided by any budgeted appropriations or grants; 
(4)  Collect data and information as to the type of industries and commercial business best suited for the city and make recommendations to proper city authorities; 
(5)  Develop, compile, and coordinate information in regard to available areas suitable for industrial and commercial development; 
(6)  Encourage the proper zoning and orderly development of areas suitable for industrial and commercial development and promote the interest of industrial and commercial areas of the city; 
(7)  Cooperate with all industries and businesses in the city in the satisfactory solution of any community problems they might have; 
(8)  After consultation with departments involved, recommend to the mayor and council the elimination or modification of any regulations which appear to place restrictions or burdens or handicaps on business and industry; 
(9)  Investigate complaints of lack of expeditious treatment of requests for information or consideration of any problems affecting business or industry; 
(10)  Develop and coordinate the processing of all applications for county, state and federal grants which might apply to community development or which might enable the city to improve or expand community services. 
(Code 1987, § 9-19; Ord. No. 74-39, § 5(b), 10-9-1974) 
Secs. 14-27-14-55. - Reserved.

ARTICLE V. - HOUSING COMMISSION[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference- Authority to create, MCL 125.653. 

Sec. 14-110. - Created. 
    Pursuant to Public Act No. 18 of the extra sessions of 1933 (MCL 125.651 et seq.), a housing commission is hereby created. 
(Code 1987, § 9-76; Ord. No. 83, § 1, 5-29-1967) 
Sec. 14-111. - Powers and duties generally; payments in lieu of taxes. 
(a)  The housing commission shall have all of the powers necessary to carry out the purposes for which it was created and those incident thereto, including all powers granted by Public Act No. 18 of 1933, extra session (MCL 125.651 et seq.) (Act 18), and any power prescribed by ordinance or resolution of the city relating to housing facilities the city or the housing commission may own, lease, operate, maintain or administer. The housing commission shall also have the authority to act as a borrower for purposes of issuing bonds or notes under Act 18 and exercising all powers conferred upon a borrower by Act 18. The powers herein granted shall be in addition to those granted by any statute, charter, ordinance or resolution, and the enumeration of any power either in city ordinance or in Act 18 shall not be construed as a limitation upon such general powers. 
(b)  All deeds, mortgages, contracts, leases, purchase or other agreements regarding real property shall be approved and executed in the name of the housing commission. Any rights to property owned by the city which are under the control of the housing commission may be conveyed or assigned to the housing commission and the mayor and clerk shall have the authority to take all action necessary to implement and accomplish such conveyances and assignments. 
(c)  Unless otherwise provided by ordinance, all property exempt by Act 18 from ad valorem property taxes may be subject to an annual service fee in lieu of taxes at the maximum rate authorized by law of the annual shelter rent obtained from the project or facility. 
(Code 1987, § 9-77; Ord. No. 97-302, 10-21-1997)

ARTICLE VII. - DOWNTOWN DEVELOPMENT[4] 
Footnotes: 
--- (4) ---
