In addition to any other remedy available to the city under this article, when an agent, officer or employee of the city identifies litter, trash or rubbish upon private property, written notice may be provided to the owner and occupant, instructing the recipient to remove such litter, trash and rubbish from the premises. Notice to the owner shall be made via the U.S. Post Office and to the occupant by posting notice in a conspicuous location on the premises. Upon the failure, neglect or refusal of the owner or occupant to properly remove and dispose of such items within 14 days after the written notice was sent via the U.S. Post Office to such owner and posted on the property, the city shall be authorized and empowered to remove and dispose of such item at the owner's and/or occupant's expense. 
(2)  Emergency disposal of litter, trash and rubbish by city. Where litter, trash or rubbish creates an emergency that presents an immediate risk of harm to people or damage to property, the city shall be authorized and empowered to enter the premises to remove and dispose of such items without notice to the owner or occupant. The costs of such removal shall be charged to the owner and/or occupant. 
(3)  Charge for disposal included in tax bill. When the city has removed and disposed of such item pursuant to subsection (b)(1) or (2) of this section, the actual cost thereof, plus accrued interest at the rate of six percent per annum from the date of the completion of the work, if not paid for by such owner or occupant prior thereto, may be charged to the owner of such property on the next regular tax bill forwarded to such owner by the city. The charge shall be due and payable by the owner at the time of the receipt of such bill. 
(4)  Recorded statement constitutes lien. Where the full amount due the city is not paid by the owner within 30 days after the removal of the litter, trash or rubbish, as provided for in subsection (b) of this section, then the full amount shall constitute a lien and privilege on the property, and shall remain in full force and effect for the amount due in principal and interest, plus costs of court, if costs and expenses shall be collected in the manner fixed by law for the collection of taxes and shall be subject to a delinquent penalty of five percent if the same is not paid in full on or before the date the tax bill upon which the charge appears becomes delinquent. 
(c)  Abandoned property, materials and vehicles. No person, firm, corporation, owner or occupier of land, or any other legal entity, shall place or store upon public or private property, or upon any premises within the city, any abandoned property, abandoned materials, abandoned vehicles, junk vehicles, used parts thereof or unused building materials, unless the same is wholly contained within a fully enclosed building and does not violate any zoning or building laws of the city, county or state. 
(1)  Notice to landowner or occupant. In addition to any other remedy available to the city under this article, when an agent, officer or employee of the city identifies abandoned materials, abandoned property, abandoned vehicles, junk vehicles, used parts of junk vehicles or unused building materials upon private property, the city shall be permitted to enter the premises for the purpose of removing such items, if written notice is provided to the owner and posted conspicuously on the premises, instructing the recipient to remove such abandoned property, materials and vehicles from the premises. Such notice should be provided to the owner and occupant of the premises as described in subsection (b)(1) of this section. 
(2)  Emergency disposal of abandoned property, materials and vehicles by city. Where abandoned property, materials, unused building materials or vehicles create an emergency that presents an immediate risk of harm to people or damage to property, the city shall be authorized and empowered to enter the premises remove and dispose of such items without notice to the owner or occupant. The costs of such removal shall be charged to the owner and/or occupant as provided in subsections (b)(3) and (4) of this section. 
(3)  Dispute of city's classification of item as abandoned, junk or unused; opportunity for hearing; disposal by the city. If the owner or occupant of the premises where abandoned property, abandoned materials, abandoned vehicles, junk vehicles, used parts of junk vehicles, or unused building materials have been identified disputes the city's classification of such items as abandoned, junk vehicle or unused building material; the owner may request a hearing before the building department hearing officer within ten days of the date the notice was sent by the U.S. Post Office and posted on the premises. In nonemergency situations, the hearing shall be scheduled no sooner than 14 days after notice of the violation is mailed to the owner and occupant of the premises. For the purposes of this subsection, the term "nonemergency situation" means a situation that does not constitute a threat to the public interest, safety or welfare. 
a.  At such a hearing, the owner or occupant of the premises must demonstrate that the item in question should not be classified as abandoned, junk vehicle or unused building material. Testimony and evidence shall be heard from: 
1.  The city; 
2.  The owner or occupant of the premises; and 
3.  Any other interested party. 
The type, manner and scope of evidence considered shall be within the discretion of the hearing officer and is not limited by the rules of evidence. 
b.  Not more than five days after the close of the hearing, the building department hearing officer shall issue a written decision containing the building department hearing officer's findings and either close the proceedings or order that the item in question be removed from the property by the owner or occupant. 
c.  If the building department hearing officer finds that the item constitutes abandoned property, abandoned materials or an abandoned vehicle, and, consequently must be removed from the premises, the building department hearing officer shall issue an order requiring the owner or occupant to remove such item by a specified date. If the owner or occupant fails to remove the item from the premises by the date specified by the building department hearing officer, the city may enter the premises and remove and dispose of such item at the owner's and/or occupant's expense, consistent with subsections (b)(3) and (4) of this section. 
d.  Copies of the building department hearing officer's decision and order shall be sent by the U.S. Post Office to the owner and posted on the premises, consistent with the notice provision contained in subsection b(1) of this section. 
e.  Where the building department hearing officer determines that abandoned property, materials or vehicles exist, the owner or occupant of the premises may file an appeal within 28 days after entry of the decision and order by the building department hearing officer. All appeals will be heard by the city council. The city council shall enter a final written decision not more than five days after the close of the hearing, either affirming the findings of the building department hearing officer or closing the proceedings. If the city council affirms the building department hearing officer's decision, it shall enter a final order specifying a date by which the owner or occupant of the premises must comply, as described in subsection (c)(3)c of this section. If the owner and/or occupant fail to comply by the date specified, the city may enter the premises and remove and dispose of the abandoned property, materials or vehicles at the owner's and/or occupant's expense, as provided in subsections (b)(3) and (4) of this section. 
(d)  Penalties for violation of ordinance prohibiting litter, trash and rubbish, improper disposal of residential waste and recyclables; abandoned materials, property and vehicles. A violation of this section shall be deemed to be a municipal civil infraction. The following civil fines shall apply in the event of a determination of responsibility for a violation of any portion of this article: 
(1)  First offense. The civil fine for a first offense violation shall be in an amount of $150.00, plus cost and other sanctions, for each offense. In addition to ordering the defendant determined to be responsible for a municipal civil infraction to pay civil fines, costs, damages and expenses, the judge or magistrate shall be authorized to issue any judgment, writ or order necessary to enforce, or enjoin violation of this article. 
(2)  Second offenses The civil fine for a second offense violation shall be in an amount of $300.00, plus cost and other sanctions, for each offense. In addition to ordering the defendant determined to be responsible for a municipal civil infraction to pay civil fines, costs, damages and expenses, the judge or magistrate shall be authorized to issue any judgment, writ or order necessary to enforce or enjoin violation of this article. 
(3)  Third or subsequent offenses. Any person, firm, or corporation who violates any of the provisions of this article for a third or subsequent time shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor and shall be punished by a fine of not more than $500.00, or by imprisonment for a period of not to exceed 90 days, or by both such fine and imprisonment. 
(4)  Continuing offenses. Each day that a violation continues to exist shall constitute a separate offense. 
(5)  Remedies not exclusive. In addition to any remedies provided for in this article, any equitable or other remedies available may be sought. The district judge shall also be authorized to impose costs, damages and expenses as provided by law. 
(Code 1987, § 15-28; Ord. No. 82-128, § 17, 9-28-1982; Ord. No. 09-438, § 15-28, 8-4-2009; Ord. No. 11-458, § 1, 4-19-2011) 
Sec. 20-184. - Collection. 
(a)  Compostable yard waste. It shall be the duty of owners, proprietors or persons in charge of every dwelling house, store, or other buildings in the city to separate compostable yard wastes from other garbage, solid waste or rubbish and to place the same in secured paper bags, as designated by the director of the department of public works, or solid waste containers in a size and of such quality as defined by this section. The same shall be placed at the curb on the normal pickup day, but shall be segregated from other garbage and rubbish placed there to facilitate its pickup so that compostable yard wastes are not picked up for disposal as are the normal garbage, solid waste and rubbish. Compostable material shall be placed at least ten feet away from the other garbage, solid waste and rubbish to be picked up and parallel to the right-of-way. Bags or containers of compostable yard waste may be rejected, that is, not collected, if they contain mixed waste or are otherwise not acceptable because of kind or capacity. Rejected bags or containers shall be clearly tagged with the reason for the rejection and that they shall be immediately removed by the owners or occupiers of the land, or by the proprietors or persons in charge, and may be placed out for the next collection. If such rejected yard waste is left at the curb, the person responsible will be subject to the enforcement action under the penalty provisions of this Code. 
(b)  Placement of containers for collection. All residential, commercial and multiple-dwelling solid waste, recyclable materials and yard waste intended for disposal by the city's disposal contractor shall be placed in containers, as described in section 20-186 and shall be placed at the street, or such other location indicated by the director of public services, for collection by the city's disposal contractor. No container shall be placed for collection until 6:00 p.m., the night before scheduled collection, and all empty containers shall be removed from the collection point no later than 8:00 p.m. the day of collection. 
(c)  License required for collection. No person shall collect, transport, deliver, dispose or remove any solid or yard waste or recyclable material generated within the city without first obtaining a license for such from the city. Such a license shall be issued upon application to the city clerk and upon payment of the license fee, as prescribed by council resolution, to the city. This section shall not prohibit lawncare services from removing yard waste from the customer's premises without a license. 
(d)  License holder requirements. It shall be an express condition of each license under this article that the holder of the license shall comply with: 
(1)  All rules, regulations and ordinances of the city and all provisions of this article; 
(2)  All applicable federal, state, county and local laws, statutes, rules, regulations and ordinances, including, but not limited to, those pertaining to the collection, transportation, delivery and disposal of residential: 
a.  Solid wastes; 
b.  Recyclable materials; and 
c.  Yard waste. 
(3)  All applicable rules and regulations of any and all disposal sites, recycling centers and/or composting sites utilized, for the city by the possessor of the license, for the disposal of: 
a.  Waste; 
b.  Recyclables; or 
c.  Yard waste. 
(e)  Containers to be weathertight. All vehicles or containers used for the collection and transfer of solid waste, recyclables or yard waste, shall be weathertight and of such construction and operated so that its contents do not: 
(1)  Spill upon the public ways; or 
(2)  Otherwise create a nuisance. 
(Code 1987, § 15-29; Ord. No. 82-128, § 18, 9-28-1982; Ord. No. 95-276, § 2, 4-4-1995; Ord. No. 99-332, § 2, 5-18-1999; Ord. No. 99-336, § 1, 8-17-1999; Ord. No. 09-438, § 15-29, 8-4-2009; Ord. No. 11-458, § 1, 4-19-2011) 
Sec. 20-185. - Recycling. 
(a)  Recyclables. All persons who are owners, lessees or occupants of residential dwellings shall dispose of recyclable materials, as defined in this article and amended from time to time, only through the use of the city's curbside and dropoff recycling program. No recyclables shall be disposed with either solid waste or yard waste. 
(1)  All recyclables shall be separated from solid waste and yard waste and prepared for curbside collection and placed in the proper container for collection as follows: 
a.  Newsprint and paper recyclables. Newspaper and paper (i.e., magazines, catalogs, junk mail, office paper and phone books). Newsprint and paper recyclables shall not be bundled in plastic or trash bags. 
b.  Glass recyclables. Only clear glass bottles, jars and containers shall be accepted and shall be rinsed and cleaned of all contents. 
c.  Plastic recyclables. Plastic jugs, bottles, household plastics and plastic grocery bags shall be accepted and shall be rinsed and cleaned of all contents. 
d.  Metal recyclables. Only ferrous and nonferrous cans and lids shall be accepted and shall be rinsed cleaned of all contents. Only metal products capable of fitting into the recyclable container shall be acceptable for curbside collection and no combined products, i.e., metal on plastic, shall be accepted. 
e.  Cardboard and paperboard. Cardboard and paperboard shall be flattened and cut into pieces to fit in recyclable cart. No wax coated paperboard will be accepted. 
(2)  If the city is operating a dropoff collection site for recyclables, larger recyclable products and/or other acceptable recyclable items shall be disposed of at that site. 
(b)  Yard wastes. All persons who generate residential and commercial yard waste shall separate the yard waste from other solid waste and recyclables for collection by the city's disposal contractor for composting. This section shall not prohibit lawn care services from removing yard waste from the customer's premises. 
(Code 1987, § 15-29.5; Ord. No. 99-332, § 3, 5-18-1999; Ord. No. 09-438, § 15-29.5, 8-4-2009; Ord. No. 11-458, § 1, 4-19-2011) 
Sec. 20-186. - Maintenance of private property. 
(a)  Responsibility of owner, occupant. The owner, occupier or person in control of any private property shall at all times maintain the premises free of litter; provided, however, that this section shall not prohibit the storage of litter in authorized private receptacles for collection. The occupier of any private premises shall, at least once in each calendar week, collect and dispose of all litter on such private premises in authorized receptacles. This includes the disposition of litter on adjoining sidewalks, boulevards, gutters, adjoining or abutting streets to the centerlines thereof and adjoining or abutting alleys to the centerlines thereof. A person who violates this section shall be responsible for a municipal civil infraction. 
(b)  Containers. The following regulations for solid waste containers are hereby established: 
(1)  Trash containers. 
a.  For residential rubbish and recycling, only the city-issued, 64 or 96-gallon containers will be allowed for use. Each residence will be provided one container for rubbish and one for recycling. The container will be the property of the City of Taylor and must remain at the address. Additional containers will be available for lease. 
b.  The container shall be not less than 10.6 mils plus or minus 0.6 mils thick and shall weigh not less than 2,507 grams. 
c.  All handles must be an integral part of the original mold and be able to support 300 pounds. 
d.  The lid must have a snaplock fit with the weight not less than 522 grams. 
e.  The container must: 
1.  Have a taper of not less than three percent; 
2.  Not be less than 22.20 inches in height; and 
3.  Be 19.46 inches in diameter. 
f.  The container: 
1.  Must be able to withstand temperature extremes from 30 degrees below zero degrees Fahrenheit to 212 degrees Fahrenheit; 
2.  The resin used must have ultraviolet light inhibitor additives; 
3.  The upper 25 percent of the container must be recessed to provide rigidity of the circumference; and 
4.  Must be NSF-approved for solid waste under NSF rule No. 21. 
g.  The city shall not be responsible for any damage to plastic trash containers. 
(2)  Metal trash containers. 
a.  Every metal trash container shall have not less than a 20-gallon capacity and not more than a 26-gallon capacity. 
b.  The container shall have sides of not less than 28-gauge USS and a bottom of not less than 29-gauge USS. 
c.  The rim of the container shall be reinforced with wire. 
d.  The container shall have no less than 0.002 inches of hot bath zinc coating. 
e.  The bottom of the container shall be reinforced by means of a heavy metal band. 
f.  The sides of the container shall be tapered. 
g.  All sides of the container are to be made with corrugated steel. 
h.  Each container must be provided with a tightly secured lid. 
i.  All containers shall have handles. 
(3)  Recyclable containers. 
a.  Recyclables shall be stored and placed for collection by the city's disposal contractor as allowed for solid waste. 
b.  Recyclables shall be stored and placed for collection by the city's disposal contractor in the proper container as provided by the City of Taylor. 
c.  The user of the container so provided shall be responsible for the container and shall be responsible for the cost, as established by the city council, for replacement containers if the original container is lost, stolen or destroyed. 
d.  Extra containers may be leased from the city. 
e.  Recyclables not within the proper container or improperly prepared will not be collected. 
(4)  Disposable solid waste containers. Rubbish must be placed in plastic bags prior to placing in container for disposal. 
(5)  Waterproof, sharp edges. All solid waste containers shall be maintained to ensure the secure placement of the lid, shall be waterproof, shall be free of ragged or sharp edges or any other defect liable to hamper or injure a collector. 
(6)  Time for placing and removing containers. No person occupying or in possession of any premises where solid waste is scheduled to be picked up shall place any container containing solid waste at the place of pickup before 6:00 p.m. of the day preceding the scheduled collection of the solid waste. No person shall leave any such container at the place of collection after 8:00 p.m. of the day of actual collection. 
(7)  Seizure and destruction of defective compost containers. The director of public works is empowered and authorized to seize and destroy all solid waste containers that are determined nonusable or in too poor repair for collection purposes. The owner or tenant will be given a seven-day written notice to replace the defective compost containers prior to the seizure. 
(c)  Preparation of solid waste material for collection. Bulky rubbish such as refrigerators, stoves, water heaters and similarly sized household items or items that will not fit in rubbish container, will be collected by special pickup for a fee established by city council. 
(d)  Material not to be collected. Bricks, gravel, rocks, dirt, sod, concrete and other building material will not be collected. 
(Code 1987, § 15-30; Ord. No. 82-128, § 15, 9-28-1982; Ord. No. 95-276, § 3, 4-4-1995; Ord. No. 99-332, § 4, 5-18-1999; Ord. No. 06-415, § 2, 10-3-2006; Ord. No. 09-438, § 15-30, 8-4-2009; Ord. No. 11-458, § 1, 4-19-2011) 
Sec. 20-187. - Maintenance of places of businesses. 
(a)  All persons occupying any place of business shall keep such place of business, including the sidewalk, parkway, boulevard, gutter, street to the centerline thereof and alley to the centerline thereof adjoining or abutting the place so occupied free and clear of litter. 
(b)  No person or authority owning, occupying, or in control of a place of business shall sweep into or deposit or cause to be swept into or deposited in any sidewalk, boulevard, gutter, street or alley or other public place within the city an accumulation of litter from any place of business. 
(c)  The operator of a drive-in restaurant shall at least once in each 12-hour period during which the restaurant is open for business collect and dispose, in authorized receptacles, all litter on the premises of such drive-in restaurant, including the adjoining or abutting sidewalk, boulevard, gutter, street to the centerline thereof and alley to the centerline thereof. 
(d)  The occupier of a place of business and the authority in control of the public building shall, at least once in each 24-hour period during which it is open for business or open to the public, collect and dispose of all litter on the premises of such place of business or public building in authorized receptacles, including litter from the adjoining or abutting sidewalk, boulevard, gutter, street to the centerline thereof and alley to the centerline thereof. 
(e)  For the purposes of this section, the operator of any shopping center shall be deemed to be the occupier of all common areas of such shopping center, including, but not limited to, the parking area, parking lots, and landscaped areas which are not leased or rented to any particular tenant. However, the operator of the shopping center shall not be deemed the occupier of any sidewalks, boulevards, or gutters adjoining or abutting any premises rented to a particular tenant. 
(Code 1987, § 15-31; Ord. No. 82-128, § 6, 9-28-1982; Ord. No. 09-438, § 15-31, 8-4-2009) 
Sec. 20-188. - Solid waste dumpsters for commercial businesses. 
(a)  Required; provided by business. Any person using or occupying any commercial business in the city shall provide and maintain in good order and repair solid waste dumpsters of sufficient number to contain the garbage or trash that will accumulate on the premises. All commercial businesses in the city shall be required to dispose of all garbage in solid waste dumpsters approved by the director of public works. 
(b)  Specifications. All garbage and solid waste for collection by the city from commercial businesses in the city shall be placed in solid waste dumpsters. Solid waste dumpsters used for storage or solid waste materials shall meet the specifications set out in this subsection. Such dumpsters shall be made of metal and equipped with covers and handles so as to be easily handled. The metal containers shall be watertight. Each solid waste dumpster shall be without inside protrusions, and the solid waste shall be loosely packed such that the contents will discharge freely when the dumpster is inverted. Additionally, each dumpster shall be weighted to prevent spillage. The City of Taylor shall issue regulations with respect to the minimum and maximum weights of dumpsters when empty and when fully loaded. 
(c)  Placement on cement surfaces. Solid waste dumpsters used by commercial businesses in the city shall, without exception, be placed on cement surfaces no smaller, per dumpster, than five-foot by eight-foot. 
(d)  Deteriorated, damaged solid waste dumpsters. Solid waste dumpsters which have deteriorated or have been damaged to the extent that the covers will not fit securely or those having jagged or sharp edges capable of causing injury to solid waste collectors or other persons whose duty it is to handle containers are declared a nuisance and shall be condemned by the director of public works. If such dumpsters are not removed within five days after notice of the defective condition to the owner or user, such solid waste dumpsters may be confiscated. 
(Code 1987, § 15-32; Ord. No. 82-128, §§ 19-22, 9-28-1982; Ord. No. 09-438, § 15-32, 8-4-2009; Ord. No. 11-458, § 1, 4-19-2011) 
Secs. 20-189-20-214. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VI. - SOIL EXCAVATION AND FILLING[6] 

Footnotes: 
--- (6) --- 
State Law reference- Soil conservation districts law, MCL 324.9301 et seq.; soil erosion and sedimentation control, MCL 324.9101 et seq. 

Sec. 20-215. - Purpose. 
    The purpose of this article is: 
(1)  To promote the public health, safety and general welfare of the residents of the city; 
(2)  To preserve the natural resources; 
(3)  To prevent the creation of nuisances and hazards to the health, safety and general welfare by: 
a.  The regulation of the removal of topsoil, subsoil, sand, gravel, earth and other materials from lands located within the city; 
b.  The regulation of depositing and dumping of sand, gravel, earth, rock, stone, concrete, minerals and other materials on land located within the city; 
c.  Providing for the issuance of permits for such activities; 
d.  Providing for fees; 
e.  Prescribing the rules and regulations and conditions for the issuance of such permits; and 
f.  Providing for bonds to ensure satisfactory performance of the terms of this article. 
(Code 1987, § 26-16; Ord. No. 75-70, § 2, 9-9-1975) 
Sec. 20-216. - Permit required. 
    The use of land for the removal or stripping of topsoil, clay, sand, gravel, muck, stones, rock, aggregates or other materials from the land by any person or filling of the land is not permitted in any district in the city without securing a permit from the director of building and safety. The fee for such permit shall be established by resolution of the city council. No permits shall be required for excavation for which a building permit has been issued. No fee, nor permit shall be required of any person dumping 12 cubic yards or less of earthen materials only. Larger amounts of earthen fill for residential lots may be permitted subject to review by the director of building and safety. 
(Code 1987, § 26-17; Ord. No. 75-70, § 3, 9-9-1975) 
Sec. 20-217. - Removal, excavation, stripping. 
(a)  Application for permit. An application for a permit to remove, excavate or strip topsoil, clay, sand, gravel, muck, stones, rock, aggregates or other materials from the land shall be requested in writing to the director of building and safety containing the following information: 
(1)  Names and addresses of parties of interest in the premises setting forth their legal interest in premises; 
(2)  Full legal description of the premises wherein operations are proposed; 
(3)  Topographical survey map at a scale of one inch equals 100 feet showing existing grades on a two-foot contour interval of the land prior to any excavation, the grades of the proposed excavations and the finished grades to show a suitable storm drainage scheme, prepared and sealed by a registered civil engineer or land surveyor; 
(4)  Detailed proposal as to the method of operation which is in compliance with article III of this chapter, what type of machinery or equipment will be used, and estimated period of time that such operation will cover; 
(5)  Detailed statement as to exactly what type of deposit is proposed to be extracted; 
(6)  Proposed method of filling excavation where quarrying results in extensive undersurface extension; 
(7)  Such other information as may be reasonably required by the director of building and safety on which to base an opinion as to whether a permit should or should not be issued. 
(b)  Bond. Before issuance of a permit, there shall be filed by the applicant a surety bond, executed by a reputable surety company authorized to do business in the state, running to the city in an amount established by the director of building and safety conditioned upon the prompt and complete compliance with all the provisions of this article and requirements of the city. The director of building and safety in establishing the amount of the bond, shall consider the scale of the operations, the prevailing cost to rehabilitate the property upon default of the operator, and other reasonable expenses. 
(c)  Issuance, term, expiration date of permit. After considering all of the available facts, the director of building and safety may issue a permit conditioned upon compliance of the permit holder with all of the requirements of this section and if the director of building and safety finds the proposed activity is: 
(1)  Compatible with adjacent uses of land; 
(2)  Not injurious to adjacent property, surrounding neighborhoods, or the community as a whole; and 
(3)  Compatible with the natural environment. 
The director of building and safety may deny, approve or conditionally approve any request regulated by this article. Any decision on a permit shall state the findings of fact and specify the conclusions drawn therefrom and any conditions imposed thereon. Any conditions imposed shall remain unchanged except upon the written mutual consent of the landowners and the director of building and safety, and which shall be maintained on file in the building department. If a permit is issued pursuant to this section, it shall be for a period of one year or less, expiring on March 31 of each year, and may be renewed annually upon payment of an additional permit fee and contingent upon compliance with the terms of the previously issued permit. 
(d)  Procedures, specifications. In addition to subsection (c) of this section, the following requirements are mandatory: 
(1)  No cut or excavation shall be made closer than 500 feet from the nearest street, highway or alley right-of-way line or nearer than 200 feet to the nearest property line; provided, however, that the director of building and safety may prescribe more strict requirements in order to give sublateral support to surrounding property where soil or geographic conditions warrant it. 
(2)  No soil, sand, clay, gravel or similar materials shall be removed in such a manner as to cause water to stand or accumulate or to result in a place of danger or a menace to the public health or safety. The premises shall at all times be graded so that surface water drainage is not interfered with. Where quarrying operations result in a body of water forming, the owner or operator of the quarry shall erect "Keep Out-Danger" signs on the required fence around the excavation not more than 200 feet apart. 
(3)  No removal or stripping of topsoil, clay, sand, gravel, muck, stones, rock, aggregates or other materials shall be permitted in the following districts of the city: 
a.  Any residentially zoned districts (R-1A, R-1B, R-1C, R-2, R-3, RM-1 and RM-2); 
b.  Any district abutting residentially zoned districts or commercially developed property for a depth of 500 feet; and 
c.  Any areas designated as tax increment financing areas (otherwise known as TIFA) or properties abutting such TIFA areas for a depth of 500 feet. 
(4)  Where an excavation in excess of five feet will result from such operations, the applicant shall erect a fence completely surrounding the portion of the site where the excavation extends. The fence will be of wire mesh or other suitable material to afford protection to persons and property and be not less than six feet in height complete with gates, which gates shall be kept locked when operations are not being carried on. 
(5)  The slopes of the banks of the excavation shall in no event exceed a minimum ratio of seven feet horizontal to one foot vertical; and where ponded water results from the operation, this slope must be maintained and extended into the water to a depth of five feet. 
(6)  No roads may be used for the purpose of ingress or egress to the excavation, stripping or removal site which are located within 400 feet of occupied residences unless such roads shall have a hard surface of cement, bituminous substances or chemical treatment. 
(7)  The applicant shall fill the land to finish grades per subsection (a)(3) of this section. Wherever topsoil exists, suitable for growing turf or for other land use, at the time the operations begin a sufficient quantity of topsoil shall be stockpiled on the site so that the entire site, when stripping or removal operations are completed, may be recovered with a minimum of four inches of topsoil and the replacement of such topsoil shall be made immediately following the termination of the stripping or removal operation. If, however, such stripping or removal operations continue over a period of time greater than 30 days, the operator shall replace the stored topsoil over the stripped areas as the operator progresses. Such replacement shall be in a manner suitable for growing turf. When the filling and grading has been completed, a topographical survey by a registered civil engineer or land surveyor shall be sealed and submitted by the owner or operator of any such operation as a check on the complete removal and filling operation, which must be approved by the director of building and safety before release of the bond. 
(8)  Additional equipment or machinery for additional operations on premises shall not be permitted unless specifically applied for in the application and for which a permit is issued. 
(9)  Reasonable operation hours for any use permitted pursuant to this section shall be as established by the director of building and safety. 
(10)  Depth of excavation is limited to five feet unless otherwise approved by the director of building and safety at the time of issuance of the permit. 
(11)  The director of building and safety may establish other reasonable requirements as deemed necessary to properly protect the general health, safety and welfare of the city. 
(Code 1987, § 26-18; Ord. No. 75-70, § 4, 9-9-1975; Ord. No. 89-203, 4-4-1989) 
Sec. 20-218. - Filling, depositing, dumping. 
(a)  Rubbish, garbage, other waste material prohibited. The filling of land with rubbish, garbage or any other similar waste material by any person shall be prohibited in the city. 
(b)  Sand, gravel, earth, rock, concrete permitted. The filling of land with sand, gravel, earth, rock, concrete or similar material, but not including rubbish, garbage or other similar waste material may be permitted in any district by the director of building and safety. 
(c)  Application for permit. An application for a permit to fill, deposit or dump sand, gravel, earth or concrete shall be requested in writing to the director of building and safety containing the following information: 
(1)  Names and addresses of parties of interest in the premises setting forth their legal interest in the premises; 
(2)  Full legal description of the premises wherein operations are proposed; 
(3)  Topographical survey map of scale of one inch equals 100 feet showing existing grades on a two-foot contour interval of the land prior to any of the proposed fillings and the finished grades to show a suitable storm drainage scheme, prepared by a registered civil engineer; 
(4)  Detailed proposal as to the method of operation which is in compliance with article III of this chapter, what type of machinery or equipment will be used, and estimated period of time that such operation will cover; 
(5)  Detailed statement as to exactly what type of material is proposed to be deposited; 
(6)  Such other information as may be reasonably required by the director of building and safety to base an opinion as to whether a permit should or should not be issued. 
(d)  Bond. Before issuance of a permit, there shall be filed by the applicant, a surety bond, executed by a reputable surety company authorized to do business in the state running to the city, in an amount as established by the director of building and safety conditioned upon the prompt and complete compliance with all the provisions of this article and requirements of the county and state. The director of building and safety shall, in establishing the amount of the bond, consider the scale of the operations, the prevailing cost and other reasonable expenses. 
(e)  Issuance of permit. The director of building and safety shall issue a permit conditioned on compliance of the permitholder with all the requirements of this article. 
(f)  Procedures, specifications. In addition to the other requirements of this section, the following may be required to protect the health, safety, and welfare of the city: 
(1)  A temporary fence may be required by the director of building and safety to enclose the filling operations to prevent the scattering of fill materials. 
(2)  No roads may be used for the purpose of ingress or egress to the fill site which are located within 400 feet of occupied residences unless such roads shall have a hard surface of cement, bituminous substance or chemical treatment. 
(3)  Additional equipment or machinery for additional operations on premises shall not be permitted unless specifically applied for in the application and for which a permit is issued. 
(4)  Reasonable operation hours for any use permitted pursuant to this section shall be established by the director of building and safety. 
(5)  The applicant shall fill the land to finish grades pursuant to subsection (c)(3) of this section. Upon completion of the filling and grading, a topographical survey by a registered civil engineer or land surveyor shall be sealed and submitted by the owner or operator of any such operation which must be approved by the director of building and safety before release of the bond filed in accordance with this article. 
(Code 1987, § 26-19; Ord. No. 75-70, § 5, 9-9-1975; Ord. No. 89-204, 4-4-1989) 
Sec. 20-219. - Barricades; protection required for excavations, holes or pits. 
    The construction, maintenance or existence within the city of any unprotected, unbarricaded, open or dangerous excavations, holes, pits or walls or of any excavations, holes or pits which constitute or are reasonably likely to constitute a danger or menace to the public health, safety or welfare, are hereby prohibited; provided, however, this section shall not prevent construction or excavation under a permit issued pursuant to this article or the state construction code where such excavations are properly protected and warning signs posted in such manner as may be approved by the director of building and safety. This section shall not apply to lakes, streams or other natural bodies of water, nor to ditches, streams, reservoirs or other major bodies of water created or existing by authority of the state, county, city or any other governmental agency. 
(Code 1987, § 26-20; Ord. No. 75-70, § 6, 9-9-1975) 
State Law reference- Covering or fencing excavation or basement, MCL 750.493c. 
Secs. 20-220-20-246. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VII. - SOIL EROSION AND SEDIMENTATION CONTROL[7] 

Footnotes: 
--- (7) --- 
State Law reference- Soil erosion and sedimentation control, MCL 324.9101 et seq.; soil conservation districts law, MCL 324.9301 et seq. 

Sec. 20-247. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Accelerated soil erosion means the increased loss of the land surface that occurs as a result of human activities. 
    Earth change shall have the meaning ascribed thereto in part 91 as defined in this section. 
    Excavation or cut means any act by which soil or rock is cut into, dug, quarried, uncovered, removed, displaced or relocated, and shall include the conditions resulting therefrom. 
    Floodplain means that area which would be inundated by storm runoff or floodwater equivalent, or that which would occur with a rainfall or flood for an intermediate regional flood. 
    Lake. 
(1)  The term "lake" means the Great Lakes and all natural and artificial inland lakes or impoundments that have definite banks, a bed, visible evidence of a continued occurrence of water and a surface area of water that is equal to, or greater than one acre. 
(2)  The term "lake" does not include sediment basins and basins constructed for the sole purpose of stormwater retention, cooling water or treating polluted water. 
    Part 91 means of Public Act No. 451 of 1994 (MCL 324.9101 et seq.). 
    Permanent soil erosion and sedimentation control measures means control measures which are installed or constructed to control soil erosion and sedimentation, and which are maintained after project completion. 
    Permitted party means the landowner to whom a SESC permit has been issued under this article. 
    Sediment means solid particulate matter, including both mineral and organic matter, that is in suspension in water, is being transported, or has been removed from its site of origin by the actions of wind, water, or gravity and has been deposited elsewhere. 
    Soil erosion shall have the meaning ascribed thereto in part 91. 
    Soil erosion and sedimentation control (SESC) permit means a permit issued to authorize work to be performed under this article. 
    Soil erosion and sedimentation control (SESC) plan means, as required under this article, part 91 and the rules for issuance of a SESC permit. 
    Stream means a river, creek, or other surface watercourse which may or may not be serving as a drain as defined in Public Act No. 40 of 1956 (MCL 280.1 et seq.), and which has definite banks, a bed, and visible evidence of the continued flow or continued occurrence of water, including the connecting waters of the Great Lakes. 
    Stripping means any activity which removes or disturbs the vegetative surface cover, including clearing and grubbing operations. 
    Temporary soil erosion and sedimentation control measures means interim control measures which are installed or constructed for the control of soil erosion and sedimentation until permanent soil erosion control is affected. 
    Waters of the state shall have the meaning ascribed thereto in part 91. 
(Code 1987, § 26-33; Ord. No. 05-406, § 1, 11-1-2005) 
Sec. 20-248. - Enabling authority; designation of municipal enforcing agency. 
(a)  It is the intent of the city to become the municipal enforcing agency in regard to implementing the provisions of part 91, soil erosion and sedimentation control (part 91), of the natural resources and environmental protection act, Public Act No. 451 of 1994 (the Act), MCL 324.9101 et seq.), adopting by reference the latest rules promulgated by the state department of natural resources and environment relative to part 91 within the municipal corporate limits of the city. Wherever the provisions of this article conflict with those of part 91, the more restrictive standard shall govern. 
(b)  The engineering division of the department of public works is designated as the municipal enforcing agency (MEA) responsible for administering and enforcing part 91 and rules promulgated thereunder, as well as this article, within the city. 
(Code 1987, § 26-32; Ord. No. 05-406, § 1, 11-1-2005) 
Sec. 20-249. - SESC permit required; plan requirements; fees. 
(a)  A SESC permit is required when an earth change is proposed which is within 500 feet of the waters of the state, a lake or a stream, or will disturb one or more acres of land. 
(b)  Prior to issuance of the SESC permit, a soil erosion and sedimentation control application and SESC plan shall be submitted to the city engineer in accordance with the rules promulgated under part 91, soil erosion and sedimentation control, of the natural resources and environmental protection act, Public Act No. 451 of 1994 (the Act), MCL 324.9101 et seq.). The plan shall be submitted with the necessary fees in accordance with a fee schedule to be determined by the city council, and amended from time to time by simple resolution. 
(c)  A soil erosion and sedimentation control permit must be issued prior to the issuance of a building permit per R323.1711, rule 1711(2). A local agency shall not issue a building permit to a person engaged in an earth change if the change requires a permit under part 91 or these rules until the county or local enforcing agency has issued the required state prescribed permit for the earth change. 
(Code 1987, § 26-34; Ord. No. 05-406, § 1, 11-1-2005) 
Sec. 20-250. - Plan review; permit issuance conditions. 
    The submitted SESC plans shall be reviewed and approved and a permit shall be issued, provided the plans meet the requirements set forth in the rules promulgated pursuant to part 91, which have been adopted herein by reference. 
(Code 1987, § 26-35; Ord. No. 05-406, § 1, 11-1-2005) 
Sec. 20-251. - SESC permit; bond requirements; time for completion. 
(a)  A SESC permit shall not be issued unless the permittee shall first post with the city clerk a cash deposit, certified check, or irrevocable bank letter of credit in the amount of the estimated total cost of all temporary and/or permanent soil erosion and/or sedimentation control measures. The total cost shall be estimated by the city engineer. 
(b)  Every instrument of credit shall include, and every cash deposit shall be made, on the conditions that the applicant shall: 
(1)  Comply with all of the provisions of this article, part 91, soil erosion and sedimentation control, of the natural resources and environmental protection act, Public Act No. 451 of 1994 (the Act), MCL 324.9101 et seq.) and the rules and all of the terms and conditions of the SESC permit; and 
(2)  Complete all of the work contemplated under the SESC permit within the time limit specified in the SESC permit; or, if no time limit is specified, within 180 days after the date of the issuance of the SESC permit. 
(Code 1987, § 26-36; Ord. No. 05-406, § 1, 11-1-2005) 
Sec. 20-252. - Grading permit; extension of time. 
    If the permitted party is unable to complete the work within the specified time, the permitted party may, at least ten days prior to the expiration of the permit, present in writing to the city engineer a request for an extension of time, setting forth the reasons for the requested extension. If an extension is warranted, the city engineer may grant additional time for the completion of the work, but no such extension shall release the permitted party or the person furnishing the instrument of credit or cash bond. 
(Code 1987, § 26-37; Ord. No. 05-406, § 1, 11-1-2005) 
Sec. 20-253. - Failure to complete work; work performed by city when; costs. 
    If the work authorized by the permit is not completed on time or is in violation of this article, part 91 and the rules or the terms of the permit, the city engineer may order such work as is necessary to eliminate any danger to persons or property and to leave the site in a safe condition, and may authorize completion of all necessary temporary or permanent soil erosion and sedimentation control measures. The permitted party and the person issuing the instrument of credit or making the cash deposit shall continue to be obligated for the payment of all necessary costs and expenses that may be insured or expended by the city as a result of any and all such work to be done. In the case of a cash deposit, any unused portion thereof shall be refunded to the permitted party. 
(Code 1987, § 26-38; Ord. No. 05-406, § 1, 11-1-2005) 
Sec. 20-254. - SESC permit; issuance prohibited when. 
    SESC permits shall not be issued where: 
(1)  The proposed work would cause hazards to the public safety and welfare; 
(2)  The work as proposed by the applicant will: 
a.  Damage any public or private property; 
b.  Interfere with any existing drainage course in such a manner as to cause damage to any adjacent property; 
c.  Result in the deposition of debris or sediment on any public way or into any waters of the state; or 
d.  Create an unreasonable hazard to persons or property; 
(3)  The land area for which the earth change is proposed: 
a.  Is subject to geological hazard to the extent that no reasonable amount of corrective work can eliminate or sufficiently reduce settlement, slope instability or any other such hazard to persons or property; or 
b.  May lie within the floodplain of any stream or watercourse (not specifically designated and delineated by the city as an area subject to flood hazard), unless a hydrologic report, prepared by a professional engineer, is submitted to certify that the proposed earth change will have, in the professional engineer's opinion, no detrimental influence on the public welfare or upon the total development of the watershed. 
(Code 1987, § 26-39; Ord. No. 05-406, § 1, 11-1-2005) 
Sec. 20-255. - Modifications of approved SESC plans. 
    All modifications of the approved SESC plans must be submitted and approved by the city engineer. All necessary reports and other appropriate information shall be submitted with any proposal to modify the approved SESC plan. No earth change work in connection with any proposed modification shall be permitted without the approval of the city engineer. 
(Code 1987, § 26-40; Ord. No. 05-406, § 1, 11-1-2005) 
Sec. 20-256. - Earth change operations; responsibility of permitted party. 
    During earth change operations, the permitted party shall be responsible for: 
(1)  The prevention of damage to any public utilities or services within the limits of earth change, and along any routes of travel of the equipment; 
(2)  Effectively reduce accelerated soil erosion and offsite sedimentation or the discharge of sediment into the waters of the state. No person shall grade on land so close to the property line as to endanger any adjoining public street, sidewalk, alley or any public or private property without supporting and protecting such property from settling, cracking or other damage which might result; 
(3)  Carrying out the proposed work in accordance with the approved SESC plans and in compliance with the permit, part 91, and rules adopted pursuant thereto, and this article; 
(4)  The prompt removal of all soil, miscellaneous debris or other materials applied, dumped or otherwise deposited on public streets, highways, sidewalks or other public thoroughfares during transit to and from the construction, where such spillage constitutes a public nuisance or hazard; and 
(5)  The prevention of discharge of sediment to waters of the state and adjacent properties by conducting any earth change in a manner that will effectively reduce accelerated soil erosion and resulting sedimentation. 
(Code 1987, § 26-41; Ord. No. 05-406, § 1, 11-1-2005) 
Sec. 20-257. - Grading operations; specifications for work. 
(a)  Any earth changes shall be conducted in such a manner which will effectively reduce accelerated soil erosion and resulting sedimentation. 
(b)  All persons engaged in earth changes shall design, implement and maintain acceptable soil erosion and sedimentation and control measures, in conformance with part 91, soil erosion and sedimentation control, of the natural resources and environmental protection act, Public Act No. 451 of 1994 (the Act), MCL 324.9101 et seq.) and the rules promulgated pursuant thereto, which effectively reduce accelerated soil erosion and sedimentation. 
(c)  All earth changes shall be designed, constructed and completed in such a manner which shall limit the exposed area of any disturbed land for the shortest possible period of time. 
(d)  Sediment caused by accelerated soil erosion shall be removed from runoff water before it leaves the site of the earth change. 
(e)  Any temporary or permanent soil erosion and sedimentation control measure designed and constructed for the conveyance of water around, through or from the earth change area shall be designed to limit the water flow to a nonerosive velocity. 
(f)  A person shall install temporary soil erosion and sedimentation control measures before or upon commencement of the earth change activity and shall maintain the measures on a daily basis. A person shall remove temporary soil erosion and sedimentation control measures after permanent soil erosion measures are in place and the area is stabilized. A person shall stabilize the area with permanent soil erosion and sedimentation control measures and meet the standards and specifications as prescribed by rule 323.1710 pursuant to part 91, as amended. 
(g)  A person shall complete permanent soil erosion control measures for all slopes, channels, ditches, or any disturbed land area within five calendar days after final grading or the final earth change has been completed. If it is not possible to permanently stabilize a disturbed area after an earth change has been completed or if significant earth change activity ceases, then a person shall maintain temporary soil erosion and sedimentation control measures until permanent soil erosion control measures are in place and the area is stabilized. 
(Code 1987, § 26-42; Ord. No. 05-406, § 1, 11-1-2005) 
Sec. 20-258. - Maintenance of erosion control measures. 
    Persons carrying out soil erosion and sedimentation control measures under this article, and all subsequent owners of property concerning which such measures have been taken, shall maintain all permanent soil erosion and sedimentation control measures, retaining walls, structures, plantings, and other protective devices. Soil erosion and sedimentation control measures shall be taken as prescribed in section 20-257. 
(Code 1987, § 26-43; Ord. No. 05-406, § 1, 11-1-2005) 
Sec. 20-259. - Minimum design standards for soil erosion and sedimentation control applicable. 
    All SESC plans, including extensions of previously approved SESC plans, shall be in accordance with the Guidebook of Best Management Practices for Michigan Watersheds, published by the state department of natural resources and environment, surface water quality division in 1997 and the Oakland County Michigan Erosion Control Manual, third edition, published in 1990 or equivalent. If the standards contained in part 91, and the rules are stricter than in the two publications set forth in this section, the provisions of part 91 and the rules shall govern. Copies of the standards shall be available for inspection in the office of the city engineer. 
(Code 1987, § 26-44; Ord. No. 05-406, § 1, 11-1-2005) 
Sec. 20-260. - Permit exemptions and waivers. 
(a)  A permit is not required for any of the following: 
(1)  A beach nourishment project permitted under part 325 of Public Act 451 in 1994 (MCL 324.32501 et seq.); 
(2)  Normal road and driveway maintenance, such as grading or leveling, that does not increase the width or length of the road or driveway and that will not contribute sediment to lakes or streams; 
(3)  An earth change of a minor nature that is stabilized within 24 hours of the initial earth disturbance and that will not contribute sediment to lakes or streams. 
(b)  The city engineer may grant a permit waiver for an earth change after receiving a signed affidavit from the landowner stating that the earth change will disturb less than 225 square feet and that the earth change will not contribute sediment to lakes or streams. 
(c)  Permit exemption sections set forth in section 9115 of Public Act 451 of 1994 (MCL 324.9115), are hereby incorporated herein by reference. 
(d)  Exemptions provided in subsections (a) and (b) of this section shall not be construed as exemptions from, enforcement procedures under part 91 and the rules or this article if the activities cause or result in a violation of part 91 and rules adopted pursuant thereto or this article. 
(Code 1987, § 26-45; Ord. No. 05-406, § 1, 11-1-2005) 
Sec. 20-261. - Inspection requirements. 
(a)  The requirements of this article, part 91 and the rules shall be enforced by the city engineer. The city engineer or designee shall inspect the work and may require adequate inspection of compaction by a soil engineer or by a soil testing agency approved by the city engineer. 
(b)  If the city engineer finds any existing conditions not as stated in the SESC application, SESC permit or approved SESC plan, the city engineer may refuse to approve further work until approval of a revised SESC plan conforming to the existing conditions. 
(c)  Routine inspections will be conducted on a weekly basis and after every rain event. Should the SESC permit be in violation of part 91 and the rules, a verbal and written notice will be issued to the SESC permit holder. SESC permit holder will have five days to make the necessary corrections. Should the corrections not be completed the SESC permit holder may be subject to fines of $100.00 per day, per violation, as a municipal civil infraction. 
(Code 1987, § 26-46; Ord. No. 05-406, § 1, 11-1-2005) 
Sec. 20-262. - Enforcement. 
(a)  If the engineering division determines that soil erosion or sedimentation of adjacent properties or the waters of the state has or will reasonably occur from land in violation of this article, part 91, or the rules promulgated under part 91, the engineering division may seek to enforce such a violation by notifying the person who owns the land, by mail, with return receipt requested, of its determination. The notice shall contain a description of the violation and what must be done to remedy the violation and shall specify a time to comply with this article, part 91, and the rules promulgated under part 91. 
(b)  Within five days after the issuance of such notice of violation, the person who owns the land subject to the notice shall implement and maintain soil erosion and sedimentation control measures in conformance with this article, part 91, and the rules promulgated under part 91. 
(c)  Not sooner than five days after a notice of violation has been mailed, if the condition of the land, in the opinion of the engineering division, may result in or contribute to soil erosion or sedimentation of adjacent properties or to the waters of the state, and if soil erosion and sedimentation control measures in conformance with this article, part 91, and the rules promulgated under part 91 are not in place, the engineering division or its designee may enter upon the land and construct, implement, and maintain soil erosion and sedimentation control measures in conformance with this article, part 91, and the rules promulgated under part 91. The municipal enforcing agency shall not expend more than $10,000.00 for the cost of the work, materials, labor and administration without ten days' prior written notice to the owner of the land. 
(d)  Notwithstanding the existence or pursuit of any other remedy, the city may maintain an action in its own name in any court of competent jurisdiction for an injunction or other process against any person to restrain or prevent violations of this article. 
(e)  The city engineer or duly authorized agents, may enter at all reasonable times in or upon any private or public property for the purpose of inspecting and investigating conditions and practices which may be a violation of this article, part 91, or the rules promulgated pursuant to part 91. 
(Code 1987, § 26-47; Ord. No. 05-406, § 1, 11-1-2005) 
ARTICLE VIII. - BLIGHTED PROPERTY 

Sec. 20-263. - Purpose of article. 
    It is the purpose of this article to prevent, reduce or eliminate blight or potential blight in the city by the prevention or elimination of certain environmental causes of blight or blighting factors which exist or which may in the future exist in the city. 
(Ord. No. 13-477, 9-3-2013) 
State Law reference- Power of municipality regarding blight, MCL 125.73. 
Sec. 20-264. - Cause of blight or blighting factors. 
    It is hereby determined that the following uses, structures and activities are causes of blight or blighting factors which, if allowed to exist, will tend to result in blighted and undesirable neighborhoods. No person shall maintain or permit to be maintained any of these causes of blight or blighting factors upon any property in the city owned, leased, rented or occupied by such person. 
(1)  In any area zoned for residential purposes, permitting or allowing grass or weeds to grow to a height of eight inches or more. For the purpose of this article, the terms "grass or weeds" shall include the broadest possible definition for the terms as commonly used. If the owner or possessor of land allows the grass or weeds on the residential property to exceed eight inches in height, the city may take action, after providing written notice or, in the alternative, by posting on the property and in City Hall, through its director of the ordinance department or his/her designee, to enter upon the land and destroy the grass or weeds or cause them to be destroyed, as prescribed in section 20-266. 
(2)  In any area zoned for residential purposes, the storage upon any property of junk automobiles, except in a completely enclosed building. For the purpose of this article, the term "junk automobiles" shall include any motor vehicle which is not licensed for use upon the highways of the state for a period in excess of 30 days and shall also include whether so licensed or not any motor vehicle which is inoperative for any reason for any period in excess of 30 days. 
(3)  In any area zoned for residential purposes, the storage upon any property of building materials unless there is in force a valid building permit issued by the city for construction upon the property and the materials are intended for use in connection with such construction. Building materials shall include, but shall not be limited to, lumber, bricks, concrete or cinder blocks, plumbing materials, electrical wiring or equipment, heating ducts or equipment, shingles, mortar, concrete or cement, nails, screws, or any other materials used in constructing any structure. 
(4)  In any area zoned for residential purposes, the storage or accumulation of junk, trash, rubbish or refuse of any kind, except domestic refuse stored in such a manner as not to create a nuisance for a period not to exceed 30 days. The term "junk" shall include parts of machinery or motor vehicles, unused stoves or other appliances stored in the open, remnants of wood, metal or any other material or other cast-off material of any kind whether or not the same could be put to any reasonable use. 
(5)  In any area zoned for residential purposes, the existence of any structure or part of a structure which because of fire, wind or other nature disaster, or physical deterioration is no longer habitable, as a dwelling, nor useful for any other purpose for which it may have been intended. 
(6)  In any area zoned for residential purposes, the existence of any vacant dwelling, garage, or other outbuilding which is not kept securely locked, windows kept glazed or neatly boarded up and otherwise protected to prevent entrance thereto by vandals. 
(7)  In any area zoned for residential purposes, the existence of any partial completed structure unless the structures is in the course of construction in accordance with a valid and subsisting building permit issued by the city and unless the construction is completed with a reasonable time. 
(Ord. No. 13-477, 9-3-2013) 
Sec. 20-265. - Nonresidential causes of blight. 
    The causes of blight or blighting factors set forth in section 20-264 as applicable to areas zoned for residential purposes are hereby determined to be causes of blight or blighting factors and subject to the prohibitions of this article if located in areas zoned for other than residential purposes, unless such uses of property are incidental to and necessary for the carrying out of any business or occupation lawfully being carried on upon the property in question. 
(Ord. No. 13-477, 9-3-2013) 
Sec. 20-266. - Enforcement. 
    The owner, if possible, and the occupant of any property upon which any of the causes of blight or blighting factors set forth in section 20-264 are found to exist, shall be notified in writing or, in the alternative, by posting on the property and in City Hall, to remove or eliminate such causes of blight or blighting factors from the property within ten days after the service of the notice upon him. Additional time may be granted by the enforcement officer where bona fide efforts to remove or eliminate the causes of blight or blighting factors are in progress. The notice may be served personally or by registered mail. Following the aforementioned notice, the city shall continue to eliminate causes of blight or blighting factors, at the owner's expense, until it receives actual written notice by the owner that he shall remedy the causes of blight or blighting factors on an ongoing basis. The city shall have a lien upon the subdivided land or lots for the amount of the expense; and if the owner fails to pay the expense, the lien shall be enforced in the same manner provided by law for enforcement of special assessment tax liens. 
(Ord. No. 13-477, 9-3-2013) 
Secs. 20-267-20-290. - Reserved. 
Chapter 22 - FIRE PREVENTION AND PROTECTION[1] 
Footnotes:
