(1)  Hunt, molest, harm, frighten, kill, trample, chase, tease, shoot or throw missiles at any animal, reptile or bird; 
(2)  Remove or have in the person's possession the young of any wild animal, or the eggs, nest or young of any reptile or bird; or 
(3)  Collect, remove, have in the person's possession, give away, sell or offer to sell, buy or offer to buy or accept as a gift any specimen alive or dead of tree snails. 
(b)  No person shall in any park give, offer or attempt to give to any animal or bird any tobacco, alcohol or other known noxious substances. 
(Code 1987, § 20-59; Ord. No. 82-130, § 7(A)(3), 10-26-1982) 
State Law reference- Wildlife conservation, MCL 324.40101 et seq.; endangered species protection, MCL 324.36501 et seq. 
Sec. 34-82. - Firearms, hunting, trapping. 
    No person shall in any park hunt, trap or pursue wildlife at any time. No person shall use, carry or possess firearms of any description, air rifles, spring guns, bows and arrows, slings or any other forms of weapons potentially inimical to wildlife and dangerous to human safety or any instrument that can be loaded with and fire blank cartridges or any kind of trapping device contrary to state law. Shooting into any park areas from beyond park boundaries is forbidden. 
(Code 1987, § 20-60; Ord. No. 82-130, § 7(D)(1), 10-26-1982; Ord. No. 10-454, § 20-60, 10-3-2010) 
State Law reference- Wildlife conservation, MCL 324.40101 et seq. 
Sec. 34-83. - Selling. 
    No person shall in any park expose or offer for sale any article or thing or operate or place any stand, cart or vehicle for the transportation, sale or display of any such article or thing. An exception to this section is made for any licensed concessionaire acting by and under the authority and regulation of the director. 
(Code 1987, § 20-61; Ord. No. 82-130, § 7(E)(15), 10-26-1982) 
Sec. 34-84. - Signs. 
    No person shall in any park paste, glue, tack or otherwise post any sign, placard, advertisement or inscription whatever, nor shall any person erect or cause to be erected any sign whatever in any park or any public lands or highway or roads adjacent to the parks except as permitted by the director. 
(Code 1987, § 20-62; Ord. No. 82-130, § 7(E)(16), 10-26-1982) 
Sec. 34-85. - Disturbing others. 
    No person shall in any park disturb or interfere unreasonably with any person or party occupying any area or participating in any activity in a park including the playing of radios, stereos, tape players at excessively loud volumes or any musical instruments of any kind in such a manner as to disturb other park users. 
(Code 1987, § 20-63; Ord. No. 82-130, § 7(E)(14), 10-26-1982) 
Sec. 34-86. - Alcoholic liquor. 
(a)  In motor vehicles. No person shall in any park consume, or have in the person's possession in any motor vehicle whether stopped, parked, standing or moving any opened containers of alcoholic liquor. 
(b)  In public buildings. No person shall in any park consume or have in the person's possession in any public building any alcoholic liquor. 
(c)  On park property. No alcoholic liquor of any type will be allowed on park property other than that area so designated by the director. 
(d)  Drunkenness. It shall be unlawful for any person to enter any park under the influence of alcoholic liquor or be under the influence of alcoholic liquor while in any park. 
(e)  Exception. At certain specifically designated recreation centers and in certain areas of specifically designated parks sale of alcoholic liquor may be authorized for a nonprofit, religious, fraternal, civic or patriotic organization with the approval of and under the strict regulation and control of the director, provided that the following are complied with: 
(1)  Any such nonprofit, religious, fraternal, civic or patriotic organization shall obtain a proper license from the state liquor control commission and that the director's approval is subject to the issuance of such license. 
(2)  Sale of alcoholic liquors shall be made only in individual drinks, not in original packages or otherwise in bulk, and shall be served for consumption only in the immediate premises of the concession. 
(Code 1987, § 20-64; Ord. No. 82-130, § 7(E)(1)-(4), 10-26-1982) 
State Law reference- Michigan liquor control code of 1998, MCL 436.1101 et seq.; possessing or consuming alcoholic liquors in parks, MCL 436.1915. 
Sec. 34-87. - Controlled substances. 
(a)  No person shall in any park have, possess, use, take or administer any drugs or controlled substances as defined in article 7 of Public Act No. 368 of 1978 of Michigan (MCL 333.7101 et seq.). 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person to enter any park while under the influence of any drugs or controlled substances or to be under the influence of any such drugs or controlled substances while in any park. 
(Code 1987, § 20-65; Ord. No. 82-130, § 7(E)(5), (6), 10-26-1982) 
Chapter 36 - PEDDLERS, SOLICITORS, HANDBILL DISTRIBUTORS AND TRANSIENT MERCHANTS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference- Home solicitation sales, MCL 445.111 et seq.; transient merchants, MCL 445.371 et seq.; exemption for a veteran's license, MCL 35.441; charitable organizations and solicitations act, MCL 400.271 et seq.; public safety solicitation act, MCL 14.301 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Secs. 36-1-36-18. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - HAWKERS AND PEDDLERS 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 36-19. - Hours permitted for selling. 
    No licensee under this article shall, between the hours of 8:00 p.m. and 8:00 a.m., sell or offer for sale any goods, wares or merchandise within the city. Licensees operating in parks, recreational facilities or at special events shall be allowed to operate between the hours of 8:00 a.m. and 10:00 p.m. 
(Code 1987, § 21-17; Ord. No. 75, §§ 7, 8, 5-5-1965; Ord. No. 75-60, § 22(c), 7-22-1975) 
Sec. 36-20. - Location for selling. 
    No licensee under this article shall have any exclusive right to any location in the public streets, nor shall the licensee be permitted a stationary location, nor shall he be permitted to operate in any congested area where the operation might impede or inconvenience the public. For the purpose of this section, the judgment of a police officer exercising good faith shall be deemed conclusive as to whether the area is congested or the public impeded or inconvenienced. 
(Code 1987, § 21-18; Ord. No. 75, §§ 7, 8, 5-5-1965; Ord. No. 75-60, § 22(c), 7-22-1975) 
Sec. 36-21. - Disposal of containers by peddlers. 
    Each peddler's vehicle shall be equipped with a receptacle for the disposing of wrappers, papers and envelopes or other containers. It is hereby made the duty of the peddler to pick up such wrappers, papers and envelopes after any sale or delivery of the peddler's products. 
(Code 1987, § 21-19; Ord. No. 75, § 12, 5-5-1965) 
Secs. 36-22-36-45. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - LICENSE 

Sec. 36-46. - Required. 
    It shall be unlawful to operate any vehicle engaged in vending, peddling or hawking upon the streets of the city without first obtaining a license to so operate. 
(Code 1987, § 21-31; Ord. No. 75, § 1, 5-5-1965; Ord. No. 75-60, § 22, 7-22-1975) 
Sec. 36-47. - Persons ineligible; exception. 
    No license required by this division shall be issued to any person who has been convicted of a felony or to any person who has been convicted of any misdemeanor pertaining to sexual deviation or moral turpitude, except that the mayor and city council may order the city clerk to issue a license when it shall appear to the mayor and the city council that such applicant is a law-abiding citizen and that the issuance of the license is not likely to adversely affect the health, welfare, morals or safety of the people of the city; provided that nothing contained in this article shall be interpreted to exempt the person issued a license pursuant to the provisions of this section from complying with all of the other requirements of this article and any other ordinance provisions of the city. 
(Code 1987, § 21-32; Ord. No. 75, § 9, 5-5-1965) 
Sec. 36-48. - Contents of application. 
    Before any license required by this division shall be issued, the applicant shall file with the city clerk a written application for a license, setting forth: 
(1)  The full name, residence, business address and occupation of the applicant at the time of filing the application; 
(2)  The nature of the article to be sold, offered for sale, hawked or peddled; 
(3)  The proposed method of hawking or peddling, whether on foot, by handcart, bicycle, truck or otherwise; 
(4)  The proposed method of delivery to buyers, whether by weight, measure, package or otherwise; 
(5)  The length of time for which the license is desired; 
(6)  Whether or not the applicant proposes to make use of measures or scales; 
(7)  Whether or not the applicant holds a license from any municipality other than the city giving the number of such licenses, if any are held; 
(8)  Whether or not the applicant holds a license from the state, giving the number of the license if such a license are held; 
(9)  Whether or not the applicant has ever been convicted of a felony or misdemeanor and, if convicted, the nature of the crime and the date and place of conviction; 
(10)  The affidavit of the applicant as to the truth of the application. 
(Code 1987, § 21-34; Ord. No. 75, § 2, 5-5-1965) 
Sec. 36-49. - Inspections; approvals of vehicles; weights and measures. 
    Upon the filing of an application for an initial license to operate a vehicle engaged in the business of vending, peddling or hawking of goods, wares and merchandise from the public streets of the city, the city clerk shall obtain from the police chief and such other city departments as may be necessary inspections and approvals of such departments for the vehicle and weights and measures to be used; upon receipt of the requisite approvals, the city clerk shall bring the application to the attention of the city council at its next regular meeting thereafter, together with information concerning the number of vehicles then licensed by the city of such particular use or purpose. 
(Code 1987, § 21-35; Ord. No. 75, § 3, 5-5-1965; Ord. No. 75-60, § 22(a), 7-22-1975) 
Sec. 36-50. - Fingerprints; investigation of applicant; denial, issuance; record. 
    Upon the filing of an application for a license required by this division, the acceptance of the sealing of the weights and measures if any such be used, the filing of the bond required by this division and the payment of the appropriate fee, the following procedure will be followed before the license shall be issued: 
(1)  The applicant shall file a complete set of the applicant's fingerprints, or the fingerprints of anyone assisting the applicant, with the chief of police, which fingerprints shall be placed on file in the noncriminal identification file of the police department. 
(2)  The application shall be referred to the chief of police, who shall cause such investigation of the applicant's business and moral character to be made as the chief of police deems necessary for the protection of the public welfare. 
(3)  If as a result of such investigation, the applicant's character or business responsibility is found to be unsatisfactory, the chief of police shall endorse on such application the chief of police's disapproval and reasons for the same, and shall return the application to the city clerk who shall notify the applicant that the application is disapproved and that no permit or license will be issued. 
(4)  If, as a result of such investigation, the character and the business responsibility of the applicant are found to be satisfactory, the chief of police shall endorse the chief of police's approval on the application and shall return same to the city clerk who shall issue to the applicant the prescribed license. 
(5)  The city clerk shall keep a permanent record of all licenses issued pursuant to this division. 
(Code 1987, § 21-36; Ord. No. 75, § 6, 5-5-1965) 
Sec. 36-51. - Bond. 
(a)  Upon the filing of the application for a license required by this division and the acceptance of the sealing of the measures and weights, if any such be used, the applicant shall present to the city clerk for approval, a bond in a sum as prescribed by resolution of the city council with two sufficient sureties who shall appear before the city clerk and justify such sureties, if so required by the city clerk. 
(b)  The bond shall be conditioned upon the full compliance with the provisions of this article and all other ordinance provisions of the city and the payment of all fines, penalties and costs which may be imposed by any court of competent jurisdiction for the violation of any of the provisions of this article or any other ordinance provision of the city; provided that the city clerk may accept a bond from a corporation covering its employees who are licensees pursuant to this division if the bond meets all of the other requirements of this section and is in the amount prescribed by resolution of the city council. 
(Code 1987, § 21-37; Ord. No. 75, § 4, 5-5-1965) 
Sec. 36-52. - Fees. 
    Before any license required by this division shall be issued the applicant shall pay to the city clerk the fee prescribed by resolution of the city council. 
(Code 1987, § 21-38; Ord. No. 75, § 5, 5-5-1965; Ord. No. 75-49, § 1, 1-14-1975) 
Sec. 36-53. - City council hearing. 
    At the meeting of the city council, the applicant for a license required by this division or any other person in that person's behalf and any other interested person may be heard upon the application. After such hearing, if the city council determines that the public convenience and necessity requires the services offered by the applicant to the public, the city council may authorize the issuance of a certificate of necessity and public convenience and further authorize the city clerk to issue a license for the vehicle. 
(Code 1987, § 21-39; Ord. No. 75-60, § 22(b), 7-22-1975) 
Sec. 36-54. - Regulations printed on back of license. 
    Every licensee engaged in business within the city under the terms of this article shall comply with the following regulations which shall be printed upon the back of the license issued by the city clerk: 
(1)  Every licensee shall, upon the request of any person to whom goods, wares or merchandise shall be offered for sale, exhibit the license issued by the city clerk and permit such person to examine the license. 
(2)  Every licensee shall exhibit the license to any police officer, marshal, sheriff or other officer of the city upon demand. 
(3)  No licensee shall use or carry about any scale or measure or have in the licensee's possession any scale or measure not accepted by the city as the sealed weights and measures. 
(4)  No licensee shall sell or offer for sale any article or commodity purporting to be in quantities of standard weight or measure, whether in original or other packages or not, unless the same shall actually be of the weight or measure purported. 
(5)  No licensee shall shout or call out wares in a loud, boisterous or unseemly manner to the disturbance of the citizens or dwellers in the city, nor shall any licensee use any horn or bell or other noise-making device to call attention to the wares except during the corresponding hours so set forth in this article. 
(6)  No licensee shall sell or offer for sale any unsound, unripe or unwholesome food or defective, faulty, incomplete or deteriorated article of merchandise; provided that if the applicant for any license shall set forth in the application that the applicant proposes to sell certain faulty or defective merchandise for a price reduced from the usual and regular cost of the articles, such fact is to be endorsed upon the license, and upon exhibition of such license to the buyer such sale may be made if the article be other than food or materials for food. 
(7)  No licensee shall stop or remain upon any private property within the city without the consent of the owner thereof or some person having authority to grant such permission. 
(8)  No licensee shall during school hours sell or offer for sale any merchandise upon the streets, alleys or public places of the city contiguous or next adjacent to any property used for school purposes and within 200 feet of the property. 
(Code 1987, § 21-40; Ord. No. 75, § 8, 5-5-1965) 
Sec. 36-55. - License card. 
    Upon full compliance with the terms and conditions set forth in sections 36-48 through 36-52 and 36-54 by the applicant, the city clerk shall issue to the applicant a license to engage in business within the city under the terms and conditions of this article, and at the same time the city clerk shall issue one pocket card of a design to be changed each year, bearing the number of the license and the words "Peddler's License, City of Taylor." The card must at all times be carried by the licensee while engaged in the conduct of the licensee's business within the city. 
(Code 1987, § 21-41; Ord. No. 75, § 10, 5-5-1965) 
Sec. 36-56. - Expiration. 
    All licenses issued pursuant to this division shall expire midnight March 31 following their issuance, unless they expire at an earlier date under the terms thereof. 
(Code 1987, § 21-42; Ord. No. 75, § 17, 5-5-1965) 
Sec. 36-57. - Grounds for refusal, suspension, revocation. 
    Any license issued under the provisions of this division may be suspended by the chief of police or the city council at any time for violation of any of the provisions of this article or of any other ordinance of the city or the state or federal statutes. Any violation thereof shall constitute sufficient grounds for revocation of any license issued pursuant to this division and shall be considered sufficient grounds for the refusal to grant a license in the first instance. 
(Code 1987, § 21-43; Ord. No. 75, § 13, 5-5-1965) 
Sec. 36-58. - Appeal of refusal, suspension, revocation. 
    If any applicant for a license required by this division is refused a license or if any licensee under this division has the license suspended, the applicant or licensee has the right to file an appeal with the city council within ten days of such refusal or suspension. The city council shall thereafter conduct a hearing on the appeal and finally determine the matter by affirming, modifying or withdrawing the refusal or revocation. 
(Ord. No. 75, § 14, 5-5-1965) 
Secs. 36-59-36-89. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - ICE CREAM TRUCKS 

Sec. 36-90. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Ice cream truck means every motor vehicle in which ice cream, ice milk, frozen dairy products or ice flavored with syrup are carried for purposes of retail sale on the streets of the city. 
    Vend, vending means offering ice cream, ice milk, frozen dairy products or ice flavored with syrup for sale from a motor vehicle on the streets of the city. 
(Code 1987, § 21-56; Ord. No. 77-85, § 1, 4-26-1977) 
Sec. 36-91. - Licenses. 
    The city clerk is hereby authorized to issue a license to any person of good character as a vendor under this article, provided that such person complies with all the requirements of this article and pays to the city through the proper department the license fee which shall be set from time to time by resolution of the city council. All licenses granted under this article shall expire on May 31 of each year unless sooner revoked. 
(Code 1987, § 21-57; Ord. No. 77-85, § 5, 4-26-1977; Ord. No. 81-119, 6-23-1981) 
Sec. 36-92. - Required equipment. 
    In addition to other equipment required by law, every ice cream truck shall be equipped with: 
(1)  Signal lamps mounted at the same level and as high and as widely spaced laterally as practicable. These lamps shall be five to seven inches in diameter and shall display two alternately flashing amber lights on the front of the vehicles and two alternately flashing red lights on the rear of the vehicle, both lights visible at 500 feet in normal sunlight upon a straight level street. 
(2)  A stop signal arm that can be extended horizontally from the left side of the truck duplicating the design size and specifications shown in subsection (4) of this section. This arm shall be red and white in color and contain two alternately flashing lights three to five inches in diameter, visible at 300 feet to the front and rear in normal sunlight upon a straight level highway. The color of the two lights facing to the front shall be amber and the two lights facing to the rear shall be red. The bottom of the signal arm shall be 42 inches above the highway. 
(3)  A convex mirror mounted on the front so the driver in the driver's normal seating position can see the area in front of the truck obscured by the hood. 
(4)  The stop signal arm required by subsection (2) of this section shall be colors to meet specifications in the 1970 Federal Highway Administration Standard Color Charts. 
(Code 1987, § 21-58; Ord. No. 77-85, § 3, 4-26-1977) 
Sec. 36-93. - Inspections. 
    Every ice cream truck shall be inspected by the county health department and the police department once each year prior to its use in this city for the purpose of retail sales of frozen dairy products. The police department shall inspect each ice cream truck to determine whether it complies with this article and other state and local laws. 
(Code 1987, § 21-59; Ord. No. 77-85, § 6, 4-26-1977) 
Sec. 36-94. - Use of special lights and stop arm. 
(a)  The driver of an ice cream truck stopped on the streets for the purpose of vending shall actuate the special flashing lights and extend the stop signal arm required by this article. 
(b)  These lights and the stop signal arm shall not be used when the truck is in motion nor at any time the truck is stopped for a purpose other than vending. 
(Code 1987, § 21-60; Ord. No. 77-85, § 4, 4-26-1977) 
Sec. 36-95. - Vending restrictions. 
(a)  A person shall not vend on main thoroughfares or on any street in the city where the speed limit exceeds 25 miles per hour. 
(b)  A person shall not vend within 500 feet of any property used as a school from one hour before the regular school day to one hour after the regular school day; provided, this subsection shall not apply on days when school is not attended by children nor on school property when vending has been approved in writing by the principal. 
(c)  A person shall vend only when the ice cream truck is lawfully parked or stopped. 
(d)  A person shall vend only from the side of the truck away from moving traffic and as near as possible to the curb or edge of the street. 
(e)  A person shall not vend to a person standing in the roadway. 
(f)  A person shall not stop on the left side of a one-way street to vend. 
(g)  Vending from an ice cream truck between the hours of 8:01 p.m. and 9:59 a.m. is expressly prohibited except during the months of July and August when the evening hours during which vending is permitted shall be extended to 9:00 p.m. 
(Code 1987, § 21-61; Ord. No. 77-85, § 7, 4-26-1977) 
Sec. 36-96. - Backing to make sale. 
    The driver of an ice cream truck shall not back the same to make or attempt a sale. 
(Code 1987, § 21-62; Ord. No. 77-85, § 8, 4-26-1977) 
Sec. 36-97. - Unauthorized riders. 
(a)  The driver of an ice cream truck shall not permit any unauthorized person to ride in or on the vehicle. 
(b)  A person shall not ride in or on an ice cream truck unless employed by its owner or unless authorized in writing to do so by the owner or police department. 
(Code 1987, § 21-63; Ord. No. 77-85, § 9, 4-26-1977) 
Sec. 36-98. - Drivers of moving vehicles to stop under certain circumstances. 
    The driver of a moving vehicle meeting or overtaking from either direction an ice cream truck stopped on the street shall stop before reaching the truck when the flashing lights and stop signal arm described in this article are in use. After stopping a driver may proceed past such truck at a reasonable and prudent speed, not exceeding 15 miles per hour and shall yield right-of-way to any pedestrian who crosses the roadway to or from the ice cream truck. 
(Code 1987, § 21-64; Ord. No. 77-85, § 2, 4-26-1977) 
Secs. 36-99-36-124. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - HANDBILL DISTRIBUTORS AND BILLPOSTERS 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 36-125. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Billposter. 
(1)  The term "billposter" means any person engaging in the business for hire of posting, fastening, nailing or otherwise affixing any written, painted or printed or printed matter of any kind, or other form or reproduction thereof, called a sign in this article, containing a message or information of any kind whatsoever, to any outdoor billboard, or to or upon any bridge, fence, pole, post, sidewalk, tree, or to or upon the exterior of any other structure; 
(2)  The term "billposter" does not apply to or include any such sign mounted on, fastened to or suspended from the outside of any building or other structure, in accordance with and authorized by any provisions of an ordinance or statute, either for any public convenience or use, or regulating the construction or use of so-called outdoor display signs, whether such display signs are illuminated or not. 
    Handbill means any printed or written matter, any sample or device, dodger, circular, leaflet, pamphlet, paper, booklet or any other printed or otherwise reproduced original or copies of any matter or literature. 
    Handbill distributor means any person engaging or engaged in the business for hire or gain of distributing handbills, other than newspapers distributed to subscribers thereof, and any person receiving compensation directly or indirectly for the distribution of such handbills. 
    Newspaper means any newspaper of general circulation as defined by general law, any newspaper duly entered with the Post Office Department of the United States, in accordance with federal statute or regulation, and any newspaper filed and recorded with any recording officer as provided by general law. The term "newspaper" means and includes any periodical or current magazine regularly published with not less than four issues per year, and sold to the public. 
    Private premises means any dwelling house, building or other structure, designed or used either wholly or in part for private residential purposes, whether inhabited or temporarily or continuously uninhabited or vacant. The term "private premises" includes any yard, grounds, walk, driveway, porch, steps, vestibule or mailbox belonging or appurtenant to such dwelling, house, building, or other structure. 
    Public place means any and all streets, boulevards, avenues, lanes, alleys or other public ways, and any and all public parks, squares, spaces, plazas, grounds and buildings. 
(Code 1987, § 3-17; Ord. No. 77, § 8-102, 9-13-1965) 
Sec. 36-126. - Purpose. 
    To protect the people against the nuisance of and incident to the promiscuous distribution of handbills and circulars, with the resulting detriment and danger to public health and safety, the public interest, convenience and necessity requires the regulation thereof and to that end the purposes of this article are specifically declared to be to: 
(1)  Protect the people against the unlawful activities or operations of dissolute persons of criminal habits or tendencies representing themselves as solicitors, canvassers or handbill distributors, by requiring the registration of all solicitors, canvassers or handbill distributors, together with the names of their employers, and by regulating the business of handbill and advertising distribution through the imposition of reasonable license fees; 
(2)  Protect local residents against trespassing by solicitors, canvassers and handbill distributors upon the private property of such residents if they have given reasonable notice that they do not wish to be solicited by such persons or do not desire to receive handbills or advertising matter; 
(3)  Protect the people against the health and safety menace and the expense incident to the littering of the streets and public places by the promiscuous and uncontrolled distribution of advertising matter and handbills; 
(4)  Preserve to the people their constitutional right to receive and disseminate information not restricted under the ordinary rules of decency and good morals and public order. 
(Code 1987, § 3-16; Ord. No. 77, § 8-101, 9-13-1965) 
Sec. 36-127. - Exemptions. 
    The provisions of this article shall not be deemed to apply to the distribution of mail by the United States, nor to newspapers, or as otherwise permitted by the First Amendment. 
(Code 1987, § 3-18; Ord. No. 77, § 8-111, 9-13-1965) 
Sec. 36-128. - Use of premises for posting prohibited matter prohibited. 
    It shall be unlawful for the owner, lessee, occupant or agent of premises to permit any person, whether licensed or acting under the terms of this article, or otherwise, to post, affix or otherwise attach to any building, structure or fixture located upon such premises, whether such fixture be natural or artificial, any poster or handbill containing any matter prohibited by the terms of this article. 
(Code 1987, § 3-19; Ord. No. 77, § 8-112, 9-13-1965) 
Sec. 36-129. - Posting handbills in public places. 
    No person shall post, stick, stamp, paint or otherwise fix, or cause the same to be done by any person any notice, placard, bill, card, poster, advertisement or other paper or device calculated to attract the attention of the public to or upon any sidewalk, crosswalk, curb or curbstone, flagstone, or any other portion or part of any public way or public place, or any lamppost, electric light, telegraph, telephone or trolley line pole, or any traffic control informational sign or post within the public right-of-way or railway structure, hydrant, shade tree or tree-box, or upon the piers, columns, trusses, girders, railings, gates or other parts of any public bridge or viaduct, or other public structure or building, or upon any pole; except such as may be authorized or required by the laws of the United States or this state and the ordinances of the city. 
(Code 1987, § 3-20; Ord. No. 77, § 8-103, 9-13-1965) 
Sec. 36-130. - Throwing, scattering, handing out handbills in public places. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to deposit, place, throw, scatter or cast any handbill in or upon any public place within this city; and it shall be also unlawful for any person to hand out or distribute or sell any handbill in any public place; provided, however, that it shall not be unlawful for any person to hand out or distribute, without charge to the receiver thereof, any handbill in any public place to any person willing to accept such handbill. 
(Code 1987, § 3-21; Ord. No. 77, § 8-104, 9-13-1965) 
Sec. 36-131. - Placing handbills in or upon automobiles. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to distribute, deposit, place, throw, scatter or cast any handbill in or upon any automobile or other vehicle. The provisions of this section shall not be deemed to prohibit the handing, transmitting or distributing of any handbill to the owner or other occupant of any automobile or other vehicle, who is willing to accept the same. 
(Code 1987, § 3-22; Ord. No. 77, § 8-105, 9-13-1965) 
Sec. 36-132. - Throwing, scattering handbills on vacant private premises. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to distribute, deposit, place, throw, scatter or cast any handbill in or upon any private premises which are temporarily or continuously uninhabited or vacant. 
(Code 1987, § 3-23; Ord. No. 77, § 8-106, 9-13-1965) 
Sec. 36-133. - Distributing handbills upon premises against wishes of occupants. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to distribute, deposit, place, throw, scatter or cast any handbill upon any premises if requested by anyone thereon not to do so, or if there is placed on the premises in a conspicuous position near the entrance thereof, a sign bearing the words, "No Trespassing," "No Peddlers or Agents," "No Advertisement," or any similar notice, indicating in any manner that the occupants of the premises do not desire to be molested or to have their right of privacy disturbed, or to have any such handbills left upon such premises. 
(Code 1987, § 3-24; Ord. No. 77, § 8-107, 9-13-1965) 
Sec. 36-134. - Distribution of handbills on private premises with permission of occupant; posting of handbills on vacant private premises. 
    No person licensed under the provisions of this article, or any other person, shall distribute, deposit, place, throw, scatter or cast any handbill in or upon any private premises which are inhabited, except by handing or transmitting any such handbill directly to the owner, occupant, or any other person then present in or upon such private premises; provided, however, that in case of inhabited private premises which are not posted as provided in this division, the aforesaid licensed or other person, unless requested by anyone upon such premises not to do so, may place or deposit any such handbill in or upon such inhabited private premises, if such handbill is so placed or deposited as to secure or prevent such handbill from being blown or drifted about such premises or elsewhere, except that mailboxes may not be so used when so prohibited by federal postal laws or regulations. 
(Code 1987, § 3-25; Ord. No. 77, § 8-108, 9-13-1965) 
Sec. 36-135. - Required printed information on handbills. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to distribute, deposit, scatter, hand out or circulate any handbill in any place, under any circumstances, which does not have printed on the cover, front or back thereof, the name and address of the following, except as otherwise permitted by the first amendment of the United States Constitution: 
(1)  The person who printed, wrote, compiled or manufactured the handbill; 
(2)  The person who caused the same to be distributed; provided, however, that in the case of a fictitious person or club, in addition to such fictitious name, the true names and addresses of the owners, managers or agents of the person sponsoring the handbill shall also appear thereon. 
(Code 1987, § 3-26; Ord. No. 77, § 8-109, 9-13-1965) 
Secs. 36-136-36-153. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - DISTRIBUTOR'S LICENSE 

Sec. 36-154. - Required. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to engage in the business of billposter for hire or handbill distributor for hire, or for any person to distribute handbills, without first complying with the terms of this article and all other relevant laws and regulations; provided, that nothing contained in this section shall apply to any person advertising the person's business or activity upon the person's own premises, if such business or activity is regularly established at a definite location in such city, and also if a license has been obtained therefor, if such license is required under the terms of any applicable law or ordinance. 
(Code 1987, § 3-41; Ord. No. 77, § 8-110(a), 9-13-1965) 
Sec. 36-155. - Application. 
(a)  Any person desiring to engage, as principal, either in the business of billposter for hire or in the business of distributing handbills for hire shall make application to and receive from the city clerk or other officer empowered to issue the license, who shall act whenever the city clerk is referred to in this division, a license in the manner and for the period prescribed by the terms of this article and by all relevant provisions of this Code. The applicant shall make written application to the city clerk upon a form provided for such purpose by the city clerk. The form shall contain, among other things that may be required: 
(1)  The name; 
(2)  The business address; 
(3)  A brief description of the nature of the business to be conducted by the applicant; 
(4)  The probable number of agents and employees so to be engaged; and 
(5)  A request for a license for the period for which the applicant seeks to engage in such business. 
(b)  The application shall be accompanied by the fee provided for in this division. 
(Code 1987, § 3-42; Ord. No. 77, § 8-110(b), (c), 9-13-1965) 
Sec. 36-156. - Fee. 
    License fees under the terms of this division shall be as prescribed by resolution of the city council. If any such license shall be surrendered by the licensee therein named, or shall be revoked for cause, neither the licensee named in such license, nor any other person shall be entitled to any refund of any part of such fee. 
(Code 1987, § 3-43; Ord. No. 77, § 8-110(c), (d), 9-13-1965; Ord. No. 75-49, § 1, 1-14-1975) 
Sec. 36-157. - Transfer. 
    No license issued pursuant to this division shall be transferable. 
(Code 1987, § 3-44; Ord. No. 77, § 8-110, 9-13-1965) 
Sec. 36-158. - Grounds for revocation. 
    Without excluding other just grounds for revocation, the city council, or official so empowered by law, may revoke any license required by this division obtained under an application containing a false or fraudulent statement knowingly made by the applicant with intent to obtain a license by means of false or fraudulent representations, or for violation of this article or any other grounds specified by law. 
(Code 1987, § 3-45; Ord. No. 77, § 8-110(c), 9-13-1965) 
Sec. 36-159. - Persons acting as agents, employees of licensees. 
    Persons acting for licensees as agents or employees in the posting or distributing of any signs or handbills shall not be required to obtain a license or pay a fee, but each such person shall comply with each and all of the other provisions hereof, and be subject thereto. 
(Code 1987, § 3-46; Ord. No. 77, § 8-110(d), 9-13-1965) 
Chapter 38 - PRECIOUS METAL AND GEM DEALERS[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference- Precious metal and gem dealer act, MCL 445.481 et seq. 

Sec. 38-1. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Agent or employee means a person who, for compensation or valuable consideration, is employed either directly or indirectly by a dealer. 
    Dealer means any person, corporation, partnership, or association, which, in whole or in part, engages in the ordinary course of repeated and recurrent transactions of buying or receiving precious items from the public within this city. 
    Gold means elemental gold having an atomic weight of 196.967 and the chemical element symbol of Au, whether found by itself or in combination with its alloys or any other metal. 
    Internet drop-off store means a person, corporation, or firm that contracts with other persons, corporations, or firms to offer its precious items for sale, purchase, consignment, or trade through means of an internet website and meets the conditions described in section 38-2(c). 
    Jewelry means an ornamental item made of a material that includes a precious gem. 
    Platinum means elemental platinum having an atomic weight of 195.09 and the chemical element symbol of Pt, whether found by itself or in combination with its alloys or any other metal. 
    Precious gem means a diamond, alexandrite, ruby, sapphire, opal, amethyst, emerald, aquamarine, morganite, garnet, jadeite, topaz, tourmaline, turquoise or pearl. 
    Precious item. 
(1)  The term "precious item" means jewelry, a precious gem, or an item containing gold, silver, or platinum. 
(2)  The term "precious item" does not include the following: 
a.  Coins, commemorative medals, and tokens struck by, or in behalf of, a government or private mint. 
b.  Bullion bars and discs of the type traded by banks and commodity exchanges. 
c.  Items at the time they are purchased directly from a dealer registered under this chapter, a manufacturer or a wholesaler who purchased them directly from a manufacturer. 
d.  Industrial machinery or equipment. 
e.  An item being returned to or exchanged at the dealer where the item was purchased and that is accompanied by a valid sales receipt. 
f.  An item which is received for alteration, redesign, or repair in a manner that does not substantially change its use and returned directly to the customer. 
g.  An item which does not have a jeweler's identifying mark or a serial mark and which the dealer purchases for less than $5.00. 
h.  Scrap metal which contains incidental traces of gold, silver, or platinum that are recoverable as a byproduct. 
i.  Jewelry which a customer trades for other jewelry having a greater value, and which difference in value is paid by the customer. 
    Silver means elemental silver having an atomic weight of 107.869 and the chemical element symbol of Ag, whether found by itself or in combination with its alloys or any other metal. 
(Code 1987, § 24-1; Ord. No. 81-118, § 2, 4-14-1987) 
State Law reference- Similar definitions, MCL 445.482. 
Sec. 38-2. - Certificate of registration. 
(a)  A dealer shall not conduct business in the city unless the dealer has obtained a valid certificate of registration from the city. 
(b)  This section does not require an internet drop-off store complying with subsection (c) of the section, or a person engaged in the sale, purchase, consignment or trade of precious items for the person to obtain a registration. 
(c)  An internet drop-off store in compliance with the following conditions is exempt from registration as a dealer under this chapter: 
(1)  Has a fixed place of business within this city except that the dealer exclusively transacts all purchases or sales by means of the internet and the purchases and sales are not physically transacted on the premises of that fixed place of business. 
(2)  Has the personal property or other valuable thing available on a website for viewing by photograph, if available, by the general public at no charge, which website shall be searchable by zip code, state or both. The website viewing shall include, as applicable, serial number, make, model and other unique identifying marks, numbers, names or letters appearing on the personal property or other valuable thing. 
(3)  Maintains records of the sale, purchase, consignment or trade of the personal property or other valuable thing for at least two years, which records shall contain a description, including a photograph, if available, and, if applicable, serial number, make, model, and other unique identifying marks, numbers, names, or letters appearing on the personal property or other valuable thing. 
(4)  Provide the police department with any name under which it conducts business on the website and access to the business premises at any time during normal business hours for purposes of inspection. 
(5)  Within 24 hours after a request from the police department, provide an electronic copy of the seller's or consignor's name, address, telephone number, driver license number and issuing state, the buyer's name and address if applicable, and a description of the personal property or other valuable thing as described in subsection (c)(3) of this section. The provision of information shall be in a format acceptable to the police department, but shall at least be in a legible format and in the English language. 
(6)  Provide that payment for the personal property or other valuable thing is executed by means of check or other electronic payment system, so long as the payment is not made in cash. No payment shall be provided to the seller until the item is sold. 
(7)  Immediately remove the personal property or other valuable thing from the website if the police department determines that the personal property or other valuable thing is stolen. 
(d)  A dealer shall apply to the police department for a certificate of registration, and pay a fee not to exceed the maximum permitted by state law to cover the reasonable cost of processing and issuing the certificate of registration, by disclosing the following information: 
(1)  The name, address, and thumbprint of the applicant. 
(2)  The name and address under which the applicant does business. 
(3)  The name, address, and thumbprint of all agents or employees of the dealer. Within 24 hours after hiring a new employee, the dealer shall forward to the local police agency the name, address, and thumbprint of the new employee. 
(e)  A dealer or an agent or employee of a dealer who is convicted of a misdemeanor under this chapter or under section 535 of the Michigan penal code, Public Act No. 328 of 1931 (MCL 750.535), or under the precious metal and gem dealer act, Public Act No. 95 of 1981 (MCL 445.481 et seq.) shall not be permitted to operate as a dealer within this city for a period of one year after conviction. 
(f)  A dealer or an agent or employee of a dealer who is convicted of a felony under section 535 of the Michigan penal code, Public Act No. 328 of 1931 (MCL 750.535), or under the precious metal and gem dealer act, Public Act No. 95 of 1981 (MCL 445.481 et seq.) shall not be permitted to operate as a dealer within this state for a period of five years after the conviction. 
(g)  This chapter shall not be construed to excuse a dealer from complying with the zoning ordinance, which appears in appendix A to this Code, or any local ordinance regulating commercial activities. However, the city may not pass an ordinance, or enforce an existing ordinance, that provides additional standards which must be met before the issuance of a certificate of registration. 
(h)  Upon receipt of the application described in subsection (d) of this section, the police department shall issue a certificate of registration in accordance with this section. 
(i)  Upon receipt of the certificate of registration from the police department, the dealer shall post it in a conspicuous place in the dealer's place of business. 
(j)  Not less than ten days before a dealer changes the name or address under which the dealer does business, the dealer shall notify the police department of the change. 
(Code 1987, § 24-2; Ord. No. 81-118, § 3, 4-14-1981; Ord. No. 91-223, § 1, 2-5-1991) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, MCL 445.483. 
Sec. 38-3. - Records of transactions. 
(a)  Contents. A dealer shall maintain in the dealer's place of business a permanent record of each transaction, on record of transaction forms provided for by subsection (g) of this section, legibly written in ink in the English language. Each record of transaction form shall be filled out in triplicate by the dealer or clerk, agent or employee of the dealer with one copy going to the police department pursuant to subsection (c) of this section, one copy going to the customer and one copy to be retained by the dealer pursuant to subsection (e) of this section. At the time a dealer receives or purchases a precious item, the dealer or the clerk agent or employee of the dealer shall ensure that the following information is recorded accurately on a record of transaction form: 
(1)  The dealer certificate of registration number. 
(2)  The date of the transaction. 
(3)  The name of the person conducting the transaction. 
(4)  The name, date of birth, driver's license number or state personal identification card number, and street and house number of the person with whom the transaction is being made, together with a legible imprint of the right thumb of the person with whom the transaction is made, or if that is not possible, then the left thumb or a finger of that person. However, the thumbprint or fingerprint shall only be required on the record of transaction form retained by the dealer. The thumbprint or fingerprint shall be made available to the police department only during the course of a police investigation involving a precious item described on the record of transaction. 
(5)  The name and address of the place from which the precious item being received or purchased by the dealer was last removed, as provided by the seller. 
(6)  A description of the precious item received or purchased, including its weight, type of metal, and physical characteristics. In the case of watches, the description shall contain the name of the marker and the number of both the works and the case. In the case of jewelry, all letters and marks inscribed on the jewelry shall be included in the description. 
(7)  The price to be paid by the dealer for the precious item. 
(8)  The number of the check, money order or bank draft to be tendered for payment by the dealer. 
(9)  At the option of the dealer, the name, street and house number of each person witnessing the transaction. 
(10)  The customer's signature. 
(b)  Numbering. The record of each transaction shall be numbered consecutively, commencing with the number one and the calendar year. 
(c)  Copy to police department; confidentiality. Within 48 hours after receiving or purchasing a precious item, the dealer shall send a copy of the record of transaction form to the police department. The record of transaction forms received by the police department shall not be open to inspection by the general public. The police department shall be responsible for ensuring the confidentiality of the record of transaction forms and ensuring that the record of transaction forms are used only for the purpose for which they were received. 
(d)  Inspection by authorized personnel. The record of transaction forms of a dealer and each precious item received shall be open to an inspection by the corporation counsel, the county prosecuting attorney, city police and the state police, at all times during the ordinary business hours of the dealer. As a condition of doing business, a dealer is deemed to have given consent to the inspection prescribed by this subsection. The record of transaction forms of a dealer shall not be open to inspection by the general public. 
(e)  Retention. Except as otherwise provided in this section, each record of a transaction shall be retained by the dealer at the dealer's place of business for not less than one year after the transaction to which the record pertains. After a period of one year from the date of the record of transaction, if a police investigation concerning a precious item described on the record of transaction has not occurred, the dealer and police department shall destroy and not keep a permanent record of the records of transaction. 
(f)  Dealer closing business or changing address. A dealer who goes out of business or changes the dealer's business address to another local jurisdiction either within or out of this state shall transmit the records of all transactions made by the dealer within one year before the dealer's closing or moving, to the city clerk, who shall promptly forward the information to the police department. 
(g)  Form of record. The form of the record of transaction shall be 81/2 inches by 11 inches in size and shall be substantially as follows: 
Record of Transaction Dealer Certificate #  _____ #  _____ (Printed on the form) (Transaction number printed

(Code 1987, § 24-7; Ord. No. 81-118, § 7, 4-14-1981; Ord. No. 91-223, § 1, 2-5-1991) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, MCL 445.484. 
Sec. 38-4. - Retention of items for nine days. 
    A precious item received by a dealer shall be retained by the dealer for nine calendar days after it was received, without any form of alteration other than that required to make an accurate appraisal of its value. 
(Code 1987, § 24-8; Ord. No. 81-118, § 8, 4-14-1981) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, MCL 445.485. 
Sec. 38-5. - Prohibited purchases or receipts of items. 
    A dealer or an agent or employee of a dealer shall not: 
(1)  Knowingly receive or purchase a precious item from any person who is less than 18 years of age or any person known by the dealer or agent or employee of the dealer to have been convicted of theft or receipt of stolen property within the preceding five years, whether the person is acting in the person's own behalf or as the agent of another. 
(2)  Knowingly receive or purchase a precious item from a person unless that person presents a valid driver's license or a valid state personal identification card. 
(Code 1987, § 24-4; Ord. No. 81-118, § 4, 4-14-1981) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, MCL 445.486. 
Chapter 40 - SECONDHAND GOODS[1]

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL

ARTICLE II. - PAWNBROKERS[2] 
Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference- Pawnbrokers, MCL 446.201 et seq. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 40-19. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Internet drop-off store means a person, corporation or firm that contracts with other persons, corporations or firms to offer its personal property or other valuable thing for sale, purchase, consignment or trade through means of an internet website and meets the conditions described in section 40-49(c). 
    Pawnbroker means any person who loans money on deposit or pledge of personal property or other valuable thing, other than securities or printed evidence of indebtedness, or who deals in the purchasing of personal property or other valuable thing on condition of selling the same back again at a stipulated price. 
(Code 1987, § 25-16) 
State Law reference- Similar definitions, MCL 446.203. 
Sec. 40-20. - Record of property received; contents, inspection. 
(a)  A pawnbroker shall keep a record in English, at the time the pawnbroker receives any article of personal property or other valuable thing by way of pawn, that includes a description of the article, a sequential transaction number, any amount of money loaned on the article, the name, residence, general description, and driver license number, official state personal identification card number, or government identification number of the person from whom the article was received, and the day and hour when the article was received. The record, the place where the business is carried on, and all articles of property in that place of business are subject to examination at any time by the city attorney, police department, the county prosecuting attorney, or the department of state police. 
(b)  Upon the receipt of any article of personal property or other valuable thing by way of pawn, the pawnbroker shall make a permanent record of the transaction on a form provided by the pawnbroker that substantially complies with the form described in subsection (d) of this section. Each record of transaction shall be completed in duplicate by the pawnbroker, legibly in the English language, and shall contain all applicable information required to complete the record of transaction form under subsection (d) of this section. This subsection does not prohibit the use and transmission of the information required in the record of the transaction by means of computer or other electronic media as permitted by the police department. 
(c)  The pawnbroker shall retain a record of each transaction and, within 48 hours after the property is received, shall send one copy of the record of transaction to the police department. 
(d)  The record of transaction form shall be 81/2 inches by 11 inches in size and shall be as follows: 
RECORD OF TRANSACTION FRONT Article Serial No. Model No. or Case No. Lens No. or Move. No. Trade Name Color Size No. Jewels Material Stone Set Design Description No. Kind of Stone Size Inscription or Initials Purchase Price  Amt. Loaned Dealer City Date Ticket No. Lady's[ ]     Gent's [ ]      Wrist [ ]     Pocket [ ]     Lapel [ ] BACK Operator's license # or Other I.D. # Customer's Name (Print) Street No. or RFD City and State Employed By: Rolled print of right thumb (If impossible then some other fingerprint.
