(Code 1987, § 25-18; Ord. No. 75-60, § 28, 7-22-1975) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, MCL 446.205. 
Sec. 40-21. - Statement to police of property received; contents. 
    A pawnbroker shall make daily, except Sunday, a sworn statement of the pawnbroker's transactions, describing the articles received, and setting forth the name, residence, and description of the person from whom the articles were received, to the chief of police. 
(Code 1987, § 25-19; Ord. No. 75-60, § 28, 7-22-1975) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, MCL 446.206. 
Sec. 40-22. - Memorandum of pawn for purchaser. 
    A pawnbroker, at the time of a loan, shall deliver to the person pawning or pledging any article a memorandum or note signed by the pawnbroker, containing the substance of the entry required to be made by the pawnbroker in the pawnbroker's book by section 40-21. A charge shall not be made or received by the pawnbroker for the entry, memorandum, or note. The memorandum or note shall be consecutively numbered and upon its back shall be printed in English in 12-point type the following: "If interest or charges in excess of three percent per month, plus storage charges provided in this document, are asked or received, this loan is void and of no effect; and the borrower cannot be made to pay back the money loaned, any interest on the loan, or any charges or any part of the charges, and the pawnbroker loses all right to the possession of the goods, article, or thing pawned, and shall surrender the item to the borrower or pawner upon due demand for the item." 
(Code 1987, § 25-20) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, MCL 446.208. 
Sec. 40-23. - Interest on loans; rate, computation. 
(a)  A licensed pawnbroker may charge upon any loan a rate of interest not to exceed three percent per month and is not required to accept any interest less than $0.50 on a single loan. A pawnbroker may also charge $1.00 per month or fraction of a month for the storage of unencumbered personal property under any single pledge or pawn. 
(b)  A pawnbroker may charge $1.00 per month or fraction of a month for a usage fee for unencumbered personal property pawned or pledged and used by the pawner during the term of the pawn or pledge. A usage fee charged under this subsection is not considered interest. 
(c)  A pawnbroker or the pawnbroker's agent or employee shall not charge or receive interest on the loan in excess of the amounts provided for in this article. 
(d)  Interest on any loan is not payable in advance and shall be computed on unpaid monthly balances without compounding. 
(e)  A pawnbroker is not entitled to any examination fee and shall not make any charge in excess of the amounts provided for in this article. 
(Code 1987, § 25-21) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, MCL 446.209. 
Sec. 40-24. - Destruction or defacing of pawned property. 
(a)  A pawnbroker shall not deface, scratch, obliterate, melt, separate or break into parts any article or thing received by the pawnbroker in pawn, or otherwise or in any manner do, cause or suffer to be done by others, anything that destroys or tends to destroy the identity of the article or thing, or tends to render the identification of the thing or article more difficult. 
(b)  A pawnbroker shall not accept by way of pledge, pawn, purchase or exchange any article or thing that customarily bears a manufacturer's serial number or other identifying insignia unless the number or insignia is plainly visible on the article or thing. 
(Code 1987, § 25-22) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, MCL 446.213. 
Sec. 40-25. - Sale of pawned property at public auction; notice; affidavit of publication of notice. 
(a)  Title to the item pledged or pawned vests in the pawnbroker upon the expiration of three months or of any period beyond three months agreed upon by the parties if the borrower has not paid the debt, interest and charges on the item pledged or pawned. 
(b)  A pawnbroker shall not sell any pawn or pledge until the item has remained in the pawnbroker's possession for at least three months. 
(Code 1987, § 25-23) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, MCL 446.210. 
Sec. 40-26. - Tender of debt and costs before sale; effect on right to property. 
(a)  If at any time before the sale of the item pledged or pawned the borrower pays or tenders to the pawnbroker the debt and interest and charges on the item, that payment or tender reinvests the pawner with the title and right of possession to the property pledged. 
(b)  A pawnbroker may agree in writing, after pledged or pawned unencumbered personal property has been deposited with the pawnbroker, to allow the pawner to maintain possession and use of the pledged or pawned unencumbered personal property during the term of the pawn or pledge transaction. The agreement may also include the payment of a usage fee under section 40-23. A pawnbroker may take possession of the pledged or pawned property pursuant to section 9609 of the uniform commercial code, Public Act No. 174 of 1962 (MCL 440.9609). 
(Code 1987, § 25-24) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, MCL 446.211. 
Sec. 40-27. - Acceptance of property from certain persons unlawful. 
    A pawnbroker shall not receive for pawn any article from any person under 18 years of age or a person the pawnbroker suspects as having stolen the article to be pawned. 
(Code 1987, § 25-26) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, MCL 446.214. 
Sec. 40-28. - Transaction of business on Sunday. 
    No license granted under the provisions of this article shall authorize any business to be transacted by pawnbrokers on the first day of the week commonly called Sunday. 
(Code 1987, § 25-27) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, MCL 446.217. 
Sec. 40-29. - Action on bond. 
    If any person shall be aggrieved by the conduct of any licensed pawnbroker and shall recover judgment against the pawnbroker therefor, such person may, after the return unsatisfied, either in whole or in part, of any execution issued upon the judgment, maintain an action in the person's own name upon the bond of the pawnbroker in any court having jurisdiction of the amount of the judgment remaining unsatisfied. Such bond shall remain in full force and effect for a period of 90 days after the expiration or cancellation of any such bond. 
(Code 1987, § 25-28; Ord. No. 75-60, § 28, 7-22-1975) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, MCL 446.204. 
Sec. 40-30. - Property pawned without owner's consent; bond of complainant. 
    The bond shall be in double the value of the property claimed, with such surety as the court shall approve, and shall be given to the person from whose possession the property was taken, with the condition that the obligor so claiming the same will pay all the costs and damages that may be recovered against the obligor by the obligee in any suit brought within ten days from the date of the bond. 
(Code 1987, § 25-29) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, MCL 446.216. 
Secs. 40-31-40-48. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - LICENSE 

Sec. 40-49. - Required. 
(a)  A person, corporation or firm shall not conduct business as a pawnbroker in this city without having first obtained from the mayor a license under this division that authorizes that person, corporation, or firm to conduct that business. This subsection does not require an internet drop-off store complying with subsection (c) of this section, or a person engaged in the sale, purchase, consignment, or trade of personal property or other valuable thing personally, to obtain a license under this division. 
(b)  Licensure under either or both of the following acts does not exempt a person from obtaining a license under this division: 
(1)  The precious metal and gem dealer act, Public Act No. 95 of 1981 (MCL 445.481 et seq.), and chapter 38 of this Code. 
(2)  Public Act No. 350 of 1917 (MCL 445.401 et seq.), and article III of this chapter. 
(c)  An internet drop-off store in compliance with the following conditions is exempt from licensure as a pawnbroker under this division: 
(1)  Has a fixed place of business within this state except that the pawnbroker exclusively transacts all purchases or sales by means of the internet and the purchases and sales are not physically transacted on the premises of that fixed place of business. 
(2)  Has the personal property or other valuable thing available on a website for viewing by photograph, if available, by the general public at no charge, which website shall be searchable by zip code or state, or both. The website viewing shall include, as applicable, serial number, make, model, and other unique identifying marks, numbers, names, or letters appearing on the personal property or other valuable thing. 
(3)  Maintains records of the sale, purchase, consignment, or trade of the personal property or other valuable thing for at least two years, which records shall contain a description, including a photograph, if available, and, if applicable, serial number, make, model, and other unique identifying marks, numbers, names or letters appearing on the personal property or other valuable thing. 
(4)  Provide the police department with any name under which it conducts business on the website and access to the business premises at any time during normal business hours for purposes of inspection. 
(5)  Within 24 hours after a request from the police department, provide an electronic copy of the seller's or consignor's name, address, telephone number, driver license number and issuing state, the buyer's name and address, if applicable, and a description of the personal property or other valuable thing as described in subsection (c)(3) of this section. The provision of information shall be in a format acceptable to the police department but shall at least be in a legible format and in the English language. 
(6)  Provide that payment for the personal property or other valuable thing is executed by means of check or other electronic payment system, so long as the payment is not made in cash. No payment shall be provided to the seller until the item is sold. 
(7)  Immediately remove the personal property or other valuable thing from the website if the police department determines that the personal property or other valuable thing is stolen. 
(Code 1987, § 25-41; Ord. No. 75-60, § 28, 7-22-1975; Ord. No. 91-224, § 1, 2-5-1991) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, MCL 446.201. 
Sec. 40-50. - Issuance. 
    The city clerk, on behalf of the mayor, may grant to any suitable person a license authorizing such person to carry on the business of a pawnbroker subject to the provisions of this article. No such license will be issued except upon the approval of the police chief and the fire chief. 
(Code 1987, § 25-42; Ord. No. 75-60, § 28, 7-22-1975; Ord. No. 91-224, § 1, 2-5-1991) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, MCL 446.202. 
Sec. 40-51. - Fee and bond. 
    No pawnbroker's license shall be issued to any person applying therefor, until the person pays to the city clerk an annual license fee as prescribed by resolution of the city council, and gives a bond to the city in its corporate name, in the penal sum of $3,000.00 with at least two sureties, to be approved by the city council as a condition for the faithful performance of the duties and obligations pertaining to the business and for the payment of all costs and damages incurred by any violation of this article. 
(Code 1987, § 25-43; Ord. No. 75-60, § 28, 7-22-1975; Ord. No. 91-224, § 1, 2-5-1991) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, MCL 446.202. 
Sec. 40-52. - Place of business designated. 
    The pawnbroker's license shall designate the particular place in the city where the license holder shall carry on business, and no person receiving a pawnbroker's license shall carry on the license holder's business in any other place than the one designated in the license. 
(Code 1987, § 25-44) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, MCL 446.202. 
Sec. 40-53. - Transferability. 
    The license issued under this division shall not be transferable. 
(Code 1987, § 25-45) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, MCL 446.202. 
Sec. 40-54. - Term. 
    The license issued pursuant to this division shall be for the period of one year from the date of issuance, unless sooner revoked for cause. 
(Code 1987, § 25-46) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, MCL 446.202. 
Sec. 40-55. - Revocation. 
    Upon the conviction of any person doing business as a pawnbroker for a violation of this article or upon the conviction of any clerk, agent, servant or employee of any such person, the license of such person shall forthwith be revoked and no part of the license fee of such person shall be returned to the pawnbroker. The city shall not issue a license as a pawnbroker to that person for the period of one year from the date of the revocation. 
(Code 1987, § 25-47; Ord. No. 91-224, § 1, 2-5-1991) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, MCL 446.219. 
Secs. 40-56-40-83. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - SECONDHAND OR JUNK DEALERS[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
State Law reference- Junkyards near highways, MCL 252.201 et seq.; licensing of secondhand and junk dealers, MCL 445.401 et seq. 

Sec. 40-84. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Automotive recycler means a person who engages in business primarily for the purpose of selling retail salvage vehicle parts and secondarily for the purpose of selling retail salvage motor vehicles or manufacturing or selling a product of gradable scrap metal or a person employed as a salvage vehicle agent as that term is defined in section 56c of the Michigan vehicle code, Public Act No. 300 of 1949 (MCL 257.56c). 
    Industrial scrap means materials that are a direct product or byproduct of any form of manufacturing, shaping or cutting process from a person whose principal business is the manufacturing, shaping or cutting of materials at a fixed place of business. 
    Internet drop-off store means a person, corporation, or firm that contracts with other persons, corporations, or firms to offer its personal property or other valuable thing for sale, purchase, consignment, or trade through means of an internet website and meets the conditions described in section 40-85(c). 
    Scrap processor means a person, utilizing machinery and equipment and operating from a fixed location, whose principal business is the processing and manufacturing of iron, steel, nonferrous metals, paper, plastic, or glass, into prepared grades of products suitable for consumption by recycling mills, foundries, and other scrap processors. 
    Secondhand dealer or junk dealer. 
(1)  The term "secondhand dealer" or "junk dealer" means any person whose principal business is that of purchasing, selling, exchanging, storing or receiving secondhand articles of any kind, scrap metals, cast iron, old iron, old steel, tool steel, aluminum, copper, brass, lead pipe or tools or lighting and plumbing fixtures. 
(2)  The term "secondhand dealer" or "junk dealer" does not include a scrap processor, an automotive recycler or a junkyard that deals principally in industrial scrap that is licensed by the city. 
(Code 1987, § 25-63; Ord. No. 07-419, § 1, 5-1-2007) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, MCL 445.403. 
Sec. 40-85. - Secondhand or junk dealer; businesses covered. 
(a)  A person, corporation, co-partnership, or firm shall not carry on the business of dealer in secondhand goods or junk dealer in the city without having first obtained a license from the city authorizing that person, corporation, co-partnership, or firm to carry on that business. 
(b)  This section does not require an internet drop-off store complying with subsection (c) of this section, or a person engaged in the sale, purchase, consignment or trade of personal property or other valuable thing personally, to obtain a license under this article. 
(c)  An internet drop-off store in compliance with the following conditions is exempt from licensure as a secondhand dealer or junk dealer under this article: 
(1)  Has a fixed place of business within this state except that the secondhand dealer or junk dealer exclusively transacts all purchases or sales by means of the internet and the purchases and sales are not physically transacted on the premises of that fixed place of business. 
(2)  Has the personal property or other valuable thing available on a website for viewing by photograph, if available, by the general public at no charge, which website shall be searchable by zip code, state or both. The website viewing shall include, as applicable: 
a.  Serial number; 
b.  Make; 
c.  Model; and 
d.  Other unique identifying marks, numbers, names or letters; 
appearing on the personal property or other valuable thing. 
(3)  Maintains records of the sale, purchase, consignment or trade of the personal property or other valuable thing for at least two years, which records shall contain a description, including a photograph, if available, and, if applicable, serial number, make, model, and other unique identifying marks, numbers, names, or letters appearing on the personal property or other valuable thing. 
(4)  Provide the city police department with any name under which it conducts business on the website and access to the business premises at any time during normal business hours for purposes of inspection. 
(5)  Within 24 hours after a request from the police department, provide an electronic copy of the seller's or consignor's name, address, telephone number, driver license number and issuing state, the buyer's name and address, if applicable, and a description of the personal property or other valuable thing as described in subsection (c)(3) of this section. The provision of information shall be in a format acceptable to the police department but shall at least be in a legible format and in the English language. 
(6)  Provide that payment for the personal property or other valuable thing is executed by means of check or other electronic payment system, so long as the payment is not made in cash. No payment shall be provided to the seller until the item is sold. 
(7)  Immediately remove the personal property or other valuable thing from the website if the police department determines that the personal property or other valuable thing is stolen. 
(d)  This section does not exempt a person purchasing or selling articles of nonferrous metals from compliance with the nonferrous metal regulatory act, Public Act No. 429 of 2008 (MCL 445.421 et seq.). 
(Code 1987, § 25-61; Ord. No. 07-419, § 1, 5-1-2007) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, MCL 445.401. 
Sec. 40-86. - License. 
(a)  The city may grant to any person, corporation, co-partnership or firm, a license authorizing that person, corporation, co-partnership or firm to carry on the business of a secondhand dealer or junk dealer subject to the provisions of this article. 
(b)  The license shall designate the particular place where that person, corporation, co-partnership, or firm shall carry on that business. The business shall be conducted only in the place designated in the license. 
(c)  The license shall be for the period of one year from date of issuance unless sooner revoked for cause and is not transferable. The city council shall establish the fee for the processing and issuance of the license. 
(d)  The city may inspect the premises of a licensed secondhand or junk dealer at any time during normal business hours. 
(Code 1987, § 25-62; Ord. No. 07-419, § 1, 5-1-2007) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, MCL 445.402. 
Sec. 40-87. - Sign; record of transactions. 
(a)  A secondhand dealer or junk dealer shall post in a conspicuous place in or upon its place of business a sign having its name and occupation. 
(b)  A secondhand or junk dealer shall make and maintain a separate book or other written or electronic record, numbered consecutively, and open to inspection by a member of the police department, in which shall be written or entered in the English language at the time of the purchase or exchange of any article a description of the article, and all of the following: 
(1)  The name, description, fingerprint, operator's or chauffeur's license or state identification number, registration plate number and address of the person from whom the article was purchased and received. The secondhand dealer or junk dealer shall make a copy of the operator's license, chauffeur's license, or state identification card as part of the book or record. 
(2)  The day and hour the purchase or exchange was made. 
(3)  The location from which the item was obtained. 
(4)  Payment for an item shall be made only by check or by an electronic payment system. The record shall indicate the method of payment. 
(Code 1987, § 25-64; Ord. No. 07-419, § 1, 5-1-2007) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, MCL 445.404. 
Sec. 40-88. - Retention of goods purchased; tagging; records to police. 
(a)  The articles purchased or exchanged shall be retained by the purchaser for at least 15 days before disposing of them, in an accessible place in the building where the articles are purchased and received. A tag shall be attached to the articles in some visible and convenient place, with the number written thereupon, to correspond with the entry number in the book or other record. 
(b)  The purchaser shall prepare and deliver on Monday of each week to the chief of police, before 12:00 noon, a legible and correct paper or electronic copy, in the English language, from the book or other written or electronic record, containing a description of each article purchased or received during the preceding week, the hour and day when the purchase was made, the description of the person from whom it was purchased, and a copy of the documentation required under section 40-87 regarding the person from whom it was purchased. The statement shall be verified in a manner acceptable to the chief of police. 
(c)  This section does not apply to old rags, waste paper, and household goods except radios, televisions, record players, and electrical appliances and does not require the purchaser to retain articles purchased from individuals, firms, or corporations having a fixed place of business after those articles shall have been reported. 
(Code 1987, § 25-65; Ord. No. 07-419, § 1, 5-1-2007) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, MCL 445.405. 
Sec. 40-89. - Person without business place; retention of goods, record for police. 
    If the purchaser or receiver, by exchange or otherwise, as described in section 40-84, is a peddler or goes about with a wagon to purchase or obtain by exchange or otherwise, any of such articles, and does not have a place of business in a building, the peddler need not retain such articles for 15 days before selling them, provided on Monday of each week the peddler files with the chief of police a report showing the place of business of the person to whom such sale was made; a copy of the record required by such section to be kept in a separate book of the articles purchased or received during the preceding week, including a description of such articles sold, to whom sold and the place of business. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, MCL 445.406. 
Sec. 40-90. - Unlawful purchases. 
    No person shall purchase or receive any article: 
(1)  Between the hours of 9:00 p.m. and 7:00 a.m.; 
(2)  On Sunday; 
(3)  From any person intoxicated or under the age of 17 years without written consent of parent or guardian; and 
(4)  From a person known or suspected to be a thief or a receiver of stolen property. 
(Code 1987, § 25-66; Ord. No. 07-419, § 1, 5-1-2007) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, MCL 445.407. 
Secs. 40-91-40-108. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - GARAGE SALES 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 40-109. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Sale means any garage sale, as defined in the zoning ordinance in appendix A to this Code. 
    Tangible personal property includes any goods, warehouse merchandise or other property capable of being the object of a sale regulated by this article. It shall encompass both new and used tangible personal property and damaged or discarded property. 
(Code 1987, § 25-101; Ord. No. 79-109, § 1, 2-27-1979) 
Sec. 40-110. - Persons and sales excepted. 
    The provisions of this article shall not apply to or affect the following persons or sales: 
(1)  Persons selling goods pursuant to an order or process of a court of competent jurisdiction; 
(2)  Persons acting in accordance with their powers and duties as public officials; 
(3)  Any person selling or advertising for sale any item of personal property which is specifically named or described in the advertisement and which separate items do not exceed ten in number; 
(4)  Any sale conducted by any merchant or other business establishment from or at a place of business wherein such sale would be permitted by the zoning regulations of the city, included as appendix A to this Code, or under the protection of the present nonconforming section thereof; 
(5)  Any bona fide charitable, eleemosynary, educational, cultural or governmental institution or organization provided that the burden of establishing the exemption under this subsection shall be on the organization or institution claiming such exemption. 
(Code 1987, § 25-102; Ord. No. 79-109, § 12, 2-27-1979) 
Sec. 40-111. - Signs. 
    No signs advertising a sale regulated by this article shall be placed without complying with section 18.06 of the zoning ordinance in appendix A to this Code. 
(Code 1987, § 25-103; Ord. No. 79-109, § 11, 2-27-1979) 
Secs. 40-112-40-135. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - PERMIT 

Sec. 40-136. - Required. 
    A permit issued by the building department shall be obtained by any person before selling or offering to sell any goods at a sale to be advertised or held out by any means to be one of the type of sales enumerated in section 40-109. No person shall conduct, advertise or promote any sale of tangible personal property without a permit issued pursuant thereto. 
(Code 1987, § 25-116; Ord. No. 79-109, §§ 2, 3, 2-27-1979) 
Sec. 40-137. - Application. 
    An application for a permit to conduct any of the sales regulated by this article shall be made available at the office of the city clerk on a form to be provided therefor, which permit shall contain the following information: 
(1)  Name and address of the person conducting the sale; 
(2)  Location at which the sale is to be conducted; 
(3)  The number of days which the sale is to be conducted within the limits prescribed in this division; 
(4)  A general description of the items proposed to be sold; 
(5)  The date, location, and nature of goods of the last past sale conducted by the applicant. 
(Code 1987, § 25-117; Ord. No. 79-109, § 4, 2-27-1979) 
Sec. 40-138. - Fee. 
    A fee for the permit required by this division shall be paid to the city at the time an application is made as set by the city council. The amount of such fee shall be determined by resolution of the city council. 
(Code 1987, § 25-118; Ord. No. 79-109, § 5, 2-27-1979) 
Sec. 40-139. - Display. 
    The permit authorizing sale regulated by this article shall be displayed in the front window or other prominent place of the location of the sale which place is clearly visible from the street. 
(Code 1987, § 25-119; Ord. No. 79-109, § 9, 2-27-1979) 
Sec. 40-140. - Term. 
    No permit issued pursuant to this division shall be issued authorizing any such sale to be conducted for a period longer than five days. 
(Code 1987, § 25-120; Ord. No. 79-109, § 8, 2-27-1979) 
Sec. 40-141. - Number of permits allowed; exception. 
(a)  No more than two permits shall be issued pursuant to this division to any person within the period of any calendar year. 
(b)  An additional permit may be issued by the city clerk during a six-month period if the applicant is in the process of moving out of or within the city; however, the city clerk may not issue more than one additional permit during the six-month period. 
(Code 1987, § 25-121; Ord. No. 79-109, §§ 6, 7, 2-27-1979) 
Chapter 42 - SPECIAL ASSESSMENTS[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Charter reference- Special assessments, ch. XIV; procedure to be fixed by ordinance, § 14.5. 
State Law reference- Power re special assessments, MCL 117.4a, 117.4b, 117.4d, 117.5; notices and hearings, MCL 211.741 et seq.; deferment of special assessment for homesteads, MCL 211.761 et seq.; collection of unpaid special assessments, MCL 211.501 et seq. 

Sec. 42-1. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Cost, when referring to the cost of any local public improvement, includes the cost of services, plans, condemnation, spreading of rolls, notices, advertising, financing, construction and legal fees and all other costs incident to the making of such improvement, the special assessments therefor and the financing thereof. 
    Local public improvement means any public improvement which is of such a nature as to benefit especially any real property within a district in the vicinity of such improvement. 
(Code 1987, § 27-1; Ord. No. 68-3, § 1, 7-29-1968) 
Sec. 42-2. - Authority to assess. 
    The whole cost or any part thereof of any local public improvement may be defrayed by special assessment upon the lands specially benefited by the improvement in the manner provided in this chapter. 
(Code 1987, § 27-2; Ord. No. 68-3, § 2, 7-29-1968) 
Sec. 42-3. - Initiation of projects. 
    Proceedings for the making of local public improvements within the city, the tentative necessity thereof, and determination that the whole or any part of the expense thereof shall be defrayed by special assessment upon the property especially benefited, provided that all special assessments levied shall be in proportion to the benefits derived from the improvements, may be commenced by resolution of the city council, with or without a petition. 
(Code 1987, § 27-3; Ord. No. 68-3, § 3, 7-29-1968) 
Sec. 42-4. - Report by mayor. 
(a)  Before the city council shall consider the making of any local public improvement, the project shall be referred by resolution to the mayor directing the mayor to cause to be prepared, a report which shall include: 
(1)  Necessary plans, profiles, specifications and detailed estimates of cost; 
(2)  An estimate of the life of the improvement; 
(3)  A description of the assessment district; and 
(4)  Such other pertinent information; 
as will permit the city council to decide the cost, extent and necessity of the improvement proposed and what part or proportion thereof should be paid by special assessments upon the property especially benefited and what part, if any, should be paid by the city at large. 
(b)  The city council shall not finally determine to proceed with the making of any local public improvement until the report of the mayor has been filed, or until after a public hearing has been held by the city council for the purpose of hearing objections to the making of such improvement. 
(Code 1987, § 27-4; Ord. No. 68-3, § 4, 7-29-1968) 
Sec. 42-5. - Determination of necessity by city council. 
    After the mayor has presented the report required by this chapter for making any local public improvement as requested in the resolution of the city council, and the city council has reviewed the report, a resolution may be passed tentatively determining the necessity of the improvement, setting forth the nature thereof, prescribing what part or proportion of the cost of such improvement shall be paid by special assessment upon the property especially benefited, determination of benefits received by affected properties, what part, if any, shall be paid by the city at large, designating the limits of the special assessment district to be affected, designating whether to be assessed according to frontage or other benefits, placing the complete information on file in the office of the city clerk, where the same may be found for examination, and directing the city clerk to give notice of public hearing on the proposed improvement, at which time and place opportunity will be given interested persons to be heard. Such notice shall be given by one publication in a newspaper published or circulated within the city and by first class mail addressed to each owner of or person in interest in property to be assessed as shown by the last general tax assessment roll of the city. The publication shall be made at least seven full days prior to the date of the hearing, and the mailing shall be made at least ten full days prior to the date of the hearing. The hearing may be held at any regular, adjourned or special meeting of the city council. 
(Code 1987, § 27-5; Ord. No. 68-3, § 5, 7-29-1968; Ord. No. 89-205, 5-16-1989) 
State Law reference- Special assessment notices and hearings, MCL 211.741 et seq. 
Sec. 42-6. - Hearing on necessity. 
    At the public hearing on the proposed local public improvement, all persons interested shall be given an opportunity to be heard, after which the city council may modify the scope of the local public improvement in such a manner as they shall deem to be in the best interest of the city as a whole; provided that if the amount of work is increased or additions are made to the district, then another hearing shall be held pursuant to the notice prescribed in section 42-5. If the determination of the city council shall be to proceed with the improvement, a resolution shall be passed approving the necessary profiles, plans, specifications, assessment district and detailed estimates of cost, and directing the city assessor to prepare a special assessment roll in accordance with the city council's determination and report the same to the city council for confirmation. 
(Code 1987, § 27-6; Ord. No. 68-3, § 6, 7-29-1968) 
State Law reference- Special assessment notices and hearings, MCL 211.741 et seq. 
Sec. 42-7. - Deviation from plans and specifications. 
    No deviation from original plans or specifications for a local public improvement as adopted shall be permitted by any officer or employee of the city without authority of the city council by resolution. A copy of the resolution authorizing such changes or deviation shall be certified by the city clerk and attached to the original plans and specifications on file in the city clerk's office. 
(Code 1987, § 27-7; Ord. No. 68-3, § 7, 7-29-1968) 
Sec. 42-8. - Limitations on preliminary expenses. 
    The city council shall specify the provisions and procedures for financing a local public improvement. No contract or expenditure, except for the cost of preparing necessary profiles, plans, specifications and estimates of cost, shall be made for the improvement, or shall any improvement be commenced until special assessments to defray the costs of the same shall have been levied. 
(Code 1987, § 27-8; Ord. No. 68-3, § 8, 7-29-1968) 
Sec. 42-9. - Roll to be made by city assessor. 
    The city assessor shall make a special assessment roll, of all lots and parcels of land within the designated district benefited by the proposed local public improvement and assess to each lot or parcel of land the proportionate amount benefited thereby. The amount spread in each case shall be based upon the detailed estimate of the mayor as approved by the city council. 
(Code 1987, § 27-9; Ord. No. 68-3, § 9, 7-29-1968) 
Sec. 42-10. - City assessor to file roll. 
    When the city assessor shall have completed the special assessment roll and shall file the same with the city clerk for presentation to the city council for review and certification by it. 
(Code 1987, § 27-10; Ord. No. 68-3, § 10, 7-29-1968) 
Sec. 42-11. - Meeting to review roll; objections to be in writing. 
    Upon receipt of the special assessment roll, the city council, by resolution, shall accept such assessment roll and order it to be filed in the office of the city clerk for public examination, shall fix the time and place the city council will meet to review such special assessment roll and direct the city clerk to give notice of a public hearing for the purpose of affording an opportunity for interested persons to be heard. Such notice shall be given by one publication in a newspaper published or circulated within the city and by first class mail addressed to each owner of or person in interest in property to be assessed as shown by the last general tax assessment roll of the city. The publication shall be made at least seven full days prior to the date of the hearing, and the mailing shall be made at least ten full days prior to the date of the hearing. The hearing required by this section may be held at any regular, adjourned or special meeting of the city council. At this meeting, all interested persons or parties shall present in writing their objections, if any, to the assessments against them. The city assessor shall be present at every meeting of the city council at which a special assessment is to be reviewed. 
(Code 1987, § 27-11; Ord. No. 68-3, § 11, 7-29-1968; Ord. No. 89-205, 5-16-1989) 
State Law reference- Special assessment notices and hearings, MCL 211.741 et seq. 
Sec. 42-12. - Changes and corrections in roll. 
    The city council shall meet at the time and place designated for the review of the special assessment roll, and at such meeting or a proper adjournment thereof shall consider all objections thereto submitted in writing. The city council may correct the roll as to any special assessment or description of any lot or parcel of land or other errors appearing therein; or it may, by resolution, annul the special assessment roll and direct that new proceedings be instituted. The same proceedings shall be followed in making a new roll as in the making of the original roll. If, after hearing all objections and making a record of such changes as the city council deems justified, the city council determines that it is satisfied with the special assessment roll and that assessments are in proportion to benefits received, it shall thereupon pass a resolution reciting such determinations, confirming such roll, placing it on file in the office of the city clerk and directing the city clerk to attach the clerk's warrant to a certified copy thereof within ten days, therein commanding the city assessor to spread and the city treasurer to collect the various sums and amounts appearing thereon as directed by the city council. The roll shall have the date of confirmation endorsed thereon and shall from that date be final and conclusive for the purpose of the improvement to which it applies, subject only to adjustment to conform to the actual cost of the improvement as provided in section 42-17. 
(Code 1987, § 27-12; Ord. No. 68-3, § 12, 7-29-1968) 
Sec. 42-13. - Objection to assessment. 
    If, at or prior to the final confirmation of any special assessments, more than 50 percent of the number of owners of privately owned real property to be assessed for local public improvement, or in the case of paving or similar improvements, more than 50 percent of the number of owners of frontage to be assessed for any such improvement shall object in writing to the proposed improvement, the improvement shall not be made by proceedings delineated by this chapter without a five-sevenths votes of the members of the city council elect, or a two-thirds vote of the city council elect if the city council membership is increased as provided for in section 4.1 of the city Charter, provided that this section shall not apply to sidewalk construction. 
(Code 1987, § 27-13; Ord. No. 68-3, § 13, 7-29-1968) 
Sec. 42-14. - Due upon confirmation of roll. 
    All special assessments, except such installments thereof as the city council shall make payable at a future time as provided in this chapter, shall be due and payable upon confirmation of the special assessment roll. 
(Code 1987, § 27-14; Ord. No. 68-3, § 14, 7-29-1968) 
Sec. 42-15. - Payment in annual installments. 
(a)  The city council may provide for the payment of special assessments in annual installments. The annual installments shall not exceed 30 in number, the first installment being due: 
(1)  Upon confirmation of the roll; 
(2)  On such date as the city council may determine and deferred installments being due annually thereafter; or 
(3)  In the discretion of the city council, may be spread upon and made a part of each annual city tax roll thereafter until all are paid. 
(b)  Interest shall be charged on all deferred installments at a rate not to exceed seven percent per annum, commencing on the due date of the first installment and payable on the due date of each subsequent installment. 
(c)  The full amount of all or any deferred installments, with interest accrued thereon to the date of payment, may be paid in advance of the due dates thereof. 
(d)  If the full assessment or the first installment thereof shall be due upon confirmation, each property owner shall have 60 days from the date of confirmation to pay the full amount of the assessment, or the full amount of any installments thereof, without interest or penalty. Following the 60-day period, the assessment or first installment thereof shall, if unpaid, be considered as delinquent and the same penalties shall be collected on such unpaid assessments or first installments thereof as are provided in the city Charter to be collected on delinquent general city taxes. Deferred installments shall be collected without penalty until 60 days after the due date thereof, after which time such installments shall be considered as delinquent and such penalties on the installments shall be collected as are provided in the city Charter to be collected on delinquent general city taxes. 
(e)  After the city council has confirmed the roll, the city treasurer shall notify by mail each property owner on the roll that the roll has been filed, stating the amount assessed and the terms of payment. Failure on the part of the city treasurer to give the notice or of such owner to receive the notice shall not invalidate any special assessment roll of the city or any assessment thereon, nor excuse the payment of interest or penalties. 
(Code 1987, § 27-15; Ord. No. 68-3, § 15, 7-29-1968) 
Sec. 42-16. - Creation of lien. 
    Special assessments and all interest, penalties and charges thereon, from the date of confirmation of the roll, shall become a debt to the city from the persons to whom they are assessed and, until paid, shall be and remain a lien upon the property assessed, of the same character and effect as the lien created by general law for county and school taxes and by the city Charter for city taxes, and the lands upon which the same are a lien shall be subject to sale therefor the same as are lands upon which delinquent city taxes constitute a lien. 
(Code 1987, § 27-16; Ord. No. 68-3, § 16, 7-29-1968) 
Sec. 42-17. - Additional assessments; refunds. 
    The city clerk shall, within 60 days after the completion of each local or special public improvement, compile the actual cost thereof and certify the same to the city assessor who shall adjust the special assessment roll to correspond therewith. Should the assessment prove larger than necessary by five percent or less, it shall be reported to the city council which may place the excess in the city treasury or make a refund thereof pro rata according to the assessment. If the assessment exceeds the amount necessary by more than five percent, the entire excess shall be credited to owners of property as shown by the city assessment roll upon which such assessment has been levied, pro rata according to the assessment; provided, however, that no refunds of special assessments may be made which impair or contravene the provision of any outstanding obligation or bond secured in whole or part by such special assessments. When any special assessment roll shall prove insufficient to meet the cost of the improvement for which it was made, the city council may make an additional pro rata assessment, but the total amount assessed against any one parcel of land shall not exceed the benefits received by the lot or parcel of land. 
(Code 1987, § 27-17; Ord. No. 68-3, § 17, 7-29-1968) 
Sec. 42-18. - Additional procedures. 
    In any case where the provisions of this chapter may prove to be insufficient to carry out fully the making of any special assessment, the city council shall provide by ordinance any additional steps or procedures required. 
(Code 1987, § 27-18; Ord. No. 68-3, § 18, 7-29-1968) 
Sec. 42-19. - Payment of principal and interest on bonds. 
    If bonds are issued in anticipation of the collection of special assessments as provided in this chapter, all collections on each special assessment roll or combination of rolls shall be set apart in a separate fund for the payment of the principal and interest on the bonds so issued in anticipation of the payment of such special assessments, and shall be used for no other purpose. 
(Code 1987, § 27-19; Ord. No. 68-3, § 19, 7-29-1968) 
Sec. 42-20. - Special assessment accounts. 
    Moneys raised by special assessment to pay the cost of any local public improvement shall be held in a special fund to pay such cost or to repay any money borrowed therefor. Each special assessment account must be used only for the improvement project for which the assessment was levied, expenses incidental thereto, including the repayment of the principal and interest on money borrowed therefor, and to refund excessive assessments, if refunds are authorized. 
(Code 1987, § 27-20; Ord. No. 68-3, § 20, 7-29-1968) 
Sec. 42-21. - Contested assessments. 
    Except and unless notice is given to the city council in writing of an intention to contest or enjoin the collection of any special assessment for the construction of any pavement, sewer or other local public improvement, the construction of any sidewalk or the removal or abatement of any public hazard or nuisance within 30 days after the date of the meeting of the city council at which it is finally determined to proceed with the making of the improvement in question, which notice shall state the grounds on which the proceedings are to be contested, no suit or action of any kind shall be instituted or maintained for the purpose of contesting or enjoining the collection of such special assessments. Regardless of whether or not any local public improvement is completed in any special assessment district, no owner of real property located in such district shall be entitled to commence any suit or action for the purpose of contesting or enjoining the collection of any such special assessment after the owner has received the benefits from the substantial completion of that portion of such local public improvement for which the owner is assessed. 
(Code 1987, § 27-21; Ord. No. 68-3, § 21, 7-29-1968) 
Sec. 42-22. - Reassessments. 
    Whenever the city council shall deem any special assessment invalid or defective for any reason whatever, or if any court of competent jurisdiction shall have adjudged such assessment to be illegal for any reason whatever, in whole or in part, the city council shall have power to cause a new assessment to be made for the same purpose for which the former assessment was made, whether the improvement or any part thereof has been completed and whether any part of the assessment has been collected or not. All proceedings on such reassessment and for the collection thereof shall be made in the manner as provided for the original assessment. If any portion of the original assessment shall have been collected and not refunded, it shall be applied upon the reassessment and the reassessment shall to that extent be deemed satisfied. If more than the amount reassessed shall have been collected, the balance shall be refunded to the person making such payment. 
(Code 1987, § 27-22; Ord. No. 68-3, § 22, 7-29-1968) 
Sec. 42-23. - Combination of projects. 
    The city council may combine several districts into one project for the purpose of effecting a saving in the costs; provided, however, that for each district there shall be established separate funds and accounts to cover the cost of the same. 
(Code 1987, § 27-23; Ord. No. 68-3, § 23, 7-29-1968) 
Sec. 42-24. - Deferred payments of special assessments. 
    The city council may provide for the deferred payment of special assessments from persons who, in the opinion of the city council and city assessor, by reason of poverty are unable to contribute toward the cost thereof. In all such cases, as a condition to the granting of such deferred payments, the city shall require mortgage security on the real property of the beneficiary on or before the person's death or, in any event, on the sale or transfer of the property. 
(Code 1987, § 27-24; Ord. No. 68-3, § 24, 7-29-1968) 
Sec. 42-25. - Public lighting furnished by DTE. 
(a)  Whenever a petition is filed with the city or upon the affirmative action of the city council, the city may enter into a contract with DTE to furnish such public lighting and charge an amount equal to 105 percent of the city's obligation to the benefited property owners upon a special assessment basis. 
(b)  The amount of such costs shall be spread annually by the city assessor upon the tax rolls and such assessment shall be based upon 105 percent of the city's obligation chargeable by DTE at the time of levying. 
(Code 1987, § 27-25; Ord. No. 74-30, §§ 1, 2, 4-23-1974) 
Chapter 44 - STREETS, SIDEWALKS AND OTHER PUBLIC PLACES[1]

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Secs. 44-1-44-18. - Reserved.

    All road construction and improvements described in section 44-19 shall include an adequate storm drainage system.

Sec. 44-21. - Sidewalks. 
    Sidewalks measuring five feet in width shall be constructed in the right-of-way within one foot of the right-of-way line of all street types in the city with the exception of alleys and residential neighborhoods where no sidewalks or curbs exist contingent upon an approved petition for exemption. 
(Code 1987, § 28-18; Ord. No. 91-226, § 1, 2-19-1991; Ord. No. 98-314, 6-2-1998; Ord. No. 03-377, §§ 1, 2, 4-1-2003) 
Sec. 44-22. - General work standards. 
    All work shall be in accordance with the standards and specifications of the city. These standards are based on current requirements of the county, state and federal governments. 
(Code 1987, § 28-19; Ord. No. 91-226, § 1, 2-19-1991; Ord. No. 98-314, 6-2-1998) 
Sec. 44-23. - Variances. 
    Variances to the minimum requirements contained in this article shall be determined by the director of the building department or the executive director of the department of public works or their designated representative. 
(Code 1987, § 28-20; Ord. No. 91-226, § 1, 2-19-1991; Ord. No. 98-314, 6-2-1998; Ord. No. 03-377, §§ 1, 2, 4-1-2003) 
Secs. 44-24-44-49. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - CONSTRUCTION OF SIDEWALKS AND DRIVEWAY APPROACHES 

Sec. 44-50. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Accepted engineering practices means those which conform to accepted principles, tests or standards of nationally recognized technical or scientific authorities. 
    Approach means that portion of a driveway which lies wholly within a public right-of-way. 
    Construction of a sidewalk/driveway approach means the installation of a sidewalk/driveway approach where no previously installed sidewalk/driveway approach exists. 
    Coterminous means having the same boundaries. 
    Crack means to break without complete separation of part. 
    Crosswalk means a specially paved or marked path for pedestrians crossing a street or road. 
    Driveway approach means that area between the curb and sidewalk over which vehicles may be driven in entering or leaving a private drive, excluding the sidewalk area itself which passes through the driveway on the public way. 
    50 percent rule as defined in section 44-51. 
    Flag of concrete means a section of concrete bordered by an expansion joint or a construction joint. 
    Improved property means land within the city which has water and sewer available and is adjacent to an improved street. 
    Isolated surface area means that area of a sidewalk or driveway approach within the boundaries formed by expansion joints or construction joints. 
    Reconstruction of a sidewalk/driveway approach means the installation of a sidewalk/driveway approach where a previously installed sidewalk/driveway approach exists, but the new sidewalk/driveway approach redesigns or repositions the path. 
    Replacement of a sidewalk/driveway approach means the installation of a sidewalk/driveway approach where a previously installed sidewalk/driveway approach exists and the new sidewalk/driveway approach does not redesign or reposition the path. 
    Sidewalk means that portion of a street between the curb or lateral lines and the right-of-way lines which is intended for the use of pedestrians. 
(Code 1987, § 28-36; Ord. No. 91-226, § 1, 2-19-1991; Ord. No. 98-314, 6-2-1998; Ord. No. 03-377, §§ 1, 3, 4-1-2003) 
Sec. 44-51. - Installation of sidewalks required; missing sections. 
    Whenever 50 percent or more of the lots or frontage including all road rights-of-way on both sides of the street in any block contains sidewalks on the public way, the owners of all lots and frontage on such block which do not contain sidewalks on the public way must construct sidewalks in accordance with the requirements of this chapter. Construction of sidewalks required by this section, is herein referred to as the "50 percent rule." 
(Code 1987, § 28-37; Ord. No. 91-226, § 1, 2-19-1991; Ord. No. 98-314, 6-2-1998; Ord. No. 03-377, §§ 1, 3, 4-1-2003) 
Sec. 44-52. - Enforcement. 
    The building department shall have general supervision and control, including inspection, of the construction and reconstruction of all sidewalks and the construction, reconstruction and replacement of all driveway approaches; except that the department of public works shall have general supervision and control, including inspection, of the construction of all sidewalks required by the 50 percent rule. The department of public works shall also have general supervision and control, including initial inspection, of the replacement of all sidewalks; except that the building department shall have the duty of conducting construction inspections for the replacement of all sidewalks. the building department shall also have the responsibility for receiving and responding to all disputes and appeals arising out of enforcement of this article. It shall be the duty of the building department, and they are hereby authorized, to enforce the provisions of this article whenever they may deem such enforcement necessary to the public health and safety. 
(Code 1987, § 28-38; Ord. No. 91-226, § 1, 2-19-1991; Ord. No. 98-314, 6-2-1998) 
Sec. 44-53. - By owner of property; by city. 
    All sidewalks and driveway approaches except crosswalks in the city shall be constructed, reconstructed, maintained and replaced by the owner of lands improved thereby in the manner and within the time prescribed by this article; provided that in case of failure of any such owner to comply with the provisions of this article, the city may construct, reconstruct, replace, maintain or cause to be constructed, reconstructed, replaced or maintained such sidewalks and driveway approaches or either or any of them and assess the entire cost thereof against such owner and against the land improved thereby in accordance with the procedures specified herein. 
(Code 1987, § 28-39; Ord. No. 91-226, § 1, 2-19-1991; Ord. No. 98-314, 6-2-1998) 
Sec. 44-54. - Maintenance of sidewalks; driveways approaches required. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to cause or permit any sidewalk or driveway approach adjoining the person's premises to fall into a state of disrepair or to be unsafe for pedestrian or other travel. It shall further be unlawful for any person to use any public sidewalk in the city in such a manner as to cause the same to be destroyed or to cause the same to become in a state of disrepair. 
(b)  Sidewalks and driveway approaches shall be deemed in a state of disrepair when one or more of the following conditions exist: 
(1)  When the sidewalk or driveway approach is not reasonably safe and convenient for public travel; 
(2)  When one or more cracks exist in any individual flag of concrete; 
(3)  When it is determined that any isolated surface area is deteriorated and deemed a safety hazard; 
(4)  When sidewalks and driveway approaches do not meet the minimum standards set forth in sections 44-61 and 44-66; 
(5)  When water ponding may occur because of unnatural grade differences or deterioration. 
(c)  The department of public works shall inspect any complaint by citizens concerning sidewalks and after inspection require construction, reconstruction or replacement as deemed necessary in the opinion of the department of public works. 
(d)  It shall further be unlawful for any person to cause to be placed rubbish, litter, dirt, vehicles or any other matter on any sidewalk in the city. 
(e)  The occupant or owner of the property, if property is unoccupied, shall remove all snow and/or ice from sidewalks contiguous to the premises of which he/she is the occupant or owner. 
(Code 1987, § 28-40; Ord. No. 91-226, § 1, 2-19-1991; Ord. No. 98-314, 6-2-1998; Ord. No. 98-321, §§ 1, 2, 11-17-1998; Ord. No. 03-377, §§ 1, 3, 4-1-2003; Ord. No. 11-462, § 1, 7-5-2011) 
Sec. 44-55. - Notice of necessity to construct, served upon owner. 
    Whenever in the opinion of the building department it is necessary to construct or reconstruct any sidewalk, excluding any sidewalk construction necessary under the 50 percent rule, or to construct, reconstruct or replace any driveway approach in the city, the building department shall cause notice to be served upon the owner of any lot in front of or adjacent to such sidewalk or driveway approach that such sidewalk or driveway approach must be constructed, reconstructed or replaced, as the case may be, within 45 days after the service of such notice, or that the work will be done by the city under the direction of the appropriate department; and the cost thereof will be charged to the owner of the property improved, and if not sooner paid by such owner, will be assessed against the property as provided in this article. The notice shall be delivered personally, by registered or standard U.S. Mail addressed to the respective owner at the address given in the last assessment roll, or by securely posting it on the premises. If the owner shall fail or neglect to comply with the terms of the notice, the appropriate department shall cause the sidewalk or driveway approach to be constructed or reconstructed or replaced as the case may be. 
(Code 1987, § 28-41; Ord. No. 91-226, § 1, 2-19-1991; Ord. No. 98-314, 6-2-1998; Ord. No. 03-377, §§ 1, 3, 4-1-2003) 
Sec. 44-56. - Notice of necessity to replace, served upon owner. 
    Whenever in the opinion of the department of public works it is necessary to replace any sidewalk in the city or construct any sidewalk under the 50 percent rule, the department of public works shall cause notice to be served upon the owner of any lot in front of or adjacent to such sidewalk that such sidewalk must be replaced or constructed, as the case may be, within 45 days after the service of such notice, or that the work will be done by the city under the direction of the appropriate department; and the cost thereof will be charged to the owner of the property improved, and if not sooner paid by such owner, will be assessed against the property as provided in this article. The notice shall be delivered personally, by registered or standard U.S. Mail addressed to the respective owner at the address given in the last assessment roll, or by securely posting it on the premises. If the owner shall fail or neglect to comply with the terms of the notice, the appropriate department shall cause the sidewalk to be replaced or constructed, as the case may be. 
(Code 1987, § 28-42; Ord. No. 91-226, § 1, 2-19-1991; Ord. No. 98-314, 6-2-1998; Ord. No. 02-363, § 1, 4-16-2002) 
Sec. 44-57. - Contents of notice of necessity to construct or replace. 
    Notices as provided for in this article shall contain the name of the owner of the lot in front or adjacent to the sidewalk or driveway approach required to be constructed, reconstructed or replaced, if known, a description of the property to be improved thereby, and shall designate the work required to be done. The notices shall also recite such other information as shall enable the owner notified to fully comply with the terms thereof. 
(Code 1987, § 28-43; Ord. No. 91-226, § 1, 2-19-1991; Ord. No. 98-314, 6-2-1998) 
Sec. 44-58. - Construction, reconstruction or replacement; approved application required. 
(a)  Every person proposing to lay, construct, reconstruct or replace any sidewalk or driveway approach in the city shall apply to the building department for an inspection application before work begins. Such application shall be in writing upon blanks to be furnished by the city and shall contain such information as may be necessary to secure the enforcement of all the provisions thereof. It shall be the applicant's responsibility to call for inspections as required by the building department, and no work shall proceed until the application has been approved. The applicant shall, upon approval of the application, pay an inspection fee which is to be set by the city council from time to time. Such charges shall cover the cost of inspection and the expenses of establishing the lines, widths and grades and testing of sidewalks and driveway approaches, provided that in cases where the work of construction, reconstruction or replacement of sidewalks or driveway approaches is to be done by the city as covered by this article, the payment of the inspection fee as prescribed by this section shall be postponed until such time as the owner of the lot being charged for such work is billed therefor; and such inspection fee shall be added to the cost of such work as set forth in this subsection. 
(b)  No person shall participate in the laying, construction, reconstruction or replacing of any sidewalk or driveway approach under any approved application issued to anyone other than that person doing the work. Provided, however, members of the homeowner's family may assist in the laying, construction, reconstruction or replacing of any sidewalk or driveway approach if the approved application is issued in the homeowner's name. 
(c)  The city reserves the right to refuse, rescind or revoke applications for inspection issued to any person who is in violation of any ordinance of the city. 
(Code 1987, § 28-44; Ord. No. 91-226, § 1, 2-19-1991; Ord. No. 98-314, 6-2-1998; Ord. No. 03-377, §§ 1, 3, 4-1-2003) 
Sec. 44-59. - Application and inspection fees. 
    Fees for inspection applications and zoning compliance required by this article shall be prescribed by resolution of the city council. 
(Code 1987, § 28-45; Ord. No. 91-226, § 1, 2-19-1991; Ord. No. 98-314, 6-2-1998; Ord. No. 03-377, §§ 1, 3, 4-1-2003) 
Sec. 44-60. - Engineer to furnish lines and grades. 
    All sidewalks and driveway approaches hereafter laid in the city shall conform to the lines and grades officially established by the city engineer, and such sidewalks and driveway approaches must be laid according to the specifications authorized and approved by the appropriate department in accordance with the provisions of this article. Applications shall be made to the department of public works for the grades and lines to be followed before the work is commenced. 
(Code 1987, § 28-46; Ord. No. 91-226, § 1, 2-19-1991; Ord. No. 98-314, 6-2-1998; Ord. No. 03-377, §§ 1, 3, 4-1-2003) 
Sec. 44-61. - Specifications. 
    All sidewalks and driveway approaches being constructed, reconstructed or replaced in accordance with the provisions of this article shall have the following minimum specifications: 
(1)  Sidewalks. 
a.  In general, sidewalks shall be constructed of concrete not less than four inches in thickness and at least five feet in width using a six-bag mix. Sidewalks coterminous with an approach shall be not less than six inches in thickness and at least five feet in width using a six-bag mix. Commercial sidewalks adjacent to approaches shall be seven inches deep using a seven-bag mix. Existing sod or other vegetation is to be removed. If fill is required, a minimum of two inches compacted sand or other granular material acceptable to the city engineer shall be used. Concrete sidewalks shall have a minimum compressive strength of 3,000 pounds per square inch. 
b.  Trees, the trunks of which are within the area of the proposed walk are to be inspected by the city engineer before the walk is laid. All tree surface roots are to be cut to a distance of four inches from the proposed walk. 
c.  Shutoff boxes, manhole tops and other castings within the walk or approach area are to be set to finish grade and inspected by the city department having jurisdiction. 
d.  When the sidewalk adjacent to the curb is replaced, the curb must be dropped and an appropriate grade established to comply with provisions for persons with disabilities. 
(2)  Approaches. 
a.  Residential approaches shall use a six-bag mix, six inches deep with a maximum width of 16 feet at the sidewalk and 20 feet at the street. Commercial approaches shall use a seven-bag mix, seven inches deep with a width dependent on use. Residential driveway approaches abutting a concrete paved street shall be concrete. Existing sod or other vegetation is to be removed. If fill is required, a minimum of two inches of compacted sand or other granular material acceptable to the city engineer is to be used. County approaches require a county permit and approval. 
b.  Residential driveway approaches abutting an improved asphalt street may be of plant-mix asphalt not less than three inches in thickness placed on a minimum of eight inches of compacted aggregate base. All concrete used in sidewalk and driveway approach construction shall be air-entrained, and shall have a 28-day compressive strength of at least 3,000 pounds per square inch, with one-inch expansion joints placed at curbs and sidewalks. The city engineer may establish additional detailed specifications, which no person shall fail to comply with, including the following: 
1.  Requirements for placement of expansion and contraction joints; subgrade compaction; and 
2.  Preparation, mixing and placement of concrete, etc., consistent with accepted engineering practices and not inconsistent herewith. 
(Code 1987, § 28-47; Ord. No. 91-226, § 1, 2-19-1991; Ord. No. 98-314, 6-2-1998) 
Sec. 44-62. - Inspections. 
(a)  Concrete. Inspection for concrete work shall take place as follows: 
(1)  An inspection shall occur when the job is ready for concrete, but before the concrete is poured. 
(2)  Construction, reconstruction and replacement shall be inspected by the city, including sidewalks constructed under the 50 percent rule, upon completion. 
(b)  Asphalt. Inspection for asphalt work shall take place as follows: 
(1)  First inspection. The first inspection shall occur when the job is ready for slag or crushed stone base. 
(2)  Second inspection. The second inspection shall occur after the base is installed. 
(c)  Responsibility for compliance. It is the responsibility of the holder of the approved application to see that the regulations of this section are complied with. 
(Code 1987, § 28-48; Ord. No. 91-226, § 1, 2-19-1991; Ord. No. 98-314, 6-2-1998; Ord. No. 03-377, §§ 1, 3, 4-1-2003) 
Sec. 44-63. - Stop work order. 
(a)  The building department may issue a stop work order to any person issued an approved application for: 
(1)  Failure to comply with this article; 
(2)  Failure to comply with the regulations, rules, plans and specifications established by the building department for construction, reconstruction; or 
(3)  Replacing of any sidewalk or driveway approach. 
(b)  The issuance of such stop work order shall be deemed a suspension of such permit. 
(Code 1987, § 28-49; Ord. No. 91-226, § 1, 2-19-1991; Ord. No. 98-314, 6-2-1998; Ord. No. 03-377, §§ 1, 3, 4-1-2003) 
Sec. 44-64. - Charge for construction; special assessments. 
    Upon the completion of the construction or reconstruction of any sidewalk or the construction, reconstruction or replacement of any driveway approach, except for the construction of any sidewalk required by the 50 percent rule, by the city in accordance with the provisions of this article, a bill for the entire cost thereof shall be mailed by the appropriate department to the owner of the property improved, if the owner's address is known or can be with reasonable diligence ascertained, demanding payment of the amount due. If the amount is not paid to the city within 30 days from the date of such bill, the amount shall be assessed against such property as a special assessment. The provisions of this section shall be applicable to all charges outstanding on or after April 11, 1986. 
(Code 1987, § 28-50; Ord. No. 91-226, § 1, 2-19-1991; Ord. No. 98-314, 6-2-1998) 
Sec. 44-65. - Charge for replacement; special assessments. 
    Upon completion of any sidewalk replacement or construction of any sidewalk required by the 50 percent rule by the city in accordance with the provisions of this article, a bill for the entire cost thereof, plus a ten percent administrative fee, shall be mailed by the appropriate department to the owner of the property improved, if the owner's address is known or can be with reasonable diligence ascertained, demanding payment of the amount due. If the amount is not paid to the city within 30 days from the date of such bill, the amount shall be assessed against the property as a special assessment. Homestead property owners shall have the option of having the cost assessed against the property in accordance with the following schedule: 
Cost for Individual Property Assessment Period $1.00-$400.00 1 year $401.00-$800.00 2 years $801.00-$1,200.00 3 years $1,201.00-$1,600.00 4 years $1,601.00-$2,000.00 5 years Over $2,000.00 A period so the annual assessment will not exceed $400.00  
The interest rate applied shall not exceed seven percent. Upon the sale of any property, any outstanding assessments for sidewalk or driveway approach reconstruction, construction, or replacement shall be paid prior to title transfer. 
(Code 1987, § 28-51; Ord. No. 91-226, § 1, 2-19-1991; Ord. No. 98-314, 6-2-1998) 
Sec. 44-66. - Liability of owners who do not construct, reconstruct or replace driveway approaches. 
    It shall be the duty of every owner of property to cause driveway approaches to be improved by constructing, reconstructing, or replacing as provided in this article and to make such improvements within one year from the date of the street paving. If any damage to the city results from the neglect or refusal of the owner to comply, such owner shall be liable to the city for the full amount of such damages. 
(Code 1987, § 28-52; Ord. No. 91-226, § 1, 2-19-1991; Ord. No. 98-314, 6-2-1998) 
Secs. 44-67-44-90. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - CULVERTS, DRAINAGE DITCHES AND GUTTERS 

Sec. 44-91. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Culvert means any transverse drain or waterway under a road, railroad, canal, driveway, sidewalk or fence. 
    Drainage ditch means any ditch constructed for the purpose of draining or removing excess water from land by means of surface or subsurface conduits. 
    Gutter means any watercourse at the roadside or elsewhere to lead off surface water, specifically that between a sidewalk and that portion of the road devoted to travel. 
    Litter means all rubbish, refuse, waste material, garbage, paper, glass, cans, bottles, trash, debris or other foreign substances of every kind and description. 
    Obstruction means any lessening of the area of a drain, which area shall be a cross section of the drain. 
    Putrescible means liable to become putrid, that is, the typically anaerobic splitting of proteins by bacteria and fungi with the formation of foul-smelling, incompletely oxidized products. 
    Refuse means all putrescible and nonputrescible solid wastes, except body wastes, including garbage, rubbish, street cleanings, dead animals, and solid market and industrial waste. 
    Rubbish means nonputrescible solid wastes consisting of both combustible and noncombustible wastes, such as paper, wrappings, cigarettes, cardboard, tin cans, yard clippings, wood, grass, bedding, crockery and other similar materials, refrigerators, stoves, washers, dryers and other similar wood or metal materials abandoned automobiles, shopping carts or devices commonly used in supermarkets, department stores and other businesses. 
(Code 1987, § 28-61; Ord. No. 91-226, § 1, 2-19-1991; Ord. No. 98-314, 6-2-1998) 
Sec. 44-92. - Enforcement. 
    The enforcement of this article shall be within those duties charged to the department of public works, which is hereby authorized to adopt reasonable regulations to carry out the intent of this article. 
(Code 1987, § 28-62; Ord. No. 91-226, § 1, 2-19-1991; Ord. No. 98-314, 6-2-1998) 
Sec. 44-93. - Duty of owners, occupiers to keep property free of litter. 
(a)  All persons owning, occupying or in control of any premises, vacant or occupied, shall keep such premises, including gutters, drainage ditches, culverts, and all adjoining public property between the centerline of the street and the centerline of the alley adjoining or abutting the place so owned, occupied or controlled free and clear of litter at all times. All litter removed shall be deposited in proper containers or removed to an approved disposal location. 
(b)  No person owning, occupying or in control of any premises, vacant or occupied, shall sweep into or deposit, or cause to be swept into or deposited, in any gutter, drainage ditch, culvert or other public place within the city any accumulation of litter refuse or rubbish. 
(c)  No person owning, occupying, or in control of any premises, vacant or occupied, shall obstruct any culvert, gutter or drainage ditch by felling any tree therein or by putting into such culvert, gutter or drainage ditch any refuse lumber, slabs or other waste materials. 
(d)  No person owning, occupying or in control of any premises, vacant or occupied, shall permit any culvert, drainage ditch or gutter on or adjoining such premises or property to fall into a state of disrepair or to be unsafe. 
(Code 1987, § 28-63; Ord. No. 91-226, § 1, 2-19-1991; Ord. No. 98-314, 6-2-1998) 
Sec. 44-94. - Right of department of public works to enter property. 
    The department of public works may enter the property, even if fenced in, and remove litter and debris found thereon and causing an obstruction to any abutting gutter, drainage ditch or culvert on public property and, if necessary, repair or replace any culvert, drainage ditch or gutter which is in a state of disrepair or unsafe. 
(Code 1987, § 28-64; Ord. No. 91-226, § 1, 2-19-1991; Ord. No. 98-314, 6-2-1998) 
Sec. 44-95. - Violations; authority of police department to ticket. 
    In any case in which the owner, agent or other person having control or management of any property: 
(1)  Allows the presence thereon of any litter or debris; 
(2)  Permits any culvert, drainage ditch or gutter on or adjoining such property to fall into a state of disrepair; or 
(3)  Allows the property to be unsafe in violation of the terms of this article; 
the police department shall have authority to ticket such violation upon request of the department of public works. 
(Code 1987, § 28-65; Ord. No. 91-226, § 1, 2-19-1991; Ord. No. 98-314, 6-2-1998) 
Sec. 44-96. - Violations; notice to owner of property. 
(a)  The director of public works is hereby authorized and empowered to notify the owner of any property within the city or the agent of such owner, within ten days: 
(1)  To properly dispose of such obstruction in the gutter, drainage ditch or culvert within five days; or 
(2)  If necessary, to repair or replace any gutter, drainage ditch or culvert which is in a state of disrepair or unsafe. 
(b)  Such notice shall be: 
(1)  By certified mail with return receipt requested, if the property is vacant or unoccupied, to the owner; or 
(2)  By regular mail, if the property is occupied: 
a.  To the owner or person in possession; or 
b.  To the person or firm listed on the tax records. 
(Code 1987, § 28-66; Ord. No. 91-226, § 1, 2-19-1991; Ord. No. 98-314, 6-2-1998) 
Sec. 44-97. - Failure of owner to comply with notice; correction by city. 
    Upon the failure, neglect or refusal of any owner or agent notified to properly dispose of litter dangerous to the health, safety or welfare within five days of receipt of the written notice or upon the failure, neglect or refusal of any owner or agent so notified to properly repair or replace any culvert, drainage ditch or gutter dangerous to the public health, safety or welfare within ten days of receipt of the written notice, the department of public works is empowered to itself remove the litter or to repair or replace the culvert, drainage ditch or gutter, or to contract for the disposing of such litter or the repair and replacement of such culvert, drainage ditch or gutter. 
(Code 1987, § 28-67; Ord. No. 91-226, § 1, 2-19-1991; Ord. No. 98-314, 6-2-1998) 
Sec. 44-98. - Authority of city to remove litter, repair and replace culverts, drainage ditches, gutters; lien on property. 
(a)  In any case where litter is present on property or premises or where a culvert, drainage ditch or gutter is in a state of disrepair or unsafe, the department of public works shall have the authority to remove all litter which may be a threat to the health and safety of the community as determined by the city. 
(b)  The city shall have a lien upon such properties for such expense, such lien to be enforced in the manner prescribed in the city Charter for the enforcement of tax liens. Any expense in such abatement, if not paid to the city within 60 days from the date of statement thereof was forwarded to the party, shall be reported to the city assessor, who shall assess the amount against the property in question.
