Any failure to give such written notice shall not constitute a defense to any action to enforce the provisions of this article under the penalty provisions of section 1-13. 
(Code 1987, § 28-68; Ord. No. 91-226, § 1, 2-19-1991; Ord. No. 98-314, 6-2-1998) 
Secs. 44-99-44-124. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - VACATION OF STREETS, ALLEYS, EASEMENTS 

Sec. 44-125. - Authorization of petition; action by city council. 
    Whenever the owners of property adjoining a street or alley within the city shall file a petition with the city council asking the council to vacate the street or alley and when the petition is signed by 100 percent of the adjoining owners, the city council may refer the petition to the planning commission for study and report to the council. When the planning commission has filed its report with the council concerning the vacation of the street or alley, the council may by resolution confirm or reject the recommendation contained in such report. In the event the council deems it advisable to vacate the street or alley, it shall adopt a resolution and shall appoint a time not less than four weeks thereafter when the council will meet to hear objections thereto. Notice of such meeting shall be given by publication in such newspaper circulating within the city as the council may direct from time to time. If on the date of such hearing no objections are filed, the street or alley or any part thereof may be vacated and the resolution vacating such street, alley or any part thereof adopted. 
(Code 1987, § 28-81; Ord. No. 91-221, § 1, 2-5-1991) 
Sec. 44-126. - Referral to planning commission. 
(a)  When the petition to vacate is signed by less than 100 percent of the adjoining owners or when the council shall deem it advisable to vacate, discontinue or abolish any street, alley or any part thereof, the council shall by resolution so declare and by that resolution shall refer the proceedings to the planning commission for study and report. The planning commission shall order a public hearing thereon; and upon a favorable report to the council advising vacation, the council shall by resolution, appoint a time, not less than 30 days, thereafter, when it shall meet and hear objections thereto. Notice of such meeting with a copy of said resolution shall be published two successive weeks before the appointed time for such meetings, in the official newspaper of the city and posted in not less than three public places on the street, alley or part thereof proposed to be vacated or abolished. 
(b)  In the event objections to such proposed action shall be filed with the clerk in writing, the street, alley or any part thereof shall not be vacated or discontinued, except by a vote of two-thirds of the members of the council. 
(Code 1987, § 28-82; Ord. No. 91-221, § 1, 2-5-1991) 
Sec. 44-127. - Vacating easement. 
    Whenever the owners of a majority of frontage of property adjoining and abutting a public easement within the city shall file a petition with the city council asking that the easement be vacated, or in the event it is deemed advisable by the council to vacate any public easement, the city council shall refer the question of the vacating of such easement to the planning commission for study and a public hearing and report to the council. Notice of such public hearing shall be sent to all public utilities servicing the city and to the engineering and public works departments of the city. In the event no objections to the vacation of easement are made by the public utilities and the vacation is approved by the engineering and public works department of the city, the planning commission may recommend its approval to the council. The council may thereafter declare by resolution that it is deemed advisable to vacate the public easement and in the resolution shall appoint a time not less than four weeks thereafter when the council will meet and hear objections thereto. Notice of such meeting shall be given by publication in such newspaper circulating within the city as the council may direct from time to time. Upon such hearing, if no objections are received, the public easement may be vacated and a resolution vacating such easement may be adopted. 
(Code 1987, § 28-83; Ord. No. 91-221, § 1, 2-5-1991) 
Sec. 44-128. - Record of discontinuance or vacating of streets, alleys. 
    Every resolution discontinuing or vacating any street, alley or any part thereof shall be recorded in a book of street records to be maintained by the city clerk; and the records therein shall be prima facie evidence of all matters therein set forth. 
(Code 1987, § 28-84; Ord. No. 91-221, § 1, 2-5-1991) 
Sec. 44-129. - Reserving of easements. 
    Whenever the city council shall by resolution vacate any street, alley or any part thereof, it may, in the same resolution, reserve an easement therein for public utility purposes within the right-of-way of any such street or alley so vacated. 
(Code 1987, § 28-85; Ord. No. 91-221, § 1, 2-5-1991) 
Sec. 44-130. - Recording of resolution with auditor general and register of deeds. 
    Upon the resolution of vacation of such street, alley, easement or any part thereof becoming effective, the city clerk shall within 30 days, forward to the auditor general and record with the register of deeds a certified copy of the resolution, together with the city clerk's certificate giving the name or names of any plat, subdivision or addition affected by such resolution; and such resolution shall have no force or effect until so recorded. 
(Code 1987, § 28-86; Ord. No. 91-221, § 1, 2-5-1991) 
Secs. 44-131-44-158. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VI. - UTILITIES USE OF RIGHTS-OF-WAY 

Sec. 44-159. - Legislative findings and purpose. 
(a)  The city presently has and in the future may permit additional utilities including, but not limited to, natural gas and electrical power (utilities) to enter into city-owned public rights-of-way, for construction, installation, operation and maintenance of, by way of example, conduits, access manholes, rights-of-way, poles, wires, pipes, mains, conductors or lines of pipe or other devices, appliances and appurtenances. 
(b)  The city has the authority to manage its public rights-of-way and to grant permits, licenses, and franchises for utilities using or crossing public rights-of-way in the city. This article is intended to minimize the disruption to the public rights-of-way and to require those who seek to construct utilities to cooperate in the construction and the restoration of public rights-of-way and of both overhead and underground lines. The city finds that it has too many unsightly overhead lines and poles in some sections of the city and that they are proliferating, adversely affecting the public safety, detracting from property values and reaching maximum safe capacity of poles and underground spaces. The city further finds that public health, safety and welfare is better served by requiring installation of new utility lines and wires in underground conduit wherever practical. 
(c)  The city has the authority under federal and state law to require fair and reasonable compensation, fees and charges for the use, access, operation and maintenance of its public rights-of-way and for the fixed and variable costs associated with site specific construction work including, but not limited to, inspections, approvals, permitting and utility staking. 
(Code 1987, § 28-92; Ord. No. 97-305, § 2, 12-2-1997) 
Sec. 44-160. - Permits required. 
    No person shall commence construction, install, maintain, operate, use, erect and/or lay conduits, poles, towers, wires (including fiber optic wire), conductors, access manholes, mains, pipes, connections, rights-of-way, cable or other devices, facilities, appurtenances and/or appliances (equipment and property) for utilities for the purpose of furnishing telephone, telegraph, voice, video, wireless communication or data transmission services, systems and upgrades, including service connections in, under or over any public rights-of-way in the city without having first obtained a nonexclusive permit from the department of public works. In those instances where any city park or city park right-of-way is involved, the person shall also obtain the prior written approval and consent of the director of parks and recreation. 
(Code 1987, § 28-93; Ord. No. 97-305, § 3, 12-2-1997) 
Sec. 44-161. - Issuance of permit. 
(a)  Any person desiring a permit under the provisions of this article shall: 
(1)  File a proper written application with the department of public works upon forms prescribed and furnished by the department; and 
(2)  Attach detailed proposed plans, maps and specifications showing the nature, timing, object, method of installation contemplated and location of the work and the equipment and property for which such permit is desired. 
The department of public works may require alteration, modification or amendment of the plans, maps and specifications. 
(b)  If the plans, maps and specifications are approved by the department of public works and the appropriate permit fees and security required by section 44-167 have been deposited, the permit may be issued in accordance with the application filed. 
(c)  In those instances where any city park or city park right-of-way is involved, the person shall also obtain the prior written approval and consent of the director of parks and recreation. The application shall contain, among other things, a full and complete explanation of the proposed use of the public rights-of-way, which proposed use may not be changed, altered, modified or expanded in any manner without the filing and approval of a new application for permit detailing the new proposed use. 
(Code 1987, § 28-94; Ord. No. 97-305, § 4, 12-2-1997) 
Sec. 44-162. - Fees. 
    The city council may by resolution from time to time, in its discretion, determine and establish the fees incidental to the issuance of any permit required pursuant to this article, including but not limited to fees for daily inspection, supervision, use and maintenance. No permit shall be issued unless any fee or fees previously incurred are paid to the treasurer of the city upon demand made and receipt obtained. In addition to the fees set forth in this section, the city reserves the right to require the applicant to also obtain a utilities system/service franchise, which franchise shall, among other things, set additional fees for the use of the public rights-of-way by the applicant. 
(Code 1987, § 28-95; Ord. No. 97-305, § 5, 12-2-1997) 
Sec. 44-163. - Cessation of rights and alteration. 
    Any right acquired under any such permit may cease by order of the mayor or director of public works or, in the case of any city park or city park right-of-way, by the director of parks and recreation. All equipment and property described under such order shall be removed or relocated at the expense of the named permittee. In the event that at any time the city shall lawfully elect to alter or change the grade or location of any street, alley or other public rights-of-way or to install other public improvements including, but not limited to, water mains, sanitary sewers, storm sewers, streets, street paving, alleys, sidewalks and driveways, the permittee shall remove, relay, and/or relocate its equipment and property at permittee's sole cost and expense. Upon failure to remove, relay and/or relocate its equipment and property upon order of the city, permittee shall reimburse the city for its costs and expenses in effecting the same. The city may utilize the proceeds of any required security by way of letter of credit or cash escrow account or otherwise for such purposes. 
(Code 1987, § 28-96; Ord. No. 97-305, § 6, 12-2-1997) 
Sec. 44-164. - Technical and construction standards. 
(a)  Each permittee shall construct, install and maintain its equipment and property in the public rights-of-way in a manner consistent and in compliance with all applicable laws, ordinances, construction standards, governmental requirements, and technical standards established by the Federal Communications Commission, state or county agency or the city. 
(b)  In any event, the permittee's equipment and property shall not endanger or interfere with the safety of persons or property within the city or other areas where the permittee may have equipment and property located. 
(c)  All working facilities, conditions, and procedures, used or occurring during construction of the system shall comply with the standards of the federal and state occupational safety and health administrations. 
(d)  Construction, installation and maintenance of permittee's equipment and property shall be performed in an orderly and workmanlike manner, and in close coordination with public and private utilities serving the city following accepted industry construction procedures and practices. 
(e)  All cable and wires shall be installed, where possible, parallel with electric and telephone lines, and multiple cable and wire configurations shall be arranged in parallel and bundled with due respect for engineering consideration. 
(f)  A permittee shall comply with the Miss Dig program pursuant to MCL 460.701 et seq. including the notification process to the city. 
(g)  A permittee shall annually provide the city with current maps of its existing and proposed installations in a standardized format for use with the city's data system unless no changes have occurred in the previously submitted map. 
(h)  No public rights-of-way used by the permittee shall: 
(1)  Be obstructed, barricaded or encumbered longer than necessary during the work of construction or repair; and 
(2)  Be restored to the same or better order and condition as when said work was commenced. 
The permittee shall monitor the restoration in an approved condition for a period of one year; provided that permittee may use a temporary repair, including repairs required in section 44-172 if the work in the public rights-of-way takes place during an emergency or in a season of the year where a permanent repair is not possible, but shall make a permanent repair as soon as time or weather reasonably permits. If the permittee does not timely make the required repair as determined in the sole discretion of the city, the city may make the said repair and utilize the proceeds of any letter of credit or cash deposit to recover its costs. 
(i)  The city in its discretion may grant permission for the trimming of trees within the public rights-of-way and such trimming shall be subject to the city's inspection and approval. 
(j)  The department of public works and/or other departments of the city may, from time to time establish such other rules and regulations for construction, installation, excavation, use and/or maintenance within, over or below the public rights-of-way. 
(Code 1987, § 28-97; Ord. No. 97-305, § 7, 12-2-1997) 
Sec. 44-165. - Prior approvals. 
    Before offering or providing any utilities system/service, the permittee shall obtain any and all regulatory approvals, permits, franchises, authorizations or licenses for the offering or provision of such utilities systems/services from the appropriate federal, state and local authorities, if required, and shall submit to the city, upon the written request of the city, evidence of all such approvals, permits, authorizations or licenses. 
(Code 1987, § 28-98; Ord. No. 97-305, § 8, 12-2-1997) 
Sec. 44-166. - Nonwaiver. 
    Nothing in this article shall be construed as a waiver of any codes, ordinances or regulations of the city or the city's right to require permittee or persons utilizing the utilities system/service to secure appropriate permits, franchises, licenses or authorizations for such use. 
(Code 1987, § 28-99; Ord. No. 97-305, § 9, 12-2-1997) 
Sec. 44-167. - Construction and performance guarantee and security. 
    A permittee shall, prior to construction and prior to the issuance of a permit, file with the department of public works, an irrevocable and unconditional letter of credit or cash deposit at the sole option and selection by the city, in a reasonable amount set by the terms of the permit based upon the construction cost and the cost of the equipment and property to be installed upon, over, across or under the public rights-of-way in the city. 
(Code 1987, § 28-100; Ord. No. 97-305, § 10, 12-2-1997) 
Sec. 44-168. - Indemnification and liability for damage or injury. 
    The person to whom such permit shall be granted shall do no injury in any public rights-of-way or to any shade trees, shrubs, lawns, concrete paving or sidewalk, berms or other like improvement, or in any manner disturb or interfere with any sewer, water main, pipe or conduit, any other public or private utilities or appliances now or later laid or constructed by any authorized person. The permittee shall fully at all times and under all circumstances, indemnify and hold harmless the city from any and all injury, loss, cost, expense, claims and damages, including attorney fees, for which the city might be made or become liable to pay by reason of the construction, using, maintaining, installing, repairing or operating of equipment and property in the public rights-of-way, or otherwise arising from the use or possession of any of the rights and privileges granted or from any neglect on the part of such persons or of any agents or employees to comply with the provisions of this section or other ordinances of the city, and shall indemnify the city and assume all liability and damages which may arise, come, or occur to the city from any injury to persons or property from the doing of any work under this section, or the neglect of any person, or its agents or employees to comply with the provisions of this section or other ordinances relative to the use of public rights-of-way, especially as to damages to property and the installing of safety lights and/or barriers at or around excavations. The acceptance by any person, of any permit under this section shall be an agreement by it to pay to the city any sum of money for which the city may become liable for or by reason of such injury; provided, such person shall be given written notice of any and all formal claims, suits and demands filed with the city within 30 days after receipt of same and shall be given an opportunity at the permittee's own expense, to defend such claims. 
(Code 1987, § 28-101; Ord. No. 97-305, § 11, 12-2-1997) 
Sec. 44-169. - Insurance. 
    The permittee shall comply with all requirements for insurance as required by the city, including but not limited to the types and amounts of insurance coverage, submission of proofs of insurance and the naming of the city as an additional insured on all said policies of insurance. 
(Code 1987, § 28-102; Ord. No. 97-305, § 12, 12-2-1997) 
Sec. 44-170. - Poles and transmission lines. 
    All poles, lines, and wires and other equipment and property for utilities erected under a permit, shall be firmly set in the ground so as not to create any obstruction to sidewalks, service walks, side drives, approaches, and other public rights-of-way. Any poles erected in public or private parking areas must be in conformity with the city code and at locations which maybe approved by the department of public works and, in the case where any city park or city park right-of-way is involved, the prior written approval and consent of the director of parks and recreation is also required. 
(Code 1987, § 28-103; Ord. No. 97-305, § 13, 12-2-1997) 
Sec. 44-171. - Mains, conduits or wires in ground. 
    All operating and conducting mains, conduits and wires which are laid below the surface of the ground shall be insulated and protected in parallel with adjacent property lines and at such locations and depth as approved by the department of public works and, in the case where any city park or city park right-of-way is involved, the prior written approval and consent of the director of parks and recreation is also required. 
(Code 1987, § 28-104; Ord. No. 97-305, § 14, 12-2-1997) 
Sec. 44-172. - General regulations. 
(a)  At least 48 hours before opening or excavating in any public rights-of-way for any purpose, except in cases of emergency, the person, intending to commence such excavation shall first notify the department of public works, and also for purposes of this section in the case of any city park or city park right-of-way being involved, the director of parks and recreation, in writing, stating the number of the permit and its issuance date. In any openings and refillings of all excavations made, the relaying of the pavement and other work necessary to the complete restoration of the street, pavement, sidewalk, grounds or other public rights-of-way to an equally good or better condition as when disturbed shall be under the supervision of the department of public works. No public right-of-way shall be allowed to remain open or encumbered for a longer period than authorized by the city to execute the work to be performed. The department of public works may extend the period allowed for the completion of such work for such time as the department may deem necessary upon proper written notice by the permittee. 
(b)  Any earth removed in making such excavation shall be removed and/or restored as conditions warrant. Where pavement has been broken, no debris, broken concrete or noncompatible substances shall be used in such refilling. Pavement shall be relaid by the permittee or the permittee's agents and shall be maintained in as good or better a condition as the surrounding pavement. 
(c)  The cost of restoring the earth or other costs arising from such excavation and the relaying of the pavement and repairs caused by the opening of any such public right-of-way shall be at the sole expense of the permittee; the work shall be performed under the supervision of the department of public works. Any expense to which the city shall be put from the neglect of the permittee or its agents or employees in the doing of any work, or the doing of the same in any unsuitable manner, for the digging of ditches or holes and erection of poles, or restoring the earth or any excavation or relaying or replacing of any pavement shall be paid by the permittee. It shall be the duty of the permittee in each instance to pay promptly all bills for labor and material, supervision, or other work incurred by the city in relaying and restoring any placement or surface disturbed by the permittee. If restoration bills remain unpaid for 30 days after the presentation, the permittee shall not be entitled to receive any additional permits under this section while the permittee remains in default in the payment of any bills and the city may deduct its full expenses from the security established in section 44-167. 
(Code 1987, § 28-105; Ord. No. 97-305, § 15, 12-2-1997) 
Sec. 44-173. - City to inspect. 
    The department of public works and also, in the case of any city park or city park right-of-way which may be involved, the director of parks and recreation, may inspect all work and all equipment and property pursuant to the permit. In the installation of equipment and property as provided in this section, the department of public works and/or the director of parks and recreation shall determine the public rights-of-way in which it shall be lawful to erect or construct such equipment and property, and no person shall erect any pole or train any wire for such lines above or in the ground in or over any public right-of-way, without a permit as provided by this section. 
(Code 1987, § 28-106; Ord. No. 97-305, § 16, 12-2-1997) 
Sec. 44-174. - Wires laid in underground conduits. 
    The department of public works and also, in the case of any city park or city park right-of-way which may be involved, the director of parks and recreation may require, as a condition to the issuing of any permit, that wires, cables, or fiber-optic wires be laid in underground conduits. 
(Code 1987, § 28-107; Ord. No. 97-305, § 17, 12-2-1997) 
Sec. 44-175. - Retention control of public places. 
    Nothing contained herein shall be construed to alienate the title of the public in and to any public rights-of-way or any portion thereof, nor shall anything herein be construed in any manner as constituting a surrender by the city of its general powers with respect to the subject matter hereof, or with respect to any matter whatsoever, or in any manner be construed as limiting the right of the city to regulate the use of and access to any public rights-of-way within its jurisdiction and to otherwise exercise its police powers to protect the public health, safety and welfare. 
(Code 1987, § 28-108; Ord. No. 97-305, § 18, 12-2-1997) 
Sec. 44-176. - Sanctions and penalties. 
    Violation of any provisions of this article shall be a misdemeanor. The city may also seek civil damages. In addition to the foregoing remedies, any person who constructs, upgrades, installs or attempts to construct, upgrade or install utilities, cable television or telecommunications system/service in the city's public rights-of-way without first applying for and obtaining the necessary permits and approvals may, for a 15-year period, be precluded by the city from supplying such utilities, cable television and/or telecommunication system/service to the residents of the city and shall remove its equipment and property at its own expense. 
(Code 1987, § 28-109; Ord. No. 97-305, § 19, 12-2-1997) 
ARTICLE VII. - TELECOMMUNICATIONS PROVIDERS USE OF RIGHTS-OF-WAY[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference- Michigan telecommunications act, MCL 484.2101 et seq.; metropolitan extension telecommunications rights-of-way oversight act, MCL 484.3101 et seq.; Michigan broadband development authority act, MCL 484.3201 et seq.; uniform video services local franchise act, MCL 484.3301 et seq. 

Sec. 44-177. - Definitions. 
(a)  The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Act means the metropolitan extension telecommunications rights-of-way oversight act, Public Act No. 48 of 2002 (MCL 484.3101 et seq.). 
    City council means the city council for the City of Taylor, Michigan. This article does not authorize delegation of any decision or function that is required by law to be made by the city council. 
    Permit means a nonexclusive permit issued, pursuant to the Act and this article, to a telecommunications provider to use the public rights-of-way in the city for its telecommunications facilities. 
(b)  All other terms used in this article shall have the same meaning as defined or as provided in the Act, including without limitation, the following: 
    Authority means the metropolitan extension telecommunications rights-of-way oversight authority created pursuant to section 3 of the Act (MCL 484.3103). 
    MPSC means the state public service commission in the department of consumer and industry services, and shall have the same meaning as the term "commission" in the Act. 
    Public right-of-way. 
(1)  The term "public right-of-way" means the area on, below or above a public roadway, highway, street, alley, easement or waterway. 
(2)  The term "public right-of-way" does not include a federal, state or private right-of-way. 
    Telecommunications facilities or facilities means the equipment or personal property, such as copper and fiber cables, lines, wires, switches, conduits, pipes and sheaths, which are used to or can generate, receive, transmit, carry, amplify, or provide telecommunication services or signals. Telecommunication facilities or facilities that do not include antennas, supporting structures for antennas, equipment shelters or houses and any ancillary equipment and miscellaneous hardware used to provide federally licensed commercial mobile service as defined in section 322(d) of part I of title III of the Communications Act of 1934, ch. 652, 48 Stat. 1064, 47 USC 332 and further defined as commercial mobile radio service in 47 CFR 20.3, and service provided by any wireless two-way communication device. 
    Telecommunications provider, provider and telecommunications services mean those terms as defined in section 102 of the Michigan telecommunications act, Public Act No. 179 of 1991 (MCL 484.2102). Telecommunication provider does not include a person or an affiliate of that person when providing a federally licensed commercial mobile radio service as defined in section 332(d) of part I of the Communications Act of 1934, ch. 652, 48 Stat. 1064, 47 USC 332 and further defined as commercial mobile radio service in 47 CFR 20.3, or service provided by any wireless, two-way communication device. For the purpose of the Act and this article only, a provider also includes all of the following: 
(1)  A cable television operator that provides a telecommunications service. 
(2)  Except as otherwise provided by the Act, a person who owns telecommunication facilities located within a public right-of-way. 
(3)  A person providing broadband internet transport access service. 
(Code 1987, § 28-109.3; Ord. No. 03-378, § 3, 4-15-2003) 
Sec. 44-178. - Purpose. 
    The purposes of this article are to regulate access to and ongoing use of public rights-of-way by telecommunications providers for their telecommunications facilities while protecting the public health, safety, and welfare and exercising reasonable control of the public rights-of-way in compliance with the metropolitan extension telecommunications rights-of-way oversight act, Public Act No. 48 of 2002 (MCL 484.3101 et seq.) and other applicable law, and to ensure that the city qualifies for distributions under the Act by modifying the fees charged to providers and complying with the Act. 
(Code 1987, § 28-109.1; Ord. No. 03-378, § 1, 4-15-2003) 
Sec. 44-179. - Conflict. 
    Nothing in this article shall be construed in such a manner as to conflict with the Act or other applicable law. 
(Code 1987, § 28-109.2; Ord. No. 03-378, § 2, 4-15-2003) 
Sec. 44-180. - Permit required. 
(a)  Permit required. Except as otherwise provided in the Act, a telecommunications provider using or seeking to use public rights-of-way in the city for its telecommunications facilities shall apply for and obtain a permit pursuant to this article. 
(b)  Application. Telecommunications providers shall apply for a permit on an application form approved by the MPSC in accordance with section 6(1) of the Act (MCL 484.3106(1)). A telecommunications provider shall file one original and eight copies of the application with the city clerk, who shall distribute them to the city mayor or designee, the city attorney, the city departments of building, planning, public works, water, police and budget and finance. Applications shall be complete and include all information required by the Act, including without limitation a route map showing the location of the provider's existing and proposed facilities in accordance with section 6(5) of the Act (MCL 484.3106(5)). 
(c)  Confidential information. If a telecommunications provider claims that any portion of the route maps submitted by it as part of its application contain trade secret, proprietary, or confidential information, which is exempt from the freedom of information act, Public Act No. 442 of 1976 (MCL 15.246), pursuant to section 6(5) of the Act (MCL 484.3106(5)), the telecommunications provider shall prominently so indicate on the face of each map. 
(d)  Application fee. Except as otherwise provided by the Act, the application shall be accompanied by a one-time nonrefundable application fee in the amount of $500.00. 
(e)  Additional information. The city mayor or designee may request an applicant to submit such additional information which the city mayor or designee deems reasonably necessary or relevant. The applicant shall comply with all such requests in compliance with reasonable deadlines for such additional information established by the city mayor or designee. If the city and the applicant cannot agree on the requirement of additional information requested by the city, the city or the applicant shall notify the MPSC as provided in section 6(2) of the Act (MCL 484.3106(2)). 
(f)  Previously issued permits. Pursuant to section 5(1) of the Act (MCL 484.3105(1)), authorizations or permits issued by the city are under section 251 of the Michigan telecommunications act, Public Act No. 179 of 1991 (MCL 484.2251) and authorizations or permits issued by the city to telecommunications providers prior to the 1995 enactment of section 251 of the Michigan telecommunications act but after 1985 shall satisfy the permit requirements of this article. 
(g)  Existing providers. Pursuant to section 5(3) of the Act (MCL 484.3105(3)), within 180 days from November 1, 2002, the effective date of the Act, a telecommunications provider with facilities located in a public right-of-way in the city as of such date, that has not previously obtained authorization or a permit under section 251 of the Michigan telecommunications act, Public Act No. 179 of 1991 (MCL 484.2251), shall submit to the city an application for a permit in accordance with the requirements of this article. Pursuant to section 5(3) of the Act (MCL 484.3105(3)), a telecommunications provider submitting an application under this subsection is not required to pay the $500.00 application fee required under subsection (d) of this section. A provider under this subsection shall be given up to an additional 180 days to submit the permit application if allowed by the authority, as provided in section 5(4) of the Act (MCL 484.3105(4)). 
(Code 1987, § 28-109.4; Ord. No. 03-378, § 4, 4-15-2003) 
Sec. 44-181. - Issuance of permit. 
(a)  Approval or denial. The authority to approve or deny an application for a permit is hereby delegated to the city mayor or designee. Pursuant to section 15(3) of the Act (MCL 484.3115(3)), the city mayor or designee shall approve or deny an application for a permit within 45 days from the date a telecommunications provider files an application for a permit under section 44-180(b) for access to a public right-of-way within the city. Pursuant to section 6(6) of the Act (MCL 484.3106(6)), the city mayor or designee shall notify the MPSC when the city has granted or denied a permit, including information regarding the date on which the application was filed and the date on which permit was granted or denied. The city shall not unreasonably deny an application for a permit. 
(b)  Form of permit. If an application for permit is approved, the city mayor or designee shall issue the permit in the form approved by the MPSC, with or without additional or different permit terms, in accordance with section 6(1), 6(2), and 15 of the Act (MCL 484.3106(1) and (2), 484.3115). 
(c)  Conditions. Pursuant to section 15(4) of the Act (MCL 484.3115(4)), the city mayor or designee may impose conditions on the issuance of a permit, which conditions shall be limited to the telecommunications provider's access and usage of the public right-of-way. 
(d)  Bond requirements. Pursuant to section 15(3) of the Act (MCL 484.3115(3)), and without limitation on subsection (c) of this section, the city mayor or designee shall require that a bond be posted by the telecommunications provider as a condition of the permit. The bond required shall not exceed the reasonable cost to ensure that the public right-of-way is returned to its original condition during and after the telecommunications provider's access and use. 
(Code 1987, § 28-109.5; Ord. No. 03-378, § 5, 4-15-2003) 
Sec. 44-182. - Construction/engineering permit. 
    A telecommunications provider shall not commence construction upon, over, across or under the public rights-of-way in the city without first obtaining a construction or engineering permit as required under applicable city ordinances, rules and regulations, as amended, for construction within the public rights-of-way. No fee shall be charged for such a construction or engineering permit. 
(Code 1987, § 28-109.6; Ord. No. 03-378, § 6, 4-15-2003) 
Sec. 44-183. - Conduit or utility poles. 
    Pursuant to section 4(3) of the Act (MCL 484.3104(3)), obtaining a permit or paying the fees required under the Act or under this article does not give a telecommunications provider the right to use conduit or utility poles. 
(Code 1987, § 28-109.7; Ord. No. 03-378, § 7, 4-15-2003) 
Sec. 44-184. - Route maps. 
    Pursuant to section 6(7) of the Act (MCL 484.3106(7)), a telecommunications provider shall, within 90 days after the substantial completion of construction of new telecommunications facilities in the city, submit route maps showing the location of the telecommunications facilities to both the MPSC and to the city. The route maps should be delivered to the city clerk in the formats required by the city unless and until the MPSC determines otherwise, in accordance with section 6(8) of the Act (MCL 484.3106(8)). 
(Code 1987, § 28-109.8; Ord. No. 03-378, § 8, 4-15-2003) 
Sec. 44-185. - Repair of damage. 
    Pursuant to section 15(5) of the Act (MCL 484.3115(5)), a telecommunications provider undertaking an excavation or construction or installing telecommunications facilities within a public right-of-way or temporarily obstructing a public right-of-way in the city, as authorized by a permit, shall promptly repair all damage done to the street surface and all installations under, over, below, or within the public right-of-way and shall promptly restore the public right-of-way to its preexisting condition. 
(Code 1987, § 28-109.9; Ord. No. 03-378, § 9, 4-15-2003) 
Sec. 44-186. - Establishment and payment of maintenance fee. 
    In addition to the non-refundable application fee paid to the city set forth in the section 44-180(d), a telecommunications provider with telecommunications facilities in the city's public right-of-way shall pay an annual maintenance fee to the authority pursuant to section 8 of the Act (MCL 484.3108). 
(Code 1987, § 28-109.10; Ord. No. 03-378, § 10, 4-15-2003) 
Sec. 44-187. - Modification of existing fees. 
    In compliance with the requirements of section 13(1) of the Act (MCL 484.3113(1)), the city hereby modifies, to the extent necessary, any fees charged to telecommunications providers after November 1, 2002, the effective date of the Act, relating to access and usage of the public rights-of-way, to an amount not exceeding the amounts of fees and charges required under the Act, which shall be paid to the authority. In compliance with the requirements of section 13(4) of the Act (MCL 484.3113(4)), the city also hereby approves modification of the fees of providers with telecommunication facilities in public rights-of-way within the city's boundaries, so that those providers pay only those fees required under section 8 of the Act (MCL 484.3108). The city shall provide each telecommunications provider affected by the fee with a copy of this article, in compliance with the requirements of section 13(4) of the Act (MCL 484.3113(4)). To the extent any fees are charged telecommunications providers in excess of the amounts permitted under the Act, or which are otherwise inconsistent with the Act, such imposition is hereby declared to be contrary to the city's policy and intent, and upon application by a provider or discovery by the city, shall be promptly refunded as having been charged in error. 
(Code 1987, § 28-109.11; Ord. No. 03-378, § 11, 4-15-2003) 
Sec. 44-188. - Savings clause. 
    Pursuant to section 13(5) of the Act (MCL 484.3113(5)), if section 8 of the Act is found to be invalid or unconstitutional, the modification of fees under section 44-187 shall be void from the date the modification was made. 
(Code 1987, § 28-109.12; Ord. No. 03-378, § 12, 4-15-2003) 
Sec. 44-189. - Use of funds. 
    Pursuant to section 10(4) of the Act (MCL 484.3110(4)), all amounts received by the city from the authority shall be used by the city solely for rights-of-way related purposes. In conformance with that requirement, all funds received by the city from the authority shall be deposited into the major street fund and/or the local street fund maintained by the city under Public Act No. 51 of 1951 (MCL 247.651 et seq.). 
(Code 1987, § 28-109.13; Ord. No. 03-378, § 13, 4-15-2003) 
Sec. 44-190. - Annual reports. 
    Pursuant to section 10(5) of the Act (MCL 484.3110(5)), the city mayor or designee shall file an annual report with the authority on the use and disposition of funds annually distributed by the authority. 
(Code 1987, § 28-109.14; Ord. No. 03-378, § 14, 4-15-2003) 
Sec. 44-191. - Cable television operators. 
    Pursuant to section 13(6) of the Act (MCL 484.3113(6)), the city shall not hold a cable television operator in default or seek any remedy for its failure to satisfy an obligation, if any, to pay after November 1, 2002, the effective date of this Act, a franchise fee or similar fee on that portion of gross revenues from charges the cable operator received for cable modem services provided through broadband internet transport access services. 
(Code 1987, § 28-109.15; Ord. No. 03-378, § 15, 4-15-2003) 
Sec. 44-192. - Existing rights. 
    Pursuant to section 4(2) of the Act (MCL 484.3104(2)), except as expressly provided herein with respect to fees, this article shall not affect any existing rights that a telecommunications provider or the city may have under a permit issued by the city or under a contract between the city and a telecommunications provider related to the use of the public rights-of-way. 
(Code 1987, § 28-109.16; Ord. No. 03-378, § 16, 4-15-2003) 
Sec. 44-193. - Compliance. 
    The city hereby declares that its policy and intent in adopting this article is to fully comply with the requirements of the Act, and the provisions hereof should be construed in such a manner as to achieve that purpose. The city shall comply in all respects with the requirements of the Act, including but not limited to the following: 
(1)  Exempting certain route maps from the freedom of information act, Public Act No. 442 of 1976 (MCL 15.231 et seq.), as provided in section 44-180(c); 
(2)  Allowing certain previously issued permits to satisfy the permit requirements hereof, in accordance with section 44-180(f); 
(3)  Allowing existing providers additional time in which to submit an application for a permit, and excusing providers from the $500.00 application fee, in accordance with section 44-180(g); 
(4)  Approving or denying an application for a permit within 45 days from the date a telecommunications provider files an application for a permit for access to and usage of a public right-of-way within the city, in accordance with section 44-181(a); 
(5)  Notifying the MPSC when the city has granted or denied a permit, in accordance with section 44-181(a); 
(6)  Not unreasonably denying an application for a permit, in accordance with section 44-181(a); 
(7)  Issuing a permit in the form approved by the MPSC, with or without additional or different permit terms, as provided in section 44-181(b); 
(8)  Limiting the conditions imposed on the issuance of a permit to the telecommunications provider's access and usage of the public right-of-way, in accordance with section 44-181(c); 
(9)  Not requiring a bond of a telecommunications provider which exceeds the reasonable cost to ensure that the public right-of-way is returned to its original condition during and after the telecommunication provider's access and use, in accordance with section 44-181(d); 
(10)  Not charging any telecommunications providers any additional fees for construction or engineering permits, in accordance with section 44-182; 
(11)  Providing each telecommunications provider affected by the city's rights-of-way fees with a copy of this article, in accordance with section 44-187; 
(12)  Submitting an annual report to the authority, in accordance with section 44-190; and 
(13)  Not holding a cable television operator in default for a failure to pay certain franchise fees, in accordance with section 44-191. 
(Code 1987, § 28-109.17; Ord. No. 03-378, § 17, 4-15-2003) 
Sec. 44-194. - Reservation of police powers. 
    Pursuant to section 15(2) of the Act (MCL 484.3115(2)), this article shall not limit the city's right to review and approve a telecommunication provider's access to and ongoing use of a public right-of-way or limit the city's authority to ensure and protect the health, safety, and welfare of the public. 
(Code 1987, § 28-109.18; Ord. No. 03-378, § 18, 4-15-2003) 
Sec. 44-195. - Authorized city officials. 
    The city mayor or designee is hereby designated as the authorized city employee, for violations under this article as provided by the city Code, to issue municipal civil infraction: 
(1)  Citations (directing alleged violators to appear in court); or 
(2)  Violation notices (directing alleged violators to appear at the municipal chapter violations bureau). 
(Code 1987, § 28-109.19; Ord. No. 03-378, § 20, 4-15-2003) 
Sec. 44-196. - Municipal civil infraction. 
(a)  A person who violates any provision of this article or the terms or conditions of a permit is responsible for a municipal civil infraction and shall be subject to a fine of: 
(1)  $1,000.00 per day; or 
(2)  $1,000.00 per occurrence. 
(b)  Nothing in this section shall be construed to limit the remedies available to the city in the event of a violation by a person of this article or a permit. 
(Code 1987, § 28-109.20; Ord. No. 03-378, § 21, 4-15-2003) 
Secs. 44-197-44-215. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VIII. - TELEGRAPH ROAD IMPROVEMENT AND UNDERGROUND RELOCATION OF OVERHEAD LINES 

Sec. 44-216. - Legislative findings and purpose. 
(a)  The city is currently in the process of designing and planning, in cooperation with the state department of transportation (MDOT), for the major reconstruction of the entire length of northbound and southbound Telegraph Road (Telegraph) in the city. In addition, the city intends to make other infrastructural improvements to and along Telegraph, including new water mains on either side of Telegraph, installation of new sidewalks, construction of conduit for median irrigation and placement of new streetlights. 
(b)  MDOT has established an aggressive schedule for the completion of the Telegraph improvements, including benchmark dates for the submission of design plans, commencement of construction and completion of the project. 
(c)  As part of the process of improving Telegraph and its related infrastructure, the city has determined that it is a necessary public improvement to relocate underground all overhead electric utility, cable television, telecommunication and other lines and wires currently running along, across, adjacent to and/or over Telegraph, its intersections and to private property adjacent to Telegraph. In connection with this line and wire relocation, the city has determined that all poles and related overhead facilities equipment to the overhead lines should also be removed to the maximum extent possible. 
(d)  The governmental functions and purposes of this relocation of overhead lines and wires and removal of poles and related overhead facilities equipment include, but are not limited to, the following public health, safety and welfare concerns of the city: 
(1)  To allow for the public improvement of the reconstruction and repair of the entire length of Telegraph in the city, and improvement and repair of related infrastructure including sidewalks, water mains, sewers and street lighting. 
(2)  To relieve the utility, transportation and infrastructural burden in the Telegraph corridor, which is a heavily-congested business district in the city, serving hundreds of businesses and accommodating thousands of vehicles daily traveling at high rates of speed along Telegraph and into and out of these businesses. 
(3)  Improvement of the city's aesthetic environment through removal of unsightly poles, lines, wires and related overhead facilities equipment out of view of the public. 
(4)  Enhancement of traffic operational safety in the city by the removal of utility poles and overhead lines, wires and related overhead facilities equipment in order to improve visibility, sight lines and eliminate vehicular accident impacts on poles, overhead lines and wires and other overhead facilities equipment. 
(5)  To better protect electrical, cable, telecommunications and other service lines, wires, poles and related overhead facilities equipment from weather damage, vehicle accident damage and other causes, in order to reduce service interruptions to residents of and businesses located in the city. 
(6)  Enhancement of the safety of city residents and persons traveling on Telegraph from falling or down lines, wires, poles and overhead facilities equipment. 
(7)  Improvement of operational reliability of electrical utility, cable television, telecommunications and other services currently provided by overhead lines and wires. 
(8)  Enhancement of existing and potential business development and other land use along Telegraph recognizing the historical pattern of development including different: 
a.  Physical location of buildings and curb cuts; 
b.  Setbacks; 
c.  Location of and limits to rights-of-way; and 
d.  Location of utility poles and overhead lines and wires. 
(e)  The city has the power and authority to enact this article pursuant to, among other sources, the state Constitution (article 7, section 29), the Home Rule Act (MCL 117.4h), city Charter (chapter XVIII, sections 18.1, 18.2 and 18.6), city utilities and telecommunications right-of-way regulatory ordinance (Ord. No. 97-305, set forth in article VI of this chapter), various ordinances and franchise agreements related to cable television, existing legal precedent, applicable MPSC rules and the city's general police power to protect the public health, safety and general welfare. 
(Code 1987, § 28-110(2); Ord. No. 00-344, § 2, 5-16-2000) 
Sec. 44-217. - Relocation directed. 
    Upon the adoption of this article and upon written notice from the city, all public utilities, telecommunications providers, cable television providers (collectively to be referred to as the companies), state and county agencies (agencies) and all other persons who own, lease, operate and/or maintain overhead lines and wires, poles and/or related overhead facilities equipment located along, across, over and/or adjacent to Telegraph, Telegraph intersections and to private property adjacent to Telegraph, are hereby directed and ordered to begin immediately to relocate underground all of their overhead lines and wires and remove all poles and related overhead facilities equipment at their sole cost and expense and at no cost or expense to the city. In complying with this paragraph, the companies, agencies and persons shall also fully comply with the city utilities and telecommunications right-of-way regulatory ordinance (Ord. No. 97-305, set forth in article VI of this chapter). 
(Code 1987, § 28-110(3); Ord. No. 00-344, § 3, 5-16-2000) 
Sec. 44-218. - Cooperation directed. 
    In connection with compliance with the requirements of section 44-217, all companies, agencies, persons and representatives of the city shall cooperate fully and in good faith with each other in the timely coordination and implementation of the planning, design, construction and completion of the Telegraph reconstruction and infrastructure improvements, including the underground relocation of overhead lines and wires, and the removal of poles and related overhead facilities equipment. The timetable for completion of work set forth in this section and section 44-217 shall be established solely by the city in accordance with the MDOT's schedule and in consultation with the companies, agencies and other persons. 
(Code 1987, § 28-110(4); Ord. No. 00-344, § 4, 5-16-2000) 
Sec. 44-219. - City contribution. 
    To assist the companies, agencies and persons in carrying out the work required in sections 44-217 and 44-218, and in order to contribute to the timely success of the Telegraph reconstruction, infrastructure improvements, the relocation of overhead lines and wires and the removal of poles and related overhead facilities equipment, the city shall, at its sole cost and expense, plan and design, conduit and/or duct banks to carry the said relocated underground lines and wires. The city may also, in its sole discretion, make other contributions to the work required in sections 44-217 and 44-218, including acquiring all necessary easements and rights-of-way. In order to facilitate this property acquisition, the city may in its discretion, exercise its powers of eminent domain. 
(Code 1987, § 28-110(5); Ord. No. 00-344, § 5, 5-16-2000) 
Sec. 44-220. - Retention of control of public places. 
    Nothing contained herein shall be construed to alienate the title of the public in and to any public rights-of-way or any portion thereof, nor shall anything herein be construed in any manner as constituting a surrender by the city of its general powers with respect to the subject matter hereof, or with respect to any matter whatsoever, or in any manner be construed as limiting the right of the city to regulate the use of and access to any public rights-of-way within its exclusive or concurrent jurisdiction and to otherwise exercise its police powers to protect the public health, safety and welfare. 
(Code 1987, § 28-110(6); Ord. No. 00-344, § 6, 5-16-2000) 
Secs. 44-221-44-250. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IX. - COMPLETE STREETS 

Sec. 44-251. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Complete streets means a design principle to promote a safe network of access for pedestrians, bicyclists and motorists of all ages and abilities. 
(Ord. No. 10-455, § 1(28-111.1), 12-7-2010) 
Sec. 44-252. - Complete streets improvements. 
    The city will plan for, design, and construct all transportation improvement projects, both new and retrofit activities, to provide appropriate accommodation for bicyclists, pedestrians, transit users, and persons of all ages and abilities in accordance with the city nonmotorized transportation plan. 
(1)  The city nonmotorized transportation plan shall be referenced and its implementation considered prior to construction or reconstruction within city rights-of-way. 
(2)  The nonmotorized transportation plan will include, at a minimum, accommodations for accessibility, sidewalks, curb ramps and cuts, trails and pathways, signage, bike lanes, and shall incorporate principles of complete streets and maximize walkable and bikeable streets within the city. 
(3)  The accommodations shall also be designed and built using guidance from the most recent editions of the American Association of State Highway Transportation Officials (AASHTO) Guide for the Development of Bicycle Facilities, the Michigan Manual on Uniform Traffic Control Devices (MMUTCD) (MDOT), and the Americans with Disabilities Act Accessibility Guidelines (ADAAG). Methods for providing flexibility within safe design parameters, such as context sensitive solutions and design, will be considered. 
(4)  The city nonmotorized transportation plan will be updated every five years from the date of its initial adoption. 
(5)  It will be a goal of the city to fund the implementation of the nonmotorized transportation plan, which shall include expending State Act 51 funds received by the city annually in accordance with Public Act No. 51 of 1951 (MCL 247.651 et seq.). 
(Ord. No. 10-455, § 1(28-111.2), 12-7-2010) 
Sec. 44-253. - Exceptions. 
    Facilities for bicyclists, pedestrians, transit users, and people of all ages and abilities are not required to be provided in instances where a documentation exception is recommended by the mayor and granted by the city council based on findings of one or more of the following conditions: 
(1)  Where their establishment would be contrary to public health and safety; 
(2)  When the cost would be excessively disproportionate to the need or probable use; 
(3)  When the cost would result in an unacceptable diminishing of other city services; 
(4)  Where there is no identified longterm need; 
(5)  Where the length of the project does not permit a meaningful addition to the nonmotorized network; or 
(6)  Where reconstruction of the right-of-way is due to an emergency. 
(Ord. No. 10-455, § 1(28-111.3), 12-7-2010) 
Chapter 46 - TAXATION[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference- General property tax act, MCL 211.1 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 46-1. - Proceeds of sale of tax reverted lands used to pay advancements by city. 
(a)  Whenever the city shall receive land from the state, which lands are tax reverted and shall offer the same up for sale, the city shall retain from the proceeds of sale all such monies previously advanced by the city in connection with the subject parcel other than ad valorem taxes. 
(b)  Advancements as referred to in this section shall include, but not be limited to, special assessments which the city must pay into a special assessment fund after the property has reverted back to the state for nonpayment of taxes. 
(Code 1987, § 30-2; Ord. No. 77-92, §§ 1, 2, 11-9-1977) 
Secs. 46-2-46-20. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - TAX EXEMPTIONS 

Sec. 46-21. - Application of tax exempt status to certain housing projects. 
    No tax exemption shall apply to all or any class of housing projects as set forth in subsection (1) of section 15(a) of Public Act No. 346 of 1966 (MCL 125.1415a(1)), within the boundaries of the city, except for senior citizen housing which enjoyed an exemption from taxes or service charges and which had been constructed in the city on or before August 14, 1988. 
(Code 1987, § 30-6; Ord. No. 88-195, § 1, 8-16-1988) 
Sec. 46-22. - The Commons of the Villages of Taylor. 
(a)  Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this section, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this subsection, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Act means the State Housing Development Authority Act, being Public Act No. 346 of 1966 (MCL 125.1401 et seq.). 
    Authority means the state housing development authority. 
    Code means the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 as amended. 
    Housing development means a development which contains significant element of housing for citizens of low or moderate income and such elements of commercial, recreational, industrial, communal and educational facilities as it relates to housing for persons of low or moderate income. 
    Mortgage loan means a loan to be made by the authority or any other governmental agency to the sponsor for the construction and/or permanent financing of the housing development or an agreement with the authority approving the issuance of tax credits for the benefit of the owner of the housing development. 
    Senior citizens means a family where the head of the household is 55 years of age or older or a single person who is 55 years of age or older. 
    Sponsor means persons or entities which have applied to the authority for a mortgage loan to finance a housing development. 
    Utilities mean fuel, water, sanitary sewer service and/or electrical service, which are paid by the housing development. 
(b)  Preamble. It is acknowledged that it is a proper public purpose of the state and its political subdivisions to provide housing for citizens of low or moderate income and to encourage the development of such housing by providing for a service charge in lieu of property taxes in accordance with the state housing development authority Act of 1966, Public Act No. 346 of 1966 (MCL 125.1401 et seq.). The city is authorized by this Act to establish or change the service charge to be paid in lieu of taxes by any or all classes of housing exempt from taxation under this Act at any amount it chooses not to exceed the taxes that would be paid but for this Act. It is further acknowledged that such housing for citizens of low or moderate income is a public necessity, and as the city will be benefited and improved by such housing, the encouragement of the same by providing certain real estate tax exemption for such housing is a valid public purpose further, that the continuance of the provisions of this section are essential to the determination of economic feasibility of housing developments which are constructed and financed in reliance on such tax exemption. The city acknowledges that the Taylor Community Development Corporation Senior Housing Partnership, Inc. (sponsor) has offered, subject to receipt of a mortgage loan and any subsequent loans from the authority or any other governmental agency, to own and operate a housing development identified as the Commons of the Villages of Taylor on certain property consisting of an approximate five acre site in the city, and located on the south side of Eureka Road; to the east of Court Village Lane; and to the west of McGuire Street, to partially serve persons of low to moderate income, and that the owner has offered to pay the city an annual service charge for public services in lieu of taxes. In the event the parcel described herein is split and combined with an adjacent parcel of land which is subject to a mortgage loan from the authority, this article shall include all parcels combined with the parcel described in this section. The tax exemption established in MCL 125.1415(a), section 15A(1) through (8) of the Act shall not apply to any class of housing projects unless designated by ordinance. This section shall not affect the tax exemption currently enjoyed by any housing development within the city. 
(c)  Establishment of annual service charge. The housing development identified as The Commons of the Villages of Taylor and the property on which it lies shall be exempt from all property taxes from and after the commencement of construction. The city acknowledging that the sponsor and the authority have established the economic feasibility of the housing development in reliance upon the enactment and continuing effect of this article and the qualification of the housing development for exemption from all property taxes and a payment in lieu of taxes as established herein, and in consideration of the sponsor's offer, subject to receipts of a mortgage loan from the authority, to own and operate said housing development, hereby agrees to accept payment of an annual service charge for public services in lieu of property taxes. The annual service charge shall equal $1.00 for each housing unit in the project. 
(d)  Payment of service charge. The service charge in lieu of taxes for the immediately preceding calendar year as determined hereunder shall be payable to the city on or before March 1 of each year. This section shall remain in effect and shall not terminate so long as the mortgage loan and any subsequent loans from the authority remain outstanding and unpaid or the authority has an interest in the property. 
(e)  Site location. The Commons of the Villages of Taylor is located on certain property consisting of an approximate five acre site in the city, and located on the south side of Eureka; to the east of Court Village Lane; and to the west of McGuire Street. The Commons of the Villages of Taylor's common address is 15000 block of Court Village Lane. In the event the parcel described herein is split and combined with an adjacent parcel of land which is subject to a mortgage loan from the authority, this article shall include all parcels combined with the parcel described in this section. 
(f)  Contractual effect of section. Notwithstanding the provisions of section 15(a)(5) of the Act (MCL 125.1415a(5)) to the contrary, a contract between the city and the sponsor with the authority as third party beneficiary thereunder, to provide tax exemption and accept payments in lieu of taxes, as previously described, is effectuated by enactment of this section. 
(Ord. No. 09-437, § 1, 4-21-2009)

ARTICLE II. - TRAFFIC CODE 

Sec. 48-19. - Adopted; conflicts; enforcement. 
    The Michigan Vehicle Code, 1949 PA 300, MCL 257.1 et seq., as amended, is hereby adopted by reference in its entirety including all amendatory and/or supplementary laws which may become enacted by the state legislature. MCL 257.625(1)(c) of the Michigan Vehicle Code is specifically adopted by reference, pursuant to Public Act 7 of 2012. 
(Code 1987, § 31-21; Ord. No. 96-296, §§ 1-4, 12-3-1996; Ord. No. 2012-471, § 3, 5-1-2012) 
State Law reference- Authority to adopt the Michigan Vehicle Code by reference, MCL 117.3(k). 
Sec. 48-19a. - Violations and penalties. 
    The penalties provided by the Michigan Vehicle Code are adopted by reference. The city may not enforce any provision of the Michigan Vehicle Code for which the maximum period of imprisonment is greater than 93 days; provided, however, that a violation of MCL 625(1)(c) is punishable by one or more of the following: 
(1)  Community service of not more than 360 hours. 
(2)  Imprisonment for not more than 180 days. 
(3)  A fine of not less than $200.00 or more than $700.00. 
(Ord. No. 2012-471, § 4, 5-1-2012)

ARTICLE III. - STOPPING, STANDING AND PARKING[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference- Authority to regulate the standing or parking of vehicles, MCL 257.606(1)(a); stopping, standing or parking of vehicles, MCL 257.672 et seq. 

Sec. 48-42. - Removal of vehicles parked in street during emergency; notice; violation. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to park a vehicle upon the streets of the city when the mayor shall have declared an emergency to exist within the city as set forth in this section. 
(b)  Whenever the mayor, or such person as is duly authorized to act by the mayor, shall determine that an emergency exists within the city by reason of a snow fall or other condition that creates a traffic and/or safety hazard so as to impede the safe flow of emergency vehicles, the mayor shall cause notification to be given to all persons residing in the area so affected to remove all vehicles parked on the street so as to permit the department of public works to remove such snow or hazardous conditions as may then exist upon the streets of the city. 
(c)  Emergency vehicles as referred to in this section shall include, but not be limited to, vehicles used by the police department, the fire department and any ambulance service. 
(d)  Notification as set forth in this section shall be made in such a manner as the mayor may determine most expedient and shall be given at least 12 hours prior to the time that such vehicles are required to be removed from the streets. Failure by the owner or person in charge of such vehicle to remove the same as provided for in this section shall be deemed to be a violation of this section. 
(e)  Any person violating any of the provisions of this section shall be responsible for a civil infraction. 
(Code 1987, § 31-691; Ord. No. 78-103, §§ 1-4, 6, 4-25-1978) 
Sec. 48-43. - Obstruction of street during garbage, rubbish collection; notice to remove; violation. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to park a vehicle upon the public street between the hours of 7:00 a.m. and 5:00 p.m. on the day or days when rubbish and/or garbage is being collected in that area. 
(b)  The director of public works shall cause notification to be given to all persons residing in the areas so affected to remove all vehicles parked on the street so as to permit the department of public works to collect and remove garbage and/or rubbish. 
(c)  Notification as set forth in this section shall be made in such a manner as the director of public works may determine most expedient. Failure by the owner or person in charge of such vehicle to remove the same as provided for in this section shall be deemed to be a violation of this section. 
(d)  Any person violating any of the provisions of this section shall be responsible for a civil infraction. 
(Code 1987, § 31-692; Ord. No. 78-102, §§ 1-3, 5, 4-25-1978) 
Sec. 48-44. - Emergency snow removal. 
(a)  Definitions. The following definitions shall apply to the interpretation and enforcement of this section: 
Mayor of the city, if the mayor is absent, means the duly designated and acting representative. 
Street or highway means the entire width between the boundary lines of every way publicly maintained when any part thereof is open to the use of the public for purposes of vehicular travel. 
(b)  Parking during declared snow emergency. All parking on the streets in the city is hereby prohibited when a snow emergency is declared. The mayor or authorized designee shall declare a snow emergency when four inches or more of snow accumulation has occurred, as designated by the National Weather Service, or when they shall predict a snowfall of four or more inches within a 12-hour period. 
(c)  Announcement of snow emergency. The mayor or authorized designee shall cause each declaration made by the mayor pursuant to this section to be publicly announced by means of radio broadcasts and/or telecasts from radio stations and/or television stations, including cable television stations, within a normal operating range covering the city and the mayor may cause such declaration to be further announced in newspapers of general circulation when feasible. 
(d)  Termination of declared snow emergency. A declaration of snow emergency shall remain in effect until termination by announcement of the mayor or authorized designee, in accordance with this section. 
(e)  Removal of vehicles from streets. A vehicle parked on the streets or highways within the city after the declaration of a snow emergency shall be subject to being ticketed, or towed, or both by the city police department. The city police department or the department of public works will tow the vehicle. 
(f)  Reclaiming towed vehicle. The owner of a vehicle which has been parked on a street after the declaration of a snow emergency and which has been towed by either the city police department or the department of public works shall not obtain the vehicle until such time as the owner has paid all costs of towing. 
(g)  Penalty. Any person, partnership, corporation or joint-stock company who violates any provision of this section, shall be deemed responsible for a civil infraction for which a civil fine in an amount not to exceed $100.00 and may be ordered in addition to the payment of all towing costs and any additional costs as may be assessed by the 23rd District Court. A separate offense shall be deemed committed on each day in which a violation occurs or continues to occur. 
(Code 1987, § 31-693; Ord. No. 00-343, §§ 1-7, 5-16-2000) 
Secs. 48-45-48-61. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - TRUCKS AND MOTOR CARRIERS[3] 

Footnotes:

State Law reference- Size, weight and load of vehicles, MCL 257.716 et seq.; Motor Carrier Fuel Tax Act, MCL 207.211 et seq.; Motor Carrier Act, MCL ch. 475 et seq.; Motor Carrier Safety Act of 1963, MCL 480.11 et seq. 

Sec. 48-62. - Truck route map incorporated by reference. 
    The streets, roads, highways and thoroughfares within the city designated as truck routes are shown on the city road map, titled "Truck Route Map," which is hereby incorporated in this article. 
(Code 1987, § 31-734; Ord. No. 85-153, § 16, 12-3-1985) 
Sec. 48-63. - Adoption of state motor carrier laws by reference. 
    There is hereby adopted by reference the Motor Carrier Safety Act, Public Act No. 181 of 1963 (MCL 480.11 et seq.), and the rules and regulations and amendments thereto promulgated by the department of state police pursuant to such Act which are incorporated by reference as though fully set forth herein. 
(Code 1987, § 31-738; Ord. No. 85-153, § 19, 12-3-1985) 
State Law reference- Authority to adopt state laws by reference, MCL 117.3(k). 
Sec. 48-64. - Violations generally. 
(a)  Any driver or operator who violates this article or a rule promulgated under section 48-63, or any owner or user of any truck, truck tractor or trailer, or any officer or agent of any individual, partnership, corporation or association or their lessees or receivers appointed by any court which is the owner or user of any vehicle, who requires or permits the driver or operator to operate or drive any truck, truck tractor or trailer in violation of this article or a rule promulgated under section 48-63, is guilty of a misdemeanor for each violation. 
(b)  A peace officer, upon reasonable cause to believe that a motor vehicle is being operated in violation of this article or a rule promulgated pursuant to section 48-63, may stop the motor vehicle and inspect the motor vehicle. If a violation is found, the officer may issue a notice to appear for that violation. 
(Code 1987, § 31-739; Ord. No. 85-153, § 20, 12-3-1985) 
Sec. 48-65. - Local prosecution. 
    When this article or a rule promulgated under section 48-63 has been violated, the offense may be prosecuted in any city in or through which the motor vehicle, driver or operator implicated was situated or passed when the offense was committed. 
(Code 1987, § 31-740; Ord. No. 85-153, § 21, 12-3-1985) 
Sec. 48-66. - Vehicle safety inspection program. 
(a)  The local authority may establish and maintain a voluntary motor carrier vehicle safety inspection program. This program may include the placing of inspection stickers on vehicles which successfully pass all criteria established for this program. Any motor carrier which is authorized by the local authority to perform self-inspections and affix stickers issued by the local authority shall comply with all requirements agreed to in writing, as set forth by the local authority. The authority to participate in the local authority vehicle safety self-inspection program may be revoked for any authorized self-inspecting motor carrier that is in violation of the requirements set forth by the local authority. 
(b)  The local authority may assess a fee to cover administrative costs of the motor carrier self-inspection safety program. However, the fee shall not exceed $1.00 per vehicle. 
(c)  Motor carriers not covered by the self-inspection program which request to participate in the program may request from the local authority a vehicle safety inspection of any truck, truck tractor or trailer. Those participating motor carriers may be assessed an inspection fee of up to $5.00 for the administration of this article, for each motor vehicle, trailer or a combination of trailers inspected. 
(Code 1987, § 31-741; Ord. No. 85-153, § 22, 12-3-1985) 
Sec. 48-67. - Adoption of Motor Carrier Fuel Tax Act. 
    There is hereby adopted by reference the Motor Carrier Fuel Tax Act, Public Act No. 119 of 1980 (MCL 207.211 et seq.) which is incorporated by reference as though fully set forth herein. 
(Code 1987, § 31-742; Ord. No. 85-153, §§ 23-26, 12-3-1985) 
State Law reference- Authority to adopt state laws by reference, MCL 117.3(k).
