ARTICLE VI. - SNOW REMOVAL EQUIPMENT 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 48-119. - Certain types prohibited. 
    No person shall operate upon the sidewalks of the city any snow removal equipment operated by a motor-driven vehicle of a gross weight in excess of 4,000 pounds, not equipped with pneumatic tires and of an overall width greater than the width of the public sidewalk and shall not in any case be wider than five feet and not equipped with a revolving-type brush. No person shall use any snow removal equipment of a scraper or plow type operated by a motor-driven vehicle. 
(Code 1987, § 31-831; Ord. No. 68-10, § 1, 11-24-1969) 
Sec. 48-120. - Effect on duties of occupants, owners, lessees to remove snow from sidewalks. 
    The provisions of this article shall in no way abrogate the duties of an occupant, owner or lessee of property to remove snow or ice from the sidewalks contiguous to the premises of which that person is the occupant, owner or lessee, as provided by the ordinances of the city and statutes of the state. 
(Code 1987, § 31-832; Ord. No. 68-10, § 6, 11-24-1969) 
Sec. 48-121. - Use of motor-driven device by occupant, owner, lessee. 
    The provisions of this article shall not be applicable to the owner, occupant or lessee who, by means of a motor-driven device, removes snow from the sidewalks contiguous to the owner's, occupant's or lessee's premises; provided, however, that such motor-driven device conforms to the provisions set forth in section 48-119. 
(Code 1987, § 31-833; Ord. No. 68-10, § 7, 11-24-1969) 
Sec. 48-122. - Enforcement. 
    It shall be the duty of the department of public works, the building department and the police department of the city to enforce the provisions of this article. 
(Code 1987, § 31-834; Ord. No. 68-10, § 8, 11-24-1969) 
Sec. 48-123. - Snow and ice removal; removed by city; financial hardship; penalty. 
(a)  Snow and ice. 
(1)  All snow and ice which has accumulated prior to 6:00 a.m. on a public sidewalk adjacent to property not zoned residentially shall be removed by the owner or occupant by noon. Immediately after the accumulation of ice on such sidewalk it shall be treated with sand, salt or other substance to prevent it from being slippery and the ice shall be removed within the time limits of this paragraph. 
(2)  With 24 hours after the end of each accumulation of snow greater than one inch, the owner or occupant of every residentially zoned property shall remove the accumulation from the adjacent public sidewalk and walks and ramps leading to a crosswalk. The accumulation may be from any source including precipitation and drifting. Immediately after the accumulation of ice on such sidewalk, it shall be treated with sand, salt or other substance to prevent it from being slippery and the ice shall be removed within 24 hours after accumulation. 
(3)  The removal of snow and ice shall mean free of snow and ice for the entire constructed width and length of the sidewalk, including walks and ramps leading to a crosswalk. 
(b)  Removal by city. If snow or ice is not removed or treated as required in subsection (a), the city may notify the owner or occupant of the violation of subsection (a). This notification may be made in person, by telephone, by mail or by written notice left at the property. If the owner or occupant fails to remove snow or ice within 24 hours of the notification of violation of subsection (a), the city may cause such snow or ice to be removed. The owner (as indicated by the records of the assessor) of the adjacent property shall then be charged the actual cost of the sidewalk clearance, plus a one-time administrative fee of $500.00. If that charge is not paid within 45 days, the city shall have a lien against the land for the amount of the expense; and if the owner fails to pay the expenses, the lien shall be enforced in the same manner provided by law or enforcement of delinquent special assessment tax liens. 
(c)  Penalty. The owner (as shown on the assessor's records) of the property with adjacent sidewalks which do not comply with subsection (a), who fails to comply with the notice given in subsection (b) shall be responsible for a civil infraction, which shall be punishable by a civil fine of not less than $150.00 for the first offense, not less than $250.00 and up to $500.00 for the second offense, and not less than $500.00 and up to $1,000.00 for each additional or subsequent offense, plus costs and all other remedies available by statute. The maximum fine for any offense shall not exceed $1,000.00. If the penalty is not paid within 45 days, the city shall have a lien against the land for the amount of the expense; and if the owner fails to pay the expenses, the lien shall be enforced in the same manner provided by law or enforcement of delinquent special assessment tax liens. 
(Ord. No. 13-479, 9-3-2013) 
Secs. 48-124-48-142. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - PERMIT 

Sec. 48-143. - Required. 
    Any person engaging in the business of operating snow removal equipment shall obtain a permit under this division. 
(Code 1987, § 31-846) 
Sec. 48-144. - Determination of public convenience and necessity. 
    No permit shall be granted until the person applying for the permit shall have secured from the director of the department of public works a certificate certifying that public convenience and necessity require the operation of snow removal equipment in the area or territory proposed to be served by the applicant for a permit; in determining public convenience and necessity, the director of the department of public works shall consider: 
(1)  The number of snow removal operators in the city, and the number of snow removal operators operating in the territory proposed to be served; 
(2)  The demand of the public for such service; 
(3)  The financial responsibility of the applicant; 
(4)  The kind, condition and the type of equipment proposed to be used; 
(5)  The condition of the sidewalks in the territory proposed to be served and the condition of the public and private property contiguous to the public sidewalks; 
(6)  The probable quality of service offered by the applicant; 
(7)  The experience of the applicant in the snow removal business and all other matters affecting the safety of the public, the public sidewalks and the contiguous private property; 
(8)  All equipment must meet applicable federal and state safety requirements. 
(Code 1987, § 31-847; Ord. No. 68-10, § 2, 11-24-1969) 
Sec. 48-145. - Duration; transfer. 
    All permits granted under the provisions of this division shall expire on September 30 of each year and shall not be transferable during the permit term. 
(Code 1987, § 31-848; Ord. No. 68-10, § 3, 11-24-1969) 
Sec. 48-146. - Conditions of issuance. 
(a)  The director is hereby authorized to grant a permit to any person of good moral character to engage in the business of snow removal by the operation of a motor-driven vehicle upon the payment of a permit fee, as prescribed by resolution of the city council, together with an inspection fee payable to the city treasurer for each piece of equipment so operated by the permittee, together with the execution of a bond to the city in a penal sum as prescribed by resolution of the city council, approved by the corporation counsel and conditioned that the permittee will reimburse the city for any and all damage done to the sidewalks, trees or any other public property, and a policy of insurance, approved by the corporation counsel, naming the permittee and the city as co-insured in the amount as prescribed by resolution of the city council for property damage or injuries to or the death of a person, arising out of the operation of such snow removal equipment. Such bond and policy shall be filed with the city clerk. 
(b)  No permit shall be granted by the director of the department of public works until the equipment has been inspected under such terms as set forth by this article, and upon payment of an inspection fee for each piece of equipment so inspected. The inspection fees shall be determined by the director subject to the approval of the city council. 
(c)  Any permit granted shall be immediately revocable without further action if, for any reason, the insurance herein required has been revoked or cancelled. 
(d)  No permit shall be issued by the director until the city clerk notifies the director that the approved bond and insurance policies required have been filed in the office of the city clerk. 
(Code 1987, § 31-849; Ord. No. 68-10, § 4, 11-24-1969; Ord. No. 75-49, § 1, 1-14-1975) 
Sec. 48-147. - Approval or denial by director; appeals. 
    All applications for permits under this division shall be approved by the director of the department of public works. If it appears from the application that the applicant was a bona fide operator of snow removal equipment within the territory for which application is made and is seeking renewal of the permit, such applicant shall receive consideration over other applicants for the territory. Where a controversy exists over applications in the same territory, the director is empowered and authorized to investigate and decide the conflicting claims and determine the same; provided, however, that any applicant whose application for permit is denied shall have the right to appeal to the city council. 
(Code 1987, § 31-850; Ord. No. 68-10, § 5, 11-24-1969) 
Secs. 48-148-48-177. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VII. - COST RECOVERY FOR EXPENSES INCURRED FROM PERSONS OPERATING MOTOR VEHICLES UNDER THE INFLUENCE[5] 

Footnotes: 
--- (5) --- 
State Law reference- Expenses for which court may order person convicted to reimburse the local unit of government, MCL 769.1f. 

Sec. 48-178. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Emergency response means: 
(1)  The providing, sending and/or utilizing of public service, police, firefighting, rescue service, or any other agent of the city at/to: 
a.  An accident involving a motor vehicle or an arrest where one or more of the drivers were operating the motor vehicle while under the influence of an alcoholic liquor, controlled substance or the combined influence of an alcoholic liquor and controlled substance; 
b.  Any scene where a person and/or driver becomes helpless, endangered or otherwise in need of assistance by reason, whether in whole or in part, of being under the influence of an alcoholic liquor or a controlled substance; or 
(2)  The making of a traffic stop and arrest by a police officer when the driver was operating the motor vehicle while under the influence of an alcoholic liquor or controlled substance, or while visibly impaired due to the consumption of intoxicating liquor and/or a controlled substance. 
    Expense of an emergency response means the direct and reasonable costs incurred by the city, or by a private person, corporation or other entity operating at the request of/or direction of the city, through the extraordinary use of public services, when making an emergency response to the incident, including the costs of providing police, firefighting and rescue service at the scene of the incident. These costs further include, but are not limited to: 
(1)  All of the salaries, wages, worker's compensation benefits and fringe benefits of the city personnel: 
a.  Responding to the incident; 
b.  Engaged in investigation, supervision and report preparation. 
(2)  All costs connected with the administration and provision of breathalyzer or chemical tests related to any prosecution of the person involved in the incident; 
(3)  The cost of equipment operation; 
(4)  The cost of materials obtained directly by the city; and 
(5)  The cost of any contract labor or materials. 
(Code 1987, § 19-37(b); Ord. No. 94-265, 7-5-1994) 
Sec. 48-179. - Purpose. 
    The city finds a significant number of traffic arrests and traffic accidents in the city involve drivers who were operating a motor vehicle under the influence of alcoholic liquors and/or a controlled substance. In addition, the city finds that, in traffic arrests and accidents involving drivers who were operating a motor vehicle while under the influence of alcoholic liquors and/or a controlled substance, there is greater training and investigative expense and a greater likelihood of personal injury and property damage. As a result, an extraordinary operational and financial burden is placed upon the police, public service, firefighting, and rescue services by persons who are operating a motor vehicle while under the influence of alcoholic liquors and/or controlled substance. The purpose of this section is to enable the city to require reimbursement of emergency response costs incurred by the city in making traffic stops, arrests and responses to motor vehicle accidents which involve drivers who are operating a motor vehicle while under the influence of alcoholic liquors and/or a controlled substance, and when assisting intoxicated individuals. 
(Code 1987, § 19-37(a); Ord. No. 94-265, 7-5-1994) 
Sec. 48-180. - Liability for expenses. 
(a)  Any person who, while under the influence of intoxicating liquor and/or a controlled substance, operates a motor vehicle and becomes involved in any circumstance which results in an emergency response, as defined in section 48-178, and is convicted of an alcohol-related criminal offense or hospitalized due to public intoxication, shall be liable for damages in the amount of the expenses of the emergency response. 
(b)  Any person whose ability to operate a motor vehicle is visibly impaired due to the consumption of intoxicating liquor and/or a controlled substance, who operates a motor vehicle, who becomes involved in any circumstance which results in an emergency response, as defined in section 48-178, and is convicted of an alcohol or controlled substance related criminal offense or is hospitalized due to public intoxication or for the use of a controlled substance shall be liable for damages in the amount of the expenses of the emergency response. 
(Code 1987, § 19-37(c); Ord. No. 94-265, 7-5-1994) 
Sec. 48-181. - Civil liability. 
    This section shall be construed to impose a responsibility and liability of a civil nature on the part of the person and shall not be construed to conflict with, contravene, enlarge or reduce any criminal responsibility or liability, including fines imposed on a person or driver by a judge or magistrate under article II of this chapter pertaining to the traffic code, for operating a motor vehicle while under the influence of intoxicating liquor and/or a controlled substance, or while the driver's ability to do so was visibly impaired due to the consumption of intoxicating liquor and/or a controlled substance. 
(Code 1987, § 19-37(d); Ord. No. 94-265, 7-5-1994) 
Sec. 48-182. - Enforcement. 
    Any person described in this section as responsible or liable for the expense of an emergency response, who fails to reimburse the city within 30 days of receiving notice of the expenses incurred by the city as a result of an emergency response, shall be considered in default. If the person who is liable for the debt refuses to reimburse the city and owns real estate within the city, the expenses shall be assessed against the real estate in the manner provided by the city Charter (delinquent bills and assessments). If the person or entity does not own real estate in the city, collection shall be pursued by the office of corporation counsel. 
(Code 1987, § 19-37(e); Ord. No. 94-265, 7-5-1994) 
Sec. 48-183. - Submission of bill. 
    The director of budget and finance shall, within ten days of receiving itemized costs incurred for an emergency response, submit a bill for same by first class mail or personal service to a person liable for such costs as are enumerated under this article, requiring payment within 30 days. 
(Code 1987, § 19-37(g); Ord. No. 94-265, 7-5-1994) 
ARTICLE VIII. - ISSUANCE OF PARKING CITATIONS BY PERSONS OTHER THAN POLICE OFFICERS 

Sec. 48-184. - Issuance of parking citations by persons other than police officers. 
    The city, pursuant to MCL 257.742(6) and MCL 257.675d, as amended, authorizes the chief of police to implement and administer a program to authorize and utilize persons other than police officers as volunteers to issue parking citations for the violations specifically set forth in section 48-185 of this chapter. The chief of police shall maintain a list of such authorized persons and may add or remove persons from that list at his/her sole discretion. 
(Ord. No. 2014-483, § 1, 3-18-2014) 
Sec. 48-185. - Prohibited parking. 
    A vehicle shall not be parked, except if necessary to avoid conflict with other traffic or in compliance with the law or the directions of a police officer or traffic control device, in any of the following places: 
(1)  On a sidewalk. 
(2)  In front of a public or private driveway. 
(3)  Within 15 feet of a fire hydrant. 
(4)  On a crosswalk. 
(5)  Within 20 feet of a crosswalk, or if there is not a crosswalk, then within 15 feet of the intersection of property lines at an intersection of highways. 
(6)  At a place where an official sign prohibits stopping or parking. 
(7)  In a parking space which is clearly identified by an official sign as being reserved for use by disabled persons that is on public property or private property available for public use, unless the person is a disabled person as described in MCL 257.19a, or unless the person is parking the vehicle for the benefit of a disabled person. In order for the vehicle to be parked in the parking space the vehicle shall display one of the following: 
a.  A certificate of identification or windshield placard issued under MCL 257.675 to a disabled person. 
b.  A special registration plate issued under MCL 257.803d to a disabled person. 
c.  A similar certificate of identification or windshield placard issued by another state to a disabled person. 
d.  A similar special registration plate issued by another state to a disabled person. 
e.  A special registration plate to which a tab for persons with disabilities is attached issued under this Act. 
(8)  In a clearly identified access aisle or access lane immediately adjacent to a space designated for parking by persons with disabilities. 
(9)  In violation of an official sign restricting the period of time for or manner of parking. 
(10)  In a place or in a manner that blocks access to a space clearly designated as a fire lane. 
(Ord. No. 2014-483, § 1, 3-18-2014) 
Sec. 48-186. - Violations and penalties. 
    Any person who violates any of the provisions of section 48-185 is responsible for a civil infraction and shall pay the fines and costs as established by the 23 rd District Court, pursuant to MCL 257.907(7). 
(Ord. No. 2014-483, § 1, 3-18-2014) 
Secs. 48-187-48-210. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IX. - RESIDENTIAL PARKING 

Sec. 48-211. - Purpose and intent. 
    The City of Taylor enacts this article to: 
(a)  Regulate and limit non-resident on-street parking in certain resident only parking zones; 
(b)  Promote efficient utilization of on-street parking in certain resident only parking zones; 
(c)  Protect the safety and welfare of residential neighborhoods within the city; and 
(d)  Provide enforcement of on-street parking regulations in certain residential only parking zones. 
(Ord. No. 2017-494, § 1, 5-16-2017) 
Sec. 48-212. - Legislative findings. 
    The city council finds that the continued vitality of the city depends on the preservation of safe, healthy, and attractive neighborhoods. The city council further finds that one factor that threatens the safety, health, viability and attractiveness of some of the city's neighborhoods is the excessive use of on-street parking by non-residents in certain residential neighborhoods. The number of non-resident motor vehicles using on-street parking in certain residential parking zones often exceeds the number of available on-street parking spaces and prevents residents from being able to utilize on-street parking. A parking system creating residential only parking zones, where appropriate, that limits non-resident motor vehicles from parking in those designated areas will reduce the burden to residents unable to find on-street parking in their residential zone and promote the general welfare of the City of Taylor and its residential neighborhoods. 
(Ord. No. 2017-494, § 1, 5-16-2017) 
Sec. 48-213. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Guest vehicle means a motor vehicle which has a guest residential parking permit that is parked in a particular residential zone. 
    Lease means an agreement by which a person pays rent or other remuneration for the use of a parcel or lot of real property as the person's principal residence. 
    Motor vehicle means an automobile, truck, motorcycle, or other motor-driven vehicle for transportation that is registered with the State of Michigan, but shall not include recreational vehicles. 
    Non-resident motor vehicle means a motor vehicle which is owned, leased or used by a person that is not a resident of a particular residential only parking zone that is parking in such zone in the City of Taylor. 
    Resident only parking zone means a particular public street or highway block within a residential zoned district where curbside parking on the public street is limited to resident only vehicles and guest vehicles. 
    Resident vehicle means a motor vehicle that has been issued a residential parking permit and is parked in the particular residential zone for which it is registered. 
(Ord. No. 2017-494, § 1, 5-16-2017) 
Sec. 48-214. - Posting of resident only parking zone. 
    A resident only parking zone shall be identified by parking signs erected in the resident only parking zone. The signs shall indicate prominently that curbside parking on public streets in the resident only parking zone is limited only to residents and authorized guests that properly display a parking permit authorized by this article. 
(Ord. No. 2017-494, § 1, 5-16-2017) 
Sec. 48-215. - Resident only parking zone. 
    The city establishes the following resident only parking zones: 
(a)  Huron Street. Beginning from the north right-of-way line of the public alley north of Ecorse Road to the south right-of-way line of Philomene Street. 
(b)  Mayfair Street. Beginning from the north right-of-way line of the public alley north of Ecorse Road to the south right-of-way line of Philomene Street. 
(c)  Weddel Street. Beginning from the north right-of-way line of the public alley north of Ecorse Road to the south right-of-way line of Philomene Street. 
    On-street parking in the above listed areas shall be limited to resident vehicles with a residential parking permit or guest vehicles with a guest parking permit for the particular resident only parking zone. 
(Ord. No. 2017-494, § 1, 5-16-2017) 
Sec. 48-216. - Determination and designation of a resident only parking zone. 
    The city council shall conduct, upon mayor's initiative, city council's initiative or upon a petition signed by a majority of 65 percent of the residents on the block street of a proposed or existing resident only parking zone, a public hearing to determine the designation or the withdrawal of such a designation, if it already exists, of a resident only parking zone. The public hearing shall be held after notice has been published once in a newspaper of general circulation in the city and on the city's website. The notice shall clearly state the purpose, time and location of the public hearing and the boundaries of the proposed resident only parking zone being proposed or affected. In addition to the published notice, a similar notification may be prominently posted in the proposed or existing resident only parking zone, or may be mailed to every residence and business in the proposed or existing resident only parking zone and to every residence and business located within 300 feet of the proposed or existing resident only parking zone. During such public hearing any interested person shall be entitled to appear to be heard or may submit a written statement for the record. 
(Ord. No. 2017-494, § 1, 5-16-2017) 
Sec. 48-217. - Designation criteria. 
(a)  In determining whether non-resident motor vehicles sufficiently impact a proposed or existing resident only parking zone, the city council shall consider factors including, but not limited to, the following: 
(1)  The extent, frequency and duration that on-street parking spaces are occupied by non-resident motor vehicles; 
(2)  The extent that residents cannot obtain adequate curbside parking adjacent to or near their residences because of widespread use of available curbside parking spaces or on-street spaces by non-resident motor vehicles; 
(4)  The effect on the safety of the residents from intensive non-resident motor vehicle parking; 
(5)  The extent of air and noise pollution, hazardous conditions and deterioration of the residential environment as a result of traffic congestion and insufficient parking in the area; 
(6)  The extent that the designation of a resident only parking zone may reduce traffic and parking congestion and any other problems referred to above; 
(7)  The extent and/or the need for parking by the general public in the particular resident only parking zone; and, 
(8)  The desires of the residents in the proposed, or existing, resident only parking zone. 
(b)  Following the public hearing, the city council may vote, as applicable: 
(1)  Whether to designate or continue the area under consideration as a resident only parking zone; or, 
(2)  Whether to withdraw the designation of an existing resident only parking zone. 
(Ord. No. 2017-494, § 1, 5-16-2017) 
Sec. 48-218. - Notice to residents of a resident only parking zone; application for resident parking permits. 
    The mayor or the mayor's designee shall mail to every residence within the designated resident only parking zone the following documents: 
(a)  A notice of designation that shall inform the residents in the designated area of: 
(1)  The existence and exact location of the resident only parking zone; 
(2)  The parking restrictions applicable to all vehicles for curbside parking spaces along public streets in the designated resident only parking zone that do not properly display a resident vehicle parking permit or guest vehicle parking permit authorized by this article; and 
(3)  The procedures to obtain a resident vehicle parking permit. 
(b)  An application for a resident only parking zone permit shall provide the following information for up to two resident vehicle parking permits: 
(1)  The name and address of the owner or lessee of the vehicle(s); 
(2)  The make, model, license plate number and registration number of the vehicle(s); and 
(3)  The signature of the applicant for the resident only parking zone permit. 
(Ord. No. 2017-494, § 1, 5-16-2017) 
Sec. 48-219. - Issuance of residential parking permits. 
(a)  Upon submission of a completed and validated resident only parking zone application, and there being no outstanding fees, taxes or other lawful charges owing to the city, and fulfillment of all applicable provisions of this article, the applicant shall receive a residential parking permit for up to two vehicles described in the application. The residential parking permit shall be securely affixed to the inside bottom left corner of the front windshield of the vehicle(s) and shall display the following information: 
(1)  The designation of the resident only parking zone and the permit number; and, 
(2)  The expiration date of the residential parking permit, if applicable. 
(b)  No resident vehicle parking permit shall be issued to a vehicle whose owner or principal operator does not reside within the designated resident only parking zone. 
(c)  The applicant for, and holder of, the resident vehicle parking permit shall be the owner or principal operator of the vehicle receiving the resident vehicle parking permit. 
(d)  Each applicant shall also receive up to two guest vehicle parking permits for use during the year. Not more than two resident vehicle parking permits and two guest vehicle parking permits shall be issued to a parcel or lot of real property used as a residence. 
(e)  No vehicle shall be issued a resident vehicle parking permit unless it displays valid state license plates, except where state law does not require the vehicle to display license plates. 
(f)  Any landlord leasing residential property located in a designated resident permit only parking zone shall provide notice of this article along with a residential parking permit application to its tenants. 
(Ord. No. 2017-494, § 1, 5-16-2017) 
Sec. 48-220. - Parking in residential parking zone or resident only parking zone. 
(a)  There shall be no on-street parking in a resident only parking zone by a vehicle unless that vehicle has displayed a resident vehicle parking permit or guest vehicle parking permit for that particular residential parking zone. A resident vehicle parking permit or guest vehicle parking permit shall not guarantee or reserve a particular parking space within a designated resident only parking zone. A parking permit shall not authorize the standing or parking of any vehicle in such places and during such times when the stopping, standing or parking of vehicles is prohibited or set aside for specified types of vehicles, and shall not excuse the observance of any other parking or traffic regulation. 
(b)  Whenever the holder of a resident vehicle parking permit no longer fulfills one or more of the applicable provisions of this article controlling the issuance, renewal or transfer of parking permits, the holder shall surrender the resident vehicle parking permit and/or guest vehicle parking permit(s) to the mayor or mayor's designee. 
(c)  Until its expiration, surrender or revocation, a resident vehicle parking permit shall remain valid for such time as the holder continues to reside within the designated resident only parking zone. 
(d)  A parking permit shall be valid only in the resident only parking zone for which it is issued. 
(e)  It shall be a violation of this article for any person to represent in any fashion that a vehicle is entitled to a parking permit authorized by this article when he or she is not so entitled. The display of a parking permit on a vehicle not entitled to such a parking permit shall constitute a violation of this article and the violator shall be subject to a civil infraction in the amount of $100.00. 
(Ord. No. 2017-494, § 1, 5-16-2017) 
Sec. 48-221. - Exemptions; temporary daily permits. 
(a)  The provisions of this article shall not supersede any provisions of the City of Taylor Code of Ordinances and any state laws relating to parking by disabled persons. 
(b)  The following vehicles are specifically exempted from the parking restrictions imposed by this article: 
(1)  A motor vehicle owned by or operated under contract to a public utility when used in the construction, operation, removal or repair of utility facilitates or engaged in authorized work in the residential parking zone; 
(2)  A motor vehicle identified as owned by or operated by a federal, state, or local governmental agency and being used in the course of official government business; or, 
(3)  An authorized emergency vehicle as defined by state law. 
(c)  Temporary daily permits. The chief of police or designee shall have the authority to issue temporary daily permits to a resident of a resident only parking zone in excess of the permits otherwise authorized by the article upon submission a timely written request. The written request shall be on a form established by the City of Taylor police department and provide the following information: 
(1)  The name and address of the resident making the request; 
(2)  The date(s) and time(s) for which the temporary daily permits are being requested; 
(3)  The detailed explanation for the request; and 
(4)  The number of temporary daily permits being request. 
The chief of police or designee shall have the sole discretion to grant or deny a request for temporary daily permits under this subsection and shall consider factors including, but not limited to, the timing of the request, the date(s) and time(s) requested, the reasons for the request, the number of temporary daily permits requested, traffic control concerns and other public health and safety concerns. Temporary daily permits will only be effective for the date(s) and time(s) approved. 
(Ord. No. 2017-494, § 1, 5-16-2017) 
Sec. 48-222. - Regulations and forms. 
    The mayor or the mayor's designee is authorized to establish such written regulations and forms necessary to implement and enforce the provisions of this article. 
(Ord. No. 2017-494, § 1, 5-16-2017) 
Sec. 48-223. - Penalty. 
    Any person violating any provisions of this article shall be responsible for a civil infraction punishable as prohibited parking in accordance with the district court's adopted fee schedule. Each day during which the violation continues shall constitute an additional, separate and distinct violation. 
(Ord. No. 2017-494, § 1, 5-16-2017) 
Sec. 48-224. - Revocation of permit. 
    In addition to the penalties provided above for violation of this article, the mayor or the mayor's designee may revoke the resident vehicle parking permit of any person found to be in violation of this article, and, upon written notification, the person shall surrender such permit, along with any guest vehicle parking permits, to the mayor or the mayor's designee. Failure to surrender a revoked residential parking permit when requested to do so shall constitute a separate violation of this article punishable as a civil infraction with a fine in the amount of $100.00. 
(Ord. No. 2017-494, § 1, 5-16-2017) 
Chapter 50 - UTILITIES[1] 
Footnotes:

State Law reference- Ownership and operation of water supply or sewage disposal facility by city, Mich. Const. 1963, art. 7, § 24; local authority to provide and regulate sewer and water service, MCL 324.4301 et seq.; water and sewer authorities, MCL 124.281 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Secs. 50-1-50-18. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - WATER AND SEWER SYSTEM 

Sec. 50-19. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Sanitary sewer means a sewer intended to carry only sanitary and industrial waste from residences, commercial buildings, industrial plants and institutions. 
    Sewage disposal system means all interceptors, sewers, storm sewers, sanitary sewers, combined sanitary and storm sewers, sewage treatment plants, and all other plants, works, instrumentalities and properties used or useful in connection with the collection, treatment and disposal of sewage and industrial waste. 
    Water supply system means all plants, works, instrumentalities, and properties used or useful in connection with obtaining a water supply, the treatment of water and/or the distribution and sale of water. 
(Code 1987, § 34-2; Ord. No. 82-129, § 2, 10-12-1982) 
Sec. 50-20. - Purpose. 
    In pursuance of and within the limits of the constitution and statues of the state, this article is hereby enacted to provide for a compilation of rules and regulations pertaining to the establishment, operation and maintenance of a water and sewer system in the city. 
(Code 1987, § 34-1; Ord. No. 82-129, § 1, 10-12-1982) 
Sec. 50-21. - Rights of bondholders. 
    Pursuant to the covenants previously made with successive holders of water and sewer bonds and coupons representing interest thereon, the city states that it will seek permission from the current bondholders to repeal any and all conflicting ordinances pertaining to the water and sewer supply systems of the city to the extent that those ordinances have not been saved by section 50-43 and also to procure the permission of those bondholders to consolidate the rules and regulations pertaining to the administration and operation of the water and sewer system. 
(Code 1987, § 34-3; Ord. No. 82-129, § 3, 10-12-1982) 
Sec. 50-22. - Water and sewer commission. 
(a)  Established. There is hereby established a joint water and sewer commission which shall operate in matters relating to the administration, management, supervision and control of the water and sewer division of the department of public works. 
(b)  Ex officio members designated. There shall be three ex officio or standing members of the water and sewer commission. These shall be the mayor, the director of the department of public works, and the manager of the water and sewer division. The mayor, the director of the department of public works and the manager of the water and sewer division shall have no vote. 
(c)  Appointment, qualifications of regular members; filling of vacancies. There shall be five other members of the water and sewer commission. These members shall be appointed by the mayor and are subject to confirmation by the city council. They must be qualified electors of the city. They shall not be employees of the city or elected officials. Vacancies on the water and sewer commission shall be filled in the same manner as the original appointments were made. 
(d)  Terms of office, removal, compensation of members. The terms of the mayor, the director of the department of public works and the manager of the water and sewer division as ex officio members of the water and sewer commission shall be coextensive with their terms of office in those capacities with the city. The five members of the water and sewer commission appointed by the mayor shall be appointed on a biennial basis with each member's term to commence in January. Any one or all of these five regular members of the water and sewer commission may be removed by the mayor with or without cause but subject to the approval of the city council. All members of the water and sewer commission shall serve on a volunteer basis with no compensation. 
(e)  Chairperson. The members of the commission shall elect one member to serve as chairperson of the water and sewer commission. 
(f)  Powers and duties. The water and sewer commission shall, within the limitations of the provisions of the city Charter and this article, assist in the direction of the water and sewer system. This shall include assistance in the preparation of an operating budget for the water and sewer system for the coming fiscal years. 
(g)  Rules and regulations generally. The joint water and sewer commission shall assist the department of public works in maintaining the water and sewer systems of the city and all improvements, extensions, and equipment pertaining thereto. The water and sewer commission shall also assist the manager of the water and sewer division in establishing rules and regulations governing the use of and connections to the water distribution system of the city. A copy of all such rules and regulations shall be submitted to the city council. The rules and regulations so promulgated shall be considered part of the contract of every person supplied with water from the city water system. In any case where circumstances make it necessary to deviate from the rules, special permission for so acting shall first be sought from the city council which shall request and receive advice from the water and sewer commission before deciding whether such deviation from the rules will be permitted. 
(h)  Authority to restrict nonessential use of water. The water and sewer commission may, pursuant to its rule-making authority, restrict the nonessential use of water throughout the city. Any person violating any duly enacted rule restricting the nonessential use of water may, upon conviction thereof, be fined for each violation. 
(i)  Contracts and agreements. All contracts and agreements which may lawfully be made by the water and sewer commission shall, after proper review by the water and sewer commission, be submitted to the city council for action and if approved be executed by the mayor and the city clerk. 
(j)  Expenditures and withdrawals of funds. All checks, drafts or other withdrawal of funds lawfully authorized shall be made upon warrants drawn and authorized by the mayor and city clerk and the checks shall be signed by the city treasurer. 
(k)  Meetings. 
(1)  Rules of order, frequency. The water and sewer commission shall provide for and establish its own rules of order. The meetings of the water and sewer commission shall be scheduled on a regular basis and shall be open to the public. Upon proper notice, there shall also be special meetings of the water and sewer commission. Special meetings of the water and sewer commission may be held upon the call of the chairperson or any three members of the water and sewer commission. 
(2)  Quorum. The water and sewer commission shall hold a minimum of ten meetings per year. Three voting members of the commission shall constitute a quorum for the transaction of business. 
(3)  Records. Minutes of each meeting of the water and sewer commission are to be kept. Complete records of the water and sewer commission shall be retained as required by law and shall be available for public inspection. The minutes of the water and sewer commission's meetings shall show the vote of each member upon any question or, if absent or failing to vote, shall indicate such fact. The water and sewer commission shall also keep records of its official actions. Every decision, recommendation, or determination of the water and sewer commission shall be filed within ten days in the office of the city clerk and shall be a public record. 
(Code 1987, § 34-4; Ord. No. 82-129, §§ 5-15, 38, 10-12-1982; Ord. No. 86-158, §§ 7-10, 12-16-1986; Ord. No. 10-441, § 1, 1-5-2010) 
State Law reference- Open meetings act, MCL 15.261 et seq.; freedom of information act, MCL 15.231 et seq. 
Sec. 50-23. - Water and sewer division. 
(a)  Established. There is hereby established by this article, a division of the department of public works, to be known as the water and sewer division. 
(b)  Administration. As provided by the city Charter, the water and sewer division shall be under the direction and control of the department of public works and administered by the manager of the water and sewer division. 
(c)  Employees. The mayor shall establish guidelines as to the duties and number of persons to be employed by the water and sewer division of the department of public works. 
(Code 1987, § 34-5; Ord. No. 82-129, §§ 4, 5, 18, 10-12-1982) 
Sec. 50-24. - Funds. 
(a)  Separate accounts. All funds, including surplus funds, if any, shall be kept in separate accounts for the benefit of the bondholders, the operation and maintenance of the water and sewer divisions, and for no other purpose. 
(b)  Water and sewer divisions. 
(1)  Separate accounting. The books of the city treasurer shall show the amount of monies received by each of the water and sewer divisions of the department of public works and the expenditures of funds by each such division. 
(2)  Revenues. Revenues from the operation of the water and sewer and divisions shall be maintained in separate funds. 
(3)  Audits. The separate funds of the water and sewer divisions shall be audited at least once each year by a certified public account. Such audits and accounts shall be open for inspection at all proper times to any taxpayer or user of the water and sewer systems or the holder of any bond or anyone acting for or on behalf of the taxpayer, user or bondholder. Copies of the audit, after approval by the water and sewer commission, shall be submitted to the city council for its final approval. 
(4)  Monthly reports. Reports of the monthly operation of the water and sewer divisions shall be furnished to the city council. 
(5)  Annual operation budget. The annual operation budget shall be prepared by the water and sewer commission and shall be submitted to the city council for approval or rejection. 
(c)  Sewer receiving fund. The revenues of the sewer system derived from the collection of the rates and charges imposed by the provisions of this article shall be set aside as collected and deposited in a bank selected by the city council in an account designated the sewage disposal system receiving fund. The revenues so deposited are pledged for the purpose of being transferred to such accounts and so as to meet the expenses of the sewage disposal system. 
(Code 1987, § 34-6; Ord. No. 82-129, §§ 34-36, 10-12-1982) 
Sec. 50-25. - Rates established by city council. 
(a)  Pursuant to the city Charter, the schedule of rates for water service shall be as set from time to time by the city council as recommended by the water and sewer commission. There shall be no free use of the water system. The rates as set by the city council, upon the recommendation of the water and sewer commission, shall be sufficient to meet all the requirements of the indentures. 
(b)  Rates and charges for the use of the sanitary sewer system of the city are hereby established and made against each lot, parcel of land or premises which may have direct or indirect connections to the system or which may otherwise discharge wastewater either directly or indirectly into the system. 
(c)  The rates and charges hereby established shall be based upon a methodology which complies with applicable federal and state statutes and regulations. The amount of the rates and charges shall be sufficient to provide for debt service and for the expenses of operation, maintenance and replacement of the system as necessary to preserve the same in good repair and working order. The amount of the rates and charges shall be reviewed annually and revised when necessary to ensure system expenses are met and that all users pay their proportionate share of operation, maintenance and equipment replacement expenses. 
(d)  Pursuant to the city Charter, the schedule of rates for the sanitary sewer system shall be set by the city council as recommended by the water and sewer commission. 
(e)  The rates and charges for operation, maintenance and replacement hereby established shall be uniform within the area serviced by the city. No free service shall be allowed for any user of the sanitary sewer system. 
(f)  All customers of the city sanitary sewer system shall receive an annual notification, either printed on the bill or enclosed in a separate letter, which will show the breakdown of the sewage disposal bill into its components for: 
(1)  Operation, maintenance and replacement; and 
(2)  Debt service. 
(g)  The reasonable cost and value of all water and sewer service rendered to the city and its various departments by the water and sewer system, including rentals for fire hydrant service for each fire hydrant connected to the system, during all or any part of the fiscal year, shall be charged against the city and will be paid for as the service accrues for the city's current funds, including the proceeds of taxes which will be levied in an amount sufficient for that purpose. All such fire hydrant rentals shall be computed at a minimum annual rate per hydrant as currently established or as hereafter adopted by resolution of the city council from time to time. All payments so made shall be considered revenues of the water supply system and shall be applied in the manner provided for in this article for the application of the revenues of the water supply system. 
(h)  The present schedule of rates as determined by the city council shall be available in the city clerk's office for inspection during regular business hours. 
(Code 1987, § 34-7; Ord. No. 82-129, §§ 16, 17, 10-12-1982; Ord. No. 93-260, § 1, 11-16-1993) 
Sec. 50-26. - Application of rates. 
(a)  Component parts of rates. The adopted rates of the department of public works shall consist of: 
(1)  A consumption charge for water service based upon the amount of water consumed; 
(2)  A sewage disposal/maintenance charge for sewer service based upon the amount of water consumed; 
(3)  A flat rate charge for meter reading, meter service, and billing for water charges based on the meter size; 
(4)  Water debt service charge; 
(5)  A flat rate charge for meter reading, meter service, and billing for sewer charges based on the meter size; 
(6)  Ecorse Creek user charge; 
(7)  All other charges as shall be determined from time to time by the city council. 
(b)  Computation of bill. Each part of the rate is computed separately, added together, and then shown on the customer's bill as a single item. The service charge shall apply from the date that the service connection is installed and it shall continue in force until the service line is disconnected from the main, or until the end of the billing period in which the water charge shall become effective if and when the water is turned on at the premises. 
(c)  Duration of debt service charge. The debt service charge shall continue until water from the main is disconnected. The charge shall remain regardless of when the water is turned on or off. 
(Code 1987, § 34-8; Ord. No. 82-129, § 27, 10-12-1982; Ord. No. 86-158, § 27, 12-16-1986; Ord. No. 93-260, § 1, 11-16-1993) 
Sec. 50-27. - Water bills. 
(a)  Frequency of mailings. Water bills, including a charge for sewer service, shall be mailed on a two-month basis. 
(b)  Reading of meters. Estimated bills shall be based upon a reading by owners, or persons in possession of the residential property to be billed on a schedule determined by the management of the water and sewer division or based upon previous consumption in lieu of a reading. However, the department of public works reserves the right to inspect meters at any time. The water meters of commercial premises shall be read every four months by department of public works employees, owners or persons in possession of the premises. 
(c)  Minimum charge. There shall be a minimum charge for water service as long as water is turned on to the premises. 
(d)  Errors. Errors, if any, in estimated consumption shall be corrected as soon as practicable and rendered after a reading of the meter has been obtained. A special bill shall be rendered without additional charge to any customer who objects to paying the estimated bill, provided that the customer requests this service and notifies the department of public works when the reading of the meter may be obtained. Such time for reading must be within the regular office hours of the department of public works. 
(e)  Delivery. Water bills shall be delivered to the premises to which the bill applies unless requested otherwise by the owner or agent. Bills shall be placed in the mail or delivered to the premises approximately ten days before the due date. 
(f)  Payment. Water bills are payable at the office of the city treasurer. Bills paid to any other person, concern, or agency are so paid at the risk of the customer. 
(g)  Lien for unpaid amounts. If, upon a review of the books of the water and sewer division, it appears that there are persons whose bills are delinquent for a period of six months, then the amount of those bills shall be transferred to the tax rolls. The amount so transferred shall then be collected by the county. An amount equal to 15 percent of the delinquent bill, or such other reasonable amount as the city council may determine, shall be added to the delinquent tax bill to cover administrative charges. 
(h)  Penalty for late payment. Bills not paid on or before the last net payment date, as indicated on the face of the bill, are subject to a ten percent penalty charge or such other reasonable amount as the city council may determine. 
(Code 1987, § 34-9; Ord. No. 82-129, § 25, 10-12-1982; Ord. No. 86-158, § 25, 12-16-1986) 
Sec. 50-28. - Sewer bills. 
    Bills for the disposal rate and other charges shall be made on the water bill for those premises served by the sewer system. Separate bills shall be prepared for premises having no connection with the water supply system. Such bills shall be rendered in conjunction with the water bills. Such bills shall be considered delinquent in the same manner as the water bill for the premises and shall have the same penalty for nonpayment within the given time, in the same manner as the water bill for such premises. Those premises which have no water connection shall be billed separately and shall be due and payable the same date as the water bill. For all such bills not paid when due, a penalty shall be charged in an amount to be set by city council resolution and such amount shall be added to the delinquent bill. The disposal rate and other charges shall be shown as a single rate on the water bill. 
(Code 1987, § 34-10; Ord. No. 82-129, § 26, 10-12-1982) 
Sec. 50-29. - Scope of systems. 
(a)  In pursuance of and within the limits of the constitution and the statutes of the state, the water supply system is deemed to include all water mains, laterals, extensions, meters and other equipment or property, buildings and improvements used or useful in the distribution of water throughout the city. These shall be operated and maintained as a single public improvement on a public utility rate basis as authorized by law. Private lines and lines inside the property lines are hereby excluded. 
(b)  In pursuance of and within the limits of the constitution and the statutes of the state, the sewer system is deemed to include all sewers which have as their outlet the sanitary sewage facilities, including all mains and lateral sewers, incepting sewers and all works, instrumentalities or properties used or useful in the collections and disposal of sewage and industrial waste and all additions, extensions or improvements. These shall be operated and maintained as a single public improvement on a public utility rate basis as authorized by law. 
(c)  The city shall not be responsible for or maintain risers or connections from the point of connection into and including property. The city shall not assume any responsibility for any connections by a property owner to a city sewer. 
(Code 1987, § 34-11; Ord. No. 82-129, § 19, 10-12-1982) 
Sec. 50-30. - Work performed as accommodation to public utilities by department of public works. 
    As an accommodation to the public utilities or other parties, the department of public works may move its mains, services, or other parts of its distribution system or perform such other work as requires the experience and specialized equipment of the department of public works. Such work will be undertaken only upon purchase order or a cash deposit to cover the estimated cost of the job. When the work is completed and cost determined, detailed bills will be rendered at costs plus 25 percent. 
(Code 1987, § 34-12; Ord. No. 82-129, § 29, 10-12-1982) 
Sec. 50-31. - Water mains. 
(a)  Location and size. Water mains shall be located as provided for in the duly enacted ordinances of the city setting forth the locations and the mains. All other distribution water mains shall be not less than eight inches in size. All distribution water mains located on a major mile road shall be not less than 12 inches in size. 
(b)  Responsibility for repairing breaks. The department of public works will assume the costs for repairing a break in a water main if the break is located from the property line to the water main. In no event shall the department of public works be responsible for a break in the lead from the building to the property line. 
(c)  Emergency repair. The department of public works shall repair or clean water mains on nondedicated streets. Thereafter, it shall charge the adjoining owners for the repairs or costs based upon actual costs to the water and sewer division. 
(d)  Use of water. No person shall tap or connect any water main, insert a service cock therein, open or close any valves or hydrants, molest or interfere with any valve box cover, water meter, detector, check valve or other part of the water supply system except for employees of the department of public works or upon written permission of the department of public works or in the case of fire. All commercial water taps shall be not less than one inch in size, and water reducers are expressly prohibited. 
(Code 1987, § 34-13; Ord. No. 82-129, § 23, 10-12-1982) 
Sec. 50-32. - Service on streets without mains. 
    Service connections on streets where no mains are located shall not be permitted to be installed on or after January 1, 1983, in any zoned district with the exception of lots in an area zoned for single-family residential lots or parcels. Private water lines in single-family residential zoned areas shall only be permitted under the following conditions: 
(1)  A minimum of two-thirds (66 2/3 percent) of the single-family residential lots or parcels must currently be developed with single-family units on improved streets between the nearest cross streets or the nearest cross street and the terminus of any existing public water main. 
(2)  An applicant for a private water line shall pay a fee as may be established from time to time by resolution of the city council to the city water department. 
(3)  The applicant shall submit a site plan identifying the proposed structure, the water service line size, type, and location and the connection to an existing water main, and in addition identify other utilities and structures in the project area. 
(4)  If the proposed water line is to cross the private property of a third party, the applicant shall provide a properly executed easement document and recordation fees to the city water department. 
(5)  If the water service line is to be placed in the city or other public right-of-way the applicant shall by agreement with the city water department assume all liability and costs for the timely repair of all damages to utilities. In addition, the applicant shall obtain any permits which are necessary from any other agencies having jurisdiction over the right-of-way. 
(6)  The applicant shall deposit a cash bond or letter of credit with the city water department. The value of the cash bond or letter of credit shall be equivalent to the length of the water service to be installed in linear feet times an amount per linear foot as currently established or as hereafter adopted by resolution of the city council from time to time. The cash bond shall be held by the city water department for a minimum of 12 months from the date of final restoration by the applicant or a contractor hired by the applicant to provide the installation of the water service. All restoration shall be completed within two months of the date upon which the water service installation has been completed. 
(7)  The applicant, prior to receiving a permit for the installation of a private water line, shall sign and have notarized the city water department agreement for privilege of constructing a private water line and shall submit said agreement to the city water department. 
(8)  The applicant shall provide a sufficient amount of liability and property insurance as shall be determined by resolution of the city council. The applicant shall also provide a hold harmless agreement in which the applicant agrees to indemnify the city, its officers, agents, employees and servants from any and all suits and judgments which may be rendered as a result of the construction or defect in the water service line. 
(9)  The construction, operation and maintenance of the water service line shall be subject to the city ordinances, codes and rules and regulations adopted by the city council and the city water department. 
(Code 1987, § 34-14; Ord. No. 82-129, § 30, 10-12-1982; Ord. No. 92-247, § 2, 5-19-1992) 
Sec. 50-33. - Water service connection application; charges; provision of service. 
(a)  Application for water service. Applications for water service must be made at the city hall by the owner of the property. Tenants may apply for water service provided that the cost for the installation of the service connection and the meter deposit is paid in full at the time of the application. In addition, the first payment as currently established or as hereafter adopted by resolution of the city council from time to time, representing an initial payment for the debt service charge, is to be made by either the owner or the tenant making application for water service. There shall be a printed application form for water service connections furnished by the department of public works. This application form shall require: 
(1)  A description of the property to be served; 
(2)  A description of the building erected or to be erected thereon; 
(3)  The name and address of the owner of the property, the type of service connection desired; 
(4)  The location of the service connection; 
(5)  An acknowledgement that the specified meter couplings were received by the applicant; 
(6)  An agreement by the applicant to perform all work in connection with extending the water pipe to and through the building in accordance with the rules, regulations, and specifications of the department of public works, the county department of health and the state plumbing code; 
(7)  The owner's signature and address; and 
(8)  Such other information as the department may reasonably require. 
(b)  Service connection charges. The cost of applying for water service shall be as determined by the city council. Charges for service connections are payable in advance and at the time that the application for the service connection is made. The information supplied by the applicant for water service and service connections shall be considered as authoritative and final. If any error in such application shall cause the installation of a service connection that is improper, either in size or location, the cost of all changes required shall be borne by the applicant. 
(c)  Debt service on service connection. The water and sewer division shall under no circumstances finance service connections. However, as to previous financing of service connections, no more than an amount as currently established or as hereafter adopted by resolution of the city council from time to time for each service connection could be financed. All additional charges on connections longer than 70 feet were required to be paid at the time application for service was made. The service connection charge for connections installed under the revenue system covering all mains in the city at the time of adoption of this article shall be as currently established or as hereafter adopted by resolution of the city council from time to time per billing or fraction thereof, the first payment being paid at the time of applying for water service and the next on the regular water bill. 
(d)  Requirements for financing debt service charges. Only under previous ordinances was financing allowed. It was permitted under the following conditions: 
(1)  Debt service on mains for owners. All persons owning property to be served with water from mains under the revenue system could finance the cost of installation of mains. 
(2)  Debt service on service connections for owners. Only persons owning property and residing thereon, as resident owners, could finance the service connection under the revenue system. 
(3)  Debt service on mains for tenants. Tenants could finance the cost of installation of mains under the revenue system providing that there has been compliance with all other requirements of the department of public works. 
(4)  Debt service on service connections for tenants. Tenants could not, under any circumstances, finance service connections under the revenue system. All service connections were to be paid in full at the time application was made. 
(e)  Compliance with city ordinances. Unless otherwise permitted, no water connection shall be made and no water served to any premises in which plumbing and sewer fixtures do not comply fully with city ordinances. 
(f)  Temporary service connections. 
(1)  The term "temporary service connections" is applied to a connection installed to serve an individual, firm or corporation for a definite temporary period for such purposes as supplying water to a construction project or to a temporary structure. The department of public works reserves the right to refuse to install a temporary service connection for any reason deemed by it to be sufficient. Charges for temporary service connections are payable in advance and at the time that the application for service is made. The charge for a temporary service connection shall be the same as the charge for a permanent service connection; however, in addition to the connection charge, the applicant shall be required to pay in advance and at the time that the application is made the sum as currently established or as hereafter adopted by resolution of the city council from time to time to cover the cost of removing the temporary connection. 
(2)  The applicant shall be required to rent a water meter from the department of public works and to prepare the temporary service line for reception of the water. The water meter is to be rented at the time the application for the temporary service is made. The water meter shall be returned to the department of public works upon completion of the project. If the water meter disappears or is destroyed, the customer shall pay an amount equal to the cost of the meter plus 25 percent. 
(3)  Water meters shall be placed as directed by the department of public works. They shall be of a size approved by the department of public works. The location and size of the water meters shall be consistent with the nature, conditions and circumstances of the individual connection under consideration. The charge for unmetered water service for construction service and purposes shall be known as a construction service charge and shall be at a flat rate based upon the size of the water meter. The charge shall be collected in advance and at the time the service connection is discontinued. This charge is to cover the period of unmetered water service from the date of service of installation to the date of issuance of the occupancy permit by the building department. 
(4)  Whenever, in the opinion of the department of public works, unmetered water service is used for a purpose or in a manner contrary to the normal usage for which the flat rate was computed, the department of public works may elect that a meter be installed and that the charge for service rendered be at the regular metered rate. 
(g)  Cross connections. No cross connection between pipes connected with the water supply system and another source of water supply shall be permitted for any purpose whatsoever. 
(h)  Manifold service connections. In all cases where manifold service connections are desired in buildings divided into separate business places, permits for such connection may be issued only after approval by the water and sewer commission. In every case of a manifold connection, there must be a master stop for each branch thereof. 
(i)  Disconnecting unused service lines. The department of public works reserves the right to disconnect from the main any unused and non-revenue-producing service connection if the cost of maintenance of such service connection becomes excessive or for such other reasons as are deemed sufficient by the department of public works and the fee for such disconnection of unused service lines shall be charged to the property and if unpaid, become a lien thereon as of the date of disconnection. In case water service is desired at the same location at some later date, application for water service and for a service connection shall be required. The charge for the installation for the new service connection shall be at that regular rate. 
(j)  Turning water service on and off. Upon request, water shall be promptly turned on or off by the department of public works, provided that all rules of the department have been met. However, water connection will not ordinarily be turned on or off in the absence of the person responsible for the premises. Furthermore, the department of public works will not shut off a supply of water where such action would involve the department in a controversy between other parties regarding a matter beyond the jurisdiction of the department of public works. 
(k)  Collection of delinquent accounts. Whenever the rates or charges fixed for services rendered are not paid, shut off of water and collection procedures shall be enforced in accordance with the laws of the state and provisions of city ordinances. 
(l)  Shutoff notice. Customers whose bills remain unpaid on the due date may be forwarded a shutoff notice. If bills are not paid within 30 days after the date of the shutoff notice, the customer's service may be turned off without further notice. 
(m)  Charges for turning water off and on. All charges for turning water off and on shall be set by city council resolution from time to time. 
(n)  Interruption of service and damage to property. The department of public works will exercise reasonable diligence and care to deliver a continuous and sufficient supply of water to the consumer as is furnished to the city by the Detroit Water Board or its successor under the supply contract in force. The department of public works shall attempt to avoid any shortage or interruption or insufficiency of the supply. However, the department of public works assumes no liability for any loss or damage occasioned by an insufficient supply of water. 
(o)  Advance notice of interruption of service. Whenever the department of public works finds it necessary to interrupt water service to any district or section served by it, it will, when practicable, give advance notice to affected customers. 
(p)  Extension of service lines beyond property limits. Except in those cases where a contrary authorization is granted by the department of public works, no extension shall be made to a service line or water pipe for the purpose of conveying water to a point beyond the limits of the existing structure or proposed structure for which the water line was installed. A determination of the limits of the property to which water has been supplied is to be made by reference to the original application for water services. Service connections between the city water main and the location of the water meter are hereby expressly prohibited. 
(q)  Persons authorized to turn on water service. Water service shall not be turned on by anyone other than an employee of or a duly appointed agent of the department of public works. 
(r)  Resale or redistribution of water. No water shall be resold or redistributed by the recipient thereof from the water supply system to any premises other than that for which the application was made and the water meter was installed. Exceptions to this rule may be allowed in emergency situations. 
(s)  Conformity to specifications. No water service shall be provided unless it conforms to approved specifications. A copy of those specifications shall be kept on file with the city and shall be available to any interested person. 
(t)  Withholding water supply. The supply of water may be withheld from premises when the ordinances of the city or the rules and regulations of the water and sewer division have been in any manner violated. If any person shall, after the water supply has been shut off to any premises, cause such premises to be supplied with water from the water and sewer division without its permission, such premises shall be disconnected from the distribution pipe of the water and sewer division. 
(Code 1987, § 34-15; Ord. No. 82-129, § 21, 10-12-1982) 
Sec. 50-34. - Specifications for water service connections. 
(a)  Application for the installation of a service connection shall be made by the owner of the property or agent to the water and sewer division. Applicants must state in full detail the purpose for which the supply is required and must give a legal description of the property to be served, including: 
(1)  The side of streets and between streets; 
(2)  The desired location of service entry; and 
(3)  Such other information required on the printed form supplied by the department of public works. 
Applicants will be held responsible for the proper execution of the applications for water service and service connections. All expenses incurred by reason of incorrect information shall be charged to and paid by the applicant. 
(b)  All service connections and pipes from the water mains to the property line two inches or less shall be furnished and installed by the department of public works, water and sewer division. The work shall consist of: 
(1)  Tapping the main; 
(2)  Inserting a corporation cock with proper couplings; 
(3)  Laying a service pipe; and 
(4)  Providing a curb stop with: 
a.  An approved type of stop box; and 
b.  A cover marked "water." 
All service connections more than two inches shall be installed by a private contractor, subject to the inspection and approval of the city. 
(c)  No service connection will be installed when the section of the service line installed by the plumber is in line with a driveway, tree, fire hydrant, catchbasin or other obstruction. 
(d)  All new service pipes connecting with the distributing mains shall be copper or such other material as approved by the department of public works. It shall have an inside diameter of at least three-quarters of an inch and not less than one inch for commercial premises. In no case will the use of galvanized or iron pipe be permitted. 
(e)  All new service pipes connecting with distributing pipes three inches in size or more may be cast iron providing that the specifications of the pipe are approved by the water and sewer commission before installation. The copper pipe used must be extra heavy, soft, and meet the following specifications: 
Normal Size 
(in inches) Exact OD Gage BWG Weight 
(per foot) Test Pressure (per sq. inch) 3/4 0.875 16 0.640 1040 1 1.125 16 0.838 780  
(f)  The allowable variation in diameters and thickness of metal shall be plus or minus 3/1000 of an inch. The copper pipe shall be seamless drawn or rolled copper tubing annealed so that any section of the pipe may be flanged equal to one-quarter of the inside diameter at right angles to the axis of the pipe without showing any cracks, seams, slivers, scale and other surface defects. The copper shall be 99.9 percent copper with silver counted as copper. 
(g)  Joints between lengths of copper pipe shall be well made, watertight, and develop the full strength of the copper tube. They shall be of the type ordinarily accepted by the department of public works on underground work. 
(h)  All control valves on cast-iron service connections three inches or larger in diameter shall be of the left hand, gate type, nonrising stem with a two-inch square head and may be constructed with an iron body or all brass. 
(i)  The top of all service pipes shall be at least five feet below the pavement or grade, and in unpaved streets or areas where final grades are not known, six feet below the surface of the earth. The five-foot depth applies to services extending into a building where there is no basement. All service connections must be installed at least three feet from the existing gas service. Before installing water connections, the plumber must check the location of the gas service. Service pipes must be uniform in size in their entirety. 
(j)  When the premises has a cellar or basement, service pipes must be extended into the same and branches taken therefrom except in the cellar or basement and on the outlet side of the meter. See section 50-33(h) for manifold connections. 
(k)  It is expressly forbidden for any plumber to lay a service pipe inside a building along the outside wall or in any position where there is danger of frost. No plumber shall make a new connection or install any new attachments or fixtures to old connections that shall require a running stream to prevent freezing. 
(l)  On future installations there shall be individual services, provided the water and sewer division in its judgment, may permit one service where conditions of use, occupancy or ownership so warrant. 
(m)  Unusual conditions not specifically contemplated in this section shall be reported to the water and sewer division for disposition. The ruling of the water and sewer division thereon shall be final. 
(n)  Water lines will not be allowed to cross public city streets or alleys without the permission of the department of public works or, where necessary, without permits from the county road commission. 
(o)  When a new service line is required, the owner of the property must have all unused service connections entering the property disconnected at the street main. Where a new building is erected upon property and an existing service line is used, the line shall be inspected by the water and sewer division personnel and an inspection fee set by the city council paid to the city prior to the inspection. All unused lines entering the property must be disconnected at the street main. Plumbers will, therefore, acquaint themselves with the existence of old service lines. 
(p)  Charges for disconnecting all services, except those in the same trench as the new service and of the screw type, shall be borne by the parties applying for the disconnection. Any connection between water pipes receiving their supply from city mains and pipes carrying water from underground storage tanks or any other service is expressly forbidden. No other source of water is allowed. 
(q)  A plugged tee or any other accessible outlet between the water meter and the main will not be allowed unless approved by the department of public works. The clearance distance from a wall or any other object to the center of a service pipe shall not be less than that shown below: 
Water Meter 
Size 
(in inches) Clearance 
(in inches) 5/8 , 3/4, 1 5 11/2 12 2 14  
Larger sizes shall be installed in accordance with blueprints approved by the building department. 
(r)  All water meter pits on public or private property must be constructed in locations free from hazards to pedestrian traffic. Pits or boxes located in or near doorways will not be permitted. Where buildings are altered, such hazards must be removed or the pits relocated. The department of public works will not be responsible for injuries resulting from hazards maintained on private property. 
(s)  No risers other than fire connections will be allowed inside or taken through the top of the meter wells. Wells shall be used for no other purpose than the reception of the water meter and valves. 
(t)  Bypasses and water meter connections the same size as the service lines will be required on all water meters 11/2 inches and larger in size. Bypasses will not be allowed on water meters one inch in size and smaller meters.
