The bypasses and water meter connections shall be constructed according to blueprints furnished by the department of public works. 
(u)  No reciprocating pump shall be attached directly to the city mains unless the same shall be used exclusively for fire purposes. 
(Code 1987, § 34-16; Ord. No. 82-129, § 32, 10-12-1982) 
Sec. 50-35. - Water meters. 
(a)  Ownership. All water meters shall be and remain the property of the department of public works which shall maintain all water meters in service, making such periodic tests and repairs as are necessary to ensure correct registration. The customer shall be charged for only those repairs made necessary by damage caused by willful act, carelessness or neglect of the occupant, such as failing to protect the water meter from freezing temperatures or allowing hot water to back through the line to the meter. All persons are forbidden to interfere with or remove a water meter from any service connection without first receiving permission from the department of public works. 
(b)  Responsibility for safekeeping. The owner of the property is responsible for the safekeeping of water meters installed on the premises and shall, if the water meter is lost or stolen from the premises, be charged with the actual cost of replacing the missing equipment. 
(c)  Defective water meters. If any water meter is found to be defective or fails to register, the customer shall be charged for the use of water in the same amount as was charged in the preceding similar seasonal billing period. 
(d)  Repair charges. Charges for repairing water meters by the department of public works shall be billed to the customers at list price for parts plus labor and costs. 
(e)  Setting and location. Water meters and their gate valves will not be allowed in crawl spaces, closets or compartments that are kept locked, in coal bins, in or under toilet room floors, under buildings, porches, crawl spaces, show windows, show boards or any area which is difficult to obtain access to. Wherever possible water meters shall be set below grade level in a cellar, basement or utility room and shall be easily accessible. All water meters shall be set horizontally in dry, clean, sanitary places, to be accessible with gate valves on both sides and where a small leak or spilling of water will do no damage. All water meters shall be set with a shutoff gate valve on each side of the meter. The plumber shall install connections ready to receive the water meter in a location to be approved by the department of public works. All water meters must be placed at a location which is nearest to the point where the service line enters the building. 
(f)  Meter pits. Upon special permission granted by the department of public works and if it is determined that it is the most appropriate way of metering service and only if part of a commercial or industrial complex, water meters may be installed in meter pits, the dimensions of which have been determined by the management of the water and sewer division of the department of public works. The service meter pits for setting meters one inch or more in size shall be of a size suitable for outside service meter settings in cold climates and of a type approved by the department of public works. The meter pit shall be a standard prefabricated type made of concrete. The meter pit shall be equipped with a cast-iron frame and double cover suitable for installation on the type of meter pit furnished. All meter pits shall be drained to a sewer if within 100 feet of a sewer and must in such instances have a trap next to the pit. If the pit is not drained in this manner, it must be provided with a pump for pumping water out of the pit. Should it be impossible to drain a meter pit, the owner or occupant must, under penalty of having water service disconnected, pump out the pit whenever required by the department of public works. 
(g)  Reading meters. All water meters covering properties used for domestic purposes shall be read on a two-month basis, approximately the same day of each month by the homeowner. A bill shall thereupon be rendered showing the present and previous meter readings and dates thereof, the amount of water used, the size of the meter, the charge for the service rendered, penalties, miscellaneous services, if any, the arrears balance, if any, the total amount due, the date payment is due, and the address of the property to which the bill applies. 
(h)  Estimated bills. If there is no response forthcoming from the owner or person in possession of the premises in regard to the reading of the water meter or, if the water meter is found to be out of order or inaccessible, the charge for water will be based, at the option of the department of public works, either on past consumption experience or upon the consumption as registered by a substituted water meter, either basis of which shall be subject to adjustment for such reasons as may be known or determined in order to arrive at an equitable charge. 
(i)  Cycle plan of reading and billing. Water meter reading, billing and collecting shall be carried out on a district cycling plan of such design as to cause a due date to fall approximately every second day in accordance with a predetermined schedule. In cases where the due date falls on a Sunday or holiday, it shall be understood that the following day shall be the effective due date. 
(j)  Unmetered service. Such service may be necessary in construction of buildings where water may be needed before the building is erected and before a water meter can be installed. 
(k)  Separate meters. There shall be separate water meters and connections for each building or unit served by the water supply system so that water or sewer service may be cut off to a certain portion of the building without affecting the building as a whole. 
(l)  Authority of employees of department of public works. The duly constituted authorities of the city shall have the power and authority to, at all reasonable hours, enter upon any premises where water service is provided for the purpose of: 
(1)  Testing, changing or reading water meters; 
(2)  Installing meters; 
(3)  Making general inspection of water usage or wastage and making an examination of all pipes and fixtures connected with the water system. 
Those authorities shall have the power and authority to require pipes and fixtures to be repaired, removed, replaced or changed where the same are defective or not in compliance with the provisions of the ordinances of the city or the rules and regulations of the department of public works. Those authorities may make such alterations and repairs or do such other acts in regards to the water system as they shall deem necessary. Employees of the department of public works engaged in such work shall be furnished with and shall prominently display on their person appropriate evidence of identification. Upon request, they shall furnish to the customer additional evidence of identification. 
(Code 1987, § 34-17; Ord. No. 82-129, § 20, 10-12-1982) 
Sec. 50-36. - Cross connections. 
(a)  Title. The city adopts by reference and incorporates into this section the Water Supply Cross Connection Control Rules of the state department of natural resources and environment, Public Act No. 399 of 1976 (MCL 325.1001 et seq.), Rule 325.11401 through Rule 325.11407 of the Administrative Code, as amended and as it may be amended in the future. This section shall be known as and may be cited as the "City of Taylor Cross Connection Control Ordinance." 
(b)  Purpose. The purpose of this section is to promote and protect the public health, safety and welfare by the prevention and elimination of cross connections which have been recognized as the cause of public health problems due to the hazard caused to drinking water quality. 
(c)  Authority. The city water department shall be the designated authority and administrator of the cross connection control program through its manager and chief accountant and/or designated representative. 
(d)  Plan. Pursuant to Public Act No. 399 of 1976 (MCL 325.1001 et seq.), Rule 325.11404 of the Administrative Code, as amended and as it may be amended in the future, a comprehensive cross connection control plan shall be developed and submitted to the state department of natural resources and environment, for its review and approval. The plan shall outline the conduct of the city cross connection control program including: 
(1)  The method for performing initial inspections; 
(2)  Determining inspection/reinspection frequencies; 
(3)  Backflow prevention assembly tracking and testing schedules; 
(4)  Annual reporting; 
(5)  Generation of compliance; 
(6)  Noncompliance; 
(7)  Pertinent piping information requests; and 
(8)  Water service shutoff notices. 
Upon approval by the state department of natural resources and environment, the city council and the city water and sewer commission, the plan shall become an instrument of this section and incorporated in the section by reference hereto for the purpose of providing program conduct and policies. Any changes to the approved plan will be submitted to the state department of natural resources and environment, for review and approval before final approval by the city council and its water and sewer commission prior to implementation by the authority/agent. The cross connection control plan will be made available to the public for review. 
(e)  Designated agent. The authority has the right to appoint a designated agent to administer the cross connection control program and perform inspections in accordance with the approved cross connection control program plan. 
(f)  Water discontinuance. The authority/agent shall have the right to enter any facility obtaining water from the municipal water system for the purpose of inspecting cross connections. Failure on the facility's part to allow the authority/agent entry shall be deemed to constitute having a cross connection that is an immediate hazard to the public health, safety and welfare and, as such, the authority/agent shall follow the steps as outlined in the approved cross connection control plan. If a facility fails to comply in correcting any deficiencies identified during the cross connection inspection and subsequent reinspection, followup inspection and the steps as outlined in the approved cross connection control plan, the water service to the facility will be discontinued until such time as the deficiencies are corrected and approved by the authority/agent. 
(Code 1987, § 34-18; Ord. No. 73-23, §§ 1-5, 7, 5-14-1973; Ord. No. 95-283, §§ 1-7, 10-17-1995) 
Sec. 50-37. - Damage caused by water leaks. 
    The department of public works will in no case be liable for damage caused by the running or escape of water from open faucets, burst pipes or faulty fixtures on the premises. Every service line is equipped with a control valve which may be used by the customer when necessary to shut off the water supply to the entire premises. Upon request, either day or night, the department of public works will shut off such control valve for emergency purposes and will turn it on again after repairs have been made. 
(Code 1987, § 34-19; Ord. No. 82-129, § 28, 10-12-1982) 
Sec. 50-38. - Installation of plumbing by owner. 
    Nothing contained in this article shall prohibit any bona fide owner from personally installing plumbing in the owner's own building, providing that the owner shall: 
(1)  Apply for water service in accordance with this article; 
(2)  Pay the required fees; 
(3)  Do the work personally in accordance with this article; 
(4)  Apply for inspection by the building department; and 
(5)  Receive approval from the building department. 
(Code 1987, § 34-20; Ord. No. 82-129, § 31, 10-12-1982) 
Sec. 50-39. - Fire hydrants. 
(a)  Obstructions prohibited; situations requiring permit. 
(1)  No person shall, without having first procured a permit from the department of public works, save for the purpose of extinguishing a fire, do any of the following: 
a.  Open any fire hydrant of the water supply system; 
b.  Tamper with the fire hydrant; or 
c.  Use water from fire hydrant. 
(2)  No person shall in any manner obstruct the use of any fire hydrant in the city or place or allow to be placed any material or thing in front thereof. Any and all material found as an obstruction to any fire hydrant may be forthwith removed by the officers and employees of the city at the risk, cost and expense of the owner or claimant. 
(b)  Issuance of permits. Permits for the purposes of opening any fire hydrant or using water therefrom shall be deemed issued only for a definite time and only to the person named in the permit. Permits shall be issued for a period beginning May 1 and ending October 1; however, special permits may be issued during the period from October 1 to May 1. 
(c)  Permit deposit. Permits shall be issued for use of a fire hydrant during the period of May 1 to October 1 upon the depositing of $250.00 with the water and sewer division, except that such deposit may be waived under a policy established by the water and sewer commission for special conditions deemed to be in the best interest of the city by the water and sewer commission and approved by the city council. The deposit shall be refunded after deduction of an amount for damage, if any, to the fire hydrant. In the discretion of the water and sewer division, permits may be issued from October 1 to May 1 or a portion thereof for opening fire hydrants to use water therefrom for construction purposes, provided that a deposit as currently established or as hereafter adopted by resolution of the city council from time to time is paid to the water and sewer division. The water and sewer division shall then refund the deposit after deducting an amount for damage, if any, to the fire hydrant. 
(d)  Permit fee. No permit shall be issued to any person to open any fire hydrant and/or use any water therefrom unless and until the person shall pay an amount established by the water and sewer commission to the department of public-works. 
(e)  Expiration of permit. Upon the expiration of the time for which a permit has been issued, the permit shall be surrendered to the department of public works. The department of public works shall immediately inspect the fire hydrant and estimate any damage resulting from its opening and/or use under the permit. After deducting the amount of the damage, if any, the balance of the deposit, if any, shall be refunded. 
(f)  On private property. Fire hydrants on private property shall be constructed and maintained in accordance with the standards established by the water and sewer division. Any maintenance for the fire hydrants shall be performed by the water and sewer division and the charge therefor established by the water and sewer commission. The customer shall be charged for only those repairs made necessary by damage caused by willful act, carelessness or neglect of the occupant. 
(Code 1987, § 34-21; Ord. No. 82-129, § 24, 10-12-1982) 
Sec. 50-40. - Water emergency conditions. 
(a)  Every person whose premises are supplied with water by the city shall be subject to the provisions of this section, and to all rules and regulations of the city water and sewer commission, pertaining to the use of city water. It shall be lawful for the water department manager or the manager's representative, to enter upon the premises of any person using the city water to install meters for measuring water used and to inspect the meters and other fixtures and appurtenances pertaining to the waterworks system. Officers of the police department, and/or the ordinance enforcement department, and/or city employees designated by the water department manager to issue ordinance violation notices and/or tickets to any person violating any provision of this section or any rule or regulation duly adopted in pursuance of this section. 
(b)  Conditions warranting initiation of water use reduction or prohibition are as follows: 
(1)  A prolonged drought or other system-wide heavy demand periods that result in supply facilities, including system pump stations and reservoirs, being operated at their optimum capacity with no apparent means immediately available to adequately maintain flows and residual pressures throughout the system. 
(2)  Any emergency condition that may arise which will negatively affect operating flows and residual pressures in any substantial portion of the system for any appreciable length of time. 
(c)  Initiation of water use reduction or prohibition procedures are as follows: 
(1)  The conditions in subsection (b) of this section may warrant a wide range of options all the way from alternate day sprinkling in a limited area to no outside water use for any community serviced by the City of Detroit water. In this case the City of Detroit and/or the state department of public health would normally take the leadership in advising of any area-wide water reduction needs. However, the city has the ultimate responsibility to initiate whatever measures are needed locally to see that all local emergencies are properly handled. 
(2)  Upon declaration of a water use reduction or prohibition emergency, the city will announce such declaration by use of public radio or television and newspapers with normal operating range covering the community. The water department manager or designee will implement whatever reductions are necessary to meet the water reduction requirements. 
(3)  The prohibition shall remain in effect 24 hours per day, seven days per week until the city has declared an end to the water use reduction emergency or the city determines that a limited prohibition will be sufficient to protect the health, safety and general welfare of the community. 
(4)  The water department manager or designee may provide exception to subsection (b)(1) of this section, where necessary, to prevent imminent financial loss to a water user. 
(Code 1987, § 34-22; Ord. No. 82-129, § 33, 10-12-1982; Ord. No. 94-273, §§ 1-3, 11-1-1994) 
Sec. 50-41. - Application for connection to sewer system. 
    Applications for connecting to the sewer system must be made in writing at the office of the building department, by the owner of the property or by a duly licensed building contractor. Each user connecting to the sewer system shall pay a disposal rate as established from time to time by the city council and as shall be lawful under the constitution and statutes of the state, the ordinances of the city, and as necessary to secure the efficient operation of the sewer system. 
(Code 1987, § 34-23; Ord. No. 82-129, § 22, 10-12-1982) 
Sec. 50-42. - Treatment of sewage. 
    If the character of the sewage of any manufacturing or industrial plant or any other building or premises shall be such as to impose an unreasonable burden upon the facilities of the system, the department of public works shall require that such sewage be treated by the person responsible therefor before being emptied into the system. Upon refusal to comply with this requirement, the right to empty such sewage may be denied if necessary to protect the system or any part thereof. 
(Code 1987, § 34-24; Ord. No. 82-129, § 37, 10-12-1982) 
Sec. 50-43. - Savings clause. 
    It is hereby declared that certain ordinances pertaining to the water supply system and the sewer system in the city will not be repealed and will remain viable notwithstanding the enactment of this article. Those ordinances saved from repeal are as follows: 
(1)  Ordinance No. 11, to the extent that it: 
a.  Provides for the construction of additions, extensions and betterments to the water system; 
b.  Establishes the location of certain water mains; 
c.  Calls for the issuance of bonds to cover the cost of such improvements and as it makes various provisions relating to those bonds; 
(2)  Ordinance No. 14, to the extent that it pertains to extensions and improvements to the water system and to the issuance of bonds pertaining thereto; and 
(3)  Ordinance No. 75-53, to the extent that it establishes a sanitary sewer district in the city and as provision is made for the payment of a sanitary sewer privilege connection fee within the district. 
(Code 1987, § 34-25; Ord. No. 82-129, § 41, 10-12-1982; Ord. No. 86-158, § 30, 12-16-1986) 
Secs. 50-44-50-74. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - SEWERS 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 50-75. - Roof drains. 
(a)  The city council deems it to be in the best interests of the public health and welfare of the residents of the community to attempt to decrease the rapid flow of surface drainage into the storm and sanitary sewers of the city in order to eliminate flooding of basements and, as a part of this program, to specifically provide for the disconnection of roof drain downspouts with the sewer system. 
(b)  To promote and protect the public health, safety and welfare, and to prevent stormwater, sewage or waste from backing up into basements and/or overflowing on public or private property, it shall be unlawful for any person, owner or occupant of any building, structure or premises to have or permit the use of any connection of a downspout, footing drain, conduit or other device or apparatus of any kind or nature whatsoever which allows or permits any surface, subsurface or stormwater from any roof, yard or premises to be deposited directly or indirectly into any sanitary sewer. 
(c)  All property owners shall disconnect all roof drains from the city sewer system. The property owner shall be given a reasonable time to comply with the directive to disconnect all roof drains, but such time shall not exceed 45 days from the date of mailing of the notice. If the property owner neglects or refuses to follow the written directive, then a final five-day certified notice shall be mailed directing compliance with the previous notice. If the property owner then neglects or refuses to comply with the notice, the city inspectors or employees shall have the power and authority at all reasonable hours to enter upon the premises for the purpose of disconnecting the roof drains and to assess the cost thereof against the property pursuant to the provisions of the city Charter. Any person refusing or neglecting to make such disconnection when so directed, after due notice shall be deemed guilty of violation of this section and liable to prosecution therefor. 
(d)  Nothing contained in this section shall be construed to limit in any manner the powers of the health officers, and if any unsanitary condition exists, the same is hereby declared to be a public nuisance and shall be abated in accordance with the provisions of the city Charter. 
(Code 1987, § 34-41; Ord. No. 68-6, §§ 1-4, 1-27-1969) 
Secs. 50-76-50-93. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - COUNTY SEWER USE ORDINANCE 

Sec. 50-94. - Purpose and authority. 
    This section is intended to accomplish the following primary purposes and objectives: 
(1)  To protect the public health and safety by abating and preventing pollution through the regulation and control of the quantity and quality of wastewater admitted to or discharged into, directly or indirectly, the sewerage collection system of the city for transportation and treatment by the county POTW. 
(2)  To prevent the discharge of pollutants into the county's POTW that do not meet applicable pretreatment standards and requirements that: 
a.  Would interfere with the operation of the POTW; 
b.  Would pass through the POTW into the receiving waters or the atmosphere; 
c.  Would inhibit or disrupt the POTW's processing, use, or disposal of sludge; 
d.  Would cause health or safety problems for POTW workers; 
e.  Would result in a violation of the county's NPDES permit or of other applicable laws and regulations; or 
f.  Would cause injury to the public health and safety or the environment. 
(3)  To regulate the discharge of stormwater or wastewater to the POTW through the issuance of permits and through other means of enforcement of the requirements of this section. 
(4)  To authorize and require all inspection, monitoring, reporting and enforcement activities by the county as necessary to ensure compliance with applicable pretreatment standards and requirements and other applicable laws and regulations. 
(5)  To provide a uniform policy for rates for stormwater and wastewater disposal service. 
(6)  To otherwise establish standards, rules, and regulations with respect to the use of the county's POTW, provide a method for the administration, application, and enforcement and ensure compliance with state and federal laws and regulations applicable to discharges to the POTW. 
This section sets forth requirements for direct and indirect contributors into the county stormwater and wastewater collection and treatment system and enables the county, and local governmental entities such as the city contracting with the county for stormwater and wastewater disposal services, to comply with all applicable state and federal laws as required by the Federal Water Pollution Control Act (also known as the "Clean Water Act"), as amended, 33 USC 1251, et seq.; the General Pretreatment Regulations (40 CFR 403); part 31 of Public Act No. 451 of 1994 (MCL 324.3101 et seq.) ("Water Resources Protection"); the rules, Michigan Administrative Code, R 323.2301 et seq., as amended, promulgated pursuant to section 3103, 3106 and 3109 of part 31 of Public Act No. 451 of 1994 (MCL 324.3103, 324.3106, 324.3109); Public Act No. 288 of 1967 (MCL 560.101 et seq.), land division act; Public Act No. 40 of 1956 (MCL 280.1 et seq.), drain code of 1956; the applicable rules and regulations pertaining to said acts; and the requirements of applicable national pollutant discharge elimination permits issued pursuant to said acts. Further, this section is enacted pursuant to the authority of Public Act No. 185 of 1957 (MCL 123.731 et seq.), Public Act No. 342 of 1939 (MCL 46.171 et seq.), Public Act No. 233 of 1955 (MCL 124.281 et seq.), and Public Act No. 293 of 1966 (MCL 45.501 et seq.), each as amended, and service contracts entered into between the county and the users of the stormwater and wastewater facilities owned and operated by the county, and the Charter of the city, sections 16.7 and 17.1. 
(Code 1987, § 34-78(a); Ord. No. 98-313, §§ I-VI, 4-21-1998; Ord. No. 98-322, 11-17-1998; Ord. No. 01-348, § I, 1-3-2001) 
Sec. 50-95. - Adoption. 
    The city hereby adopts, incorporates herein and makes a part of this section, the following articles and sections of the county sewer use ordinance No. 2000-404, as amended, subject to the "Amendments and Specific Provisions to Wayne County Sewer Use Ordinance" set forth in section 50-97: 
Article I. Definitions. 
Article II. Permit requirements. 
Article III. Design and construction requirements for wastewater transmission facilities. 
Article IV. Design and construction requirements for stormwater facilities. 
Article V. Discharge of wastewater into public sewers (amendments to this article are as follows): 
    6.10.2 Municipal Civil Infractions. 
(a)  Violation; Municipal Civil Infraction. Except as provided by section 6.10.3, a person who violates any provision of this section (including, without limitation, any rules, regulations, licenses, permits, orders, agreements or determination issued, adopted or entered by the county under this section) is responsible for a county municipal civil infraction, subject to payment of a civil fine of not less than $500.00 per day for each infraction and not more than $27,500.00 per day for each infraction, plus costs, expenses and other sanctions; except that a person who violates any of the following sections of this section shall be subject to payment of a civil fine of not less than $1,000.00 per day and not more than $27,500.00 per day for each infraction, plus costs, expenses and other sanctions: 
(1)  Section 5(a)(1)(A); section 5(a)(2)(B); section 8; or section 10 of article III; 
(2)  Section 1 of article IV; or 
(3)  Section 2.01.1; sections 2.01.2(a), (b), (d), (e), (f), (g), (i), (l) or (n); section 2.02.2; section 2.03; section 2.05.6(c)(1); section 2.09; section 4.01(b)(1); section 5.01; or section 5.02 of article V. 
(b)  Repeat Offenses; Increased Fines. Increased fines may be imposed for repeat offenses. As used in this section, "repeat offense" means a second (or any subsequent) municipal civil infraction violation of the same requirement or provision of this section (i) committed by a person within any 12-month period and (ii) for which the person admits responsibility or is determined to be responsible. The increased fine for a repeat offense under this section shall be as follows: 
(1)  Except as provided by section 6.10.2(b)(2), the fine for any offense that is a first repeat offense shall be not less than $1,000.00, plus costs; and the fine for any offense that is a second repeat offense or any subsequent repeat offense shall be not less than $2,500.00, plus costs, expenses and other sanctions. 
(2)  For violations of the following sections of this section, the fine for any offense that is a first repeat offense shall be not less than $2,500.00, plus costs; and the fine for any offense that is a second repeat offense or any subsequent repeat offense shall be not less than $5,000.00, plus costs, expenses and other sanctions: 
(A)  Section 5(a)(1)(A); section 5(a)(2)(B); section 8; or section 10 of Article III; 
(B)  Section 1 of Article IV; or 
(C)  Section 2.01.1; sections 2.01.2(a), (b), (d), (e), (f), (g), (i), (l) or (n); section 2.02.2; section 2.03; section 2.05.6(c)(1); section 2.09; section 4.01(b)(1); section 5.01; or section 5.02 of Article V. 
(c)  Amount of Fines. 
(1)  Municipal Civil Infraction Citations. Subject to the minimum fine amounts specified in sections 6.10.2(a) and (b), the following factors shall be considered by the court in determining the amount of a municipal civil infraction fine following the issuance of a municipal civil infraction citation for a violation of this section: the type, nature, severity, frequency, duration, preventability, potential and actual effect, and economic benefit to the violator (such as delayed or avoided costs or competitive advantage) of a violation; the violator's recalcitrance or efforts to comply; the economic impacts of the fine on the violator; and such other matters as justice may require. A violator shall bear the burden of demonstrating the presence and degree of any mitigating factors to be considered in determining the amount of a fine. However, mitigating factors shall not be considered unless it is determined that the violator has made all good faith efforts to correct and terminate all violations. 
(2)  Municipal Civil Infraction Notices; Schedule of Fines. Notwithstanding any provision of this section to the contrary, the amount of a municipal civil infraction fine due to the County in response to the issuance by the County of a municipal civil infraction notice for a violation as provided by section 6.10.2(a) shall be according to the following schedule: 
(A)  For violation of any provision of this section (except as provided by 6.10.2(c)(2)(B), below): 
First Offense: $500.00. 
First Repeat Offense: $1,000.00. 
Second Repeat Offense (or any Subsequent Repeat Offense): $2,500.00. 
(B)  For violation of any provision of any of the following sections: Section 5(a)(1)(A); section 5(a)(2)(B); section 8; or section 10 of Article III; section 1 of Article IV; or section 2.01.1; sections 2.01.2(a), (b), (d), (e), (f), (g), (i), (l) or (n); section 2.02.2; section 2.03; section 2.05.6(c)(1); section 2.09; section 4.01(b)(1); section 5.01; or section 5.02 of Article V: 
First Offense: $1,000.00. 
First Repeat Offense: $2,500.00. 
Second Repeat Offense (or any Subsequent Repeat Offense): $5,000.00. 
For any fine not paid in full at the Wayne County Municipal Ordinance Violations Bureau within 30 days of the time specified for appearance in the municipal civil infraction violation notice, the fine amount due shall automatically be double the amounts listed immediately above. A copy of this schedule shall be posted at the Wayne County Municipal Ordinance Violations Bureau. 
(d)  Authorized County Officials. The following persons are "authorized county officials" for purposes of issuing municipal civil infraction citations (directing alleged violators to appear in district court) or municipal civil infraction violation notices (directing alleged violators to appear at the Wayne County Municipal Ordinance Violations Bureau) for violations under this section: the Director of the Wayne County Department of Environment (and the Director's designees); and any County police officer. 
(e)  Definitions. As used in this Section: 
    "Act" means Public Act No. 236 of 1961, Revised Judicature Act of 1961 (MCL 600.101 et seq.). 
    "Bureau" means the Wayne County Municipal Ordinance Violations Bureau established by the County under Section 8396 of the Act to accept admissions of responsibility for municipal civil infractions in response to municipal civil infraction violation notices issued and served by authorized county officials, and to collect and retain civil fines and costs as prescribed by this section. 
    "Municipal civil infraction" means an act or omission that is prohibited by this section, but which is not a crime under this section, and for which civil sanctions, including, without limitation, fines, damages, expenses and costs, may be ordered, as authorized by Chapter 87 of the Act (MCL 600.8701 et seq.). A municipal civil infraction is not a lesser included offense of a violation of this section that is a criminal offense. 
    "Municipal civil infraction action" means a civil action in which the defendant is alleged to be responsible for a municipal civil infraction. 
    "Municipal civil infraction citation" means a written complaint or notice prepared by an authorized county official, directing a person to appear in district court regarding the occurrence or existence of a municipal civil infraction violation by the person cited. 
    "Municipal civil infraction determination" means a determination that a defendant is responsible for a municipal civil infraction by any one of the following: 
(1)  An admission of responsibility for the municipal civil infraction. 
(2)  An admission of responsibility for the municipal civil infraction, "with explanation." 
(3)  A preponderance of the evidence at an informal hearing or formal hearing on the question under Section 8719 or 8721 of the Act (MCL 600.8719 or 600.8721), respectively. 
(4)  A default judgment for failing to appear as directed by a municipal civil infraction citation or other notice, at a scheduled appearance under Section 8715(3)(b) or (4) of the Act (MCL 600.8715(3)(b) or (4)), at an informal hearing under Section 8719 of the Act, or at a formal hearing under Section 8721 of the Act (MCL 600.8721). 
    "Municipal civil infraction violation notice" means a written notice prepared by an authorized county official, directing a person to appear at the Wayne County Municipal Ordinance Violations Bureau and to pay the fine and costs, if any, prescribed for the violation by the schedule of civil fines adopted by the County, as authorized under Sections 8396 and 8707(6) of the Act (MCL 600.8396 and 600.8707(6)). 
(f)  Other Requirements and Procedures. Except as otherwise provided by this section, the requirements and procedures for commencing municipal civil infraction actions; issuance and service of municipal civil infraction citations and notices; determination and collection of court-ordered fines, costs and expenses; appearances and payment of fines and costs; failure to answer, appear or pay fines; disposition of fines, costs and expenses paid; and other matters regarding municipal civil infractions shall be as set forth in Chapter 2 ("Municipal Civil Infractions") of the Wayne County Code. 
    6.10.3 Criminal Penalties; Imprisonment. Any person who (1) at the time of a violation knew or should have known that a pollutant or substance was discharged contrary to any provision of this section, or contrary to any rules, regulations, licenses, permits, orders, agreements or determination issued, adopted or entered by the County Agency under this section; or (2) intentionally makes a false statement, representation, or certification in an application for, or form pertaining to a permit, or in a notice, report, or record required by this section, or in any other correspondence or communication, written or oral, with the County Agency regarding matters regulated by this section; or (3) intentionally falsifies, tampers with, or renders inaccurate any sampling or monitoring device or record required to be maintained by this section; or (4) commits any other act that is punishable under state law by imprisonment for more than 90 days; shall, upon conviction, be guilty of a misdemeanor punishable by a fine of $500.00 per violation, per day, or imprisonment for up to 90 days, or both in the discretion of the court. If a violation is committed by a person who acts or fails to act on behalf of a corporation or a partnership, that person shall be held personally liable for the fine or imprisonment, or both. 
    6.10.4 Separate Offenses. Each act of violation, and each day or portion of a day that a violation of this section, or of any permit, license, order, notice or determination issued, made or entered into under this section is permitted to exist or occur, constitutes a separate offense and shall be punishable as provided by this section.

DIVISION 3. - ECORSE CREEK USER CHARGE SYSTEM 

Sec. 50-125. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this division, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Act means the Federal Clean Water Act (33 USC 1251 et seq.) as amended. 
    Operations, maintenance and replacement (O, M & R) means those activities required to ensure the dependable and economic function of the facilities. 
(1)  Operation means the control of the unit processes and equipment that make up the facilities, including, but not limited to: 
a.  The financial and personal management; 
b.  Records; 
c.  Laboratory control; 
d.  Processing control; 
e.  Safety; and 
f.  Emergency operation planning. 
(2)  Maintenance means preservation of functional integrity and efficiency of equipment and structures, including preventive maintenance, corrective maintenance and replacement of equipment as needed. 
(3)  Replacement means expenditures for obtaining and installing the equipment, accessories or appurtenances which are necessary for the useful life of the treatment works to maintain the capacity and performance for which such works were designed and constructed. The treatment operation and maintenance includes replacement. 
    Service or user charge means the charge, including the user charge and the administrative charge if any, that the city collects for use of the facilities of the district. 
    User means any property located within the city that is connected either directly or indirectly to the sanitary sewer system. 
(Code 1987, § 34-94; Ord. No. 86-156, § IV, 7-15-1986; Ord. No. 91-228, 4-2-1991; Ord. No. 94-262, § 1, 1-18-1994) 
Sec. 50-126. - Purpose. 
    This division has as its purpose the protection of the public health and safety by abating and preventing pollution through the control of the quantity and quality of wastewater admitted into the public sewer collection system of the city for transportation to the publicly owned treatment works of the county. Its further purpose is to allow the city and the Ecorse Creek Pollution Abatement Drain No. 1 Drainage District, referred to in this division as district, to comply with all applicable federal, state and local laws and regulations, particularly the regulations of the United States Environmental Protection Agency, referred to in this division as EPA, pursuant to the authority of the Federal Clean Water Act of 1977, as amended, relating to uniform user charges. 
(Code 1987, § 34-91; Ord. No. 86-156, § I, 7-15-1986; Ord. No. 91-228, 4-2-1991) 
Sec. 50-127. - Authority. 
    This division is enacted in accordance with the authority and requirements of the Federal Clean Water Act of 1977 (33 USC 1251 et seq.), as amended, part 31 of Public Act No. 451 of 1994 (MCL 324.3101 et seq.), the drain code of 1956, Public Act No. 40 of 1956 (MCL 280.1 et seq.) and the service contracts existing between the city and the district. 
(Code 1987, § 34-92; Ord. No. 86-156, § II, 7-15-1986; Ord. No. 91-228, 4-2-1991) 
Sec. 50-128. - Statement of policy. 
    By this division the city provides for the regulation of discharges into the publicly owned sewer system and ordains that the charges for the use of the publicly owned sewer system shall be adopted for the users in accordance with the user charge system of the district, such system having been approved by EPA and the state department of natural resources and environment and adopted pursuant to the authority of the drain code of 1956, Public Act No. 40 of 1956 (MCL 280.1 et seq.). 
(Code 1987, § 34-93; Ord. No. 86-156, § III, 7-15-1986) 
Sec. 50-129. - User charge rate structure. 
    Pursuant to the city Charter, the schedule of rates for the Ecorse Creek user charge system shall be set by the city council as recommended by the water and sewer commission. The rates charged for the individual users shall be based on flow measured by each user's water meter. Any billing and administrative costs incurred by the city may be added to the system's cost. 
(Code 1987, § 34-95; Ord. No. 86-156, § V, 7-15-1986; Ord. No. 91-228, 4-2-1991; Ord. No. 94-262, § 1, 1-18-1994) 
Sec. 50-130. - Assessment of costs for facilities. 
(a)  This section presents a method of assessing operation, maintenance, and replacement costs for facilities constructed as part of the city within the Ecorse Creek Pollution Abatement Drain No. 1 and Phase II Drainage District, and the Ecorse Creek Pollution Abatement Drain No. 3 Drainage District to ensure that costs are assessed in proportion to benefits received. The methodology is based on tributary impervious acreage developed from land use and surface runoff coefficients. 
(b)  Facilities constructed as part of The Ecorse Creek Pollution Abatement Drain No. 1, phase I and phase II, and the Ecorse Creek Pollution Abatement Drain No. 3 Drainage District are grouped into separate cost centers for purposes of identifying, assigning, and assessing operation, maintenance, and replacement costs. The individual drainage districts tributary to each cost center, identified on a governmental unit basis with a tabulation of each unit's percentage of the total impervious acreage in the cost center as follows: 
(1)  Cost center No. 1, construction contract Nos. 6 and 7.
